Like Fire in Our Bones

by acuteneurosis

Summary

With all of the most important things in the galaxy literally exploding around her, Leia is given the chance to go back and help keep a promise she never personally made.

But then, for Skywalkers, saving the galaxy was always a family matter.

Notes

Delving into a new fandom here. Hope you enjoy.

Desert Born

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

The first thing she noticed as she woke was the pain. She wasn‚Äôt expecting it and was more than a little surprised to realize it felt like her skin had shrunk over her muscles and that her joints all ached as if they had been wrenched almost apart.

Normally, the pain only came after she was awake enough to realize that Luke was still gone.

The ache in her heart pulsed, and Leia made herself breathe slowly as the last thought crossed her mind twice more, checking itself against reality. Yes, that faint light that had been ever-present in her mind was still dark and cold. Yes, she could not find her brother. Yes, Luke really was still gone.

Riding the waves of anguish that the unavoidable next thoughts brought (yes, that meant Han and Chewie were gone too) Leia forced herself to open her eyes and suffered another shock.

This was not her room.

Not Coruscant. Not planetside on any of the places that she had visited in the past weeks. Not her quarters on the ship that had almost started to feel like home until the moment when she had realized she might never find home ever again.

Not her room.

Pale walls, sparse furnishings, a musty smell like it was rarely used. No windows, but an open door, and the light seeping from that portal brought more brightness than she would have expected. Looking down at herself, but hesitating to move, Leia noted thin, white sheets, soft and well worn, slightly greyed from use.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre awake,‚Äù a gentle, low voice murmured, and Leia turned to face the woman who slowly entered the room. Dark hair just barely touched with grey, a concerned, motherly look (which touched another pain, older but more painful again for the new pains stacked atop it), and cheap if serviceable clothes. Desert style and well worn, like the face of the woman. Like the sheets.

Shmi.

‚ÄúOh hell,‚Äù Leia groaned, squeezing her eyes shut and trying desperately not to remember. To her surprise, that earned a soft chuckle.

‚ÄúNot quite, but close enough,‚Äù Shmi‚Äôs voice was smiling, Leia knew. Not at all offended, but maybe a little curious. ‚ÄúAnd you seem to have caught the worst of it.‚Äù

The tentative, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù died in the back of Leia‚Äôs throat. She‚Äôd done enough apologizing these past months. So much it had almost crushed her even before all of this. ‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù she managed instead. ‚ÄúYou definitely saved me.‚Äù

There was a gentle shush of fabric moving and the bed dipped slightly. ‚ÄúIt isn‚Äôt wise to be caught in the desert during a storm. We‚Äôve been wondering how you got here.‚Äù

Hazy figures tugged at Leia‚Äôs memory, but she couldn‚Äôt remember them distinctly. Everything after she had landed was still mostly a blur. Except that brief introduction.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm Shmi Skywalker. You‚Äôre safe.‚Äù

‚ÄúTo be honest,‚Äù Leia said, struggling to sit up without wincing, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think I could explain it. I‚Äôm not really sure how it all happened.‚Äù

That was a lie. Or at least a violent exaggeration of the truth. But there was no way she was going to try and explain it. Not to this woman and not now. Maybe someday‚Ä¶

‚ÄúCliegg is worried,‚Äù Shmi started, and seeing Leia‚Äôs confusion added, ‚ÄúMy husband. We don‚Äôt get many visitors out here, and almost everyone from the planet knows how to not get caught in a storm. You aren‚Äôt from here,‚Äù she said, giving Leia a brief look over, ‚Äúand he‚Äôs worried what it could mean.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy? I‚Äôm not dangerous.‚Äù Also a lie, but a much less obvious one.

Shmi hesitated. ‚ÄúThe last time I let strangers into my home who were from off world to protect them from a storm, one was a Jedi. And he took my son. It is‚Ä¶ difficult to not see the similarities.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sending you to someone safe. Probably the only one who can help you actually fix everything. Do whatever is necessary. And don‚Äôt look back.‚Äù

The words were a cold impression on Leia‚Äôs mind, and she swallowed slowly. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not a Jedi,‚Äù she said carefully. ‚ÄúI never could be.‚Äù

‚ÄúMost of us can‚Äôt,‚Äù Shmi said, a cautious look on her face. ‚ÄúThat is a‚Ä¶ unique way to put it.‚Äù

It took two more swallows and a deep breath before Leia managed in a tight voice, ‚ÄúMy brother‚Ä¶ was. Was‚Ä¶ a Jedi.‚Äù

It was all she could manage. There was probably more she ought to add, to explain. Luke hadn‚Äôt really been a Jedi in the way that Shmi would be familiar with, if she had met a "real" Jedi. Temple trained Jedi. Child stealing Jedi (and Luke had never really gotten over that when he had realized how it had to have been, and what had happened to his‚Äîtheir fa‚Äî to Vader).

A warm hand covered hers, and Leia looked into eyes filled with deep sympathy and compassion. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry. So sorry that you lost someone you loved.‚Äù

‚ÄúEveryone,‚Äù Leia croaked, the grief lodged in her throat. ‚ÄúIt was everyone, over and over‚Äî‚Äú

Alderaan and the rebels and planet after planet that they couldn‚Äôt bring into the new Republic and Luke and Han and Chewie and Artoo and‚Äî

‚ÄúAnd don‚Äôt look back.‚Äù

She couldn‚Äôt. Couldn‚Äôt stop. Her eyes firmly fixed on the past, Leia cried and cried. Cried like she hadn‚Äôt allowed herself for years. Not since her mother and father had buried their friends as traitors and refused themselves even a single tear, just to protect her. She cried with grief and rage and hopelessness, sobbing in Shmi's arms, words and whispers of comfort washing over her in gentle, unintelligible waves. And Leia knew, no matter how much it hurt, she could never go back.

But she wasn‚Äôt strong enough not to look. Not yet.

Maybe never.

The Lars homestead was exactly as Luke had once described it and also nothing like his description at all. The basic framework was all there. Buildings mostly below ground level, different sections to spare power when it was scarce and confuse possible raiders, desert colors, few doors, and sand. Sand everywhere, no matter what you did. Always, all the sand. But that was just a feature of Tatooine, he‚Äôd said. All the sand in the worlds.

It was also a home. The ceilings were painted with dark designs in contrast to the pale walls. There were some tapestries and it had a very well used kitchen that smelled of earth and something Leia couldn‚Äôt quite place. For a place where nothing was supposed to grow, there was still the occasional splash of pale green and all the Larses were adamant that they were on a farm.

Leia hoped it was true, though it was a bit difficult to believe them.

Shmi was also mostly what Leia had expected, and nothing like. Luke's mentions of a grandmother that had died before he was even born had spoken of her kindness and gentleness, conveyed to him by stories from his aunt and uncle.

He hadn't mentioned that Shmi was strong. And brave (it took a lot to comfort a close friend, much less a complete stranger).

Leia let her fingers skim across the wall as she was led out of her room and down the hall. The tightness of her skin made it agitating, but there was something grounding in the action so she didn‚Äôt stop. Just took slow, careful steps as her bones creaked and her muscles stretched and eventually relaxed. Taking the few steps up to the open courtyard Shmi was leading Leia to was a little more painful, but she managed.

‚ÄúSo what brought you to our crack in the galaxy?‚Äù Cliegg had asked the moment she had reached out to shake his hand, carefully not wincing at the firm pressure.

Sensing his distrust (and was that just her experience talking, or was she feeling the Force at all, why hadn‚Äôt Luke ever explained the difference?) Leia hesitated before she answered. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm looking for something. A‚ÄîA new start, I think. Or maybe just something better than where I was.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo you came here?‚Äù was the patently skeptical answer. ‚ÄúWhoever sold you that story was full of‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúCliegg,‚Äù Shmi cut him off firmly. ‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt let her finish.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs alright,‚Äù Leia said, shrugging. ‚ÄúI know I‚Äôm out of place here. I understand his disbelief.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you?‚Äù he pressed, looking her up and down, taking in her fine, dark clothes (she wouldn‚Äôt think about mourning, not under his scrutiny) and carefully styled if now mussy hair. She knew her skin was still mostly soft, even after all her adventures. There might be a few new stress lines on her forehead and around her eyes, but there was nothing about her that said she had ever been exposed to the idea of manual labor, much less put thought into practice.

Four years with her home gone and even a complete stranger still saw her as a delicate little princess.

‚ÄúNo need to look so surprised,‚Äù she managed to say with enough of an edge that Cliegg‚Äôs eyebrows shot up. ‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt planning on being here earlier today, but now I am and that‚Äôs just how it is. I can handle it.‚Äù

That earned her a snort. ‚ÄúSays the girl who landed in the middle of a sandstorm,‚Äù he shot back. ‚ÄúWhere‚Äôs your ship?‚Äù

And of course he had to start with that awkward question. ‚ÄúI los‚Äî I exchanged it. To get here.‚Äù

Technically true. Completely false.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt care what pile of scrap you were piloting,‚Äù Cliegg was, if possible, even more dismissive now, ‚Äúif you traded it to stay here, you were cheated. And you deserve it.‚Äù

Leia managed not to mutter a bitter agreement and forced herself to keep his gaze until he was the one that looked away. But it was a dirty trick. He wasn‚Äôt wrong. Not about anything important.

‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt we have lunch?‚Äù Shmi intervened gently, placing a hand on each of their shoulders. ‚ÄúI think everyone will feel better after we‚Äôve eaten.‚Äù

There was a grunt of reluctant assent from her husband and Shmi used it as an excuse to immediately shoo Leia to the kitchen to help with the meal. Since at this point that mostly meant helping to carry the dishes that a girl introduced as Beru seemed to have been preparing (that was Luke‚Äôs aunt, wasn‚Äôt it, why hadn‚Äôt he talked about this place more?) Leia was able to be unembarrassed and helpful.

Who knew how long that would last.

Oh, this really is hell.

It was a brief thought that flared for a bright and sharp moment, hot and dry as the surrounding landscape, as the protocol droid in front of her turned and with an all too familiar stunted gesture in an all too familiar helpful tone announced, ‚ÄúHello, I am C-3PO, human cyborg relations. And who might you be?‚Äù

‚ÄúLeia,‚Äù she managed with what she felt was remarkable clarity as she stared at the grey metal coverings so unlike the gold she remembered and tried to reconcile the two images. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Leia.‚Äù

‚ÄúA pleasure to meet you, Mistress Leia. I hope I may be of service during your stay here. I‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù she cut him off with what she hoped was not too forced of a smile. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll let you know if I need anything.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course! Only say the word and I...‚Äú

It was a relief to hear Shmi chuckle next to Leia, and made the younger woman relax as the all too familiar droid took several more seconds to pledge his service.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a bit‚Ä¶ excitable,‚Äù Shmi admitted when they finally moved away from the vaporators and back towards the house (and it turned out this pile of rocks and machinery really was a farm, of sorts). ‚ÄúBut I can‚Äôt help but love him in spite of it. Anakin begged me to keep him when he left.‚Äù

Heart stuttering slightly, Leia hesitantly asked, ‚ÄúAnakin?‚Äù

‚ÄúMy son,‚Äù Shmi answered quickly, her eyes gazing determinedly out across the desert. ‚ÄúThe one who was ta‚Äîwho left. With the Jedi. I expect he is still training with them, since they didn‚Äôt bring him back.‚Äù

The forced humor in her tone resonated with a tight feeling that prickled over Leia‚Äôs skin and she hoped (if only Luke had ever properly explained) that it was a Force driven sense of what Shmi was clearly feeling. Grief and loss. Maybe even regret?

It resonated even more as Leia thought about it, so that was probably right. If there were any feelings Leia would be able to pick up on right now, those would be it.

‚ÄúAre you sorry?‚Äù The words had escaped before she could think them through, and Leia winced a bit as Shmi‚Äôs gaze snapped back to her guest.

There was a moment of hesitation before she answered. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt regret freeing him. He deserved to be free. Everyone does. I couldn‚Äôt make him stay here either. Not after having been raised a slave. He would have tried to stay with me, tried to work for Watto to make him let me go. And that wouldn‚Äôt have worked. No better than before at least. He is‚Äîwas such a sweet child. Always wanting to help everyone. I couldn‚Äôt hold him back. Not here. Not like this.‚Äù

It was difficult, impossible even for Leia to imagine what Shmi was saying. The only image in her head of Anakin Skywalker was a grown man, firm in his position in the Empire. Commander, tormentor, Sith.

How had he gone from being the sweet boy that Shmi remembered to being‚Ä¶ that?

‚ÄúIt must be hard,‚Äù Leia said at last, tripping a little over the words. They were so inadequate.

Shmi sighed. ‚ÄúWe do anything for the people that we love. No matter what it costs us. It‚Äôs the joy and pain of being a parent.‚Äù

‚ÄúI owe you. Possibly more than anyone else. Will you let me do this?‚Äù

With a shudder Leia dragged herself back to the present, away from that ghostly place in her mind, cold blues and blacks, the saddest eyes (but she would never, ever forgive him), words that echoed pain across the empty silence in her heart (she couldn‚Äôt feel Luke‚Äôs heartbeat, not anymore). Grinding her steps into the sandy ground, Leia let the irritation and pain of each movement grate through her mind in place of the memories that wanted to linger there.

‚ÄúIs it worth it?‚Äù She hadn‚Äôt meant to ask that question either, but something in Shmi‚Äôs face told Leia the woman had not been asked this question often enough.

‚ÄúI hope so,‚Äù was the whispered response. ‚ÄúI hope it was worth it.‚Äù

Descending the stone steps back into the house, Leia turned that thought over and over in her mind, lingering on it.

There was a pressure to it. Not quite like the tight prickling of grief, but with the same ethereal tone it swirled about in Leia‚Äôs mind. Ephemeral and delicate, as if it could change from one heartbeat to the next.

Hope.

The thought lingered as Leia helped with dishes and then allowed Beru to guide her through some basic attempts at helping with the cooking. It danced around, back and forth as Owen and Cliegg returned and the family sat down to dinner. It swelled as Leia found herself staring at C-3PO later that evening while helping the family shut down the homestead for the night.¬† It burned as she changed into the clothes she had borrowed, letting her hair out and combing through the strands more meditatively than productively. The thought twisted and writhed as she tried to connect Shmi‚Äôs longing to the masked face of Darth Vader and failed time and again to feel anything beyond the pain of the past.

‚ÄúWhy did you send me here?‚Äù she asked the darkness in hushed tones, knowing there would be no answer. That there couldn‚Äôt be, not anymore.

That had been the price.

‚ÄúDo whatever is necessary.‚Äù

Could she? Leia didn‚Äôt even know what was necessary. Had virtually no training to reach into the Force and try and figure it out. She had only her gut instincts. And longing. Longing so deep and painful it almost stole her breath as she allowed it to come forward and gave it the attention she had been denying it all day.

It didn‚Äôt hurt as much now, she noticed. Now that she had cried some of it out.

She had a feeling though, that it would be back. In force.

Something clicked then, a dangerous thought.

What would Shmi give, to have a second chance?

The pressure around her swelled and for a split second Leia knew, knew that if she offered Shmi the chance to see Anakin again Shmi would take it. No questions asked. Knew it as well as she had known the feeling of her brother‚Äôs life, shining near or far in the galaxy. As well as she knew her own name.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt,‚Äù she said out loud, thinking of Cliegg and Owen and Beru. Of responsibilities here and now. Of a lack of ship, or destination. Leia didn‚Äôt even know where Anakin Skywalker was right now. Or what year it was. Or anything.

‚ÄúDo whatever is necessary.‚Äù

Luke had told her she was brave. Braver than he was (as brave as Shmi was?).

She hoped that was true.

‚ÄúAnd don‚Äôt look back.‚Äù

Chapter End Notes

I won't make any hard promises now about how much Extended Universe content will or will not appear in this story, but odds are higher than not that I will not be especially EU compliant, long or short term.
You have been warned.

I'll be adding more tags as they come up.

Reckless Abandoned

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

The cold of the morning surprised her a little and Leia moved hurriedly from her room, across the courtyard, and into the kitchen where Beru, bless her, was already busy preparing breakfast.

‚ÄúIs there anything I can do to help?‚Äù Leia asked, swallowing pride and preparing to admit that whatever came out of Beru‚Äôs mouth would probably be outside the limit of the once princess‚Äô cooking knowledge.

Luckily, Beru was either the kindest secondary hostess alive, or had read Leia perfectly well the day before. ‚ÄúThe power‚Äôs still off in the droid garage. Could you go and turn it on? That way the droids can warm up before Cliegg and Owen need them.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course.‚Äù Because naturally Leia was more at home among wires and oil baths than kitchen implements and home cooked meals. She‚Äôd been in the rebellion far too long if this was what it had done to her.

What would her mother have said?

Not much, Leia had to admit as she bounded up one set of stone steps and then down another. Breha had never been one to fight her daughter‚Äôs nature, and Leia had been bound for adventure and rebellion as long as she had known the difference between the words Empire and Republic. The Alderaanian woman probably would have laughed and recommended Leia hire good help for the kitchen.

Smile tugging at her lips, Leia was able to face C-3PO‚Äôs morning greetings with more composure than she had anticipated.

‚ÄúWell, if it isn‚Äôt Mistress Leia. So good to see you again. I trust you have been enjoying your stay here.‚Äù

Biting back the truth (there was nothing enjoyable in anything about this place) she managed, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm very grateful. The Larses have been very kind, letting me stay here like this. I‚ÄîI don‚Äôt have any way to repay them.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh, I‚Äôm sure they don‚Äôt mind that,‚Äù Threepio said cheerfully. ‚ÄúThey are, as you said, most kind and most generous. Only think, Mistress Shmi insisted I be kept on all these years, and even convinced Master Cliegg that I needed new coverings. He said I wouldn‚Äôt be very useful, and indeed sometime I wonder if I‚Äôm best suited for this job. My primary programming is etiquette, you know, and...‚Äú

Nodding and making humming noises in all the right places, Leia checked the room to make sure the power was reaching everything properly, and that the droids were powering up as they should. C-3PO trailed along directly behind her, offering increasingly useless help and complimenting almost every choice she made in the few minutes it took her to make a full circuit of the room.

Who would have thought she‚Äôd be so sick of a familiar face already?

‚ÄúThreepio,‚Äù she said, placing a hand over his mouth as she turned, ready to head back inside, ‚ÄúI need to go and see if Beru needs anything else. I‚Äôll see you later today?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy of course. I‚Äôll just be out at the vaporators again. You must let me know if there is anything I can do for you. Anything at all."

"Thank you," Leia managed another smile, still tight but almost equal parts amused, and escaped back to the house before the protocol droid could start up again. She found Beru alone in the kitchen still. "Anything else I can do?"

Halfway through whatever would probably end up being the main part of their breakfast, Beru paused to think about the question. "No, I'm probably all good in here for now. Everyone else should be up soon." Then, conscientiously, "Did you sleep alright?"

The truth was probably close to, "As well as could be expected," but keeping in mind who she was talking to (and realizing she hadn't dreamed of her and Han's potential child again, so there weren't any tiny figures with dark eyes and soft, dark curls haunting her today) Leia managed instead, "Very well, thank you."

This was probably a good chance to also explain why she was up before sunrise, especially since no one had asked her to be available this morning, but Leia struggled to find those words and frame them in any way that came across naturally. She couldn't decide whether to be grateful or embarrassed when Beru's solution to the silence was to quietly turn back to breakfast and not push or even say anything.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre up early.‚Äù

And of course it would be Cliegg who would notice. And say something. Leia set the tray of drinks on the table and smiled calmly, drawing on her senatorial experience almost as naturally as breathing. ‚ÄúI do that sometimes.‚Äù

A gentle nudge from Shmi prevented any further comments from her husband and they managed to sit down to a quiet breakfast. Owen and his father made plans for the day and Shmi explained to Leia that she wouldn‚Äôt be expected to help with any of the chores.

‚ÄúI‚Äôd be happy to help,‚Äù Leia immediately offered, pointedly ignoring Cliegg‚Äôs skeptical look. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm pretty quick at picking things up.‚Äù

Shmi hesitated, looking between her guest and her husband. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll be going over the building systems today, making sure the climate control is working properly. And maybe gathering the mushrooms from around the vaporators. It helps keep the animals away so they get less damaged.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve worked a little on climate control before,‚Äù Leia offered. Multiple times, in completely different environments with a plucky multi-purpose astromech droid to help her, but who was really counting? ‚ÄúAnd I can always carry things.‚Äù

It was a winning idea as far as not feeling guilty while everyone worked that day. It was less successful in that Shmi and Beru had a work method that required minimal verbal communication, and frequently required very little from Leia as well. Which meant a day of very light physical labor and plenty of time to linger in her own thoughts.

Leia spent a lot of time practicing thinking about nothing (except a vicious loop of Luke‚Äôs voice telling her to clear her mind), but she wasn‚Äôt really sure about how well it worked.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre tired,‚Äù Shmi said that evening as Leia returned from helping with the nightly shut down again. And there was an invitation in the words that suggested they meant more than just physical exhaustion.

It took two long breaths and swallowing twice as many lies before Leia could answer, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been a long day.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù Shmi put an arm around Leia‚Äôs shoulders, her voice understanding and gentle. ‚ÄúIt isn‚Äôt always easy to be alone with the memories.‚Äù

‚ÄúDoes it feel like he‚Äôs dead then?‚Äù Leia asked before she could think better of it. She barely repressed a flinch at her own words.

Shmi hesitated before answering in an almost inaudible whisper, ‚ÄúSometimes. Yes, sometimes it does.‚Äù

Leia remembered that.

She thought about it over and over in the following weeks as she learned more than she had ever planned to about vaporators and the shockingly small amount of water that seemed to exist on Tatooine. She thought about it between thoughts of her brother, and of Han, and Chewbacca, and every time Threepio asked her if there was anything that he could do to be of service. She thought about it as Cliegg‚Äôs gruff demeanor gradually improved and she earned what she thought was the beginnings of respect. She thought about it as she watched Owen and Beru, smiling and laughing together and having whispered conversations about their future when the family gathered underground for the evening.

Leia thought about it the day she saw raiders in the distance and urged Shmi back into the house with a level of panic that thoroughly surprised the princess and nearly brought her to her knees.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs alright,‚Äù Shmi had said once they were inside, Leia braced against the wall and breathing slowly. ‚ÄúThey won‚Äôt come after us. Cliegg has agreements with the other farmers. They keep us safe.‚Äù

And Leia was grateful that Shmi hadn‚Äôt asked questions and had waited until they were inside to say that.

And she thought about Anakin Skywalker, and how to Shmi, sometimes he was dead.

And she dreamed.

‚ÄúDo you want children?‚Äù Beru asked one evening, when they were cooking together. ‚ÄúYour own family?‚Äù

‚ÄúSomeday,‚Äù Leia hedged, not really sure she wanted to talk about this, images of a now impossible future stuttering through her mind.

‚ÄúAre you worried about it? That you won‚Äôt find someone to have a family with?‚Äù

It was a natural thought, given how things were going with Owen and Leia could understand how Beru wanted the reassurance and also to share her happiness. All of the Larses had a tendency to want to share everything they had, no matter how small.

Leia was careful when she answered, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not really in a place to think about wanting children. They wouldn‚Äôt have a very safe life, even if they were an option. But I don‚Äôt worry about it. My parents adopted me when they realized they couldn‚Äôt have children. I can have a family when the time is right.‚Äù

If that family had been more real just a few short months ago, had taken on specific colors and features for a short time, she didn‚Äôt have to think about that right now.

Didn‚Äôt have to think that some of those features would once have belonged to Anakin Skywalker. Who Shmi sometimes remembered as one who was dead (and the smoke and the fire and the dark form on the pyre were just a dream, but one she had shared with Luke, so she knew that once it had been real and he had seen it and always remembered).

Leia remembered, and swallowed tears of rage over what had been stolen.

(Every day when she woke up, she still couldn‚Äôt feel his heartbeat or that warm ethereal glow.)

The warmth of a home surrounded her and Leia couldn‚Äôt accept it. The peace of the desert enveloped her, day after day as she moved from working in the house on menial tasks the Larses thought she could handle to more complicated ones as they realized that yes, in fact, she really was a quick learner.

Nothingness for miles and miles around nothing. Nothing but sun and sand and sun and hot wind for the day and chill gusts in the night. Nothing but occasional tuskens, infrequent jawas, and dozens of bizarre forms of resilient desert life. Whomp rats and banthas and‚Äî

One day, as they had been moving along between the vaporators, a cry had echoed faintly across the desert. And when Leia had searched across the desert and found nothing, Owen had whispered, with something between awe and fear, ‚ÄúKrayt dragon. Must be hunting.‚Äù

Leia remembered that cry. It was a song in her heart that she just kept singing, over and over, as the days passed by.

‚ÄúThank you for helping us like this,‚Äù Shmi said one day as they were out gathering mushrooms before the suns got too high. ‚ÄúIt would have been natural if you had just left. Not many people want to work out on the farms. Especially‚Ä¶ for as little as we‚Äôve been offering.‚Äù

Just room and board and no questions asked that she couldn‚Äôt refuse to answer if the grief was too much (at least that was the excuse, because more than grief it was often that there just wasn‚Äôt a safe answer).

‚ÄúI needed space,‚Äù Leia answered. ‚ÄúTo think about where I‚Äôm going next. This was as good a place to start as any. You‚Äôve been very gracious, letting me stay this long. I‚Ä¶ I want to pay you back.‚Äù

That earned a soft smile. ‚ÄúYou have.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think I‚Äôve paid Cliegg. But not you.‚Äù

And for a moment, Shmi‚Äôs expression sharpened. She breathed deeply, once, twice. Leia didn‚Äôt move, didn‚Äôt blink. Willed the woman who would have been her grandmother to understand without any words between them at all.

Shmi looked away, shaking. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt need anything. I‚Äôve been very blessed. My child is safe, my family is free, and I am not a slave. I have everything I wanted.‚Äù

‚ÄúExcept your son,‚Äù Leia said softly. ‚ÄúExcept Anakin.‚Äù

‚ÄúI love Owen,‚Äù Shmi answered, meeting Leia‚Äôs eyes again. ‚ÄúAnd dear Beru. They are my children.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo is Anakin.‚Äù

The conversation stopped, but it hadn‚Äôt ended.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm thinking it will be time for me to leave soon,‚Äù Leia announced at dinner a few days later. Beru looked the most disappointed, but Owen seemed sorry to hear it and Cliegg‚Äôs face took on the gruff edge that said he didn‚Äôt like what he‚Äôd just heard.

‚ÄúWhat, before the harvest?‚Äù he demanded.

Leia hesitated, then nodded. ‚ÄúYes. It needs to be soon. I‚Äôve got an idea now of where I‚Äôm going, and I‚Äôll need to get there quickly, before I miss any more opportunities.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhere are you going?‚Äù Shmi asked, and Leia hoped no one noticed that the older woman had hesitated.

‚ÄúOff planet. There‚Äôs some‚Ä¶ government work that I‚Äôd like to do, but I‚Äôll need to be closer to the core worlds. The news that‚Äôs trickling out here says civil war is a possibility, and I‚Äôd like to help try and prevent that.‚Äù

It had been a little while since she‚Äôd seen Cliegg so patently skeptical, but it was nice to know the expression hadn‚Äôt changed much. And in the stillness of the moment, Leia thought she might be able to feel a bit of the concerned disappointment as well. ‚ÄúGovernment affairs? No use getting involved in that business. You need money, and lots of it, to have a voice if you don‚Äôt have the connections born into your planet and family name. Fool‚Äôs errand, for someone who was making a new start and had to pick this planet.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôd still like to try,‚Äù Leia countered, biting back the desire to list off her years of experience and knowledge that would give her no small edge as she creeped back into that world.

And it was time. What little news she had been able to glean from the Lars‚Äôs small network and her rough memory of pre-empire dates, the Clone Wars were fast approaching. Which meant it was high time to find Anakin and see if she could right his wrongs. Before they had even happened.

Please, before any of them had really happened. She had no idea all the things that Darth Vader may have ever done. As a Jedi or Sith.

‚ÄúWhat exactly do you plan to try?‚Äù Cliegg pressed, and Leia knew she didn‚Äôt really want to get into this conversation.

‚ÄúThere are more than a few planets that are probably working on negotiations. I‚Äôm sure there‚Äôs something that I can help with.‚Äù

She tried to say it with the confidence of a seasoned negotiator and politician, but uncertainty crept in and lingered. Leia did have plenty of experience, for all the good it had done her the past few years, putting out fires across that galaxy and dragging planets back into the New Republic, only to watch other conflicts arise and old allies turn away, shaking their heads and saying maybe later. When things were more settled. When they had everything in line.

Looking back, Leia couldn‚Äôt remember not hating every single minute of it from the moment she stepped off of Endor and into that new, fledgling world.

Even before it had taken her family away from her.

‚ÄúDo you know where you‚Äôll be heading first?‚Äù Beru asked, breaking a slightly awkward silence.

Leia smiled. ‚ÄúMos Eisley first, I think,‚Äù she answered, ignoring Owen as he choked on his food. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll need passage and it‚Äôs the closest spaceport.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd the most dangerous,‚Äù Cliegg growled.

Which was not technically true. Leia had seen plenty of spaceports in her time, and while Mos Eisley was certainly one of the dirty, smuggling heavy ones, it was far from being the most dangerous. Smugglers could be bought. The Emperor‚Äôs Imperial troops had had a tendency to love pain more than money. Or to take cash without really being bought.

‚ÄúI can handle myself,‚Äù Leia retorted with more confidence in that statement than she had managed for her political skills. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm used to that sort. I know how they do business, and I know how to deal with it.‚Äù

Her hand had found her blaster at her hip, the last remnant of her old life besides the clothes she had come in that she still had. Han had given it to her, had picked it out specially to fit her hand, had practiced with her until she‚Äôd been able draw while firing as he so often had.

It made her burn to even think about it, but she could use it.

She already had.

‚ÄúYou won‚Äôt earn any favors by causing trouble,‚Äù Cliegg seemed even more determined than before. ‚ÄúStay here the rest of the year, finish the harvest with us. We‚Äôll take you in with us and you can book passage when you have real money to barter with.‚Äù

It was tempting. Leia had no material wealth to her name, and she couldn‚Äôt afford to sell her blaster (not in the least because she was pretty sure this model couldn‚Äôt possibly exist yet), not if it was going to be her leverage in a port of smugglers and bounty hunters.

But a sense of urgency had been growing day by day, swelling in Leia‚Äôs chest. It almost didn‚Äôt leave room for the pain her grief brought, it was so consuming. She didn‚Äôt have time to wait anymore. This would be her last night. She was sure of it.

Shaking her head, Leia managed, ‚ÄúI appreciate it, but it‚Äôs time. I‚Ä¶ don‚Äôt know how to explain it, but if I don‚Äôt leave now I know I‚Äôll lose the chance to do what I need to the most. I‚Äôve got my feet under me now, and I know I have all of you to thank for it.‚Äù

Cliegg held her gaze as Leia said the words, and a little of the gruffness left him. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôd be happy to keep you. You do good work.‚Äù

‚ÄúI hope so,‚Äù was her immediate response. ‚ÄúAnd I hope the Republic thinks so too.‚Äù

All that earned was a humph, but Leia accepted it with a smile. Maybe she could still negotiate with stubborn, irascible people.

But now would be the really tricky part.

Summoning all her courage (and drawing on the pressure in her chest that suddenly was almost threatening to explode), Leia turned to Shmi and asked, ‚ÄúI was wondering if you'd like to come with me.‚Äù

Dead silence. Everything frozen in place, completely still. In that silence Leia was almost certain she heard Shmi‚Äôs heart stop, as Beru‚Äôs and Owen‚Äôs started racing. Leia knew her own heart was pounding in her chest, not fast but heavy and deliberate. She felt the blood moving through her veins, felt something tightening over her skin, felt the world slowly slipping a little away, as if she was almost watching herself and the others at the table with outside eyes.

Shmi‚Äôs heart stuttering into a beat again.

Cliegg‚Äôs breathing going in and out in two quick, sharp hisses.

Her own eyes blinking once, twice, while her gaze was unflinching.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll probably end up going to Coruscant,‚Äù she felt her mouth say, almost as if it was someone else speaking the words. Or as if she was parroting what someone had whispered in her ears. ‚ÄúThe Jedi temple is there. You might see Anakin.‚Äù

It was cheating. Leia knew it. But she wasn't fighting fair. Hadn't since her first act of espionage. Since that blast of green energy and the death of Alderaan. Since Luke and Han and Chewie and Artoo had disappeared in a wave of heat and pressure, obliterated beyond recognition, beyond existence. Since that bright and shining light had been ripped out of her heart.

‚ÄúDo whatever is necessary. And don‚Äôt look back.‚Äù

Since she‚Äôd looked into the darkness and seen her own pain reflected in a stranger‚Äôs eyes. We failed them. All of them. And there is no going back. It can‚Äôt be undone.

Not without a price.

He had paid it. She had accepted it. Now was the time to act on it.

‚ÄúShmi?‚Äù

There was no need to press the point, Leia knew. From the moment she said the words, she knew her once grandmother had lost the will to fight. All that was left was the longing. Taking a deep breath, Shmi barely managed, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs fair that I leave before the harvest. Perhaps another time, if you ever come back‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be ridiculous.‚Äù Cliegg‚Äôs words were sharp and his tone was frighteningly flat. But Leia turned to him, ready to face anything he threw at them. Except for what he actually said. ‚ÄúTake the protocol droid with you. Maybe Anakin can fix him so he‚Äôs less obnoxious.‚Äù

There was another silence, just as deep but less distant than the last. Leia blinked twice more, felt everyone at the table make a sharp intake of breath.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù Shmi managed to speak first. ‚ÄúCliegg‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt argue,‚Äù he growled. ‚ÄúI won‚Äôt change my mind about it. We always said those Jedi should have taken you with them. Now‚Äôs your chance, and you‚Äôll take it.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut you need‚Äî‚Äú Shmi began.

‚ÄúOne less set of hands won‚Äôt ruin the harvest,‚Äù he grumbled, shoving food into his mouth and quickly swallowing it. ‚ÄúYou always said you‚Äôd go if you had the chance. We both knew it. Leia says she‚Äôll take you, and crazy as she is, I think she‚Äôll make it. So go.‚Äù

Blinking furiously, Shmi reached across the table and placed her hand over her husband‚Äôs. ‚ÄúI‚ÄîI can wait. I‚Äôm sure Leia would be willing to come back. Sometime later.‚Äù

Willing, yes. But now was the moment and Leia was grateful when Cliegg looked up, met his wife‚Äôs eyes and said, ‚ÄúBut she‚Äôs here now, and you can go this time.‚Äù A quick breath, and then, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt make us watch you carry that regret. You‚Äôve never given us the others, no matter how often we would‚Äôve taken them.‚Äù

Apparently Shmi didn‚Äôt have any response for that. Her hand clenched into a fist and she took a deep breath. ‚ÄúI do want to see him again,‚Äù she admitted in a hushed voice. ‚ÄúI really do.‚Äù

Something eased, not just in the room but in Leia‚Äôs heart. ‚ÄúThen we‚Äôll make that happen,‚Äù she promised, feeling the comforting weight of those words as she spoke them.

Shmi smiled, and Leia saw hope in her eyes.

Chapter End Notes

Thank you to everyone who commented, especially who left suggestions or asked questions. It helps. Hope you enjoyed chapter two.

Sky Walkers

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

It wasn‚Äôt that she hated space ports, but Leia never really felt safe in them anymore. Especially not one with this many bounty hunters roaming around.

‚ÄúIs everything alright?‚Äù Shmi asked, stepping closer as she did and eyeing a cluster of traders with the mistrust of a woman who had once walked very similar streets as a slave.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù Leia answered, willing it to be true as she tried to tune out the instinctual itch that came in a crowd with this many eyes on her (and maybe some of that tension had always been her sensitivity to the Force). ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just trying to decide where to start.‚Äù

She was also regretting sending Owen back so quickly. They had said all their goodbyes at the farm that morning and he was needed for work back home, but it would have been nice to have another warm body to stand behind her, creating a safe space there (a space a Wookiee had once filled, and no one else would ever quite manage), and looking a bit more imposing than just Leia could.

‚ÄúThreepio,‚Äù she called, wishing the protocol droid had a bit more mobility to him, ‚Äúdon‚Äôt fall too far behind.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course, Mistress Leia. I am right behind you,‚Äù the faithful droid answered, shuffling as fast as his stiff metal legs would allow. They needed to get him off this planet. The sand slowed him down just enough extra that he was practically useless.

An arm linked with Leia‚Äôs and she looked over at Shmi, who half whispered, ‚ÄúWhat exactly are we looking for?‚Äù

Leia bit back her immediate response (a miracle), and smiled as confidently as she could. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll know it when we see it.‚Äù

Which didn‚Äôt seem to inspire much confidence in Shmi, but the older woman just nodded and Leia thanked the stars for a grandmother who understood that some things just couldn‚Äôt be explained out loud. Like the conviction that Leia had that they were, in fact, in the right place right now. They just needed to be patient. And keep looking.

Probably.

‚ÄúYou lost?‚Äù an overly helpful pilot asked them at one point, eyeing them in a way that made Leia immediately defensive.

But she just gave him a look (perfected on Han, in a very different time), and he instinctively took a half step back even before she had vocalized her clear and concise, ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

There were two other times that people almost approached, smiles broad and overeager. Leia kept her hand on her blaster, her eyes narrow, and her nose just a little in the air.

Thankfully, that at least seemed to work. The patience was a more dubious pursuit.

She was starting to severely question her gut instincts when some anxious chatter reached her ears.

A party of twelve or so rodians had caucused near the entrance of a docking bay, gesticulating and making a number of high pitched tones in their native tongue that made Leia hesitate instead of passing them.

‚ÄúWhat is it?‚Äù Shmi asked, at almost the same moment Leia turned back to Threepio and asked, ‚ÄúWhat are they saying?‚Äù

There was the familiar slight head cock and arm twitch as Threepio answered, ‚ÄúWell, it seems they are having trouble with the pilot of their ship. Apparently he doesn‚Äôt want to take them any further, not at the rate they‚Äôre offering to pay him. How unfortunate. Do we have enough money to hire a pilot?‚Äù

Instead of answering Leia moved forward, slipping away from Shmi and asking Threepio to introduce them. He tapped one of the rodians on the shoulder and made a series of noises Leia hoped were the proper greeting for this kind of circumstance.

The rodian responded and Threepio turned to Leia to relay, ‚ÄúThey offer their greetings and want to know what we would like from them. He also,‚Äù Threepio hesitated, ‚Äúmade a rather rude and idiomatic statement about this being a public street and being allowed to stand here.‚Äù

Smiling, Leia turned to face the rodians and started speaking, pausing every so often so that Threepio could translate. ‚ÄúWe got the impression you could use some help getting off planet and thought we‚Äôd offer our services. Where are you heading?‚Äù

‚ÄúHerdessa,‚Äù Threepio informed her when one of them answered. ‚ÄúThey thought about stopping here rather than continuing, but apparently there isn‚Äôt much work beyond bounty hunting, at least around here. Which they are‚Ä¶ not pleased about. What help are you offering? Work?‚Äù

‚ÄúA pilot,‚Äù Leia said, waiting for Threepio to translate and for the group to react. A few heads turned in her direction, and she felt something like the slight lightening of a pressure.

‚ÄúHe says they have a pilot,‚Äù Threepio translated after a moment, ‚Äúbut we know that can‚Äôt be true, because we just heard them say they didn‚Äôt.‚Äù

Leia ignored the worry and said, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a better pilot. And you don‚Äôt have to pay me.‚Äù There was a skeptical tittering as Threepio translated this before Leia added, ‚ÄúI would just want passage for me and for my companions, the woman and the droid. We want to get off of this rock as much as you do.‚Äù

It was humiliating how long the crowd debated, Leia realized after the first couple of minutes. No one had ever questioned Luke or Han if they could fly a ship (and that sharp pain of regret wouldn‚Äôt show on her face, she was at least a good enough diplomat to avoid that).

‚ÄúThey would like to leave immediately,‚Äù Threepio told her, when the leader of the small group turned to the droid with an answer. ‚ÄúIf you really can get them to Herdessa.‚Äù

‚ÄúJust show me the ship,‚Äù Leia said, still projecting that unnatural certainty. The ships here might be older, but she‚Äôd been taught a thing or two about flying in the past few years. Enough to at least make the jumps necessary to get them to Herdessa. There would be more work options there for everyone, including Leia and Shmi.

Hopefully she wouldn‚Äôt have to resort to bounty hunting. It was technically an option, but Leia wasn‚Äôt sure her traveling companions would really like it.

The Millennium Falcon had always been the junkiest ship Leia had flown in. Until this moment. It was with more than a bit of bitterness that Leia realized her family and friends and even the rebellion had spoiled her with what to expect from any kind of transport ship. Or freighter.

The ship in front of her was actual junk. Probably literally pulled from some sort of scrap heap somewhere and cobbled together with desperation as much as skill. She could understand the rodians‚Äô sudden transition of loyalty from their old pilot, and willingness to try Leia‚Äôs skills. These people had almost nothing left. And they would be damn lucky if they could even scrap this mess wherever they landed.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think,‚Äù Shmi said very quietly, ‚Äúand I‚Äôm not an expert of course. But I don‚Äôt think it should look like that.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs space worthy,‚Äù Leia answered. ‚ÄúIf they‚Äôve made it this far. Threepio said they came from Khubeaie. That‚Äôs not a nothing trip. We should be able to make it to Herdessa, no problem.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd from there?‚Äù Shmi prodded. ‚ÄúThat wasn‚Äôt our actual destination.‚Äù

Facing the reality that no one here (except possibly, maybe C-3PO) thought she was capable of doing any of this, the once princess squared her shoulders and admitted, ‚ÄúIt may take some time. But Herdessa will be a safer, easier place to work with. To get to where we really want.‚Äù She could try and look up old (or rather, at this point very young) contacts, people that had soft enough hearts Leia could spin some sort of lie (or even truth) and get them help. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs also a refugee stop, which is probably why the Rodians are heading there. We can use this.‚Äù

And they could. The controls were less clunky than she had been expecting, more familiar than she would have thought. She asked a couple questions to confirm a few things, made sure they had completely refueled the ship, and winced when the leader admitted through Threepio that with Hutt ‚Äútaxes‚Äù they hadn‚Äôt quite managed to get all the resources that they wanted.

‚ÄúRight,‚Äù Leia grumbled as she turned back to the console, fingers gripping the controls to prevent her from rubbing her head. ‚ÄúHutts are here.‚Äù

And damn that fat worm and his putrid breath and stubby, slimy hands and bulbous, flat face. That wriggling, slithering blob had the audacity to be alive again after all the work she had done to remove his gross presence (and the flood of emotions and memories that came with the rancor and the sarlacc, and Han frozen against the wall, and having to rely on Lando after his betrayal, and the dark and mysterious Luke that had led them after Bespin because of Vader, and all that he had done and stolen), and Leia wasn‚Äôt ready to forgive that.

She would be back. If only to finish that.

‚ÄúYou look comfortable there,‚Äù Threepio said, on behalf of Coq Zita, the rodian answering Leia‚Äôs questions. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve done this before?‚Äù

‚ÄúA thousand times,‚Äù Leia answered, and the slight snout twitch that Leia recognized as a rodian smile made a brief appearance. Coq spoke a bit more and Threepio added, ‚ÄúHe says they like you much more than their last pilot. You‚Äôre much prettier. And more polite.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll bet I smell better too,‚Äù Leia smirked, and was a little embarrassed when the protocol droid decided to translate that too.

‚ÄúHe says most certainly, yes,‚Äù Threepio informed her after Coq had laughed. ‚ÄúAnd I think it was rather impertinent of him.‚Äù

Leia laughed too, started preparing the ship and setting the nav computer, and two hours later (because a host of other, Hutt marked ships got clearance first) they were off.

Shmi joined Leia in the cock pit after a few hours. Impressed that it had taken that long for Shmi to lose interest in their traveling companions, Leia didn‚Äôt say much when the woman came and leaned up behind the pilot‚Äôs seat, staring out the window at the blue white stream of hyperspace.

A half glance back confirmed to Leia that Shmi‚Äôs eyes were wide, her lips pressed firmly together.

‚ÄúHow fast are we going?‚Äù she eventually asked.

‚ÄúReally fast,‚Äù Leia answered, taking a more relaxed posture, letting her hands rest on the controls without gripping them. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why the ship is doing most of the work at this point.‚Äù

Moving her hand to one of Leia‚Äôs shoulders, Shmi gripped tight. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs wonderful. And terrifying.‚Äù

‚ÄúCan you imagine Anakin flying in this?‚Äù Leia asked, and noticed that Shmi‚Äôs grip eased.

She chuckled. ‚ÄúOh yes. Yes, he would love it.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure he would.‚Äù After another silence, Leia volunteered, ‚ÄúI actually prefer the parts of travel outside of hyperspace. It‚Äôs beautiful, and you get a real sense of how large the galaxy really is. How much life and light are out there.‚Äù

Nights on Tatooine had been hard, but when she couldn‚Äôt sleep Leia had snuck out to the open courtyard, braved the chill, and laid back and stared up into the night sky, trying to remember the location of all her favorite stars (and relish that within the orbit of that sun, Alderaan was still alive). The little dots of light had been a soothing blanket that covered a multitude of hurts.

She loved the coldness and the distance of those lights. And the darkness that held the stars and kept them hung in the sky.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know if I was meant for this,‚Äù Shmi admitted softly, and Leia didn‚Äôt answer right away.

‚ÄúBiologically speaking, you‚Äôre not. No life form I‚Äôve ever met was. That‚Äôs probably what‚Äôs so terrifying about this. Your body knows it‚Äôs not supposed to be here. You just have to convince it to suck it up and fly anyway.‚Äù

The feeling of Shmi trying to conquer her fear rolled around the small room. Leia recognized it and trusted that she knew what it was. Reading Shmi was somehow easier than reading other people. It came more naturally and created a solid baseline for Leia to gauge whether other things that she was feeling were from herself, or were an impression left by movement in the Force.

‚ÄúI think I will go back and sit with the others,‚Äù Shmi said. ‚ÄúThank you, for sharing this.‚Äù

Leia nodded, turning her attention to the screens in front of her. ‚ÄúAny time.‚Äù

The door hissed open and closed and Leia was left alone again, watching the blurred movement of space. Leaning back in her seat, she tried again to figure out what Luke had meant about clearing her mind, tickled by a sensation like stars flickering in darkness that skimmed over her skin.

It was the rough equivalent of the middle of the night, and Leia was starting to regret not taking Coq up on covering her for a bit to let her catch some sleep before she would be needed at the controls to handle landing. With the interplanetary time differences, Leia knew they would be setting down mid-morning on Herdessa, for all that it would still feel like the dark abyss before the crack of dawn.

She‚Äôd thought she could handle the sleep deprivation. She‚Äôd managed it before.

She‚Äôd forgotten about waking dreams.

Tapping into the well of energy that never seemed quite depleted, one that she had drawn from over and over again across the years (and it was so strange, that she had always had this access to the Force, and had never realized what it really was) kept Leia conscious. But it also triggered other senses.

Like visions of the past.

Here, in the cold light of space, her mind took her to a different ship. One that had often felt more like home than land had over the past five years. She could see the wookiee in the cockpit, trying to hold the ship steady while also maneuvering around heavy fire from a half dozen enemy cruisers. Could feel the slight rocking from the guns that were being manned down the hall. Could hear Chewie‚Äôs final roar and a screeching beep from a droid behind her as two torpedoes in a large cluster made it past the dead eye shooting coming from the Falcon‚Äôs manned guns.

She saw fire.

She saw nothing.

She saw space.

‚ÄúMistress Leia?‚Äù a metallic voice chimed and Leia jumped slightly in her seat. ‚ÄúOur passengers are wondering how close we are to landing, to see if they should wake the children up.‚Äù

‚ÄúForty minutes,‚Äù Leia answered, having checked the screen as Threepio had started talking. ‚ÄúThey probably don‚Äôt need to wake anyone yet. I‚Äôd say wait another thirty minutes.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course, Mistress Leia. Thank you.‚Äù

Collapsing back in the chair, Leia allowed herself several deep breaths before she tried closing her eyes, not sure what would be behind them.

Fire again, as it turned out.

Instead of turning away from it, she tried to face it. To see past the bright heat to the crumbling ship and disintegrating form she had been watching before.

She could almost see it this time, she thought.

‚ÄúJust like hell,‚Äù she muttered to herself. Then thought of Shmi and snorted. ‚ÄúOr close enough.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd here I was thinking we‚Äôd finally escaped it,‚Äù came an amused reply.

Leia turned and gave a tired smile to her companion. ‚ÄúApparently,‚Äù she answered with more heaviness than she had intended, ‚Äúsometimes we just get to carry it with us.‚Äù

The look Shmi gave her was a little too understanding and Leia turned back to the controls to avoid as much of it as she could. Thankfully, when she spoke all Shmi said was, ‚ÄùThreepio says we‚Äôre landing soon.‚Äù

‚ÄúThirty minutes out,‚Äù Leia confirmed.

When it was clear the younger woman wasn‚Äôt adding anything else, Shmi asked, ‚ÄúWhat is it like, landing on a new planet? On Herdessa?‚Äù

It took Leia a moment to find an answer. ‚ÄúLanding on a new planet is‚Ä¶ always nerve-racking,‚Äù she eventually managed. ‚ÄúEven when you think you know what to expect. Herdessa‚Ä¶ I‚Äôve only been a few times, very briefly. But we‚Äôll be landing in the capital, which is where I visited. It will be busy, packed with people. And it‚Äôs an industrial planet, so expect lots of buildings and droids and smog.‚Äù

‚ÄúSmog?‚Äù Shmi asked, and Leia had to think about that one too.

‚ÄúDark smoke, but from industrial burning, not just simple fires. Not quite clouds, but it can make the air,‚Äù she struggled for a word that would make sense to someone from a completely arid environment, and settled on, ‚Äúthicker. Or something.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt will probably be easier to explain once I see it,‚Äù Shmi replied with a grateful smile. Then she frowned again. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have any papers. Cliegg only had my slave note, and I didn‚Äôt think that would be of much use.‚Äù

Nodding, Leia turned half her attention to the ship and dropping them out of hyperspace. ‚ÄúIt wouldn‚Äôt be any use. We‚Äôll be fine without papers though. Plenty of people travel without them. The Rodians have some, but they know what kind of work they are looking for, and what quarter they want to settle in. Papers help with that. We‚Äôre a bit more‚ÄîWell, we‚Äôre improvising. If we stay here long enough, we could look into getting papers, probably claiming some sort of refugee status. But if not, we can just pick them up on the next planet, or whenever we get to Coruscant.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe aren‚Äôt‚ÄîWill there be a lot more planets? Before Coruscant?‚Äù

Leia tried to sound as soothing as possible. ‚ÄúI doubt it. Herdessa is more likely to have ships heading straight there. I might be able to offer my services as a pilot again, but more likely we‚Äôll stay here for a bit, earn some money with odd jobs, and then pay for passage with someone else. Maybe at discount, if we volunteer to work on whatever craft we find.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚ÄîI don‚Äôt know much about ships. Anakin did. He was very good with them. I only know farm equipment. And housekeeping.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôd be surprised at how much you already know, just from the farm equipment,‚Äù Leia said, making sure to meet Shmi‚Äôs eyes for a moment. ‚ÄúAnd what did you do for‚Äîbefore Cliegg and the farm?‚Äù

There was a brief pause before Shmi answered, ‚ÄúNot much. Watto had much more use for Anakin. I cared for his home, cooked his meals. Shopped sometimes, or rummaged for spare parts that Anakin could repair for him. I‚Äôm‚ÄîI‚Äôm not lazy. I just don‚Äôt know that I know anything that will be useful‚Ä¶ here.‚Äù

As Shmi said the words they softened, as if the growing image of the planet outside had absorbed them. Thick, brown grey tufts hovered where clouds would normally be, over the massive cities that sprawled so heavily they could be seen in basic outline, even from this distance.

More grey than Coruscant, Leia thought. Dirtier, even from this height.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure we‚Äôll find something,‚Äù she managed to say after a few moments. ‚ÄúIt won‚Äôt be glamorous, but we‚Äôll make do.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think I belong anywhere glamorous,‚Äù Shmi retorted with a chuckle (and maybe a hint of bitterness, coloring the edges of it). ‚ÄúSo this will probably suit me just fine.‚Äù

Rather than suggesting she was wrong, Leia focused on their flight, trying to ease the ship through the atmosphere.

There were a disturbing number of creaks and groans as they descended, but the ship held together and the systems all reported that everything onboard was still safe. Following directions from the landing operators, they eventually managed to touch down, almost smoothly.

‚ÄúVery well done,‚Äù Shmi said with a smile. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve made it.‚Äù

Two hours later, things were looking worse, not better.

It had taken forever for a deck official to come to clear them, and now‚Ä¶

‚ÄúCoq Zita does not understand what the problem is,‚Äù C-3PO repeated probably for the tenth time. ‚ÄúTheir papers are in order and their ship has landed in an appropriate zone. Could you please clarify?‚Äù

After a few frustrated snorts and growls, there was a mostly articulate reply from the official processing their paperwork, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not Coq that‚Äôs the problem. Not his people either. It‚Äôs the pilot.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù Threepio said cheerfully. ‚ÄúWell, why didn‚Äôt you say so before?‚Äù He turned to Leia. ‚ÄúMistress Leia, it seems that we‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI heard him,‚Äù she said before he could get too excited. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the problem? We aren‚Äôt asking to be processed with the rodians. We‚Äôre a separate group, who happen to have been traveling on the same vessel.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo pilot‚Äôs license,‚Äù the official huffed.

Leia raised her eyebrows. ‚ÄúNo local one? Of course not. This is my first time on planet. And they aren‚Äôt required on Tatooine.‚Äù

Possibly a lie, but she was pretty sure it would stick. A confident posture and authoritative voice went a long way. And then there was the natural Skywalker charisma. Not something she had used to assume she had, but now‚Ä¶

Well, something was unnatural about her. There was no denying it.

And it appeared to be working. ‚ÄúWell, I suppose‚ÄîI guess‚ÄîThat‚Äôs fine then. But no more flying here. And you can‚Äôt be processed with them. You don‚Äôt have papers.‚Äù He nodded to Coq and the other Rodians.

‚ÄúFair enough,‚Äù Leia smiled. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll stand over here while you finish. Threepio, can you please explain the delay to our friends?‚Äù

The protocol droid was more than happy to continue to help, and Leia stood with Shmi, watching from a short distance.

Hoping to prepare them for whatever was ahead (this would be trickier than she had thought) Leia took the moment to close her eyes and try again to quiet her mind.

As usual, it didn‚Äôt really work. The more she tried to reach out, the noisier everything became around her. It ebbed and flowed in moments of perfect silence (as if she had shut off all her senses and pushed everything away) and crushing awareness, where she was pulled in a thousand different directions by random scents, sounds, and sensations across her skin.

Trying to sort through it, Leia kept getting the impression of something glittering right behind her. She turned, opening her eyes and scanning the other landing platforms. Most of the ships nearby were only in slightly better condition than hers, but not too far away was a bright, shining silver vessel.

Leia blinked. It looked like‚Ä¶ it looked like the government ship Senator Pooja Naberrie had always flown in.

Almost without thinking, her feet started carrying her away from their passengers and ship and toward this new, bright spot in her vision. She made it about ten steps before she felt someone catch her arm and turned to see Shmi‚Äôs confused face.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs something over there, I think,‚Äù Leia tried to explain. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just going to look for a bit.‚Äù

Crossing two other landing platforms and dodging the irritated crew members, Leia made it within throwing distance of the ship, Shmi trailing slightly behind her, before she came to a stop, suddenly leery.

Something tightened like a vice in her chest and her head snapped to the right, finding a group moving towards the ship.

‚ÄúSenator, please.‚Äù The voice was unfamiliar, but the vice feeling tightened even further as Leia heard it. ‚ÄúI know this is a difficult time for you‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúSenator Amidala, I agree with you,‚Äù came a slightly harried reply. ‚ÄúThere is a growing crisis and I want to help. But the Senate isn‚Äôt providing the funding necessary for us to keep taking on more and more refugees, and I don‚Äôt know how long we can keep making things work like this.‚Äù

‚ÄúShea,‚Äù Senator Amidala had stopped walking and placed a hand on the other woman‚Äôs arm, ‚ÄúI know how difficult this is. I‚Äôm willing to do everything I can to make it happen. Please, just tell me you‚Äôre willing to help.‚Äù

There was a brief silence and a long, exasperated sigh from the other Senator. ‚ÄúI want to, Senator Amidala. You know I do. But I have my people to consider, as you have yours.‚Äù

There was a flash of hurt on Senator Amidala‚Äôs face (and Leia might be having a slight panic attack because she was looking at the heroic, beautiful, intelligent, courageous Senator Padm√© Amidala of Naboo) and Leia felt a stabbing sensation right through the tension that was grabbing her heart. The sensation of betrayal cut deep and even with her extraordinarily limited experience, Leia knew this was the Force.

An awkward silence was growing, and Leia was as surprised as anyone when Shmi stepped forward and in a tentative voice called out, ‚ÄúPadm√©?‚Äù

The full attention of the senatorial party was now directed their way, and Leia watched in fascination and something close to envy as Senator Amidala‚Äôs expression moved from confusion to complete surprise.

‚ÄúShmi? Shmi Skywalker?‚Äù The senator crossed the distance between them with quick strides, coming right up to the older woman and looking into her face with delight and wonder. ‚ÄúOh. Oh it‚Äôs so good to see you again!‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, of course,‚Äù Shmi‚Äôs hands fluttered a bit. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt think‚ÄîI wasn‚Äôt expecting to see‚Ä¶‚Äù

Senator Amidala frowned, ‚ÄúWhat are you doing here?‚Äù

There was a slight hesitation before Shmi answered, ‚ÄúWe‚ÄîWe were just stopping here. On our way to Coruscant‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúWe?‚Äù Senator Amidala turned to look at Leia, and the poor one-time princess immediately forgot how to speak. Or think. Or breathe.

‚ÄúThis is my friend,‚Äù Shmi answered when it became clear that Leia wouldn‚Äôt. ‚ÄúLeia offered to travel with me, to make sure I was safe.‚Äù

The smile Leia got from the senator was a bit hesitant, but thankfully some part of Leia‚Äôs brain had reengaged (and how in the hell that was Tatooine did Shmi Skywalker know Senator Padm√© Amidala of Naboo), and she was able to smile in response and execute something more formal than a nod, but not quite as proper as a bow.

‚ÄúSenator,‚Äù she managed to say without stuttering. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a pleasure to meet you.‚Äù

The sincerity echoing from each word earned the senator‚Äôs smile and Leia felt like she had been exposed to a very focused shaft of sunlight.

The vice-like grip on her heart somehow tightened even more and she desperately hoped she wouldn‚Äôt have to speak again until it let up. She wasn‚Äôt entirely sure she could.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt believe it,‚Äù Senator Amidala said, turning back to Shmi. ‚ÄúI never would have guessed, suspected‚Äî‚Äú

Shmi folded her arms, shaking her head. ‚ÄúIt was a surprise for me too. Being here‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs like a dream.‚Äù

Senator Amidala opened her mouth for a moment, then hesitated. Leia was stunned to see the senator looked a bit ashamed. ‚ÄúI‚ÄîI owe you an apology.‚Äù

Shmi blinked several times. ‚ÄúFor what?‚Äù

The senator met Shmi‚Äôs eyes, her own a little moist as she said, ‚ÄúI‚Ä¶ I didn‚Äôt come back for you. I should have. I‚Äôm so sorry.‚Äù

A taste of longing and regret filtered through the pain that was still constricting in Leia‚Äôs chest for a moment before Shmi shook her head. ‚ÄúWe had no deal. You made me no promise. It‚Äôs‚ÄîIt‚Äôs alright.‚Äù

‚ÄúI still should have come back. It would have been right.‚Äù

Voice cracking Shmi said, ‚ÄúI just‚Ä¶ wanted to see my son. To see Anakin again. That‚Äôs all.‚Äù

There was a pause while Senator Amidala took a deep breath. ‚ÄúI can‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúSenator Amidala?‚Äù The Herdessa senator approached along with two of Senator Amidala‚Äôs guard and an all too familiar blue and white astromech (and Leia‚Äôs clenched heart screamed and she heard a warning beep and saw fire and nothing), all eyeing the two strangers with some concern. ‚ÄúAre these friends of yours?‚Äù

Before the Naboo senator could answer, there was a shout of, ‚ÄúOi, you two! You haven‚Äôt been processed yet!‚Äù

The official from the other landing pad was storming over, fur bristling while C-3PO scuttled along behind him. Leia heard an expressive blat from Artoo, but couldn‚Äôt decide who it might be directed at.

Coming to a halt a couple paces away from Shmi and Leia, the landing official began, ‚ÄúAnd just what do you think‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre with me,‚Äù Senator Amidala said, moving Shmi aside slightly and stepping forward. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Senator Amidala, of the Naboo.‚Äù

‚ÄúCoo, they didn‚Äôt come with you, my lady,‚Äù the official said, narrowing his eyes. ‚ÄúCame in just now with that pack of new rodians. Looking for work, they are, and not likely to find it here, I tell you. And this one,‚Äù he pointed a finger at Leia, ‚Äúnot even licensed to fly.‚Äù

‚ÄúHere,‚Äù Leia corrected, voice strained more by the bizarre and heavy sensations in her chest than actual anger. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not licensed to continue flying here. We already discussed this.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, she‚Äôs not going to keep flying here,‚Äù Senator Amidala intervened. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs coming with me. And our pilots are licensed to fly anywhere in the Republic.‚Äù

The official seemed slightly appeased by this, but seemed to realize he had also been derailed from a point. Before he could find it again, the Herdessa senator added, ‚ÄúThey do still need to be processed though. And they shouldn‚Äôt have left their landing platform until they were.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù Leia managed to get out in a mostly normal voice. ‚ÄúThat was my fault. Of course we‚Äôll go back and finish being processed properly.‚Äù

This mollified the official, but when he continued to grumble as he was retreating Senator Amidala stated, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm coming too.‚Äù

The grumbling stopped, and the travelers ended up being escorted back to the ramshackle ship (which Leia delightedly and embarrassingly noticed that Senator Amidala eyed with no small amount of horror and scorn) by both senators, two of each of their guard, C-3PO, R2-D2, and someone who was probably the Herdessan senator‚Äôs assistant.

Paperwork finished and ship designated for scrapping, Leia turned back to the task at hand. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry for the trouble,‚Äù she directed her words to both senators. ‚ÄúThank you for all of your help.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe did nothing,‚Äù the Herdessan senator said a bit stiffly, watching Leia with more than a little wariness. ‚ÄúAll of this was standard procedure.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen I‚Äôm sorry we interrupted your conversation,‚Äù Leia tried instead.

The senator winced and looked anxiously at Senator Amidala, who was glancing at her colleague out of the corner of her eyes. The Naboo woman eventually sighed. ‚ÄúSenator Sadashassa, we both know things can‚Äôt continue the way they‚Äôve been.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Senator Sadashassa agreed. ‚ÄúBut I‚Äôve already explained how little there is that I can do to help you. Our cities may not, strictly speaking, be full, but our systems are overrun with people fleeing the increasing conflicts around the outer rim. We can‚Äôt process them quickly enough, even if we have the space for them. Eventually.‚Äù

Senator Amidala thought for a moment, fingers touching her chin as she stared at the ground. When she looked up, she smiled. ‚ÄúI know. And I know you have reservations because you feel Naboo isn‚Äôt doing what it should be to help.‚Äù

‚ÄúI never said that,‚Äù Senator Sadashassa murmured.

Senator Amidala just kept smiling. ‚ÄúDidn‚Äôt you? I thought you had, in your own way. No,‚Äù she raised a hand, ‚Äúdon‚Äôt apologize. You‚Äôre right. I‚Äôve been so busy with work in the senate, I haven‚Äôt coordinated enough with the Queen and her council, to make sure that matters are being taken care of properly at home. That we‚Äôre setting the right example.‚Äù Her chin came up. ‚ÄúIf we create, and implement, a higher volume refugee program on Naboo and it succeeds, will you agree to be the next site to test it, so that we can recommend it to the senate?‚Äù

Senator Sadashassa smiled, her shoulders relaxing. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm willing to promise that.‚Äù

A feeling like sunlight rolling off of her, Senator Amidala grinned, ‚ÄúThank you, Shea.‚Äù

As the two women bowed and shook hands, Leia felt the vice grip on her heart give one last, horrid squeeze, before the pressure released and she could breathe again. In that moment, as everything inside her expanded, she felt the world almost twist slightly, lurching from where the two senators stood holding hands.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sending you to someone safe. Probably the only one who can help you actually fix everything. Do whatever is necessary.‚Äù

Leia had no idea if this was right or not, but she knew, knew in her bones that now sang with the shifting sands of the desert, in her heart that now filled more space in her chest that it had before, that something had definitely changed.

‚ÄúAnd don‚Äôt look back.‚Äù

Chapter End Notes

I like to think that Bail shamelessly encouraged Leia's rebel streak partially accidentally by trying to make sure that she knew every story he could possibly think of about her biological mother. Because even if she couldn't know she was related to Padm√©, it would just be such a waste not to tell Leia all the stories.

Leia's greatest dream has secretly always been to meet Senator Amidala. She maybe a little subscribed to the conspiracy that Padm√© never really died and was out there, fighting for the rebellion, somewhere.

The Lap of Luxury

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Naboo was green.

It shouldn‚Äôt have surprised Leia, but there was something about the greenness that stood out to her as the ship approached the ground. It wasn‚Äôt the dark, dusky green of Endor‚Äôs moon. It was‚Äî

It was more like the blue touched green of Alderaan. It was rolling hills and hints of mountains, and lakes and rivers that stretched for miles.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve never seen anything like this,‚Äù Shmi whispered reverently, leaning towards Leia as they both stared out the window. ‚ÄúHave you?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú Leia stumbled (shattered in a bolt of green, blue then black and nothing). ‚ÄúYes. I‚Äôve seen places like this. I love them. They‚Äôre like home.‚Äù

The words were true, but the last one in particular tasted hollow on her tongue. Acrid and bitter in comparison to the sweet sight of Theed, and the generous senator that was standing beside the pilot, looking back at them and smiling. Senator Amidala murmured something to her guard and with surprisingly quick, strong strides came over to join her guests.

Leia was only a little envious that the senator addressed Shmi first. ‚ÄúDo you want to come up a bit more? There‚Äôs plenty of space. You won‚Äôt distract anyone and the view is lovely.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe noticed,‚Äù Shmi replied, still giving most of her attention to the view port. ‚ÄúIf it isn‚Äôt any trouble?‚Äù

‚ÄúNone at all,‚Äù the senator promised, offering her arm to Shmi and walking her over.

They made their way forward and Leia followed, lingering behind. She heard the metallic scuffle of Threepio coming forward and her lips twitched as he caught his first glimpse of the planet and exclaimed, ‚ÄúOh, how marvelous!‚Äù

Shmi and Senator Amidala both turned back with knowing grins, catching the expression on each other‚Äôs faces and chuckling as they turned back to the view. There was a pervasive serenity in the moment, and Leia could see that Shmi was much less anxious about this landing than the previous one.

Which was good, because Leia was more nervous, and doing everything in her power to hide it.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got clearance, Senator,‚Äù the pilot said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll be docking soon.‚Äù

If it was meant as a suggestion that the passengers should get ready to get off, it was ignored. Senator Amidala thanked him, and pointed out the palace to Shmi as they approached.

‚ÄúAnakin came with me here,‚Äù the senator was explaining. ‚ÄúBefore he went to the temple to train. He, ah, accidentally got stuck in one of the ships and was in the middle of space before anyone could catch him.‚Äù

There was clearly more to the story. Leia saw it more in the faces of the senator‚Äôs guards than heard it in her tone, but it would be worth exploring. For now though, it was just a relief to hear Shmi chuckle ruefully.

‚ÄúHe did always want to be a pilot,‚Äù she acknowledged. ‚ÄúHe always talked about it.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe way he told it, he already was a pilot, even then,‚Äù Padm√© answered with a broad grin.

Sadness struck, vicious and unsuspected. In the calm of that moment, Leia saw another pilot, another child of Tatooine. One who had wanted to be just like his father (‚ÄúI‚Äôm a Jedi,‚Äù he had told her when he had come back from the Death Star, ‚Äúlike you could be.‚Äù), and who had been the galaxy‚Äôs greatest pilot those past four years. Brave and strong and full of promise.

Struck down by the horrible remaining fragments of the ruined Empire.

It wasn‚Äôt until Threepio said something that Leia realized she was crying.

‚ÄúMistress Leia, are you alright? Is the landing too rough for you?‚Äù

Stepping out of her memories with a force of will she was just starting to master, Leia shook her head and did her best to smile at the two women now looking at her. Shmi at least understood grief that could not be shared, and the senator was polite enough to ignore what wouldn‚Äôt be spoken. So when Leia said, ‚ÄúNo Threepio. It‚Äôs just the light here. My eyes are adjusting,‚Äù there weren‚Äôt any awkward questions.

Which made Leia grateful.

And sad.

(They‚Äôd never know him, that bright and shining star in the universe, and all that he had done and become, and all he knew he could be, and she grieved for that, with bitter longing and remorse.)

The pilot announced, ‚ÄúHere we are,‚Äù and the craft glided to a gentle stop, lowering slowly and touching down with only the tiniest of shifts felt on the inside.

‚ÄúWelcome to Naboo,‚Äù Senator Amidala said, looking first at Shmi and then to Leia. ‚ÄúI hope you enjoy it here.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe plan to,‚Äù Leia managed to answer, blinking a few times to keep any lingering moisture from leaving her eyes. ‚ÄúThank you for inviting us.‚Äù

They disembarked without any mishap and with only modestly interrupted fanfare. While the current queen of Naboo was not in attendance, several of her court were, and they were clearly surprised to see that Padm√© had arrived with guests. But years of practice and a very natural courtesy took over as they were formally introduced. An amphibious humanoid called Jar Jar Binks was particularly obsequious in his welcome, but it was such a cheerful, honest display that Leia felt only mildly annoyed and partially charmed.

It was Threepio‚Äôs comment of, ‚ÄúOh dear, you‚Äôre not that clumsy fellow, are you? Please don‚Äôt get stuck in anything this time,‚Äù that cemented her opinion.

‚ÄúI'm not clumsy no more,‚Äù Jar Jar said defensively, and the looks on the faces of everyone else in the room pronounced this to be a complete lie. Leia found herself smiling as she extended her hand to the poor man.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a pleasure to meet you,‚Äù Leia said, and was not surprised when he took her hand in both of his and shook it very vigorously.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a great great pleasure to meet any friend of the senator!‚Äù he exclaimed cheerfully, and Leia had to bite back a correction. She glanced a bit nervously at Senator Amidala, who smiled at the exchange.

‚ÄúThank you, Jar Jar,‚Äù the senator‚Äôs voice had the hint of a laugh in it. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd like to show them inside now, is that alright?‚Äù

The suggestion was met with true enthusiasm and the whole party made their way out of the large hangar lined in yellow fighters to enter the main part of the palace.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll need to report to the queen immediately,‚Äù Senator Amidala was explaining to Shmi, guiding the older woman along. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll stop by the senator‚Äôs suite here in the palace and I‚Äôll leave Dorm√© and Cord√© with you and Leia. They‚Äôll help you get settled.‚Äù

There was the faintest hint of concern as Shmi answered, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre staying here?‚Äù

It was probably covering outright panic, and Leia wished she could claim that was a Force reading and not just intimate knowledge of Shmi Skywalker.

‚ÄúJust for a few days,‚Äù the senator said in a soothing tone. ‚ÄúThen I‚Äôll take you to meet my family. They‚Äôre outside the capital, so I‚Äôll need to finish some work here before I go and see them.‚Äù

Shmi nodded, and Leia noticed her hands twitch a few times, but nothing else.

The rooms they were settled in were gorgeous, with high ceilings and luxurious furnishing done in warm, neutral tones and sprinkled with hints of vibrant color. Each room of the suite looked out over a scenic snapshot of the city and sparkling water ways. The large windows did not open, and Leia assumed that meant they were also made with blaster proof glass, given whose suite this was. It was disappointing, she thought there might be a good breeze outside, but the rooms were comfortable enough to make up for it.

"Feel free to pick any of these," Cord√© said, gesturing to the rooms on the left. "Padm√© will be in the one over there, and either Dorm√© or I will be in the one next to her."
