"It didn't happen," Padm√© threw her headdress onto one of the chairs, not even noticing when it fell to the floor. Eirta√© picked it up without making a comment, but her eyes followed the senator's every move. "We got caught up in the stupid military creation question again and were completely derailed. Somehow everything keeps coming back to that."

Not a surprise, but Leia just said, "I take it you won't need me tomorrow then?"

Face twisting with guilt, Padm√© shook her head. "I can't get them to agree on things they already promised, much less focus on a broader scale of attack. It's a problem that is only getting bigger, and if they would deal with it then it would make these other issues less of a crisis. Better trade routes, more loans through providers who don't have a monopoly on interest rates. But do they listen?"

"No," Leia handed Padm√© a cup and made sure the senator actually drank. "Any support?"

"Shea," Padm√© sighed. "But I can't even get Bail to budge on this. He's caught up reacting to it too. Well, and trying to hold the coalition together."

But wars were won and lost by small actions as much as big ones. "Mon Mothma?"

"No, she's like me. Too new. Relatively speaking. And Uncle Ono is thinking of heading back to Rodia. He's not sure he can keep his seat with things going the direction they are. Not if he also votes against military action."

"His people need better trade options."

"Oh, I'm aware," Padm√© slumped into a seat, rubbing her face with both hands. "We've even talked about it. He likes our ideas, he's just not sure we can get the movement we need."

"Tens of thousands of systems," Leia mused, "With several thousand senators representing them. And we still can't get a single thing done."

She could, objectively, see the appeal of having an executive leader who pushed things along. It was just hard to also come up with a list of the correct limitations to prevent them from pushing only their own agenda.

Although, making sure they weren't a Sith lord would probably help. A lot.

"I just don't understand," Padm√© said, pulling Leia's attention back. "Why doesn't anyone want to get things done?"

It was hard to not just nod at the sentiment, but Leia forced herself to say, ‚ÄúThey do. They just want to get things done that relate to them."

"There's also the issue of money," Eirta√© pointed out. "Or just resources generally. Once the Republic started changing the terms of entry and representation, systems had different concerns for qualifying to be part of the body. And you know how many just opt out, or allow themselves to be pulled into someone else's district."

A numbers game. Leia had been enjoying those first few weeks, sorting through the data and making it make sense. But now she needed the numbers to do her bidding, and that was a much harder task. Because what the numbers represented were people, who were frequently irrational and‚Äî

"What do they want?" she asked, mostly to herself. "What do they want to have? To maintain?"

Leverage, they needed leverage and‚Äî

"Leia?" Padm√© and Eirta√© were both watching her curiously.

"Why do they want an army?" Leia asked. "Really want one? Who is it that wants the military force? They have the Jedi," which didn't factor into her calculations nearly enough, she realized. "Where do they think the soldiers are going to come from? The supplies? The ships? Who do they think is going to be taxed?"

They spent twenty minutes working through that, and lifted Padm√©‚Äôs spirits enough that when she got a request to go and talk to the Trade Federation delegate, she had fire in her eyes again.

When she had left, Leia asked, "Where do the staffers meet to share the best gossip? I've tried the refectory and several of the lounges, but it seems like those are still too public."

Eirta√© blinked. "We didn't show you? Come on, there are a few good options."

"Mixed company?" At Eirta√©'s baffled look, she added, "Mixed delegations. Staff low enough on in the hierarchy they don't mind fraternizing with the enemy a bit."

The really dangerous ones, who sometimes stayed in those positions for years, had the best information and the best sabacc faces. They were Leia's favorites.

"I‚Ä¶don't know. We don't go down there as much now."

Well, they would need to fix that.

Ten days, and Leia's head was already swimming with the feeling of being back on Coruscant for too long. She needed calm, she needed quiet, she needed peace. And she wasn't really sure where she could go to get it.

Something in the air here tasted like Palpatine. She wouldn't have noticed, but she had finally lived in a world without him, and now having him back‚Ä¶

Sometimes it was like the very air she breathed was slick with the oily feel of his corruption.

"How are things going?" Leia asked Shmi, trying to focus on the call instead of her own misery.

"Well enough. Things are moving a bit faster than we anticipated. We've already processed ten ships."

"Ten?" Leia didn't know if she should be impressed or horrified.

"Ruwee and Jobal say this is good. Our system is holding so far. Not flourishing. We're still working out problems with every flight that lands. But we haven't been overwhelmed, and the camps and stations that have been set up aren't generating more problems. The locals currently barely know we're here."

That would change, Leia thought, when people came looking for work and education. Started integrating with the current populace. But if they'd processed another six ships already, that meant the process wasn't just working in Theed, it was working across the planet, and even further out in the system. Which was good. It meant they were off to the right start.

"Do you have any idea how many more you can expect?"

"Not immediately. Ruwee's in conversations with several Outer Rim contacts, but most of their people don't want to settle here. Which is one of our big problems. We have plenty of transplants, but not the best ground to plant them in."

Which meant, "I assume he's contacting other systems."

"Yes. But things have been slow as far as reception."

It was delightful to see the spark of anger in Shmi's eyes. For the first time in her life she had the power to do something, to change other's circumstances. She was made for it. "I'm sorry. I'll talk to Padm√© and see if she has any ideas of people who might be willing to get on board with the test runs. It would be better to see if the process holds up in other systems."

She'd talk to Shea about it, Leia thought. That was where all of this had gotten started anyway.

‚ÄúJust as long as it doesn‚Äôt add to your workload,‚Äù Shmi said sternly. ‚ÄúYou have enough on your plate already.‚Äù

Thinking back to her own years working in the senate, and then to the multiple positions she‚Äôd had to simultaneously fill in the Rebellion, Leia could only shrug. ‚ÄúI have space for this.‚Äù

Shmi took a moment to give Leia the most motherly stare before asking, ‚ÄúHow much sleep are you getting?‚Äù

‚ÄúOn average?‚Äù Leia stalled, scrambling for an answer that wasn‚Äôt a lie. Shmi was too good at spotting those. And also half-truths.

‚ÄúLeia‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúNot enough,‚Äù she confessed, shrugging as nonchalantly as she could. ‚ÄúBut I‚Äôm used to it. I‚Äôll catch up later and‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not how sleep works. And you need your mind sharp for your work.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, Grandmother,‚Äù Leia muttered, freezing as she realized what she had said.

Shmi had frozen too, then relaxed and smiled, something in her expression warming in a way Leia couldn‚Äôt pinpoint. ‚ÄúI love you, Leia.‚Äù

Tears pricked at the corner of Leia‚Äôs eyes and she whispered, ‚ÄúI love you too.‚Äù

And it was true. Shmi was family and friend and companion, brave and gentle and strong. Leia was proud to be a part of this woman‚Äôs legacy. It healed so much hurt that had been haunting her since that lonely night on Endor.

‚ÄúI know you like to work hard. But don‚Äôt forget to take care of yourself.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll do my best,‚Äù Leia promised.

‚ÄúDo better.‚Äù The dryness was offset by real affection, but Leia got the message.

She ended the call with Shmi and leaned back against the couch, glancing around at the empty apartment. Padm√© was at some sort of dinner party tonight, Dorm√© was seeing someone special she thought no one knew about, and the other handmaidens on planet were nominally watching Padm√©. Leia guessed they were more likely flirting and spying.

She needed to get in more on that part of their work. But how to convince them? Showing up uninvited was a definite no.

As happened often now when she didn't have enough to do, Leia found herself in her quarters, digging the misplaced lightsaber out of her bag and turning it over and over. She rarely turned it on. There was something about the hum of it that made her hair stand on end. Something angry and heartbroken.

Sometimes she saw yellow eyes in a red face and felt‚Ä¶ nothing (like the blackness she felt every time she'd met the Emperor's eyes).

Sighing, Leia put the saber back. And plotted how to get Padm√© to let her help with the military creation movement. She'd be good at helping, she knew she would. And if she were indispensable‚Ä¶

When all else failed, repeat what had already worked.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre up early.‚Äù

Finishing the sentence she was reading, Leia used the time to pull herself together before she looked up to greet the Jedi. ‚ÄúMaster Gallia. Not really, just having breakfast here instead of at home. Things are a bit tumultuous this morning.‚Äù

There‚Äôd been an invitation to some sort of political dinner in the coming week or so. And a lively debate about whether or not they should even show up, much less who would be appropriate to bring and what to wear.

‚ÄúSo you came here for peace and quiet,‚Äù there was an almost envious looked on Master Gallia‚Äôs face as she looked around the room.

‚ÄúFor quiet at least,‚Äù Leia founded herself saying before she had thought about it. ‚ÄúPeace is in short supply these days.‚Äù

The Jedi master looked slightly surprised, then shook her head. ‚ÄúI have the privilege of being able to retreat to the Temple at night. I suppose that does give me an advantage.‚Äù

‚ÄúA pity it can‚Äôt be shared,‚Äù Leia mused, hoping it came across more humorous than scathing.

‚ÄúThe grounds are open,‚Äù Master Gallia said with a casualness that had Leia‚Äôs attention where a pointed comment might have slid by. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not the Temple proper, but there are shrines and gardens and peace there. Have you ever visited?‚Äù

Setting her datapad aside, Leia said, ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been just outside, but I‚Äôve never seen the grounds. I keep pretty long hours here.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey open the doors early,‚Äù Master Gallia nodded towards the window in what Leia assumed was the direction of the Temple. ‚ÄúAs soon as the first Jedi are up and moving. You could go now, if you wish.‚Äù

It was still technically another hour before she needed to be here. But she‚Äôd finally gotten into the flow of things and was loath to stop. ‚ÄúMaybe I‚Äôll finish early tonight and head over then.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course. Well, don‚Äôt let me keep you from your work.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you for stopping in,‚Äù Leia knew the words were rushed, but she didn‚Äôt want to leave a bad impression. ‚ÄúIt was good to see you.‚Äù

That earned a warm, ‚ÄúMay the Force be with you, Leia.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou as well,‚Äù managed to slide off her tongue, but Leia found she couldn‚Äôt make herself repeat the sentiment. She felt the pressure of a flood of memories that would come with it, and she couldn‚Äôt handle that this morning.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know you had met Senator Clovis.‚Äù Eirta√©‚Äôs tone was bordering on suspicious and Leia set aside her food to give the handmaiden her full attention. ‚ÄúHe was asking about you.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe ran into each other in the hall the other day. He recognized me as from Naboo and mentioned he and Padm√© had joined the senate at the same time.‚Äù And gotten a little too cozy and close while doing it. Leia had almost allowed herself to be flattered, until she had caught his tone when he had said Padm√©‚Äôs name. They didn‚Äôt look that much alike, dammit. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt think much of it.‚Äù

Cord√© laughed. ‚ÄúDid he ask you about Padm√©? If she‚Äôd mentioned him?‚Äù

‚ÄúNot directly,‚Äù Leia was relieved she‚Äôd read that right. ‚ÄúShould she have? Shea mentioned that they were associates, maybe friends.‚Äù

‚ÄúSenator Sadashassa?‚Äù Cord√© sounded impressed and Eirta√© looked slightly scandalized. But she also seemed jealous when Leia called Padm√© by her name as well. That was an ally that hadn‚Äôt been quite won over yet. ‚ÄúOh right, you had dinner together. How did that go?‚Äù

Not sure if Cord√© was actually distracted, or just unwilling to talk about Clovis, Leia answered, ‚ÄúPretty well. I may have broken civil codes in her presence when Padm√© picked Shmi and I up on Herdessa, but I don‚Äôt think she‚Äôs holding that against me, and I‚Äôm grateful.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs a tricky one,‚Äù Cord√© popped a piece of bread into her mouth, chewing while she thought. ‚ÄúShe does hold grudges when she takes offense, but she‚Äôs unlikely to tell you the reason why she was offended. She‚Äôll just make something up to make you squirm as you try and fix it.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou broke a civil code?‚Äù Eirta√© would get stuck on that.

‚ÄúI left my landing platform before my paperwork had been processed. I went back and got everything put together before we left, but it was kind of silly and I felt stupid about it.‚Äù

Later, when she‚Äôd had time to think about it and realize that she‚Äôd let herself be led around by the Force without thinking about the consequences. Maybe people like Luke or real Jedi could get away with that. Leia definitely hadn‚Äôt.

The answered seemed to mollify Eirta√© though. ‚ÄúI suppose that isn‚Äôt too bad.‚Äù

Her blush told Leia she hadn‚Äôt meant to say that out loud as much as Cord√©‚Äôs snort. ‚ÄúSays the person who parked our speeder at the completely wrong building, much less landing zone, on Alderaan.‚Äù

‚ÄúAll the buildings there are tall and white,‚Äù Eirta√© protested. ‚ÄúHow was I supposed to know which one they were talking about?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou weren‚Äôt given an escort?‚Äù Leia blurted. The surprised looks she got almost rivaled her own feeling.

‚ÄúWe weren‚Äôt there on official business. Padm√© was, but we were just sightseeing. They offered, but it seemed wrong to accept.‚Äù

Leia frowned. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve worked with royalty before. They would hardly offer if they didn‚Äôt want you to accept it.‚Äù

Cord√© sniggered and Eirta√© was definitely blushing. ‚ÄúIt seemed so trivial‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúUntil you parked at the wrong place and our speeder was impounded. Padm√© nearly died laughing when she found out. And you were so embarrassed we actually walked back.‚Äù

‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt claim political exemption,‚Äù Eirta√©‚Äôs hands were dancing around her head. ‚ÄúWe were sightseeing.‚Äù

A thought occurred to Leia. ‚ÄúDid you go to see the hot springs? Near the great theatre?‚Äù

Embarrassment became horror for Eirta√© and Cord√© nearly choked trying not to laugh at her friend. ‚ÄúOh yes. We went to the springs. We had a lovely time there, didn‚Äôt we?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a very traditional spot,‚Äù Leia said primly, knowing her eyes had to be giving away her amusement. ‚ÄúThe buildings are very old, but the open air baths are excessively lovely.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve been?‚Äù Cord√© seemed genuinely curious, but Leia found herself shutting down. Backing away from the truth as much as she could.

‚ÄúOnce. It was‚Ä¶I only had the chance once.‚Äù

She‚Äôd gone with her mother, as a special treat while her father was gone. Leia still wasn‚Äôt sure if he‚Äôd been scandalized that they went, or just jealous they had gone without him.

Several of the baths were designed for deliberate mixing of genders and species, a part of Alderaan‚Äôs historically open and welcoming culture. And places the royal family were unlikely to visit at that point. Since there had been so much galactic conflict and it left the royalty‚Ä¶exposed.

‚ÄúMaybe we should all go together sometime,‚Äù Cord√© suggested, ignoring Leia‚Äôs hesitance. It was hard to tell if she was just bold, or unflappable. ‚ÄúTake Shmi and Padm√© with us.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think‚Äî‚Äú Eirta√© began, just as Leia laughed and said, ‚ÄúOh absolutely yes. It would be so much fun.‚Äù

Although, Leia would have to warn Shmi first. Surprising Padm√© with hot springs would be fine. The Tatooine woman was still adjusting to showers with water. Forget public baths.

Unsettled Spirits

When the numbers started to jumble on the screen in front of her, Leia knew she would have to call it a day. There was just too much data here and she needed to find a more efficient way to sort through it now that she had about ten times as much of it to handle.

Without having Padm√© hire someone else. Leia wasn‚Äôt ready to have the nagging suspicion someone was (even accidentally) outing their plans as a constant worry just yet.

‚ÄúAre you finished for today, Mistress Leia?‚Äù Threepio asked, looking up from his own work. He‚Äôd been asked to come up with a list of more casual events they could invite delegates to for fostering better working relationships.

‚ÄúYes, Threepio. If you want to stay here and finish anything, I‚Äôm sure the senator or Cord√© would be more than happy to bring you home.‚Äù

Standing, he said, ‚ÄúOh no, that‚Äôs quite alright. I have a good list so far and I‚Äôm just working on cutting some of the more expensive or outlandish ideas. Anything that Artoo would approve of has already been cut from the list.‚Äù

Laughing at that particular standard, Leia suddenly stopped. ‚ÄúDo you know where he is right now?‚Äù

‚ÄúI would assume with Senator Amidala. He tends to follow her around during the day when she isn‚Äôt in private meetings.‚Äù

Where he got to when he wasn‚Äôt with the senator was a question Leia should have asked a long time ago. But for now, she commed Padm√© and asked if Artoo was available. He rolled into the office a minute or two later, beeping a query of what Leia wanted.

‚ÄúAre you up for an adventure?‚Äù she asked, hoping he‚Äôd get into enough trouble to keep him entertained, but little enough that she wouldn‚Äôt get called on it.

Artoo gave a strong affirmative.

‚ÄúGood. I was hoping you could compile‚Äî‚Äú A thought flashed. ‚ÄúNo. I need‚Ä¶ Artoo, do you know how to access official reports from the senate database?‚Äù

He asked which ones, but she knew him well enough to know it was more to gauge what how much trouble she would get him into, not lack of ability.

‚ÄúI need the financial and transport records for the Trade Federation, and also the other trade groups that are approved by the senate. I need to compare their official reports to the primary source records and see if the patterns they are officially listing actually match their monetary and resource movement.‚Äù

Artoo whistled something she didn‚Äôt quite get and she looked at Threepio. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs wondering where you got the information you already have, and what you were hoping to compare it to specifically.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve got the public record reports that were submitted by the senate committees, but not their internal committee reports. And I have manifests and records from the systems I‚Äôm most concerned about.‚Äù

Some more beeps were, ‚ÄúWould you like him to consolidate the data and represent it visually for you? He says he can link the visuals to the data tables for quick searching.‚Äù

‚ÄúWould you?‚Äù Leia asked, relieved. ‚ÄúIt would be a huge help.‚Äù

She didn‚Äôt need a translation of the affirmative beeps and whistles, and she thanked both the droids before offering to take them home. Artoo opted to stay and get started on his new project, and after some consideration, Threepio decided to stay with him. ‚ÄúTo make sure he doesn‚Äôt get into trouble. Well, at least not more than he needs to.‚Äù

‚ÄúAlright. Just make sure you let Padm√© know that she needs to bring you both home.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, of course.‚Äù

Checking her chrono, Leia grimaced as she made her way out of the building. It was early. Her sleep was starting to seriously impact her work. She needed to do something about that.

Her immediate plan to return to the apartment and take a nap failed when she got there and could only toss and turn, sleep evasive in spite of her tiredness. Instead of rest she got wandering thoughts and the quiet that led to things she did not want to be thinking about.

Dodging memories of her father, Luke, a ship whose crew quarters sounded very appealing right now, and the impression of fire in her mind if she spent too much time thinking about Artoo or Threepio, Leia‚Äôs thoughts eventually started circling back to the lightsaber hidden in the room.

And how it wasn‚Äôt hers.

And how it was somebody‚Äôs life, and had ended up in a literal trash heap.

Nothing poetic in that at all.

When sleep proved to be far enough away that it wasn‚Äôt worth the effort, Leia threw herself out of bed and stomped over to the lightsaber, pulling it out and turning it over and over in her hands. Flashes of faces she didn‚Äôt know clouded her mind and she almost threw it out the window, sick of the whole mess, before she realized there was something so much easier she could do with it.

So she left a note for whoever got back next and hopped onto the rail at the nearest station, lightsaber tucked under the folds of an over robe she had picked up here on Coruscant.

She dreamed in flashes of color and unintelligible sounds with her eyes open all the way to the Jedi temple.

The crowd outside ebbed and flowed as groups approached and left the structure. Ships of all shapes and sizes seemed to be docking in landing bays around the upper levels, many of them personal sized vessels, others definitely not. Some of the crowd that wandered through the gate was pairs of Jedi, or even occasionally a single Jedi or a small group. But mostly it seemed to be scholars, political attach√©s, or just tourists here for the famed sight of the home of the Order.

‚ÄúYou here to see someone, miss?‚Äù one of the guards asked as she made her way in. She shook her head and he encouraged her to enjoy the grounds and take all the time that she wanted.

Once she had made it inside, past the thick outer walls, the noise dropped off abruptly. Not to silence, but the sounds of Coruscanti traffic were diminished, and the people that moved around out here, many though they were, seemed to have dropped to hushed tones and whispers.

The Jedi were clearly the most prevalent and comfortable people present. Leia wondered what the exact significance was of all the robes they wore and the different colors and styles. Many of the younger ones, looking adolescent as much as she could guess depending on species, seemed to have some sort of braid or chain and short cropped hair where applicable. Younger than that and they usually had some sort of older escort and were dressed in pale colors. And there was a broad mix of ages. Some of the garden paths and groves were usurped by what had to be lessons.

There was an uncanny lack of blasters but an overwhelming number of lightsabers. Leia would have felt more nervous if she hadn‚Äôt known she was carrying one herself. For all the sense of peace that Master Gallia had promised, there was an underlying sense of danger that Leia just couldn‚Äôt shake.

These people were powerful. And they knew it. And they expected to be treated like it.

She visited a few shrines and eavesdropped on what were probably a couple of informal tours, picking up various historical details about the building and its various structures, but not finding anything useful in the information. She found herself looking up to the central tower, where the High Council supposedly met, and wondered if they were in there and if anyone was looking down into the gardens, amused or irritated or just ignoring the mass of people down here.

‚ÄúAre you lost?‚Äù

The question had an unusual hesitance to it, and when Leia looked up she was surprised to see a face that had the slightest hint of being familiar. Human, possibly mid or early thirties, male, shoulder length hair brushed back, neatly trimmed beard, blue eyes‚Ä¶

She knew him. She just couldn‚Äôt place‚Äî

‚ÄúMiss?‚Äù

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù Leia managed a short smile, hesitant. ‚ÄúNo, I‚Äôm fine. I mean, I‚Äôm not looking for anyone in particular. Although,‚Äù she cursed her sleep deprived mind for not linking this past with whatever distant future image. She hadn‚Äôt known that many Jedi. ‚ÄúMaybe you can help me. I‚Äôm‚Ä¶ trying to take care of something.‚Äù

‚ÄúI will certainly do my best,‚Äù his expression was pleasant and unsuspicious, but Leia‚Äôs skin tingled like he was observing her much more closely than his eyes belied. ‚ÄúDo you need to forward a request for something? I can direct you to where we process submissions. I assume, since you‚Äôre here personally, it‚Äôs not senate business.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Leia shook her head, hand reaching into her robe and noticing that prickling feeling focusing on that movement, even as his eyes stayed fixed on hers. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not exactly personal. I just found something, and I‚Äôm not sure what to do with it.‚Äù

She‚Äôd expected surprised when she pulled out the saber, but what she got was another moment of sharp shock, suddenly there and suddenly gone like she had felt from Master Gallia. It lingered maybe a breath longer as those blue eyes widened and blinked twice, three times, a hand coming forward on instinct and almost snatching before the Jedi caught himself and was just as quickly composed.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, but where exactly did you find that?‚Äù

Hating to have to give the information, but knowing it would be so much more suspicious to conceal, she mumbled, ‚ÄúA junk yard outside of Theed. On Naboo.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm aware of where Theed is,‚Äù the Jedi‚Äôs voice trembled slightly, and the hand that had almost snatched the saber flipped over. ‚ÄúMay I see it?‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù came out of her mouth, but Leia was sure she was bleeding reluctance. It wasn‚Äôt hers, no matter if she had found it. She didn‚Äôt need to be armed, even if more than half the people around her were. Even the children. ‚ÄúYou recognize it?‚Äù

There was a somewhat self-recriminating amusement coming from him as he answered, ‚ÄúYes. It was mine. My last as a padawan. I lost it in a duel‚Äî‚Äú He blinked and instead of finishing said, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Jedi Knight Obi-Wan Kenobi. You are?‚Äù

Hoping her shock hadn‚Äôt crashed into him the way his had slammed her, she managed, ‚ÄúLeia.‚Äù And nothing else.

He seemed confused, but didn‚Äôt push. ‚ÄúI hope you‚Äôll forgive me, I was under the impression you were one of the senatorial staff that occasionally visit.‚Äù

‚ÄúI am. That is, I work for Senator Amidala.‚Äù He was too smooth. She was tripping over her own tongue like she was a first year senator again and it rankled. She needed to focus. ‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt consider this official business though.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou said it was personal. I assume you were the one that found this. Did the senator recommend you bring it here?‚Äù

Shaking her head, Leia said, ‚ÄúNo. I just assumed this was the best place to try and return it. Since I was already coming to Coruscant. I didn‚Äôt think‚Äî‚Äú

She had no idea what she had thought anymore. She‚Äôd wanted to keep it. She‚Äôd wanted to chuck it. She wanted to have nothing to do with it and wanted desperately to make it her own.

(She wanted Luke back, to explain to her again what is was and how it worked and why it was important and to tell her it was okay, she could do this‚Ä¶)

Whatever General Keno‚Äîwell, not General now‚ÄîObi-Wan Kenobi was getting off of her must have been confusing him. Instead of trying to explain it she just looked soulfully at him, hoping he would feel the need to direct the conversation.

He did.

‚ÄúThank you for returning this to me,‚Äù he said, clipping it to his belt next to the one he was already carrying. ‚ÄúI would never have thought I would see it again.‚Äù

‚ÄúI would never have thought I would be able to hand it to you personally,‚Äù Leia said. ‚ÄúI had no idea it was yours.‚Äù

Hell, for all she knew it might not be. His emotional reaction could all be a ruse. Or just an easy explanation to quickly get a random citizen to hand over a dangerous weapon.

But Obi-Wan seemed amused at her words. ‚ÄúThere are no coincidences in the Force. I don‚Äôt usually make a habit of coming out here, but felt drawn here today. I can only imagine that it was exactly for this.‚Äù

There was something about how he said it that made Leia suspect he had also been drawn to her, but she didn‚Äôt feel up to asking him if he‚Äôd had any glittery flashes coming from her direction. She wasn‚Äôt even sure if that was how trained Force users saw things like that. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad I could be of service.‚Äù

‚ÄúDid you have any other business you needed to see to? Or anywhere here in the Temple you wished to go?‚Äù

She had a few points of interest she had heard about in her past, but they would all be beyond this public sphere. ‚ÄúNo, I just came to see if I could find someone to hand that off to. And to look around. I‚Äôll be heading out now.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen may I escort you to the gate?‚Äù He didn‚Äôt exactly offer his arm, but the gesture he made to invite her to his side was very polished, and she allowed him because she could acknowledge being impressed. He asked a few polite, inane questions about whether this was her first trip to Coruscant and recommended a few places she should visit including a diner in CocCo Town that sounded slightly seedy and thus very promising.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve known the owner for years,‚Äù Obi-Wan confessed. ‚ÄúLong before he was running the place. He‚Äôs something else.‚Äù

‚ÄúA besalisk?‚Äù Leia checked, and Obi-Wan nodded. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll look forward to meeting him.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt tell him I sent you,‚Äù the Jedi insisted. ‚ÄúHe might start telling stories, and he knew me from my first missions.‚Äù

It was an offer as much as a plea, and Leia wondered if he had surprised himself with it. ‚ÄúIf you promise to tell me all your darkest secrets, I promise I won‚Äôt try and get them from anyone else.‚Äù

And where the hell had that come from? She knew her father had trusted this man at one point, but that shouldn‚Äôt be making an impact on her actions now.

‚ÄúI think you‚Äôre supposed to wait for a second meeting before requesting dark secrets,‚Äù he had stepped back a bit, but they were at the gate, so it didn‚Äôt have to be nervousness. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs part of keeping with appearances, I‚Äôm told.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll try to remember that,‚Äù she promised, feeling on shaky ground again and searching for some way to take back the conversation. He bowed and just as he was turning to go she blurted, ‚ÄúYou should cut your hair short.‚Äù Well, that had certainly gotten his attention. ‚ÄúOr tie it back. If you‚Äôre keeping with appearances.‚Äù

There was only the briefest flash of bafflement before he chose to be amused and waved as she turned to go. She glanced back in time to see him walking away, tugging on a chunk of hair as if he was just noticing the length of it.

Well, not ideal, but still. He probably wouldn‚Äôt forget her.

Hopefully that was a good thing.

She really needed to sleep.

Obi-Wan was observing his reflection in a window, running his hands through his hair when Anakin finally found him. ‚ÄúI thought vanity was against the Jedi Code, master.‚Äù

There was a rueful chuckle before, ‚ÄúIt is. But caring for your body is within Code appropriate behavior, and keeping up appearances is always important. As representatives of the Order.‚Äù

Something in ‚Äúkeeping up appearances‚Äù had humor radiating off of him, and Anakin wasn‚Äôt sure he wanted to know the joke. Also, ‚ÄúWhy do you have two lightsabers? Did you steal someone‚Äôs? For a prank?‚Äù

‚ÄúI am a Jedi Knight, my very young apprentice,‚Äù there was that finger, pointing and shaking in Anakin‚Äôs face. He‚Äôd hoped that wouldn‚Äôt become a habit and was greatly disappointed. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt do pranks.‚Äù

‚ÄúTell that to Master Yoda,‚Äù Anakin grumbled, thinking of any number of misleading comments the grandmaster had made over the last ten years. The old troll loved subtle wordplays and getting people into trouble.

‚ÄúFair,‚Äù Obi-Wan immediately conceded. ‚ÄúBut no, it‚Äôs not a prank. It‚Äôs my old lightsaber. The one I lost when I was fighting...Maul.‚Äù It was a small trip, but the hesitation was there. ‚ÄúOne of the Naboo returned it to me.‚Äù

‚ÄúPadm√© was here?‚Äù Anakin felt something sparkle inside him, looked out the window even knowing that if Obi-Wan were here, she would already have to be‚Äî

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù his master was far too amused and Anakin glared. ‚ÄúNot the senator. One of her aides. Leia, she said her name was.‚Äù

None of Padm√©‚Äôs friends had been more important than Padm√© and Anakin couldn‚Äôt have named any of them, so it was no surprise that he didn‚Äôt recognize this one. ‚ÄúDid they say she was going to come by?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù the diminishing patience tone wasn‚Äôt much better than the amusement. ‚ÄúLeia was just returning the saber. She barely mentioned the senator at all.‚Äù

But at least Padm√© was alright. If she hadn‚Äôt been mentioned, that meant she couldn‚Äôt be in danger because no one was asking for help. That was good. ‚ÄúWhat are you going to do with it?‚Äù

‚ÄúExtract the crystal, probably, and see if I can use it. The hilt design doesn‚Äôt really suit me anymore.‚Äù

Knowing what he did about his master‚Äôs saber habits, Anakin wasn‚Äôt convinced about that. But he also knew that duel with Maul had changed the rules for Obi-Wan about what was good, what was necessary, and what was to be forgotten. ‚ÄúMaybe we should try it out, just to see.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you have course work to finish?‚Äù Obi-Wan asked.

‚ÄúNo. What do you think I‚Äôve been doing all evening?‚Äù

‚ÄúI had assumed you went to go see the new ship that came in today and volunteer to help with the test run.‚Äù

Well yes, but that hadn‚Äôt taken all evening. There was a limit to how much Anakin was willing to beg, and they never told him yes unless it was a star fighter. As if it was safer if he was in one of those. ‚ÄúYou underestimate me, master. It‚Äôs very disheartening.‚Äù

‚ÄúShow me what you‚Äôve done,‚Äù Obi-Wan seemed okay with being teased now. ‚ÄúAnd then if we have time, maybe I‚Äôll let you help me test my old saber.‚Äù

Tactical Governance

Chapter Notes

I... grossly underestimated the reactions people would have to Leia and Obi-Wan's meeting last chapter. Which is kind of silly on my part.

As a more general note, I've been updating the tags these last few chapters to reflect the broader cast of characters that is actively involved in the plot and will probably update again as more relevant changes crop up. You have been warned.

‚ÄúSo where did you run off to last night?‚Äù

Leia had to give Padm√© props, she knew when it was pointless to be subtle. ‚ÄúThe Jedi Temple. Master Gallia suggested that I visit it sometime, and I‚Äôd been meaning to go. I had time yesterday.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou got back late.‚Äù

That was true. Instead of coming straight back, Leia had wandered for a while, pondering the existence of Obi-Wan Kenobi, trying to remember how her father had described him to her verses how her brother had talked about the Jedi as a ghost.

They‚Äôd been painful recollections, constantly tripping over grief from Alderaan and her brother and everyone else she was now missing. ‚ÄúI was thinking about things. Hoping the fresh air would help me clear my head.‚Äù

Fresh being a very relative term. Nothing on Coruscant really qualified as fresh air. Although the Temple grounds had been cleaner than most places she was familiar with.

‚ÄúDid it work?‚Äù There was something measured in that question, and Leia wondered what Padm√© meant by it. A glance at the handmaidens at the table wasn‚Äôt enlightening.

‚ÄúFor a given value of clarity, yes,‚Äù Leia admitted. She‚Äôd reconciled herself to be at ground level with Obi-Wan, too unsure of his motivations or insights to know how exactly he would be useful to her. Actually, now that she thought about it, ‚ÄúDo you know Jedi Knight Obi-Wan Kenobi very well?‚Äù

That caught the table by surprise. Eirta√© was frowning, Dorm√© looked puzzled, and Cord√© was smiling in a way that Leia was not sure she liked. But Padm√© simply answered, ‚ÄúNot especially well. I knew his master, Qui-Gon Jinn, for a little while during the siege of Naboo. Shmi might remember him. He took charge on Tatooine of getting us ship parts.‚Äù The way her mouth moved told Leia her friend had not been happy about that in some way. ‚ÄúObi-Wan was training with him at the time, but I didn‚Äôt spend much time around him. I know he‚Äôs a good Jedi though. He fought the assassin the Trade Federation sent after me who was trained with a lightsaber. His master didn‚Äôt survive the fight,‚Äù she added softly.

Something clenched in Leia‚Äôs gut as she recalled the images, visions, she‚Äôd experienced as she‚Äôd held that lightsaber. ‚ÄúThey sent a Sith after you?‚Äù

‚ÄúA what?‚Äù

Leia froze. ‚ÄúA dark side Force user. A Sith. The opposite of a Jedi,‚Äù she added seeing some confused looks.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt think there were any more Sith,‚Äù Padm√© said after a moment. ‚ÄúI thought they had all been killed a long time ago.‚Äù

Never assume that evil is gone, her father had always told her. It has an uncanny tendency to always find a way back, especially in prosperous moments, when it has the most to feed on. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an ideology,‚Äù Leia said instead, shrugging. ‚ÄúAnd training. They may have been dead for a long time, but that doesn‚Äôt mean someone couldn‚Äôt bring them back.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù Dorm√© twisted her napkin in her hands. ‚ÄúDo you think they‚Äôll come back now then? Since the Jedi already killed them again?‚Äù

A master and an apprentice, Leia thought bleakly. And cursed the Jedi. Keeping people in ignorance was not a good way to protect them.

Specific time traveling exceptions aside, of course (she could almost hear Luke and Han laughing at her).

‚ÄúYou‚Äôd have to ask the Jedi,‚Äù she decided on. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not really an expert.‚Äù

Cord√© caught that one as a lie, Leia thought as she took another bite of food. And Padm√© might have noticed, because she asked, ‚ÄúHow did you meet Obi-Wan?‚Äù

‚ÄúAt the temple. He was wandering the grounds.‚Äù

After a moment of staring, Padm√© said, ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs training Anakin.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh?‚Äù Leia knew she hadn‚Äôt gotten the tone right on that one. She should have been more surprised. Shmi had no idea who Anakin‚Äôs master was.

‚ÄúSince Master Jinn couldn‚Äôt,‚Äù the senator was ignoring her food, and Leia knew she‚Äôd be blamed for that. ‚ÄúHe took Anakin as his padawan on Naboo.‚Äù

Scrambling for a clever dodge, Leia tried, ‚ÄúDoes Shmi know that?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚ÄîI don‚Äôt think I mentioned it. Not specifically.‚Äù Well, flustered was better than on the hunt.

‚ÄúPadm√©,‚Äù Eirta√© interrupted, ‚Äúyou need to finish. We have a meeting this morning. The queen is calling.‚Äù

There was some deliberation, but Leia decided to stay. There was going to be an official update on the refugee situation, and while she trusted Shmi‚Äôs observations it was just as important to know what the higher ups were saying. If they were getting the same information.

Leia also used the time to try and recalibrate after the conversation this morning.

If she kept doing odd things, it would only get harder and harder to explain why.

The council update itself was illuminating. Governor Bibble seemed fine with the policy changes as they hadn‚Äôt damaged his image in Theed. Leia made a note to keep an eye on him to see if his support was too fair weather. The other members seemed mostly onboard, with the exception of the head of the cultural preservation committee. No surprises there.

The queen herself seemed delighted, and Leia almost wondered if it was as much finally having something significant to put to her own name as it was the success of the project. But Queen Jamillia had always struck Leia as also having a kind heart, and the queen went on enough about the children that Leia thought she also had personal investment in the project‚Äôs success.

‚ÄúDo you need anything from us to keep things moving smoothly?‚Äù Padm√© asked once the details had been reviewed.

‚ÄúMore refugees?‚Äù Governor Bibble suggested. ‚ÄúWe should probably test this to its breaking point if we can.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe not that far,‚Äù the queen corrected. ‚ÄúBut yes, we need more people to help. And more places to send them, if possible. The gungans have volunteered to give temporary housing to more aquatic species, but they aren‚Äôt in a position to take them on personally. We‚Äôll need another planet, possibly several.‚Äù

That was doable, but Leia didn‚Äôt say anything as Padm√© hedged instead of making promises. Her mind drifted to Senator Darsana, but Leia immediately rejected the thought. The anselmi had enough territory trouble without introducing another species to the mix.

Although, if they could pick a fully aquatic one‚Ä¶ It would be something to occupy the nautolans. She would have to think about it.

‚ÄúThat wasn‚Äôt so bad,‚Äù Dorm√© stretched carefully, making sure not to hit Leia. ‚ÄúDo you think it will continue to work?‚Äù

Leia looked at Padm√©. ‚ÄúI think we need to talk to Senator Sadashassa. Even if she‚Äôs not ready to implement anything we have, letting her know how quickly this is moving is very important.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to sound like we‚Äôre bragging,‚Äù Padm√© hesitated. ‚ÄúShea‚Äôs been at this a lot longer than I have, especially locally.‚Äù

‚ÄúAsk Threepio to coach you,‚Äù Leia suggested. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs good at catching major cultural gaffes at least.‚Äù

Nodding as she stood Padm√© said, ‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt need him this morning‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs all yours.‚Äù

The conference room was empty when Leia got there. She set up, knowing that the meeting had probably been cancelled and Padm√© had just been too busy to mention it. Her guess was confirmed when one of the office‚Äôs aides, not one of Padm√©‚Äôs personal ones, ran into the room and apologized for not catching her in time.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs no trouble,‚Äù Leia said, already packing her things. ‚ÄúI figured something had come up.‚Äù

‚ÄúFloor vote tomorrow,‚Äù the boy, Rashi she thought, managed between breaths. ‚ÄúSomething happened and they‚Äôre pushing to make a committee for the military stuff.‚Äù

Frowning (hadn‚Äôt they been doing that already), Leia asked, ‚ÄúA different committee?‚Äù

Rashi just shrugged as he followed her out. ‚ÄúDunno. I only caught a bit of it. The senator‚Äôs upset though. They‚Äôd been courting people thinking they had more time than this.‚Äù

Panic was a close enough description of the feeling dancing in the office when Leia entered it. Padm√© was giving instructions on things she wanted people to work on while she was busy with the rest of the coalition. Each of the handmaidens had a world or two to approach, gauging interest. Leia hoped there would be a lot more people on that list. She didn‚Äôt like how it looked from here.

‚ÄúDo you need me to do anything?‚Äù she asked, stepping further into the room.

Padm√© shook her head, ‚ÄúNot unless you know people.‚Äù

‚ÄúMostly only the Loyalist Committee,‚Äù Leia had to admit. ‚ÄúDo you know if anyone else needs help though? Has anyone talked to the Jedi about this?‚Äù

It slid off her tongue without thinking and everyone who heard her went quiet. It was Padm√© that answered, ‚ÄúThe High Council will meet with the Chancellor to deal with the logistics of things that involve them. But they stay out of the details of Senate business.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhen they‚Äôre the enforcement?‚Äù that sounded wrong, but she shouldn‚Äôt be surprised. ‚ÄúCan they at least speak to their friends? Not persuade but test the waters? Gather information?‚Äù

‚ÄúThey really don‚Äôt like implying they‚Äôre favoring any particular delegates,‚Äù Cord√© was shaking her head. ‚ÄúAs though inaction isn‚Äôt just as bad in most cases.‚Äù

Yes, well, never ask a Jedi to solve a problem before they‚Äôd tried to meditate about it. Luke had gotten more and more frustrating on that point as things had gone on.

Although he had been nervous, always wanted to get things right (she‚Äôd had no idea how it worked, wanted nothing to do with it, if she‚Äôd just been there, supported him‚Ä¶), and her brother had been nothing if not incredibly responsible for things he had nothing to do with.

‚ÄúI can at least wander the halls,‚Äù Leia offered. ‚ÄúTake Artoo and Threepio. Gather information. Nothing helps more than a lot of gossip at times like this.‚Äù

And the droids wouldn‚Äôt miss anything important, or forget it. They wouldn‚Äôt even have to be advised beyond follow and listen. They were smart enough for this.

Twelve hours later, Leia was on clean up duty, making sure that the senators that were still in the building had eaten sometime that evening and were getting rides home if they weren‚Äôt flying themselves.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs no fun sleeping on a desk,‚Äù Leia told Shea, ‚Äúno matter how good it sounds.‚Äù

The Herdessan chuckled as she shoved herself away from her work. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not ready for this,‚Äù she whispered, glancing around at the few other members still in the room. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been trying to put it off‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúCivil war conflict,‚Äù Leia was just as quiet in return. ‚ÄúNo one‚Äôs ever ready for that. For what it really means.‚Äù

That there were people around you, neighbors and lovers and friends, that you couldn‚Äôt believe in, couldn‚Äôt trust. That you might be smiling today and outright enemies tomorrow. And the people you might need to rely on, who might agree with you in principle, were people you would almost rather die than work with.

To say nothing of the scale of the conflict. The Rebellion had traveled the length and breadth of the galaxy, but their problem had been that, so often, there was enough of a semblance of peace. And no one wanted to release that.

‚ÄúHas anyone had any successful contact with the Separatists?‚Äù she asked, watching Shea‚Äôs reaction.

It was very muted. ‚ÄúNot officially, no. Almost all of us know someone, personally, that felt they had to secede on a matter of principle or honor. A few because they would have lost the support of their planet. Most of us that are left that want to negotiate are suffering from similar conflicts, but have an older system in place that makes us harder to supplant, even if our constituents turn against us.‚Äù

Naboo appointed people to the post through the queen, it didn‚Äôt hold a general election. Alderaan had an election, but it was based on delegates that were preselected by the council, which was how Leia had even been considered. To say nothing of other systems where the local government wasn‚Äôt elected, and they appointed their representatives.

What a mess.

‚ÄúDo you know if Jar-Jar Binks is coming?‚Äù she asked Shea, not really expecting her to know. They‚Äôd left the gungan to help with the refugee settlement (and it had been almost shocking to realize that he was Junior Representative), but he would probably have been a great help in a moment like this. No one could accuse him of being anything less than sincere.

‚ÄúPadm√© hasn‚Äôt mentioned it to me, but that isn‚Äôt unusual. She plays things pretty close to the vest.‚Äù Shea quirked a brow, ‚ÄúAnother thing you two have in common.‚Äù

‚ÄúPolitics are politics,‚Äù Leia suggested, giving the senator a knowing look. ‚ÄúYou play things pretty close with me.‚Äù

‚ÄúLess than you might think,‚Äù Shea was just smiling now, and there was something surprisingly affectionate in it. ‚ÄúWhich probably means you‚Äôre right and I should head home to bed. All our people we need to lock in have already gone home. I‚Äôll be of more use in the morning if I don‚Äôt keep wasting away like this.‚Äù

Offering a hand that the senator accepted, Leia kept steady and pulled Shea to her feet. ‚ÄúTake care of yourself,‚Äù Leia said. ‚ÄúHowever this ends, it‚Äôll be a long fight ahead.‚Äù

Tapping Leia on the nose, Shea actually giggled. ‚ÄúPretty sure I should be the one telling you that.‚Äù

Leia hoped she hadn‚Äôt actually blushed. She wasn‚Äôt that bad.

It was surprising how similar and different the senate floor was in this time.

Leia looked over the hover pods, the round chamber, the dais in the middle that rose and fell at different times when the Emp- Chancellor used it, the sporadic and thus dramatic lighting.¬† The echoes of the chamber, carrying the muted tones of even the lowest whisper.

In other ways, it was completely different.

There was a sense of purpose in the room now that Leia might not have noticed had she not been in the same environment when it was not present. Representatives visited each other in different pods, conducting last minute business before the floor opened. That never happened in the world she remembered. Business had always been conducted in fine restaurants or exclusive clubs, maybe in the offices (or even chambers) of the Emperor‚Äôs closest associates. The senate floor had just been the stage from which the Emperor had announced his edicts and the desires of his sycophants that he was willing to allow for a time.

There were also more representatives. Each pod was actually filled, and most spots had more representatives in them than Leia was used to.

It was a little overwhelming.

‚ÄúThe first time is the hardest,‚Äù Dorm√© whispered into Leia‚Äôs ear. She was smiling reassuringly and Leia smiled back, letting her ruefulness at getting caught staring carry a slightly false message. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt worry, you‚Äôll adjust.‚Äù

‚ÄúI plan to,‚Äù Leia whispered back, turning to look out over the room again. This time her gaze was more deliberate, slowly moving across the room and testing her knowledge of the people she saw.

Orn Free Ta was present, which made her skin crawl slightly. Then there were dozens of others that fell under her gaze but brought no sense of recognition. There were a series of nemoidians, which also made Leia twitch, more because of the stories from Padm√© than her own distant history. There was Mon Mothma in her pod with a number of other delegates, probably trying to organize how this morning‚Äôs vote was going to go, reassuring them in that gentle put steadfastly firm way she had.

Bail Organa.

Even expecting him, Leia felt a strong tightening in her chest as her eyes landed on him. He was smiling, laughing with some of his associates and shaking hands confidently.

Also securing votes. Her father had always turned up his indefatigable charisma when he was working the hardest to get what he wanted.

There were others that Leia recognized, but most were unfamiliar to her. The variety of species that were less humanoid impressed her. And horrified her. Because their lack of being present in her memories had no good implications about how they had been made to disappear. And in a relatively short time.

Thousands of systems, removed from the circle of power that had once been the Republic.

How had they ever thought that the New Republic would work itself out?

‚ÄúPadm√©,‚Äù Dorm√© greeted as the senator arrived, smiling confidently. ‚ÄúDid you make your rounds?‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course. We should have everything in place for stopping more aggressive action.‚Äù

Leia‚Äôs eyes drifted towards the neimoidians, and then back across the room to the Banking Clan representatives. ‚ÄúDid we secure much of the Outer Rim votes?‚Äù

Dorm√© frowned and Padm√©‚Äôs brows drew together a little. ‚ÄúI believe we had a senator working on them, but it wasn‚Äôt Bail or me. I think we‚Äôll be alright. They‚Äôre usually pretty reliable. A prolonged conflict doesn‚Äôt work for them.‚Äù

‚ÄúUnless it creates a standing army that can be repurposed to fight pirates,‚Äù Leia suggested quietly, with growing unease. With Count Dooku‚Äôs success in assembling the Separatist congress, they had a slimmer margin for error than Padm√© probably believed. And somehow Leia had failed to properly convey that.

Fortunately, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll have some time to make opening remarks,‚Äù Padm√© said confidently, catching Bail‚Äôs eye from across the floor and tapping her wrist. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll give Bail warning about what we might expect.‚Äù

That brought relief. The smallest bit.

Now was the tricky part. Making herself stand back and just watch.

It was awful.

Not that she'd had many opportunities to take the floor during her short time as senator. Emperor Palpatine had had little time to offer to anyone not himself, or singing his praises. She'd spoken the most in committees, and that in direct proportion to how much the committee had mattered. The more it had mattered, the less safe to have said.

Now, there was an open debate on the floor and Leia had to bite her tongue and squeeze her hands behind her back to remind herself to stay behind, to say nothing, don't interrupt.

This wasn't her fight. She shouldn't have come.

It was like watching Luke flying, she thought distantly. She knew what he was doing, saw the beauty of it, could even imagine what it felt like, and how his trust in the Force just made everything right. But she wouldn't do it herself. It was his battlefield up in the sky. Her place was‚Ä¶ her place was down below. Planning. Watching. Being ready when the ships started to go down.

The first big hit was from the neimoidians, irritatingly enough. "Wouldn't you agree, Senator Amidala, that a standing Republic army would be of great benefit to a planet like yours. You have had some difficulty in the past, have you not, with keeping your people safe?"

It was a low blow, and did earn a rushed murmur, but it was a risky one, and one that Padm√©, though clearly angry, was ready for.

"I don't understand why the Trade Federation is so constantly insistent that they personally need access to an army," Padm√© shot back. "Naboo has no need of military forces if the members of this Republic are willing to acknowledge its sovereignty and treat it with equitable respect. We have never," she added, "been under assault by any forces from outside the Republic."

It was a good sting, but led to several minutes of vicious chaos. And did not change the point made by Malastare, "Yes, but even if Naboo has not been attacked yet, Count Dooku is building a coalition of systems that stand in opposition to the Republic. Surely we must consider how this changes the circumstances."

"We have plenty of open lines for negotiation," Mon Mothma interjected, responding to some signal that Bail had sent. "Many representatives of these systems have been our close friends. Have served in this Senate. If they have objections to our governance, we have an obligation to hear them, and allow them the representation they were granted as members of the Republic."

"But they're not anymore!" someone shouted, and Leia had to agree with them. Treaties had been signed in some cases. Having a voice in the senate for some of these systems would mean renegotiating entrance to the Republic.

And that, Leia knew from personal experience, would be a mess.

She‚Äôd tried so hard, she thought, hands throbbing from how tightly she held them. Why was it never enough?

(Luke had always managed. Always. Always, always, always. Except‚Ä¶)

It hurt.

But she swallowed the grief and pain and failure and stepped forward slightly, reminding Padm√© of her presence. That the senator wasn‚Äôt alone.

She could feel the comfort and Padm√©‚Äôs confidence as she noticed Leia and knew it gave them both hope.

It still felt like a failure when a committee was voted in to investigate what resources the Republic had available to create a standing army.

Silent at Your Grave

‚ÄúYour friend is charming and lovely.‚Äù

Leia ignored the words that she shouldn‚Äôt have been listening for, smiling at Senator Onaconda and nodding at what he was saying.

‚ÄúAnd what would your wife think of that?‚Äù Padm√© whispered back to her friend, and Leia wished she had the self-control to tap out and ignore the conversation.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôd agree with me. Why haven‚Äôt you introduced us?‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs been overwhelmed, Bail. Give her some time.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe seems fine now.‚Äù

Leia tried to reengage with her conversation partner, to ignore the subtle truth that underlay what Padm√© had just said.

She‚Äôd noticed. She‚Äôd noticed that Bail Organa made Leia uncomfortable. Padm√© was going to try and control the first meeting with him. Maybe even give Leia warning, a chance to back out.

She had been doing that, Leia realized with a lurch. And she‚Äôd had been taking Padm√© up on it. Leia had met everyone else from the coalition, except Bail. Because Padm√© had always offered her a discreet escape.

This was going to be a mess.

‚Äú‚Äîwon‚Äôt press the issue,‚Äù she caught Bail saying, more softly now. ‚ÄúI just wonder what I, or my people have done to offend her.‚Äù

There was an appreciable pause before Leia caught Padm√©‚Äôs whispered, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs that simple.‚Äù

And wondered what impression exactly she had given, to make Padm√© as uncertain as that.

When she was finished with Senator Onaconda, Leia considered going over to meet Senator Organa, but eventually decided against it. She wasn‚Äôt sure she wouldn‚Äôt start crying all over him, and that would be easier to deal with not in a room full of people she needed to work with.

And also because Senator Sadashassa came over, offering Leia a drink and whispered warning, ‚ÄúThe Chancellor wants to meet you.‚Äù

Yes, one emotional nightmare of a meeting was enough for today.

‚ÄúYou must be our new consultant,‚Äù the mild tone sent ice down her spine as it always did, somehow worse coming from a face that was younger and more vibrant than the one in her memory. Leia swallowed bile, twitched her lips into a nervous smile, and found the floor with her eyes as often as possible. For now, shy was the best she could manage.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm working on behalf of Naboo, yes,‚Äù she murmured, playing with her glass, glancing up through her lashes. ‚ÄúSenator Amidala was good enough hire me.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd you were good enough to be hired by her,‚Äù seeing him smile so much was unnerving. And so was the lack of‚Ä¶ anything around him. There was a mild pleasantness, but it didn‚Äôt seem to be coming from him. More like a cloak he was wearing.

Leia wondered what she felt like to him and hoped that whatever training she had been doing wasn‚Äôt enough to make her more noticeable than her first days in the senate.

She‚Äôd need to consult a Jedi about that wouldn‚Äôt she, dammit.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve been very grateful for the opportunity. Although I wish I were doing more to help.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, this is a dreadful business,‚Äù every movement, every sigh was so exaggerated. Leia was exhausted just watching him. ‚ÄúOne does not want civil conflict in the galaxy. I have to adhere to the will of the senate, of course, but it will strangle negotiations if the Separatists find out about this.‚Äù

Surely he wasn‚Äôt planning on keeping it from them? That wasn‚Äôt remotely possible. The results of floor votes were public. ‚ÄúWhat was the vote listed as on the official register?‚Äù

‚ÄúA vote on a committee to investigate our aid resources,‚Äù he answered promptly, obviously pleased with himself.

Leia had to bite her tongue to not point out that if the vote had failed, that would have been bad for the senate, in the Republic if not out of it. But then, that was exactly what he wanted, wasn‚Äôt it? She‚Äôd need to make sure Padm√© knew about that. And Senator Organa. And probably Shea too. They would understand, and have influence in the future.

‚ÄúYou have a plan for everything, Chancellor,‚Äù she managed after a moment. She hoped he took her silence for awe.

There was the sound of footsteps, the swish of fabric, and a hand tucked itself through her elbow. ‚ÄúAre you saying hello to our newest member?‚Äù Padm√©‚Äôs voice held fondness, but there was something tremulous and aching in her that Leia tried to avoid noticing. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs been working wonders for us.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo I‚Äôve been told. I haven‚Äôt been able to see any of her reports yet, however. Are they still in the works, or do I need to scold my secretary again?‚Äù

‚ÄúStill in the works,‚Äù Leia said before Padm√© could answer. ‚ÄúI had some preliminary ones that were done on a very small scale, but I haven‚Äôt presented my new findings to any committees yet.‚Äù

She‚Äôd surprised him. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre presenting to the committee? Well, well. Senator, it looks like you‚Äôve finally taken my advice and claimed a prot√©g√©. How marvelous. Such a pity you couldn‚Äôt find anyone in the youth legislative program.‚Äù

Something wrenched in Padm√© then, and Leia wondered what that was about. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve done my best to mentor all of the people that I‚Äôve worked with,‚Äù the senator said, her fingers a little tighter on Leia‚Äôs arm. ‚ÄúOf course, I‚Äôm still also being mentored myself. Senator Organa has been a tremendous help in teaching me how to navigate the senate and still hold to my principles.‚Äù

That was an accusation, and while Palpatine might look like it had stung him, Leia was pretty sure it rolled right off him. Or hit his pride, rather than his conscience.

Leia was fiercely proud of her father just then.

‚ÄúWell, I hope that you and he can do better finding votes for us going forward. Our efforts at negotiation will be for nothing if we‚Äôre overtaken by the bureaucrats.‚Äù

Padm√©‚Äôs answering smile was thin. Thankfully, someone came and caught the Chancellor‚Äôs attention and he drifted away to condole with another member of the Loyalist Committee.

‚ÄúThat wasn‚Äôt very kind,‚Äù Leia remarked, taking the smallest sip of the drink Shea had brought her. A very mild wine. Shea was a good friend.

Her lips managed a smile, but Padm√©‚Äôs voice was tight as she answered, ‚ÄúWe had a bit of a falling out when I let Bail look after me when I got started here. At first I just didn‚Äôt want to waste the Chancellor‚Äôs time. I didn‚Äôt have a claim on him, in spite of our history. And I didn‚Äôt want to start any talk, or make it look like he was playing favorites. But‚Ä¶‚Äù she spun her glass in her hands, ‚Äúhe just doesn‚Äôt do what he says he should.‚Äù

There was an impulse to offer comfort. To make inane statements about how difficult politics was, how as Chancellor he had to balance so many interests, how it wasn‚Äôt anyone‚Äôs fault‚Ä¶

And then Leia remembered who he was, and what he was doing here, and it took all her strength not to scream at him from across the room. To shout his crimes to the sky and reveal him for the fraud he was.

She had no proof and would only make things worse.

But the temptation was strong.

Instead she said, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad you found someone who could be a trustworthy mentor. Senator Organa makes sure everything he does is in line with his principles. And while I know you‚Äôre naturally inclined to be that way as well, it‚Äôs always nice to have support. And someone to show you the ropes.‚Äù

There were so many questions in Padm√©‚Äôs eyes when Leia stopped speaking, but they would have to wait. Even if her friend had voiced them, Leia would have never answered them here.

It was another three days before Leia worked up the courage to have Padm√© introduce her to Senator Organa. It took a while to find the right excuse, but eventually she managed, ‚ÄúWould you mind formally introducing me to Bail Organa? Threepio says Alderaanian tradition respects the commendation of mentors or teachers.‚Äù

True in that Threepio had probably said that at some point in her life. Not this Threepio, here and now, but one of them.

There‚Äôd only been the slightest hesitation from Padm√© before she had agreed and Leia took it as a good sign, mostly from desperation.

She could barely breath when she was led into the office.

Nothing was different from her memory. The decorations were sparse, a few hints to his homeland‚Äôs culture. But this was his place of work to reach out to the galaxy, and he‚Äôd carefully curated it to be as unimposing as possible. The scent of his favorite tea was a lingering hint in the air and Leia‚Äôs knees almost buckled as she realized that she had forgotten it.

His hair was darker, his face less lined. But she could remember everything about him so clearly in that moment. In a few years‚Äô time, he might have been her father, the one in all the happy memories of her childhood.

Hating her weakness (in all fairness to herself, she would have never really been ready for this), Leia found her eyes automatically drifting down, her hands seizing as she forced them not to clench into fists. Her eyes burned, but she refused to shed tears.

One second, three, four. Leia made sure her breathing was under control and her face was at least passive as she finally looked up, catching the tail end of Padm√©‚Äôs greeting. ‚Äú‚Äîsince we had some time. If it‚Äôs no trouble.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot at all,‚Äù Senator Organa (he had to be Senator Organa, not Papa, she couldn‚Äôt let him be Papa) smiled as he turned to her, and it only faltered a little. Leia forced her face to relax, her lips to make a pleasant gesture. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve heard quite a bit about you, and I‚Äôve been anxious to meet you.‚Äù

She caught the hint of suspicion on him and was hurt by it until she realized what it was. Concern, for Padm√©. Leia was new, and a stranger, and Padm√© was his friend.

He wouldn‚Äôt let anything happen to her.

It should probably have worried Leia more that his suspicion made her relax, but there was just something about it. Something so calm and soothing to see him acting in the defense of another. And it gave her a good idea of where she stood. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry to have kept you waiting. Though I understand you‚Äôve been quite busy these past weeks.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe have,‚Äù he agreed, offering his hand to her, and she was very proud that she managed to shake it and pull back before she started trembling (there would be no escape if she threw herself into his arms and started weeping). ‚ÄúAnd we‚Äôll be busy for a while, yet I‚Äôm sure. Probably better that you see me now, before we‚Äôre really in for it.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure you‚Äôll be fine,‚Äù it was hard to make the words sound right, they felt so inadequate. And she had to keep smiling even though (I‚Äôve seen you weeping, she thought, horror creeping over her. I know your birthday and your anniversary and how you like to spend time with your wife, and what you sound like when you yell at your daughter because she‚Äôs terrified you, and I‚Äôve watched you bend and bow under the darkest pressure and never yield, and I watched you die because I couldn‚Äôt save you, I‚Äôve felt you leave the universe.) she didn‚Äôt feel like smiling at all. ‚ÄúI doubt you‚Äôve ever been at a loss yet.‚Äù

That twitch of his lips was an aborted smile over a personal secret. Probably something to do with her mo‚Äî with Queen Breha, Leia thought, if the shift of his eyes and the hint of a blush was any clue. ‚ÄúNot often. And I try not to repeat my mistakes.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre hard enough to swallow the first time?‚Äù Leia found herself asking, hoping for reassurance and realizing he had no idea that was what she was looking for.

And yet, ‚ÄúPain is never easy,‚Äù he said, and she could feel him looking at her, trying to see something he knew he was just missing. ‚ÄúI think we all try not to repeat it. But if we can‚Äôt avoid it‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúThen we carry on,‚Äù she finished, feeling the start of her own blush as she realized what she had done, reciting his words from memory.

His look was pensive and mild, but she knew she‚Äôd really startled him. ‚ÄúYes. We carry on. For those who continue to need us.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo whatever is necessary. And don‚Äôt look back.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe do.‚Äù

Leia managed not to shudder, to end the conversation quickly and politely and without collapsing into complete and utter panic.

And then she left Padm√© and left the building and didn‚Äôt stop moving until she had found herself once again at the Jedi Temple, surging through the gardens to someplace quiet where she curled up in on herself from every possible angle and wept and wept and wept.

The Negotiator

Jedi weren‚Äôt a rare sight in the Executive Building, but Leia hadn‚Äôt been expecting this one. ‚ÄúMaster Kenobi!‚Äù

He turned in surprise, and she almost smiled as she watched his hand move as though he would run it through his hair, then stop midway. It was even more delightful when he grimaced as he realized she had noticed. ‚ÄúMiss‚Ä¶ Leia. How are you doing?‚Äù

Dreadful. She‚Äôd been trying to help with the actions against the Military Creation Act while also reviewing the data Artoo had compiled for her. And, since she was also doing her level best to avoid all of her feelings, she‚Äôd been running on progressively less sleep.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve been better. The Confederacy of Independent Systems is giving us a lot to think about and we‚Äôve been having trouble arranging some of the negotiations.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo I‚Äôve heard,‚Äù Obi-Wan fell into step beside her, indicating she should lead the way. ‚ÄúThe Jedi are doing what they can, but there are limits to the kinds of conflicts that we can reconcile. It‚Äôs only reasonable that those who feel neglected would band together to voice their complaints.‚Äù

She gave him a long look. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm surprised to hear you say that.‚Äù

He laughed. ‚ÄúBecause Jedi are always wise and mysterious?‚Äù

‚ÄúI was thinking more that in the middle of a bunch of senators and their aides was not the ideal place to voice that,‚Äù she countered, and got to see an interesting mix of chagrined and impressed on his face.

‚ÄúTrue. I like to think though, that since nobody has declared war yet, it‚Äôs still safe to voice a broadminded opinion on the subject.‚Äù

Leia frowned. ‚ÄúYou think it will come to that?‚Äù she asked softly.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù it came out strong, and she wondered if she had surprised him. ‚ÄúNo, I don‚Äôt think we‚Äôre heading for a civil war. But I wouldn‚Äôt be surprised if there were some major upheavals in several sectors in order to keep the peace. They‚Äôre going to have to break up the Banking Clan and the Trade Federation, at least as far as their business goes, if we‚Äôre going to keep the peace.‚Äù

‚ÄúWith what leverage?‚Äù she asked, curious what else he knew.

Apparently not much, because he shrugged. ‚ÄúThankfully, that is for the Council to figure out, and not part of my job. At least,‚Äù he looked back the way he had come, ‚Äúnot yet. And I hope they know I‚Äôm not going to be very useful for this.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis?‚Äù

He looked a bit guilty. ‚ÄúA Jedi assignment. One I got roped into because we‚Äôre still not ready to leave the planet. It should be brief, but now that I‚Äôm missing Master Gallia‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúIs she alright?‚Äù Leia only had a vague impression of the Tholothian, but she‚Äôd seemed in good health only a week ago. Had she been removed from her post working with the senate?

‚ÄúOh yes,‚Äù Obi-Wan reassured, gesturing for her to step into the lift before him.¬† When the doors closed he added, ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs been given another assignment, one that takes priority over this ghastly dinner. I was supposed to be her second, so to speak, and now I‚Äôll be taking point.‚Äù

As they exited onto their floor, Leia asked, ‚ÄúAre the Jedi mediating at the banquet for the Outer Rim systems?‚Äù

‚ÄúAh, right. Naboo was one of the delegations that was invited. Yes, that one.‚Äù He shook his head. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm really not the best one to bring in to negotiate, but I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs the point. I imagine they want a Jedi there for the gravitas, and to keep a hand on things if they get heated. I‚Äôm hoping at most I prevent any outright fights springing from the debates. But I‚Äôll confess to being woefully underprepared. Anakin and I have been taking a lot of missions off world, and I‚Äôm not as up to date on‚Äî Leia? Are you alright?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù she said on instinct, and got a look so familiar from the sheer volume of faces she‚Äôd seen it on she felt comfortable giving her most pointed look back. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm fine.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou are now. I said something that‚Ä¶ surprised you.‚Äù And not just surprised, she could see him not saying.

But she didn‚Äôt have an obligation to explain to him, so she just kept walking. ‚ÄúI just wouldn‚Äôt have thought the Jedi would send someone who wasn‚Äôt prepared. Aren‚Äôt there other Jedi who are familiar with the senate?‚Äù

‚ÄúMore than a few,‚Äù Obi-Wan agreed. ‚ÄúBut the Chancellor apparently asked for my presence. I have a‚Ä¶ reputation for being valuable during negotiations.‚Äù

More than that, if Leia remembered correctly. But she didn‚Äôt push. ‚ÄúThe Chancellor himself asked?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt claim much credit for that,‚Äù Obi-Wan seemed uncomfortable all of a sudden. In a way that was more under Leia‚Äôs skin than being picked up by her eyes. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs taken a keen interest in Anakin, my apprentice,‚Äù he added at her confused look. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs something of an‚Äîof a prodigy, even among the Jedi, and the Chancellor has been interested in his progress.‚Äù

Each word made something sink in Leia‚Äôs heart. And she‚Äôd noticed his slip, wondered which exact word he had chosen to switch out. Didn‚Äôt like the immediate options that sprang to mind. ‚ÄúSurely the Chancellor can‚Äôt dictate the Jedi Council.‚Äù

‚ÄúDictate, no,‚Äù Obi-Wan agreed. ‚ÄúBut strongly suggest, he regularly does. And the Council trusts his assessment of the political landscape. Especially when others like Master Gallia aren‚Äôt available.‚Äù

They‚Äôd reached her office and Leia stopped to look at Obi-Wan. To really think about all he had just said. ‚ÄúWhy are you telling me this?‚Äù

‚ÄúI thought you‚Äôd asked,‚Äù he smiled benignly. She didn‚Äôt trust it. ‚ÄúAnd I wanted your opinion. Naboo‚Äôs position on the conflict with the Separatists has my personal support, although strictly speaking I‚Äôm as neutral as any Jedi. A war will only lead to death and heartbreak, and none of us want that.‚Äù

All true, yet, ‚ÄúAnd what else?‚Äù

‚ÄúReally, I just wanted to pick your brain a bit. One of the senators in the meeting mentioned you were something of a subject matter expert as to the causes of some of the conflict. I‚Äôd hoped to get some advice, or at least an idea of the tone you thought these meetings would have.‚Äù

The door slid open and she gestured with her head for him to come in. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve got a report I‚Äôve been meaning to give to the Loyalist Committee. If you‚Äôve got forty minutes, I can show you the highlights.‚Äù

Relief, pure and simple shimmered off of him and Leia was struck again by how real his feelings were, like Master Gallia‚Äôs. ‚ÄúI would greatly appreciate that.‚Äù

‚ÄúCome on. I‚Äôll have Artoo get things warmed up. Tell Threepio what you‚Äôd like to drink. And don‚Äôt say nothing. You‚Äôll break his heart.‚Äù

There was the briefest impression of surprise at her words, but he requested tea when the protocol droid approached.

The steady stroking of his beard was starting to get on Leia‚Äôs nerves. Less because of the tic itself and more because she knew he was thinking lots of different things and he wasn‚Äôt sharing his thoughts. And she needed to know what Kenobi was thinking.

‚ÄúDoes it make sense?‚Äù she asked, sure he had forgotten she was there.

His slight jump said more than his silence. ‚ÄúOh, yes. It‚Äôs‚Ä¶ quite a lot isn‚Äôt it? And this is only the highlights? Not the details you‚Äôve unearthed?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe things I feel I have the best odds of getting taken seriously when I present them to the delegates,‚Äù she said, leaning an elbow on the desk to get a more direct look at him. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm honestly not sure anymore how to begin to classify which problems as the most serious. I‚Äôm not familiar enough with the ground situation in any of these places. I‚Äôve started doing some general news searches to try and overlay basic patterns, but‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat you need are the Jedi incident reports,‚Äù he muttered, scrolling through to different sections. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not familiar with all the conflicts or situations, but I recognize the names of most of these systems. I‚Äôve heard them in conversation recently.‚Äù His brow was deeply creased between his eyes and Leia fought the sudden impulse to poke it. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm worried that the Confederacy might have a deeper hold than we thought.‚Äù

It was a relief it was to hear him say it. To have him see, so clearly, the scale of what she was afraid of and acknowledge it. ‚ÄúOr at least have better openings. I don‚Äôt know what their resources are for negotiation with other wavering planets. Obviously enough they now have their own congress, but still.‚Äù

‚ÄúDiplomatic teams take years and significant manpower to put and keep together,‚Äù Obi-Wan agreed. ‚ÄúWhich suggests either they aren‚Äôt interested in the long term, they‚Äôre overconfident, or they know something we don‚Äôt. Have resources, as you said, that we don‚Äôt suspect.‚Äù

Leia‚Äôs money was on all three. She wished she knew more about the Clone Wars. Never mind not knowing exactly where the Republic had gotten its army, she barely knew anything about the forces they had fought against. But the war had lasted at least three years, strung out across the galaxy. And the damage from that time was still being addressed in her adulthood. Which suggested a lot of resources on both sides.

‚ÄúI think‚Äî‚Äú

She was interrupted by the door opening and Cord√© saying, ‚ÄúHave you had lunch yet? Padm√© was wondering‚ÄîOh.‚Äù It was a flicker of the eyes, a subtle gesture of the fingers, and a quirk of the mouth as she asked, ‚ÄúAm I interrupting?‚Äù But Leia knew what it meant.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù she said with as much disinterest as she could manage. ‚ÄúMaster Kenobi is just looking over my project. I was getting his advice on planetary conflicts and how they might match up.‚Äù

‚ÄúPadm√© will lose her mind if you keep expanding this project,‚Äù Cord√© wasn‚Äôt laughing, but Leia soaked up the humor coming off the woman and noticed Obi-Wan subtly doing the same, his mouth hidden behind his hand. ‚ÄúAnd she‚Äôll want to know you‚Äôve been entertaining guests.‚Äù

‚ÄúWould you like to see her?‚Äù Leia asked Obi-Wan, standing. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure you‚Äôd be welcome to join us for lunch.‚Äù

She couldn‚Äôt interpret what exactly he was weighing as he thought about it, but he nodded. ‚ÄúYes, I think that‚Äôs a good idea. I may need to ask her if I can steal you for a bit.‚Äù

Cord√©‚Äôs cough was almost a choke, and Leia ignored it. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a bit busy today, but if you have time tomorrow?‚Äù

‚ÄúAh, I was actually thinking about the party,‚Äù he admitted, looking guiltily between them. ‚ÄúIf Senator Amidala doesn‚Äôt already have plans for you. And if it would be alright.‚Äù

‚ÄúSubject matter expert?‚Äù she supplied, knowing this was going to be talked about extensively when they got home tonight.

‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt mind.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll have to confirm with Padm√©, but I don‚Äôt have any objections.‚Äù

He didn‚Äôt turn his head, but his eyes did drift to Cord√© at the pulse of‚Ä¶something Leia didn‚Äôt quite catch. ‚ÄúI cannot tell you how much I appreciate it.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt isn‚Äôt fair,‚Äù Anakin stared out the window, willing himself not to whine. ‚ÄúHe knows I‚Äôm qualified to go with him, and he‚Äôs still taking someone else. Not even a Jedi!‚Äù
