The Chancellor moved up next to him, also watching the lines of traffic. ‚ÄúI know. I‚Äôm very sorry, Anakin. I had hoped he would choose to bring you when I recommended him. Of course, it wasn‚Äôt a stipulation. And with Master Gallia backing out, I can hardly retract the request.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course not,‚Äù Anakin tried to look up, faltered, and felt his eyes move to the floor again. ‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt expect you to do that. Master Obi-Wan is qualified. He should be there.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut you had hoped he trusted you enough to bring you with him,‚Äù the amount of empathy in the Chancellor‚Äôs voice was almost uncomfortable. The feel of it almost swallowed Anakin as he stood there, just trying to keep his emotional balance

He was not out of control because he was too young. ‚ÄúI heard‚Ä¶ Is Pa‚ÄîSenator Amidala going to be there?‚Äù

He knew the answer. Knew Obi-Wan was taking one of her people, someone else from Naboo, to be his partner for that evening. But it still stung when the Chancellor said, ‚ÄúOf course. I think they‚Äôll be seated next to each other. The groups, that it. I don‚Äôt know exactly where the senator and your master will be seated.‚Äù

Something gnawed at Anakin‚Äôs insides, and he tried to swallow it, to beat it down like he‚Äôd always been able to do. ‚ÄúWell, I hope he enjoys himself then. And doesn‚Äôt make a fool of himself. It would be terrible if he made Naboo look bad.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure he‚Äôll do his best.‚Äù

The amusement was even worse than the empathy. He should never have talked about Padm√© to the Chancellor.

War Rooms

Chapter Notes

It is impressive how ten seconds of Palpatine talking to Anakin unearths such a depth and breadth of rage that lingers in the hearts of readers.

The look on Eirta√©‚Äôs face was almost worth the misery of having this conversation. ‚ÄúYou got invited to the dinner by a Jedi?‚Äù

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt think they were allowed to date,‚Äù Cord√©‚Äôs face was half hidden by her drink, but even if Leia hadn‚Äôt spotted her crinkled eyes, her amusement was dancing clearly about the room. ‚ÄúHe must fancy you.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou mean my brilliant and neurotic mind?‚Äù Leia shot back, keeping half her attention on Padm√©. She‚Äôd been a bit somber since lunch. ‚ÄúHe did make it clear he wanted me there for professional reasons.‚Äù

‚ÄúFor a man trying not to appear to be taking sides, he‚Äôs making quite the statement,‚Äù Eirta√© pointed out. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure we should have said yes to this.‚Äù

It was Dorm√© who countered, ‚ÄúIt will be a mixed reception. If we style it correctly, Leia can come across as looking more independent. She‚Äôs not a handmaiden, specifically recruited to Padm√©‚Äôs service. If she‚Äôs seen with someone as neutral as a Jedi‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúMore people might talk to her,‚Äù Padm√© agreed, still looking solemn. She faced Leia directly. ‚ÄúWhat do we tell Shmi?‚Äù

Oh. Right. Leia hadn‚Äôt thought of that. ‚ÄúThe truth. I‚Äôve been invited to the party by Anakin‚Äôs Jedi master. It‚Äôs an event for work. From what Ob‚ÄîMaster Kenobi was saying, he won‚Äôt be bringing Anakin along.‚Äù

The name still tasted wrong. She could say it to Shmi easily enough, when they were talking about his childhood stories. But when Leia said it, in her own context, she was always swallowing Vader first. And burying the memories that came with it.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôll understand,‚Äù Cord√© said, surprisingly not teasing Leia about her slip. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs chosen not to approach him yet. Maybe this will be a good chance to get some information and see where things stand.‚Äù

It would be difficult, Leia thought. She didn‚Äôt know Obi-Wan well enough to guess at how mentioning his padawan or asking about Anakin‚Äôs past might set things off. Especially since Kenobi already seemed to think of his apprentice as a‚Ä¶ prodigy. ‚ÄúIf we‚Äôre having me act as an independent agent, how much do we want to collaborate on this?‚Äù

They spent the rest of the evening hashing out details and finished the night with a few rounds of target practice. Everyone seemed to be a bit off.

Just before they went to bed, Padm√© pulled Leia aside. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to do this,‚Äù she said once they reached the relative privacy of the balcony. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll be making more of a target of yourself.‚Äù

The teasing remark that the last eight months had been the longest she‚Äôd lived without a bounty on her head in almost as many years died in Leia‚Äôs throat. She managed, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not worried about that. Sometimes we have to take risks to get things done. And this, this needs to get done. We aren‚Äôt making enough headway with me just politely waiting for the committee to have time. It can‚Äôt hurt to have Jedi support.‚Äù

Probably. Hopefully. Leia was also very curious what her appearance with Obi-Wan Kenobi would signal to the senate, and the galaxy at large.

And one man in particular.

‚ÄúShmi would be devastated if you got hurt,‚Äù Padm√© blurted, and Leia was almost shocked.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to a dinner party, not a war zone. I mean, well, some of them can be very similar. But this is on Coruscant. The Chancellor will be attending. I‚Äôm hardly going to be the biggest target.‚Äù

Frankly, now that Leia thought about it, she was much more concerned for the other members who had just submitted a no vote for the military committee. Being at the dinner was probably the only way she would find peace that night. Better to be facing a fight than waiting for it.

‚ÄúAt the party, no,‚Äù Padm√© agreed. ‚ÄúBut you‚Äôve got the least protection of all of us if you do stand out.‚Äù Her expression turned stubborn on top of serious. ‚ÄúI may have to ask Captain Typho to arrange security for you afterwards.‚Äù

Leia felt her mouth drop. ‚ÄúA personal guard?‚Äù she checked. Padm√© nodded. ‚ÄúI really don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs going to be necessary‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI‚Äôve heard, from no fewer than ten people, that the first person they think of is me when they see you. I know what I am,‚Äù she was smiling, but it was a smile that was as self-deprecating as anything. ‚ÄúAnd I know what you are too. Better to be ahead of the curve.‚Äù

Well, that was fair. There wasn‚Äôt anything honest Leia could do to argue with it.

‚ÄúMay I join you?‚Äù Master Kenobi was almost lurking in the doorway, more hesitant than Leia would have expected.

‚ÄúOf course. What can I do for you?‚Äù She gestured to a chair that was in front of her desk, clearing her workspace so that she wouldn‚Äôt be tempted to split her attention.

The Jedi took a seat, glancing around at the walls that lacked windows and the dim lighting Leia preferred, an amused note to his voice. ‚ÄúThey certainly have you in pleasant quarters, don‚Äôt they?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt limits my distractions,‚Äù Leia confessed, reaching back to the wall controls and adjusting the lights. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm told it‚Äôs not good for my eyes, but I‚Äôll believe that when I can‚Äôt see it.‚Äù

It didn‚Äôt earn a chuckle, which disappointed her, but his eyes smiled. ‚ÄúMy apprentice likes to work in similar conditions when he‚Äôs focused on a project. He claims that he works enough by the Force that his eyes aren‚Äôt doing much anyway.‚Äù

‚ÄúYour apprentice Anakin?‚Äù Leia checked, ignoring the implications of that revelation.

‚ÄúYes. I‚Äôll introduce you sometime, when we‚Äôre both here. If that‚Äôs alright,‚Äù he added after a moment, his eyes narrowing slightly. Leia knew she hadn‚Äôt twitched, but maybe he had felt something.

She was certainly surprised. She would never have guessed that Obi-Wan would want to introduce his padawan to a non-Jedi without an explicit need. But maybe that was just her prejudice speaking and not all Jedi were as aloof as the ones she had seen wandering the building.

‚ÄúOf course. Padm√© was saying she met him during the siege of Naboo.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe all met then, yes,‚Äù Obi-Wan was smiling, but it was shadowed by a feeling Leia was all too familiar with. We won, but at what cost?

‚ÄúBut that isn‚Äôt what you came to talk to me about,‚Äù Leia prompted, willing to let the topic drop. There would be plenty of time to trespass on heavy memories later. And as far as people she was happy to not think about‚Ä¶

With a shift that pulled him back to the present, Obi-Wan said, ‚ÄúNo. I had hoped to talk to you some more about the dinner. I don‚Äôt know how much you‚Äôve been told about it. Or what your plans were.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve got a rough outline of the guest list,‚Äù Leia said, pulling over the notes she had made based on Padm√© and the handmaidens‚Äô conversations. ‚ÄúAnd an idea of some of the goals the Loyalist Committee is aiming for. But anything you can add, especially in relation to your role, will help.‚Äù

‚ÄúYour friends haven‚Äôt filled you in?‚Äù

Leia shook her head. ‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt going to be directly involved, and then we decided it was better if I act independently if I‚Äôm going with you. The Jedi are supposed to be a neutral party, yes?‚Äù

He seemed both relieved and impressed that they had thought of that, and quickly filled her in on the briefing he had been given. She got the impression he was hitting only the most important highlights, and that he was used to this kind of briefing as a form of self defense.

She took notes, let him finish, and then went back and asked him to fill in details, some of which amused him, others that confused, and a couple that had him raising his brows as he answered.

‚ÄúForgive my brevity,‚Äù he told her after a fourth follow up question on what the Jedi‚Äôs position was regarding enforcing trade treaties. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm used to working with a slightly less focused audience.‚Äù

‚ÄúYour apprentice doesn‚Äôt take an interest in politics?‚Äù Leia suggested.

‚ÄúNot especially. He‚Äôs more than happy to let me handle things.‚Äù There was an odd expression at the end of that, hinting at something familiar that Leia couldn‚Äôt quite place.

She asked, ‚ÄúIs it frustrating that he doesn‚Äôt try?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh, he does try,‚Äù Obi-Wan said, leaning back into his chair and stroking his beard. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs just rather‚Ä¶ direct when he does choose to be involved. And it can lead to‚Ä¶ interesting negotiations.‚Äù

Remembering her own quick temper and the constant battle to bite her tongue, Leia could only sympathize. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure he‚Äôll catch on. Once you find the right motivation.‚Äù

Obi-Wan didn‚Äôt look sure of any such thing, and thinking of that black horror that still loomed in her memory, Leia didn‚Äôt blame him. ‚ÄúDid you have any other questions for me?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat are you going to wear?‚Äù Leia asked, and was both pleased and worried that she had surprised him.

He looked down at himself and then back to her. ‚ÄúThis?‚Äù Pressing her lips shut, forcing her eyes not to rove over the outfit and catalogue every stain, fray, and tear, Leia counted to ten and held her breath. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not that bad,‚Äù he complained. ‚ÄúJedi robes are formal. They‚Äôre traditional.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you have a set you keep on planet exclusively for formal events?‚Äù she asked, working very hard to keep a straight face and even voice.

He still seemed to catch the implications. ‚ÄúI can get access to ones that have seen less field work, yes. These are the set that stay on planet, so that they‚Äôre always presentable in a more‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúUrban environment,‚Äù Leia suggested, knowing her lips had twitched.

‚ÄúYes, something like that.‚Äù

She took a moment to really study him then, leaning back to catch another angle. ‚ÄúAre they all brown?‚Äù

‚ÄúMy robes? Certainly. It‚Äôs‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúTraditional?‚Äù Leia knew she had a wry smile down to an art. ‚ÄúDo you think you can find anything else traditional with a bit more color? It would be easier to match.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh, you don‚Äôt have to‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI‚Äôm deliberately not wearing anything that will automatically align me with the Naboo representatives,‚Äù she said, standing and walking around the desk to come up to him. He stood as well, and she noted the differences in their heights. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm assuming it would be something of a scandal if I showed up in Jedi robes, imitation or otherwise,‚Äù and she didn‚Äôt want to think about the image that conjured up (wasn‚Äôt a Jedi, never a Jedi, should have helped Luke‚Äî), so she continued. ‚ÄúBut we are going together and it would be better if we were coordinated.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs true, but‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYou‚Äôd look good in blue,‚Äù she said, ‚Äúnot too bright, something a little darker. More muted. It would bring out your eyes. And would be easy to match,‚Äù she added when he looked like he was going to protest. ‚ÄúBlues are easy to find.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚ÄîI suppose I could try,‚Äù he conceded. ‚ÄúIf you have a dress in mind, I can look for something to match it.‚Äù

She shook her head. ‚ÄúJust send me the dye setting code. You should be able to get it from wherever the item was manufactured. It‚Äôll be a more precise match that way. I was already going to buy something,‚Äù she added as he looked ready to object again. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not part of the official entourage. I have to build my own wardrobe.‚Äù

‚ÄúI see,‚Äù he didn‚Äôt seem happy about it, but looked ready to concede.

Which was good, because, ‚ÄúAnd can you do something about your hair?‚Äù She tried not to stare as his hand made an abortive move towards his head. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to cut it. It is yours. But if you could tie it back, or put it partly up‚ÄîI know some styles that would work,‚Äù she added, talking more quickly. ‚ÄúIf you come by early enough I can help you find something that would work and you would like.‚Äù

She‚Äôd have to do some refreshing, and make sure to check current Coruscanti styles so that it didn‚Äôt end up too Alderaanian. But so help her, if she had to go with him looking like this (she could almost see her mother, shaking her head and smiling in a way that warned Leia there would be changes), she couldn‚Äôt be liable for what might happen.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll think about it,‚Äù he managed, bowing to her. ‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôll get you the color code once I‚Äôve found something appropriate. I‚Äôll even have Master Gallia check it first.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù Leia said as she led him to the door and watched him take his first step out. ‚ÄúMaybe the Force be with you, Master Kenobi.‚Äù

He actually stared at her for a second before answering, ‚ÄúMay the Force be with you, Leia. Good luck on your work.‚Äù

She was certainly going to need it.

Dawn was just hinting at arriving on the barest sliver of the sky. Leia braced herself against the wall, pulled her knees further up, and glanced back at the holocall in her hand. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know why I‚Äôm doing this,‚Äù she admitted ruefully.

Shmi was never one to rush into an answer, but it always made Leia nervous when she had to wait. Shmi also had a tendency to say things that were exactly true and the opposite of what you wanted to hear. ‚ÄúNo one else does either,‚Äù her grandmother pointed out, hands moving in a gesture that was open kindness to ease the sting. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not something that you‚Äôve shared with us.‚Äù

‚ÄúI want the galaxy to be right,‚Äù Leia complained, her head falling back as she tried to imagine it as she once had. That perfect conglomeration of worlds. Only now‚Ä¶

Now everything was complicated, and things she had once taken for granted were more important, not less, and things she had thought were essential had fallen to the wayside of maybes, if everything else was working out alright these thing might be nice and (nowhere in this universe was she going to find what she most personally wanted, those arms that had held her and kept her safe, those smiles that had lifted her up when she thought that she had nothing left, those eyes that had looked and known and seen her) she couldn‚Äôt pin down what she thought would even be perfect anymore.

She could find happiness in a crowded bunker with cheap liquor and tasteless food rations as long as she was with good friends. She could find courage in the middle of a battlefield, friends and allies dying around her, because she knew her cause was just.

She dreamed of a world where she had never met Darth Vader and nothing that had mattered to her had ever been lost.

Unfortunately, that wasn‚Äôt a world where she would be getting what she missed the most.

‚ÄúThings do not have to be perfect to be worthwhile,‚Äù Shmi‚Äôs gentleness had hardened some. ‚ÄúI know you‚Äôve said this, Leia, but I wonder if you‚Äôve ever meant it when it matters most.‚Äù

When, Leia wondered helplessly, would she ever stop being a soft, Core world princess? ‚ÄúI won‚Äôt stop fighting if I can‚Äôt make things perfect,‚Äù she muttered. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not as selfish as that.‚Äù

Shmi took a moment to consider that. ‚ÄúDo you plan to ever stop fighting at all?‚Äù

If she looked straight up she could still see the hint of a few stars in the sky. Dim and wavering, hidden by the harsh aura of the cityscape that covered the planet, but still there, still burning. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know. I don‚Äôt know what I would do if I had to stop.‚Äù

‚ÄúI meant, do you see a future where there is no need to fight, not will you be forced out of it?‚Äù

No. No, that hadn‚Äôt occurred to her at all. Not since (fire, pressure, nothing) Endor. Or Alderaan. Or the whispers of maybe things had been better when someone had taken charge. Maybe not for everyone, but he‚Äôd been better than nothing. ‚ÄúWill there ever be a world where no one has to fight?‚Äù

Because that was how she saw her options. She couldn‚Äôt be herself and exist in a place where there would be conflict and she didn‚Äôt choose a side of it. Didn‚Äôt stand up and take part. Not anymore. Not after everything that had been lost.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Shmi said, and that simple acknowledgement was a condemnation and a relief. ‚ÄúBut that does not mean you have to spend all of your life fighting.‚Äù

Maybe not. But today, that was just who Leia was. And her past wouldn‚Äôt let her forget about it.

Arsenals

Leia sat back on her heels, looking over Artoo‚Äôs dome one more time as she made a final swipe with her rag. ‚ÄúThere. I think that should do it.‚Äù He whistled with pleasure and she patted him as she stood, looking around the room for Threepio. ‚ÄúNow where has your friend gotten to?‚Äù

She could only partially interpret the series of whistles and beeps coming from the droid, and accepted that it was either, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù or ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt care.‚Äù

Which was fair. She couldn‚Äôt always be expecting Artoo to keep an eye on Threepio.

‚ÄúI‚Äôd better go find him. He could be getting into trouble.‚Äù

The astromech beeped an affirmative and offered to come. They had almost made it to the door when it opened and Threepio shuffled in. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sorry, Mistress Leia. I meant to return immediately, but I was most inconveniently held up.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs fine,‚Äù Leia said, waving him over so that she could start to buff some of the spots on him. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm still taking a break. Where did you get caught up?‚Äù

He came over as she had bid and helpfully turned as she worked on different places. ‚ÄúThe most peculiar thing. I ran into the Chancellor of all people. Can you believe it?‚Äù

Leia paused, her breath catching. ‚ÄúDid you really?‚Äù She made sure her hand didn‚Äôt tremble. ‚ÄúHow did that go?‚Äù

‚ÄúI was incredibly disappointed. The man is a horrid gossip. Would you believe he wanted me to answer questions about you, Mistress Leia? Not even related to your work, which is none of his business I‚Äôm sure.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt isn‚Äôt?‚Äù Leia hadn‚Äôt considered the matter and was a little surprised. Threepio had always come across to her as chatty. He seemed willing to talk to anyone.

‚ÄúCertainly not. Especially if you‚Äôre not there. How can I know if you want me to tell a thing or not if you aren‚Äôt there for reference? Really, it was quite frustrating. And then he wanted to know about your work too, as if I had anything to do with. I‚Äôm a protocol droid, I told him. I‚Äôm only here to advise you on how to get along with other delegates, by respecting their cultures and such. And he laughed at that!‚Äù

The sudden image of Jar Jar appeared in her mind, his frequent comment of ‚ÄúHow rude,‚Äù almost making Leia smile. ‚ÄúThat wasn‚Äôt very wise of him. You‚Äôre an excellent protocol droid.‚Äù

‚ÄúI am trying,‚Äù Threepio said, waving his arms so abruptly that Leia almost took one to the face. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve made sure to constantly update my databases so that I have things to draw from, especially in relation to the current delegates. I‚Äôve cross referenced so many languages and forms of communication to make sure I‚Äôm getting local dialects right, I‚Äôm not sure which ones are new and which were native to my programing anymore. It‚Äôs really quite exhausting. Yes, I know you‚Äôve been busy too,‚Äù Threepio snapped when Artoo warbled at the last comment.

‚ÄúThank you, Threepio,‚Äù Leia said when the resulting beeps from the astromech told her and argument was about to start. ‚ÄúI really appreciate your efforts. And your discretion.‚Äù

She had his full attention again. ‚ÄúYou would prefer me to continue to not divulge personal details when I‚Äôm asked?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù she answered, stepping back to take a good look at him. ‚ÄúAnd if you could, only discuss details of my work with someone if you‚Äôve heard me mention the topic to them directly. I‚Äôd rather they come to me if they want to know about what I‚Äôm up to.‚Äù

Threepio was only too happy to promise and Leia let both droids go, saying she needed to get back to work.

But it was some time before she could make herself focus again.

Memories of Threepio‚Äôs behavior were frequently fuzzy in her memory. She‚Äôd considered him more of an annoyance growing up, and had assumed any discretion that he had, he had learned from her father, having been given explicit instructions not to discuss certain topics. He‚Äôd never kept any secrets from Luke, but then he‚Äôd also considered Luke his master, much like he felt like he answered to Leia. He‚Äôd never listened to Han, at least not without being threatened.

Curling up in her chair, Leia thought about how Anakin Skywalker, a slave on Tatooine, was the one that built Threepio. How he was supposed to help Anakin‚Äôs mother. How they were all functionally slaves, but there would have been secrets they would have kept, even from their master.

How clever had that boy been, to disguise with rigid politeness and keep away with neurotic evasion?

It was a dark, clever genius, that.

‚ÄúTrouble?‚Äù Leia hadn‚Äôt heard Cord√© come in, but she smiled once she‚Äôd recovered from being startled.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Leia said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve just been distracted.‚Äù

Humming, Cord√© took a seat on the edge of the desk. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre thinking of heading home for a bit. Once the dinner‚Äôs past.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat sounds lovely,‚Äù Leia confessed. ‚ÄúI think I‚Äôve reached another major block on my project, and won‚Äôt get anywhere with it until we get the committee to make some moves.‚Äù

‚ÄúTalk to Padm√©, get her permission to run it by some of them one on one. Maybe get her to hand off the refugee project as well. It‚Äôs past time we showed Senator Sadashassa. Throw it in with some trade negotiation ideas to soften her up.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think she does soft,‚Äù Leia sat up, already grabbing a datapad and checking to make sure the relevant documents were on it. ‚ÄúBut I‚Äôm willing to try it.‚Äù

Apparently Padm√© had a secret passion for shopping.

This shouldn‚Äôt have surprised Leia. The senator had an extensive wardrobe, coordinated and cross coordinated, containing dresses and headpieces and jewelry and accessories and shoes. So. Many. Shoes.

Not that Leia didn‚Äôt know what a state wardrobe could be like. She‚Äôd had her own collection of gowns, robes, dresses, casual outfits, all carefully styled and arranged and tailored so that she always came off as looking a bit more professional or put together than the average person.

But Padm√© apparently went above and beyond even that, and now Leia was getting first hand experience.

‚ÄúI thought we weren‚Äôt going to coordinate,‚Äù she said, forcing herself to not back away from the trio in front of her. ‚ÄúI was just letting you know where I was going so you would know where to reach me.‚Äù

Dorm√©, of all people, seemed to be smirking, and it was Eirta√© who was looking at Leia pityingly. Padm√© was simply resolute. And a bit too cheerful. ‚ÄúThere is a complete difference between us giving you clothes to wear that belong to us, and us helping you find the best outlets.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm really not sure‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll be able to introduce you to the right people,‚Äù Padm√© added, already vibrating with excitement.

‚ÄúAnd get you discounts,‚Äù Dorm√© added, her smile sliding back into something more kind and less mischievous. Although that could be a trick. Now Leia wasn‚Äôt sure. ‚ÄúThere are people who will be friendly with certain systems or delegations.‚Äù

‚ÄúOr committees,‚Äù Eirta√© added.

Padm√© stepped forward. ‚ÄúThe point is, Leia needs to go shopping and it will be so much more efficient and useful if she doesn‚Äôt go by herself.‚Äù

Which was the exact moment that Padm√©‚Äôs comm went off and she excused herself to the other side of the room for relative privacy. Leia breathed a sigh of relief and was about to make her excuses and flee under the cover of the distraction when she caught the handmaidens‚Äô looks.

‚ÄúShe needs the break, doesn‚Äôt she?‚Äù Leia asked low enough Padm√© wouldn‚Äôt hear. And was unsurprised when both women nodded.

A tingle in her feet and her back were the promise that they would be aching later. And possibly her head as well.

But it had been so long since she had gotten to do anything like this (shopping with Shmi was an exercise in the strictest, most efficient economy) with anyone who had been interested. And Padm√© would love it and needed the break.

So Leia stayed until the call was finished, helped them rearrange the schedule for the day, and meekly accepted the three women and two droids that became her companions as they headed out into one of the nearer shopping districts, desperately hoping they would find something quickly.

They didn‚Äôt.

Coruscant had always been one of Leia‚Äôs least favorite places to find clothes, and even pre-Empire, several of the worst details still stood out to her. The most notable being every. Single. Person. Mentioning how short she was. Indirectly.

The showrooms and displays had gorgeous gowns and lovely dresses, simple and elaborate styles. There were more shops catering to various species, which was an improvement from her memory. Things were busier, there was more light and laughter and smiles than she remembered. Although there was still a fog of something beyond the pollution, dimming things around her.

The actual clothes were okay, although that was mostly helped by Padm√© being right, and having a better knowledge of where a young, newly rising political aide would find a proper wardrobe.

But the standing, and the undressing, and the redressing, and the twirling, and the comments (and every single one somehow coming back to her height being human non-standard) started to get grating more quickly than Leia had expected. And there was a lot of disagreement between the handmaidens, Padm√©, and Threepio as to what would be considered appropriate for the occasion.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt want too low of a back,‚Äù was the general consensus, along with, ‚ÄúNothing too warm. We‚Äôre expecting a fair number of people.‚Äù

But from there it was a disagreement between three quarter sleeves or shorter, should they match the color they‚Äôd been given exactly or pick a complimentary one, did she actually want a dress or something more like a suit with an over-robe?

There was a lot of laughter, but somewhere in her mind, Leia found it tedious.

How long had it been since she had done something this‚Ä¶ normal?

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre tired,‚Äù Padm√© said after the third store and about fifteen different dresses that had had real promise. ‚ÄúShould we stop here for today?‚Äù

Shaking her head, Leia admitted, ‚ÄúI need to have it ordered by tonight if I‚Äôm not going to worry about everything being ready in time.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe dinner is another week away.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù Leia said. ‚ÄúBut I still need to get some accessories, try everything on, make sure it‚Äôs properly fitted, get it adjusted when it‚Äôs inevitably too long, and figure out what I‚Äôm going to do with my hair.‚Äù

And Obi-Wan‚Äôs, if he‚Äôd let her. She‚Äôd realized she probably needed to completely make up a new style of her own as she‚Äôd been researching what she could do for him.

After a few moments of thought, Padm√© asked, ‚ÄúWhat are you looking for?‚Äù

They‚Äôd started with a question of what she needed, but as they‚Äôd gone along Leia had realized that hadn‚Äôt been good enough. Padm√©‚Äôs new question was more to the point.

‚ÄúSomething practical that I can move in. Something that will match Obi-Wan‚Äôs style, but not too closely. Something simple, not elaborate. I want‚Ä¶‚Äù She tried to picture it in her mind. The shape and the feel of the fabric. The color that she had been sent. ‚ÄúMinimalism, something that hints at the Jedi‚Äôs restraint in their aesthetic without copying the pieces. Some similar lines in the shoulder and around the waist, but in a dress, I think.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù Padme said, smiling again, ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs go and find you that then.‚Äù

It took them two more stores to find something close enough to what Leia had described that it only needed to be moderately adjusted, but things went well and by the time they got home about an hour later, Leia had a dress and stole, new shoes, a bronze necklace and bracelets, and a lot more confidence about how she would be styling her hair.

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù she told them all as she went to go and put everything away. ‚ÄúYou were a big help.‚Äù

Even Threepio, who had managed to help her sort through the different shapes on the jewelry she had chosen and make sure to avoid any that would be directly or subtly insulting to the parties that had been invited for negotiation.

‚ÄúIt was fun,‚Äù Padm√© seemed to be almost glowing with delight. ‚ÄúWe should do that again sometime.‚Äù

The thought was exhausting, but if she was going to be here for a while, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure I‚Äôll need more than one dress if I‚Äôm going to further my political career.‚Äù

It was meant to be wry and sarcastic, leaving a bit of uncertainty as to whether or not she was really planning on staying. But apparently Padm√© was starting to catch on. Or was just determined to apply what she wanted to happen and let Leia catch up. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôd better get you ready then. There‚Äôs going to be a lot of opportunities for you to prove yourself in the coming months.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll look forward to it.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt expecting to see you here,‚Äù there was an amused voice from the doorway and Leia looked up, blinking in surprise when she saw Senator Darsana looming in the entryway.

‚ÄúI do work here,‚Äù she found herself retorting before she could think better of it. ‚ÄúThis is, in fact, my office.‚Äù Which was when her brain reengaged and she managed, ‚ÄúWould you like to take a seat?‚Äù

She moved things around, reached to adjust the lights, noticed him twitch, and let her hand drop. ‚ÄúMost of the time, when the light sensors indicate this low, humans are not working in the office,‚Äù he commented as he sat down, bringing his hands together in front of his chest and propping his elbows on the arms of his chair. ‚ÄúSo I was surprised when it opened as I walked by.‚Äù

Rather than answering his implied questions, Leia asked, ‚ÄúIs there something that I can do for you?‚Äù

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù he said, smiling in a way that told her to be wary of what came next, ‚Äúyou could tell me what is going on with the other Loyalists.‚Äù

She hadn‚Äôt been expecting that exactly, and certainly hadn‚Äôt expected him to come out and just say it. Her political maneuvering skills were still better fitted for a court where everything was implied, not outright stated. But she answered easily enough, ‚ÄúAs a member of that committee, I would think that you are better placed to know what people are up to than I am.‚Äù

‚ÄúSome members, certainly. But our, ah, unique position of not openly advocating against the military creation measures has led to some‚Ä¶ difficulties in getting people to respond to us. When we ask uncomfortable questions.‚Äù

Leia brought her own hands together on the table, her lips twitching in a half smile. ‚ÄúLike how are you supposed to maintain functional profit margins when the Trade Federation won‚Äôt lend you their battle droids to fight off pirates, and there are no Republic funded alternatives?‚Äù

‚ÄúSomething like that, yes.‚Äù

She considered the issue and asked, ‚ÄúWhat does the Trade Federation say about lending you their support?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat they cover the lanes of travel they are involved in, and depend on us to fulfill our contract in our own space.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd any planet that can‚Äôt do so will have to submit their report to the congress at the end of the year, and might lose their direct representation in the senate. And have to submit to sector sovereignty.‚Äù

He had a very unpleasant smile when he chose. ‚ÄúI am afraid you are delightfully blunt. Yes, that would be one factor in not wanting to make this a matter of general scrutiny before the senate.‚Äù

‚ÄúEven if the Trade Federation were committing fraud?‚Äù

And suddenly she had his complete and undivided attention. ‚ÄúI imagine,‚Äù he said, watching her very closely, his mouth hanging open between words, ‚Äúyou would have very good reason to make that sort of accusation.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf I brought it before the full senate,‚Äù Leia said calmly, ‚Äúyes, I would. As it stands, I‚Äôm not at that point.‚Äù

Senator Darsana leaned back now, still tasting the air as he observed her. ‚ÄúBut you believe you would be able to find such facts.‚Äù

‚ÄúI find it hard to believe that with an increasing number of systems scrambling for access to basic resources, a planet like Cato Nemoidia could completely avoid similar trouble if it were acting in the best interests of the Republic which has allowed it to grow‚Ä¶ unmolested.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey provide their own security,‚Äù the senator pointed out. ‚ÄúAnd there are the new taxes.‚Äù

Leia pulled a datapad out of the mess scattered across her desk, made sure it had the right charts pulled up, and handed it over. ‚ÄúThese are their growth margins for the last ten years. Since the tax imposition. And the invasion of Naboo.‚Äù

‚ÄúStrong word,‚Äù the senator murmured, accepting the datapad and glancing over it. He stopped, brought it closer to his face, then looked at her. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt be serious.‚Äù

‚ÄúThose aren‚Äôt the officially reported numbers,‚Äù Leia told him, taking it back. ‚ÄúJust what I‚Äôve been able to put together from other extrapolated data.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe planet isn‚Äôt large enough to hold that many goods,‚Äù Senator Darsana said, his teeth clicking together, the fingers of one hand gripping the arm of his chair so tightly she could see the digits paling even in the relative dark. ‚ÄúThey couldn‚Äôt possibly be holding that much in reserve.‚Äù

‚ÄúPersonally, no,‚Äù Leia agreed. ‚ÄúWhich begs the question, if they don‚Äôt have it, where is it?‚Äù

A bitter smile. ‚ÄúPirates?‚Äù

‚ÄúOnly if they‚Äôre supplying all of Hutt space,‚Äù Leia said. ‚ÄúIn which case, we might need an army. To deal with that particular challenge of sovereignty. But that,‚Äù she added, ‚Äúwould be up to the senate. Once they had reviewed the issue.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd once the supplies are found.‚Äù

‚ÄúPrecisely.‚Äù

He took his time thinking about what had been said, just sitting there. It was tempting to work while she was waiting, but Leia gave him her full attention. She‚Äôd told him his time was valuable, and it could be small things that would prove it.

She admired him, that he had come to her directly. And that he hadn‚Äôt been subtle about it. He‚Äôd said he‚Äôd test her. To the very edge of her limits.

He chuckled. ‚ÄúIt occurs to me,‚Äù his teeth were flashing again, ‚Äúthat you in no way actually answered my question.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not privy to many secrets,‚Äù she confessed (at least, not from this time), ‚Äúbut even if I were, I would be a sad example if I were to discuss them, even with you.‚Äù

He nodded. ‚ÄúIt would be very hard,‚Äù he agreed, ‚Äúfor you to maintain any trusts.‚Äù He stood. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm looking forward to the results of your work. I will have relevant documents brought to you regarding our system, once we are able to assemble them.‚Äù

Standing with him, Leia made sure not to blink in surprise. ‚ÄúThat would be a great help.‚Äù

‚ÄúI am certain,‚Äù he said, making a farewell gesture, ‚Äúthat you will make the effort worth it.‚Äù

‚ÄúI live to serve,‚Äù she mostly kept the smile to herself. His wheezing chuckle told her she‚Äôd need to make more effort in the future.

Even the Best Laid Plans

When her chrono pinged Leia stretched as far as she could in the chair and rubbed her eyes, letting the words she‚Äôd been reading sink into her mind. Once she was sure she would remember them she tried to turn her mind to tonight‚Äôs dinner and found the effort sluggish and ineffective.

She needed to meditate or something before she left. Not enough time to go shooting, but she could take ten minutes to clear her mind.

It felt important.

She left the front room, waving at Cord√© who was reviewing travel arrangements with Captain Typho, and made herself comfortable on her bed. Once comfortable, she peeled her mind away from the information she had been processing, sinking away from the numbers and names and systems and into that cool, dark feeling that was her self.

It had been speckled with lights once, glowing like dozens of stars littered in her senses. She felt now, sensed, that those stars and lights were still there, she just couldn‚Äôt see them. Could feel them beyond the thick, dense haze that was her grief and sorrows, her anger and despair. But that haze between her and them was so cold.

She should probably deal with that.

She wouldn‚Äôt tonight.

Once she‚Äôd centered and grounded, Leia reached out, beyond her sense of self to the pearlescent glow that was the world around her. That was power and being and yesterdays and tomorrows and sometimes even the clearest perception she ever had of the now.

Sometimes it brought noises, various sounds. Feelings or warmths or blazing heats or a cold of its own, sometimes ambivalent and others very sinister.

Tonight it was quiet. Quiet and peaceful calm. Like the center of the storm, or the stillness right before a disaster. It reminded her of being trapped in that cell, waiting for the return of Vader. Then composing herself, putting herself back together to face Tarkin.

Just before her world had ended.

It was clarity. And a warning.

‚ÄúMaster, do you think I should‚Äî‚Äú

Anakin‚Äôs words died as he walked into the room and caught sight of Obi-Wan, standing in front of a mirror and adjusting his robe. A new robe, Anakin noted. A lighter brown to go with his also new, dark blue undershirt. His boots weren‚Äôt new, but they were clean and polished.

None of which was as startling as his haircut.

‚ÄúDo I think you should what?‚Äù Obi-Wan asked, not even looking over as he fiddled with his clothes some more, and then smoothed at his beard.

Anakin couldn‚Äôt remember what he‚Äôd been about to ask. ‚ÄúYou cut your hair.‚Äù

Something about how he said it must have finally clued in his master, who turned, a very odd sort of smile on his face. ‚ÄúIt was this or let Leia style it. I just couldn‚Äôt bring myself to allow that.‚Äù

It took a moment before Anakin realized that his mouth was hanging open. ‚ÄúI‚ÄîI thought‚Äî‚Äú

It‚Äôd been a stupid thought, really. His master hadn‚Äôt said anything about it, Anakin had just assumed. Served him right for‚Äîfor thinking Obi-Wan cared.

‚ÄúYou thought what?‚Äù

It was a genuinely curious tone, and so open that Anakin found himself saying, without thinking, ‚ÄúYou were waiting for my knighting.‚Äù

His voice dropped off as he finished. He couldn‚Äôt meet Obi-Wan‚Äôs eyes and wished he was holding something to distract his hands. But he‚Äôd get scolded if he just summoned something to play with.

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù Obi-Wan sounded baffled. ‚ÄúNo, I‚ÄîI just was enjoying not having to get regular haircuts. I mean,‚Äù he stroked his beard, ‚ÄúI may have cut it, once you were knighted. I really don‚Äôt know. I hadn‚Äôt thought about it.‚Äù

Which also squelched the idea that he‚Äôd been growing it in memory of Master Qui-Gon. But Anakin wasn‚Äôt going to make the mistake of voicing that thought. ‚ÄúWell, it looks very nice.‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù and he sounded actually reassured, which made Anakin nervous. Obi-Wan was never this weird about his appearance. And he seemed to be worried about what this Leia thought.

Very strange.

‚ÄúSo, this is for the party?‚Äù It was a stupid question, especially since Obi-Wan had gone over Anakin‚Äôs plans for the evening five time already. But he couldn‚Äôt make his brain get back to what he‚Äôd meant to talk to Obi-Wan about.

Smoothing his clothes, Obi-Wan said, ‚ÄúYes. This is for tonight‚Äôs banquet. Which is more of a negotiation dinner than a party, Anakin.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt seems too fancy and frivolous,‚Äù Anakin shrugged. ‚ÄúEspecially if you‚Äôre trying to reconcile with Outer Rim worlds.‚Äù

‚ÄúI am hardly dressed in anything that would be considered fancy,‚Äù Obi-Wan objected, which reminded Anakin just how little his master knew about want and what it meant and what it looked like.

Sometimes now, even Anakin forgot, he‚Äôd been in the Temple so long. And then they‚Äôd go on a mission, and he‚Äôd remember. Everything.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs more than most of them probably have,‚Äù was what he wanted to say. But instead, he just shrugged. ‚ÄúWell, I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôll do the Order proud.‚Äù

‚ÄúI hope so. They haven‚Äôt really been clear on what I‚Äôm supposed to be doing.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe they don‚Äôt know,‚Äù he hadn‚Äôt meant to say that, but it happened. And he couldn‚Äôt take it back.

His master gave him the look. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure they have a plan.‚Äù

Nodding was the right response, but Anakin didn‚Äôt really believe it. Every day he was less and less sure the Jedi had any idea what they were doing.

There was a knock, closely followed by, ‚ÄúLeia?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù she called as she twisted her hair, wrapping it carefully so it would stay with only the slightest help from a pin. It would have to survive like this for several hours.

The door slid open and Padm√© said, ‚ÄúWe just wanted to make sure you had everything you need before we left. Oh, that‚Äôs lovely.‚Äù

The senator‚Äôs styles frequently involved elaborate hair pieces and tonight was no exception. There was something between a net and a cage holding a crest around the back of her head, glittering gold that complimented the rich purples of her dress. In comparison, Leia felt that her own hair seemed simple, no matter the relative complexity of the wide, flat bun braided and twisted around the crown of her head.

It was nice to have gotten the compliment. ‚ÄúThank you. You look wonderful yourself.‚Äù

Padm√© was too experienced to titter or blush, but Leia felt the rush of embarrassment from her friend and was a little surprised by it. ‚ÄúThank you. Hopefully it‚Äôs not too much.‚Äù

There was pretty obvious wealth in the design that had been chosen, but it was also more open and less layered than many of Padm√©‚Äôs outfits. And the luxury helped hide her youth, which was probably a good thing in these circumstances. The only issue, ‚ÄúIs purple the color of the evening for all the loyalists?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo. Is it a problem?‚Äù

Not inherently, but, ‚ÄúDo you know what the Chancellor is wearing? He favors a lot of purples and similar dark colors. I was wondering if you would match, and if it was deliberate.‚Äù

Frowning, the senator stepped further in to borrow Leia‚Äôs mirror for a moment. Leia took the chance to fold and wrap her sash, grateful that the sand tone stood out so clearly against the blue. It made it much easier to tie, and then twist and reposition until it lay mostly flat against her stomach and sides. She slid a few combs into it to test how visible they were and was pleased with the results.

‚ÄúIt could be similar,‚Äù Padm√© admitted, sounding dubious. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll have to ask Bail if I resemble the Chancellor‚Äôs party too much.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry. I should have said something before.‚Äù

Shaking her head, Padm√© moved to the door. ‚ÄúNo, we left you out of the planning on purpose. At least that worked. You and I don‚Äôt look anything alike.‚Äù

Well, not more than passingly, Leia thought. But yes, their styles were very different. Padm√©‚Äôs satins shone and shimmered as she moved, holding their shape with their stiffness. Their colors did not compliment, and they‚Äôd gone for very different styles in their makeup. Leia‚Äôs was minimalist, while Padm√©‚Äôs harkened back to her time as queen. Another decision to disguise her age and emphasize her experience.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôd better be going,‚Äù Leia said, checking the time. ‚ÄúI know you were planning on being early.‚Äù

‚ÄúTake care. We‚Äôll see you there.‚Äù

When the door closed Leia was already back in front of her mirror, placing a few more pins and putting on her jewelry. She‚Äôd add her stole a few minutes before Obi-Wan was supposed to arrive. That and the sash should balance out the dark blues, she thought, and add the implication of the flowing impression of Jedi robes without imitating them.

As far as being dressed for battle, she was feeling mostly prepared.

‚ÄúYou look lovely.‚Äù

He didn‚Äôt need to sound so surprised. But then, Obi-Wan had gotten the first word in because he‚Äôd caught Leia staring at him. ‚ÄúThank you. You‚Äôre looking very nice yourself.‚Äù

His smile told her he knew he‚Äôd won the surprise round, but Leia counted it a victory on her part. He looked much better with short hair. And he was standing straighter too, which she wouldn‚Äôt have guessed would be a side effect.

Or maybe it was just the image he was projecting for tonight.

Either way, it looked better.

‚ÄúThank you for coming to pick me up,‚Äù she said as she grabbed her things. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a bit out of your way.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm fairly certain you‚Äôre the one doing me a favor in all this,‚Äù Obi-Wan pointed out, actually offering her his arm as they made their way to the lift. ‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt any trouble at all.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen I‚Äôm glad to be of service.‚Äù

Her dress didn‚Äôt move with the shushing silkiness she was used to, but it was comfortable and fit in a way that allowed her more freedom of movement than she had used to have at these events. Which was probably good. She‚Äôd have to work her way back into more restrictive dresses if she wanted to attend any really fancy parties.

‚ÄúAny new updates you can provide?‚Äù Obi-Wan asked as they climbed into the speeder. Leia gave him the most relevant notes she had compiled over the last week. He seemed equal parts worried and impressed. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not walking into a very advantageous situation, are we?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs partly problematic because what motivates the Core worlds is a desire to avoid more bloodshed. But for those that are leaving the Republic‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre already losing so many lives, having soldiers might actually be a benefit to them.‚Äù He sighed, moving through traffic with more caution that she would have expected. ‚ÄúThe Jedi are not an army. And we aren‚Äôt equipped to act like one.‚Äù

Leia nodded. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs probably for the best. You‚Äôre isolated enough as is. If you were full time combatants‚Ä¶‚Äù

She thought of the humanity that had been lost when people looked at her brother, seeing only the Death Star destroyer, the Emperor killer (and he hadn‚Äôt even done that one, not that anyone ever listened) and Leia mourned the opportunities that had been missed to place him where he would have excelled.

Luke would do what was necessary. But he was also forgiving, had discovered that it was healing. And that, more than anything else, had been what their new Republic had needed.

They‚Äôd sent him to be an enforcer instead. A subtle threat of what the systems would be standing against if they didn‚Äôt listen to the Alliance.

Once he‚Äôd figured it out he‚Äôd hated it, and resented that he hadn‚Äôt been told. Leia didn‚Äôt even try and claim it had all been for the best. She knew better than that.

"I didn't intend for that to be such a depressing comment," Obi-Wan remarked, and Leia gave herself a mental shake.

"No, that was me. I distracted myself.‚Äù

He didn't say anything, and Leia allowed what she assumed was a comfortable silence. His, "Do you get distracted often?" made her wonder what he was thinking.

"It depends on the situation," she admitted. "But when I'm working, I generally stay very focused."

"Not making any promises then?" he asked, and there was humor in his tone, but an undercurrent of worry that she couldn't miss.

She shifted in her seat, catching her first glimpse of the formal hall they were using, all lit up and glittering, even against the millions of lights around them. "I have done this before," she managed. "I'm just loath to make any absolute promises on anything. Life has taught me that nothing is certain."

"There is always the Force," Obi-Wan seemed to be quoting, or at least repeating a very familiar refrain. "That much is certain."

Maybe, but it wasn't much of a comfort. The Force hadn't saved Alderaan, or Han, or Luke. It hadn't even been the one to send her back. That had been‚Äî

"You really are very distracted," Obi-Wan said, and she was a little surprised by the gentleness in his tone. "I can't promise that no one will make any comments, but I can promise I will stay with you all night and help mitigate any‚Ä¶ pretensions as best I can."

It was a kind promise, if a weak one, hard to uphold. Leia steeled herself, putting as much confidence into her voice and expression as she could. ‚ÄúI really am ready for this, that much I can promise.‚Äù

More than the rest of them perhaps. She didn‚Äôt know for certain if Palpatine had organized this event in her past, if Obi-Wan Kenobi had been at it, either with someone or alone. She didn‚Äôt know the exact details or how different people would react.

But she knew it wasn‚Äôt really a stage for reconciliation, it was for sabotage. And knowing that meant she knew what tools she would need to deal with it.

Obi-Wan at least seemed reassured. ‚ÄúI am confident in your competence. Come on. Let‚Äôs see what‚Äôs going on inside.‚Äù

They left the speeder in capable hands and made their way up a long series of steps to the hall. Leia wasn‚Äôt technically breathless when they reached the top, but she had her suspicions that Kenobi had been using the Force. He was too collected when they reached the top step.

Not ideal, part of her thought, or welcoming to have so many stairs.

Inside glittered almost as much as out. The entryway was filled with delegates and guests, milling about, handing over cloaks and coats, making initial greetings, and gauging the atmosphere.

The noise immediately around them stopped when they walked in, and eyes turned towards them for a moment. Leia swallowed, breathed in a sense of invisibility and nothingness, but not too much, and met those stares with as much composure as she could manage.

Obi-Wan‚Äôs arm wasn‚Äôt linked with hers, but she felt his hand hovering near the small of her back, acting as a shield and a guide as they made their way into the part of the hall that had been set up for dinner.

The Chancellor was easy to spot at the front of the room near the head of the table, and Kenobi was clearly planning on heading that way first to make his greetings, but Leia stopped him, indicating with her eyes more than her head that they should approach Bail Organa first, and some of the guests that he was chatting with.

None of them were from the Senate.

Catching her intentions, Obi-Wan squeezed her wrist briefly, with a touch of a nod, and started moving them in that direction.

‚ÄúMaster Kenobi,‚Äù Senator Organa said when he spotted them. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a pleasure to see you this evening. May I introduce you to our friends?‚Äù

The crowd had varied reactions, some delight and relief, others suspicion, and the rest somewhere in between. Obi-Wan bowed to the company and Leia dropped a curtsy and a nod, smiling as sweetly as she knew how.

‚ÄúIt would be our pleasure, Senator Organa. Please.‚Äù

These were representatives from systems around Glee Anselm, Leia realized, and others from Felucia and its nearby systems. Around the room she could hear other names being thrown about, Christophsis, some systems she knew were near Naboo, and some places she had never heard of even.

When he had finished introducing the visiting delegates, Senator Organa said, ‚ÄúThis is Jedi Knight Obi-Wan Kenobi, and his associate, Leia Skywalker.‚Äù

His face didn‚Äôt slip, but Leia felt something plummet around Obi-Wan in the Force when he heard that name.

Shit. She‚Äôd forgotten that she hadn‚Äôt told him.

‚ÄúAssociate?‚Äù the representative from Felucia asked, eyeing Leia skeptically. He was one of the only people in the room shorter than she was.

‚ÄúAdvisor and associate,‚Äù Obi-Wan managed. To someone less familiar he sounded calm, but Senator Organa seemed to catch whatever it was in Obi-Wan‚Äôs tone that was also telling Leia the man had been badly shaken. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs one of the consultants tracking trade information around the Republic and the Jedi Council have found her advice invaluable.‚Äù

‚ÄúHave they?‚Äù the felucian blinked a few times. ‚ÄúAnd what have you learned?‚Äù

‚ÄúMany things that make us concerned,‚Äù Obi-Wan said honestly. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd appreciate hearing your perspective on how things look on the ground. Data can show patterns, but it can‚Äôt inform us in the same way as experience. And the AgriCorps aren‚Äôt in all of the systems that have a vested interest in being here tonight.‚Äù

Listening, Leia thought, trying not to blink too much in the onslaught of lights (another minor offense?) and followed that thought. These people thought no one was listening. If Kenobi was going to do something to help that worked, the Jedi would have to do something at the end of all of this.

She would have to think about that. Leia didn‚Äôt have any direct connections to the Jedi Council. Yet.

They only spoke in vague terms for a few moments before mixing with other crowds as they made their way up toward the Chancellor. People began sitting before they had quite made it, and Leia only shrugged when Obi-Wan indicated with his eyes to see if they should push forward. She had no interest in facing Sheev Palpatine tonight. But if the Jedi insisted‚Ä¶

He didn‚Äôt. Winding through the crowd, they made their way to their seats and Leia had time to curse the placements at the table.

The guests who were being influenced by the Separatists were all seated on one side, across from the Loyalists and others the Chancellor had invited. It was clear too, which of them he had been working with personally, because they were the ones seated closest to him. It would be difficult, almost impossible, for informal conversation to happen across the parties during the meal. Which meant the evening would be long when they were mingling later.

Leia groaned internally, then braced herself. She‚Äôd faced worse.

Glancing at her dinner partner as he held a chair for her, Leia wasn‚Äôt entirely sure he wouldn‚Äôt be the most difficult part of this evening.

Under Fire

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt suppose you were ever going to tell me?‚Äù

Since he‚Äôd caught her at a moment when they were both turning, kept his voice too low to carry, and hadn‚Äôt let his polite smile slip, Leia forgave Obi-Wan for his frustration as she answered, ‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt ask.‚Äù

It was a mistake, she knew. A hostile reaction to what, deep down, was a perfectly honest question. She just didn‚Äôt want to have to dance around the answer right now, and it was getting more and more difficult to avoid that.

He didn‚Äôt actually respond since they were greeting the neimoidian delegation. Hoping that the stiffness in his spine and tension all around him was more for facing the Trade Federation than her, Leia made her best effort to be professional.

She wished, distantly, that she could send him some sort of reassurance in the Force, some idea that things were going to be okay. It had always been a relief when she‚Äôd received one from her brother and had carried truth that was so easily distorted by words.

Since that wasn‚Äôt an option, Leia worked on being a polite and obscure guest.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt mean to make that so much of an accusation,‚Äù he added sometime later as they were taking a breather near one of the walls, a clear peace offering. ‚ÄúIt was just so unexpected‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI should have told you,‚Äù Leia agreed, using her cup to hide the movement of her lips. ‚ÄúIt was unkind and unprofessional not to. I‚Äôm just not sure it‚Äôs something you want to talk about. Or would find relevant.‚Äù

He seemed to juggle that for a moment, but when he couldn‚Äôt come up with an immediate answer, they dove back into the crowd, taking time with the guests around Senator Organa, and then finally making their way into a conversation with the Naboo party.

Padm√©‚Äôs head was held high, her eyes sparkling, but she seemed to be having a good time. She was in a spirited debate with one of the guests from Christophsis, asking where they expected to have a military force stationed if it was approved, and how his citizens would feel about it. Not the most diplomatic approach, but he seemed to be trying to flirt with her as he made his counterarguments, and Leia got them out as soon as she could.

They weren‚Äôt wanted as part of that conversation.

She spotted Rush Clovis as they were walking away though, eyeing Padm√© as she laughed at the most recent point and grabbed another drink for her opponent.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure how to feel about it,‚Äù Obi-Wan made his way back to their discussion again as they paused so he could help her adjust her stole after someone had nearly trampled her. ‚ÄúYou say it isn‚Äôt relevant, and I‚Äôd like to agree, but I don‚Äôt know who you are.‚Äù

The, ‚Äúand that concerns me,‚Äù was written on his face for a moment, and Leia hoped it was covered by their movements.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs simple enough to explain,‚Äù Leia said, touching her hair to make sure everything was still in place. ‚ÄúWhen we settled on Naboo, I left my old family name behind and Shmi Skywalker offered me hers. I suppose you could say I was adopted, or something like that.‚Äù

He seemed about to ask her what exactly that old family name had been, but caught himself and didn‚Äôt bring it up again until after they‚Äôd made another half circuit of the room, quelling no fewer than four arguments that looked like they might be moving beyond shouting towards violence (places Palpatine had been only a few moments before).

‚ÄúAnakin doesn‚Äôt know about you?‚Äù

‚ÄúHe has no idea that I exist,‚Äù Leia said.

That actually earned a chuckle. ‚ÄúI did mention you to him. So that is slightly untrue.‚Äù

‚ÄúAre you going to tell him?‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you want me to?‚Äù

That question sat unanswered almost all the way to the end of the evening. They actually got separated at some point, Leia liaising with Senator Darsana and the other representatives from systems around Glee Anselm while Obi-Wan was dragged away to greet someone he‚Äôd met during his time as a padawan.

Apparently, his dignity was too delicate to have her around to witness that one.

When they met up again later, she opened with, ‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt want to tell him, I don‚Äôt have an opinion one way or another. If you think he needs to know, you should tell him, and introduce him to me.‚Äù

‚ÄúI will think about it,‚Äù Obi-Wan said. ‚ÄúHis situation is so different from the other initiates. I try not to make it harder by making him think about his old life.‚Äù

His home, Leia wanted to say. His family. She didn‚Äôt like it, but she tried to understand.

(The idea of Luke being ripped away from her, never knowing where she was, never speaking to her again, didn‚Äôt settle well in her heart.)

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to make his life, or yours, more difficult.‚Äù Not directly, anyway. She wasn‚Äôt sure what the consequence would be from her actions, but she had an idea about how bad it could get.

Hypothetically.

Historically.

‚ÄúWell, I appreciate that. And will take your words under advisement.‚Äù

They were making a final round of the room, moving more than speaking to make sure things were calm, when Senator Sadashassa caught up with them, smiling at Obi-Wan and winking at Leia. ‚ÄúI see you two are keeping things under control.‚Äù

Not sure if he was ignoring the wink because he didn‚Äôt know what to do with it, or because he felt it was safer to ignore, Leia was amused when he answered, ‚ÄúWe are doing our level best.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you mind if I borrow your friend for a moment?‚Äù Shea asked him, offering an arm to Leia. ‚ÄúI have a someone I want her to meet.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù Obi-Wan stepped to the side after a look to Leia, her approval a half smile. ‚ÄúShall I come and find you, or will you find me?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôll be easier to spot,‚Äù Leia said, acknowledging that even in her shoes, which made a modest addition to her height, she wasn‚Äôt going to stand out in this crowd.

Obi-Wan moved with the usual Jedi circle of space around him.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs an interesting man,‚Äù Shea commented as they made their way around. ‚ÄúHow did you end up with him?‚Äù

‚ÄúI made a visit to the Temple and bumped into him in their gardens. Then saw him again in the Executive Building. He‚Äôd heard about my project.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo this is just a professional engagement?‚Äù

It was hard to tell, with all the ambient noise, how much teasing there was in that statement. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt think Jedi had another type.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not that naive,‚Äù Shea was teasing now. ‚ÄúThough it is hard to manage with most of them.‚Äù

‚ÄúProfessional,‚Äù Leia stated, deciding she didn‚Äôt want to encourage this particular topic. ‚ÄúStrictly, entirely professional.‚Äù

‚ÄúNoted.‚Äù

They approached a visitor from Ryloth who Shea introduced as Cham Syndulla. He greeted Leia rather stiffly as she was introduced as the Jedi‚Äôs dinner companion from Naboo. She didn‚Äôt take it personally. Syndulla was side eyeing everyone in the room.

‚ÄúCham, this is my friend I told you about. She‚Äôs been working on the report regarding the Trade Federations deals, and how they‚Äôre impacting certain system economies. Leia, could you give him your perspective on Ryloth‚Äôs situation?‚Äù

It was hard to keep back the sentiment of, ‚ÄúYour senator is sabotaging your people to get in with a Sith Lord Emperor,‚Äù but Leia managed and said, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt mind sharing my observations. Could you help me correct any points where you notice errors? Data doesn‚Äôt tell me everything.‚Äù

His lekku twitched slightly, and his answering smile was almost a sneer, but Syndulla said, ‚ÄúCertainly, I will offer any corrections.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood. Because the outlook I‚Äôm getting from the data is a non-viable situation for Ryloth in the long term, and I would like to know if I‚Äôm missing any mitigating factors, or need to list it as a most urgent priority.‚Äù

He didn‚Äôt like that, not the mention that his planet might be weak. He was a fighter, Leia saw. Even if he didn‚Äôt regularly see combat, he was willing to fight how things were if he didn‚Äôt like them.

She hoped she could win him over. It would be the thrill of a lifetime if Syndulla or one of his associates could overthrow Orn Free Ta.

‚ÄúWhat do you mean, non-viable situation?‚Äù he asked, and his frown deepened and deepened as she told him. After the second time Shea interrupted to compare Ryloth‚Äôs situation to Herdessa, Leia made a conscious effort to add those comparisons herself, as well as other similar systems. She wasn‚Äôt sure if it was to make him feel less exposed, or just not alone in his situation, but ultimately it didn‚Äôt matter. Leia trusted Shea‚Äôs judgement.

Syndulla was still frowning when she finished. ‚ÄúThat is,‚Äù he hesitated, ‚Äúnot an inaccurate picture of our situation. Ryloth is a healthy mixture of some large cities and many more rural areas. They do not suffer from want naturally‚Äî‚Äú

He had to pause, and Leia watched various veins twitching as he looked around the room, spotted Orn Free Ta next to the Chancellor, and the several women that were in attendance around them.

Well, it was marginally harder to run out of resources if you kept shipping large chunks of your population off planet as slaves.

‚ÄúIt is unequal,‚Äù he finally stated. ‚ÄúEntry into the Republic has made many desire a Republic, a Core Republic style of living. Some,‚Äù his eyes shot towards Senator Free Ta again, ‚Äúmore than others. We are import heavy, and when basic necessities become too expensive to ship in from off planet, then we begin to drain our people dry. And our people have only so much to give. Ryloth is a tumultuous planet.‚Äù

Thinking of the bare wasteland of Tatooine, Leia could understand the problem only too well. ‚ÄúRyloth is against the creation of a Republic Army?‚Äù

There was a serious shifting of unease. ‚ÄúThere are lanes of traffic around and through our planet that do not meet Republic standards,‚Äù he admitted. What a novel way of saying black market slave and spice lines. ‚ÄúThere could be further imbalance if the people of Ryloth had to station troops to deal with those problems.‚Äù

‚ÄúSurely pirates and smugglers make fair trade for Ryloth more difficult as well?‚Äù Leia checked, wondering exactly where Syndulla stood in all of this. She worried it was with the planet generally, not with the Republic, or even all of Ryloth‚Äôs people.

‚ÄúThey do,‚Äù he agreed. ‚ÄúIt is a difficult problem to sort out. And not everyone is interested in trying.‚Äù

His eyes didn‚Äôt go to the twi‚Äôlek senator again, but Leia could tell it took an effort. She let Shea excuse them and take her back to Obi-Wan, pondering the mess that was the Outer Rim.

All in all, when the evening had finished, Leia could only feel that she had made one new ally. And as he had been one she‚Äôd nearly lost, she counted that as a mixed success.

‚ÄúDid you have a good time?‚Äù Eirta√© asked as she slipped over, leaving Padm√© saying goodnight to the Chancellor and Senator Organa. ‚ÄúYou look like you‚Äôve had a night of it.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll have to see how productive it was,‚Äù Leia murmured, keeping her eyes on the groups slowly making their way toward the doors. No one seemed to be looking forward to those steps. ‚ÄúDid you have a good evening?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt was nice to be invited,‚Äù Eirta√© answered, gesturing to Leia and Obi-Wan to follow her back towards Padm√©. ‚ÄúNormally we wouldn‚Äôt be part of this kind of event. And I do think it will end up being very productive. If the senator doesn‚Äôt get herself kidnapped for her impertinence.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs taken a very strong stand on the anti-military creation side of things,‚Äù Obi-Wan pointed out, his hands clasped behind his back. ‚ÄúShe could make more than a few personal enemies that way.‚Äù

Eirta√© nodded. ‚ÄúWe know. She always does, when she gets like this. But I don‚Äôt think telling her that will encourage her to stop. She believes courage and resolution are the tools for moments like that, not the byproducts of surviving them.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe a little of both,‚Äù Leia suggested, making a half bow and a formal wave to Senator Darsana as he and his aide left. ‚ÄúAlthough, I‚Äôm not sure it‚Äôs good to tell her that either.‚Äù

‚ÄúTell me what?‚Äù Padm√© demanded with a smile as she approached them, accepting a nod from Obi-Wan with one of her own. ‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt do something drastic, did you?‚Äù

‚ÄúShe was perfectly well behaved,‚Äù Obi-Wan promised, falling into step next to them. ‚ÄúThank you for lending her to me for the evening. She was very put together and very insightful.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd she didn‚Äôt get completely drunk and collapse over anyone,‚Äù Dorm√© added, her narrowed eyes flashing over to where Senator Orn Free Ta was having words with Mas Amedda.

‚ÄúShe did not do that,‚Äù Obi-Wan agreed cheerfully.

They debated a little whether Obi-Wan should take her back, but decided it just wasn‚Äôt practical. Most of the guests they were concerned about had already left, and they hadn‚Äôt made it a secret that Leia was technically from Naboo.

And it was late. Leia felt bad for keeping the Jedi up longer than needed.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt mind,‚Äù he was saying as they had made their way halfway down the steps. ‚ÄúNot that I think you‚Äôre wrong, but‚Äî‚Äú

It was a flash like pain all over her skin, like lightning, and Leia moved before she had completely thought about it, slamming into Padm√© and knocking them both sideways as they tumbled and slid down a few stairs, the sound of something tearing almost drowned out by someone‚Äôs scream and the sound of a blaster bolt slamming into the stone.

Before she could get her bearings, or even process how badly she was hurt, Leia was being moved, lifted and almost dragged, and it was hard to tell if it was actually the speed or her roaring head that was making everything blur as it moved past her.

‚Äú‚Äîhere!‚Äù she almost caught what had to be Obi-Wan shouting before he dove out from behind the statue, his lightsaber a cobalt blaze in the darkness, blurring with absurd speed as he covered the other guests who were ducking behind that statues lining the stairway.

Everything seemed to slow around her as Leia forced herself to watch him, to trace the shots to a building that seemed almost impossibly far away. She should go out there, be with him, he shouldn‚Äôt be alone‚Äî

‚ÄúLeia!‚Äù

Gasping, Leia collapsed against the stone base hiding them, trembling as she pulled her eyes from Obi-Wan and found Dorm√©‚Äôs gaze. She was helped down slowly, two bodies pressing on either side of her, Padm√© to her left and Dorm√© to her right.

‚Äú‚Äîcalled the security officers?‚Äù Padm√© was asking, both arms pulling Leia against her, watching Dorm√© handle her comms while keeping half an eye on Obi-Wan. The shots seemed to have stopped, but his saber was still drawn, and he kept ordering people to stay down, to wait for an all clear.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre working on it,‚Äù Eirta√© promised, and Leia felt some of the feeling coming back into her fingers, warmth creeping towards her toes. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôve got the Chancellor on lockdown inside.‚Äù

Anger seethed, and Leia had to swallow it over and over. This. This had his name all over it.

How dare he?

It was only a few minutes before several more Jedi had arrived and began escorting the remaining parties to their vehicles as Coruscant security set up ground perimeters and coordinated the chase for the shooter. Leia didn‚Äôt say anything, just listened, trying to slow her breathing and not to lose track of time again.

‚ÄúSenator Amidala,‚Äù Obi-Wan rejoined them, kneeling. There was a scorch mark on the shoulder of his new robe and Leia wanted to cry when she saw it, couldn‚Äôt stop herself from reaching out and brushing her fingers across it.

He covered her hand with his and smiled so, so kindly. ‚ÄúI guess this one will have to retire from the diplomatic core. Think they‚Äôll let me go with it?‚Äù

Giggling, Leia shook her head. ‚ÄúNo chance. No one died tonight. I think you‚Äôll be stuck with it.‚Äù

He made a face at her words, but she felt his relief. He squeezed her fingers one more time, then moved her hand back to her knees. ‚ÄúI think we‚Äôre going to wait until some of the other buildings have been cleared before we try moving you, Senator Amidala. They didn‚Äôt seem too concerned with hitting other targets, but I‚Äôm pretty sure‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI‚Äôm the one they wanted,‚Äù she agreed. Glanced at Leia. ‚ÄúDo you think we‚Äôll be here long? We could use some blankets.‚Äù

Without any hesitation, he shrugged out of his robe and tucked it around Padm√© and Leia. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm afraid you‚Äôll have to make do with this for now. But I‚Äôll see what I can do. Hopefully even if we can‚Äôt move you away, we can at least get you back inside for the evening.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaster!‚Äù

Leia felt everything wrench. The warmth that had been returning fled, and she froze with it. Her breathing almost stopped, she was sure her heart tripped. It was hard to make out his features clearly in the backlight, but Obi-Wan was already moving towards him, almost groaning, ‚ÄúAnakin, you‚Äôre supposed to be‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre under attack!‚Äù he didn‚Äôt let Obi-Wan finish, was almost looming over his teacher in his frustration and anxiety.

And Leia felt it. Felt everything. He hadn‚Äôt been there, and now suddenly he was, slamming against her senses in every possible way and she was‚Äî

(Cold and grey and white and red and black, that steady breathing that kept stealing her oxygen, that pressure on her mind, needling for her secrets, something in her body, in her system, willing her, urging her to talk)

‚Äînot going to throw up, not here. Dorm√© was in a half crouch, keeping herself a barrier between this new stranger and her charges. Leia hid in that shadow, pulling in and in and in on herself, until even she wasn‚Äôt sure she hadn‚Äôt completely faded away.

‚Äú ‚Äîknow you‚Äôre concerned, but I have everything under control. You need to let go of your anxieties, Anakin.‚Äù

‚ÄúAni?‚Äù

All that pressure, that focus, snapped from seething across her senses, sharpened and slammed into Padm√© and Leia couldn‚Äôt believe her friend was still standing. Hadn‚Äôt even noticed. ‚ÄúPadm√©?‚Äù

It shouldn‚Äôt have been possible to find more dread, but in that moment, it was all Leia could feel at all. The reverence in that tone was so poignant and demanding she wanted to scream (not you, not you, not you!), but could only manage to watch as Padm√© stood, moving towards Dorm√©, who was not happy.

It just wasn‚Äôt fair.

‚ÄúYou need to stay under cover, my lady,‚Äù the woman was telling Padm√©, and the worry all around her snapped Anakin out of his staring, making him reach out and try to sense any possible danger around them. He felt his master‚Äôs irritation building, but thankfully Obi-Wan had stopped trying to say that Anakin shouldn‚Äôt be here.

As if he could be anywhere else when Padm√© and Obi-Wan were in trouble.

‚ÄúWho did this?‚Äù Anakin demanded, turning to his master, knowing he was seething in the Force and trying and trying and trying to swallow it. ‚ÄúWhere are they?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe security force is tracking the shooter,‚Äù Obi-Wan said, trying to be firm and calm and Anakin hated it. He wasn‚Äôt a child, they were in danger, he had to do something‚Äî ‚ÄúWe were trying to set up a clear path to move Senator Amidala and her handmaidens back into the building. They‚Äôll be with the Chancellor in there, and have better security.‚Äù

Something wrenched in the Force and Anakin felt his eyes being pulled back to Padm√©, who was nodding at Obi-Wan‚Äôs words. But, but that was wrong. What he‚Äôd felt, it was so strong. Would they be safe with the Chancellor?

‚ÄúAre we sure we should move them?‚Äù

Obi-Wan‚Äôs anger was starting to leak out in more than just the Force. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs freezing out here, Anakin,‚Äù it wasn‚Äôt, but Padm√© was shivering, probably shock more than, ‚Äúthere‚Äôs nothing comfortable for them to rest on, and the entrance isn‚Äôt that far away. There‚Äôs no reason to leave them.‚Äù

Unless moving them would make one of them dead. It couldn‚Äôt be Padm√©, Anakin wouldn‚Äôt allow that. And she‚Äôd be hurt if she lost one of her friends. They needed a better plan. ‚ÄúCan‚Äôt we move them somewhere else? A secure enough transport won‚Äôt buckle to a couple of sniper shots.‚Äù

‚ÄúLike what?‚Äù Obi-Wan demanded as Anakin already found himself smiling. ‚ÄúPadawan, no.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôll be a good opportunity to give it another test run,‚Äù he tried. ‚ÄúAnd the shields are more than enough‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a space vessel, not a ground transport‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúIt‚Äôll work‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúAnd we don‚Äôt have the licenses to fly it in the city,‚Äù Obi-Wan threw that down with a sternness that said he wasn‚Äôt budging on the subject, no matter how unreasonable he was being. ‚ÄúAnakin, I know you want to help, but right now there are more practical solutions we can see to. Please try to be in the here and now.‚Äù

Normally he would have argued, but Anakin glanced up and saw Padm√©, saw that she was bruised, that she was worried, and he swallowed his first words to force out, ‚ÄúYes, Master.‚Äù

It didn‚Äôt make Obi-Wan completely relax, but some of the tension left. Anakin took it for as good as it was going to get for where things currently stood. ‚ÄúThank you. Now, will you go help Master Windu and see if we‚Äôre safe to move them?‚Äù

Rolling his eyes to hide the unease those words brought, Anakin still nodded, managed a bow when he got a raised brow, and took off up the steps to that tightly wound presence in the Force that was Master Windu.

This was just not his night. And if he didn‚Äôt hurry, he might not get to really see Padm√©.

‚ÄúHe got taller.‚Äù

When she spoke, Padm√© voice only trembled once. Obi-Wan came back over to help her sit down again and get tucked back under the robe Leia was now hoarding. ‚ÄúHe did shoot up quite a bit. It‚Äôs always a little disappointing when I meet another person who insists on being taller than me all the time.‚Äù

This time his joke didn‚Äôt bring anything more than a mild smile from anyone, but Eirta√© said, ‚ÄúHe must have been very worried about you. He came here very fast.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe was supposed to stay in the Temple,‚Äù Obi-Wan objected, but there wasn‚Äôt a lot of strength to it. ‚ÄúI suppose he had to get permission to come, since this zone is blocked off, but the whole point was that he wasn‚Äôt supposed to come.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe can‚Äôt be that much of a disaster,‚Äù Eirta√© objected.

Before Obi-Wan could make any snide or sincere remark, Leia managed, ‚ÄúHe loves you. He couldn‚Äôt leave you behind.‚Äù

The degree of shock that poured off of Obi-Wan at those words, even for the briefest moment, was almost startling enough to make Leia retreat again, but she held her ground. Whatever was wrong with her was fading, and she couldn‚Äôt keep whimpering like this. ‚ÄúJedi are forbidden to have attachments,‚Äù Obi-Wan crossed his arms as he crouched, like he was trying to not reach for his beard.

‚ÄúSo they can‚Äôt care?‚Äù Leia demanded, flabbergasted. ‚ÄúNot even about their teachers being in danger? Or unprotected? Abandoned?‚Äù

Apparently this was the night for Leia to keep toppling Obi-Wan Kenobi. He almost smoothly managed, ‚ÄúNo. No we don‚Äôt expect our students not to care. Or to‚Ä¶ leave us. Behind.‚Äù

A flash of yellow and red eyes, a black and red face, a man falling to the ground, and Leia had a sudden feeling of clarity as to how she had done this.

Deep breath, cool night air in, warm air out. Ignore the slightly acid taste now curling on her tongue. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry. I didn‚Äôt mean to accuse. I just‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs hard not to care when the people closest to you are in danger. And you could have been hurt.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt,‚Äù he pointed out, and Leia allowed herself to try a look she knew her mother had used on her countless times. With a hint of Shmi thrown in.
