It worked. ‚ÄúWell, it was nothing serious in any case. More wounded pride than anything. I‚Äôm honestly shocked you were able to respond so quickly. How did you see it?‚Äù

He seemed genuinely surprised, and Leia had no idea how to answer. Because she hadn‚Äôt seen anything, she‚Äôd just felt it. The moment when a pending storm had crashed. And she wasn‚Äôt going to lose anything else.

Thankfully, she didn‚Äôt have to answer. A Jedi, probably the aforementioned Master Windu, came back with a sulking Anakin in tow and said they‚Äôd been approved a transport to take Senator Amidala to the security force offices for statements.

It would be a long night, but at least Leia could keep that secret.

Chapter End Notes

There you have it. Leia has met Anakin Skywalker.

Reunion

Shmi Skywalker was a force to be reckoned with.

‚ÄúWhat do you mean, she got shot at?‚Äù The Tatooine woman was standing with her arms crossed, glaring at Captain Typho with a seriousness that had the man flustered if not outright trembling. Leia, curled up next to the senator on the couch, sipped at her tea and enjoyed the show, only mildly interested in the conflict.

‚ÄúShe wasn‚Äôt seriously hurt,‚Äù that hadn‚Äôt been Captain Typho‚Äôs line last night when they‚Äôd finally made it back from giving their statements. He‚Äôd been much more upset then, demanding to know why he hadn‚Äôt been allowed to come and what the senate was planning to do as far as increasing security. ‚ÄúThe Jedi was there and he took care of things.‚Äù

Sure he did, Leia thought, taking another sip and enjoying the shifts that she knew were Padm√© suppressing laughter. Obi-Wan had taken care of everything. Once he had realized there was danger.

(And Leia was not thinking about that, and what it meant, and how in that moment Padm√©‚Äôs life had rested on her and the Force.)

‚ÄúDo you,‚Äù Shmi demanded, ‚Äúhave any idea how utterly inconceivable it is that the senator was fired on in such a way, and under such circumstances, and no one had any idea that it could happen?‚Äù

Which was an interesting point in two ways. One, there really should have been some sort of warning in a posted bounty or information gathered by spies. A threatening note or contact would probably have been a bit much, but killing Padm√© without any warning meant it wasn‚Äôt obvious what kind of statement was being made. And two, Shmi was enough aware of the social and political maneuvering to see that there was something wrong about it.

Leia wasn‚Äôt sure which concerned her more.

Dorm√© came forward, putting a hand on Shmi‚Äôs arm. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre working on finding out what caused the oversight. Would you like to come and sit down? Join us for breakfast?‚Äù

Her bag was still sitting by the door, and it looked like Shmi hadn‚Äôt slept yet. Leia knew her grandmother had gotten on a ship the moment word had reached Naboo that the senator‚Äôs party was under fire, and she‚Äôd been in the air by the time security had set up a perimeter at the dinner hall. They‚Äôd gotten back to a call from Ruwee promising that home was on the way and as soon as he had things under control with the RRM, he and Jobal would be coming too.

Padm√© was still working on dissuading her parents without admitting that having them nearby could be a further security risk.

Once everyone was seated around the table, Threepio arrived with food, exclaiming happily when he saw Shmi and begging her to tell everyone to be more careful. ‚ÄúI really don‚Äôt think they‚Äôre nearly enough concerned about this,‚Äù he whined. At Artoo‚Äôs beeps, he snapped, ‚ÄúYes I know you think you‚Äôre clever, but you are not enough to protect them if someone has a blaster!‚Äù

‚ÄúDid you find out if they have a name for the shooter?‚Äù Leia asked the astromech, earning a look from Captain Typho that she ignored. ‚ÄúIt would be a big help in figuring out who might have hired them.‚Äù

The series of beeps was a clear negative, but Threepio translated, ‚ÄúHe hasn‚Äôt been able to get access to the security reports yet, but he‚Äôs still trying. He does say that there aren‚Äôt any clear bounties posted that he can find.‚Äù

Well, so much for that being easy.

‚ÄúWe are investigating‚Äî‚Äú Captain Typho began, but Dorm√© cut him off.

‚ÄúI think we should table this discussion until after breakfast, Captain. Would you please make sure things are still quiet downstairs?‚Äù

Apartment management was not thrilled that they had an active political target determined to stay in the building. Building security was only being nominally cooperative. Still, better than nothing.

They‚Äôd made their way through most of the meal and were catching up on more mundane topics when the door slid open and there was a cheerful, ‚ÄúWell this looks cozy.‚Äù

Leia smiled at Obi-Wan, carefully not focusing on the boy standing next to him, almost vibrating as he tried to contain his emotions. Her own feelings were swinging. In one second, Shmi was going to turn around and‚Äî

Something lurched in the Force again, twisting as Shmi stood, Anakin‚Äôs reaction registering first, Obi-Wan a step behind as he noticed his padawan‚Äôs feelings twist.

‚ÄúMom?‚Äù

There was the barest pause, the shortest glance towards Obi-Wan, before Shmi answered, ‚ÄúAnakin.‚Äù

In a blink he was across the room, yanking her across the couch to pull her into a hug, squeezing her so tight Leia wasn‚Äôt sure he wouldn‚Äôt break her.

(There was a feeling in the room, so old and familiar and so not what she was looking for that it ached and stretched and she couldn‚Äôt breathe and, ‚ÄúProbably the only one who can help you actually fix everything.‚Äù)

Obi-Wan‚Äôs faint protest of, ‚ÄúAnakin‚Ä¶‚Äù trailed off as he looked around, seeing everyone else‚Äôs faces. He looked back to his padawan as a choked sob came out, as Shmi murmured into her son‚Äôs cheek, placing kisses there and wrapping her arms around him, stroking his hair as a few tears escaped.

‚ÄúAni, oh Ani, you‚Äôre so big now.‚Äù

‚ÄúMom,‚Äù he managed, but seemed to be stuck there.

She tried to absorb the happiness, to bask in it, and in the relief. But all Leia could feel, beyond it all was a sense of everything being so fundamentally unfair. She wanted her brother and all she was getting, all she had gotten‚Äî

‚ÄúAnd don‚Äôt look back.‚Äù

If she cried a little, she could blame it on being happy for Shmi. It would be a lie, but it was one she could hold as a shield, protecting what was left of her heart, trying not to let it break.

She was almost under control again when Anakin finally looked up, and suddenly all she could see were Luke‚Äôs eyes.

Promises, Promises

Obi-Wan Kenobi looked incredibly uncomfortable, and Leia could only sympathize with him. Anakin wasn‚Äôt curled around his mother anymore, but he was seated right next to her, his whole attention focused on her when it wasn‚Äôt pulled away for brief moments by Padm√©. He was practically glowing in the Force, swimming in happiness, and if that wasn‚Äôt overwhelming all by itself (and sitting on the same couch, Obi-Wan had to find it at least a little overwhelming), there was also the practical implications of the meeting.

When he looked over at her, hopelessness in his eyes, Leia could only shrug at the Jedi Knight, offering as much apology in that movement as she could.

In her defense, their conversation last night had been a pretty timely warning, all things considered.

‚ÄúAnd that was how we made it to Naboo,‚Äù Shmi told her son. Leia noticed her grandmother had skipped over a lot of details regarding Leia‚Äôs arrival at the Lars‚Äôs farm. Which was how she preferred it. ‚ÄúPadm√© took us to meet her family, and we settled in at Theed. I‚Äôve been doing work with the Refugee Relief Movement. They‚Äôve been making some procedural changes, and have found some of my experience to be a help.‚Äù

So much of an understatement it was almost completely a lie, but Anakin didn‚Äôt seem to notice. He was just smiling, squeezing his mother‚Äôs hand, shaking his head. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm so glad you got out of there. I‚ÄîI‚Äôm sorry I didn‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúAni,‚Äù Shmi‚Äôs hand came up to his cheek, and she waited until he was meeting her eyes again. ‚ÄúYou are not responsible for saving everyone. You are not even responsible for saving me. I am so glad to see you again, and I would have been just as glad if I had seen you on Tatooine or on any other planet. You are my gift, and my love. And I would never blame you for anything that happened to me. I never have.‚Äù

He had to pause before he could say, ‚ÄúI know. But I promised.‚Äù

There was a weight to the word that tugged at Leia‚Äôs heart, made her think about how some promises took more than one lifetime to fulfill. It was Shmi who answered, ‚ÄúYou said we would see each other again. And we have. And that, Ani, was the only thing I ever truly wanted.‚Äù

It was so hard to parse how much of that was the truth, Leia realized. There were probably a lot of things that Shmi thought about, saw as ideal, dreamed might happen, saw as a fulfillment of hope. But she seemed to be careful about allowing herself to experience wanting. She had been deprived of so much, to see the world constantly from a perspective of things she didn‚Äôt have would have been a crushing weight. One she chose not to carry, not allowing herself to collapse under the misery.

Leia wished she could think like that. It would make it easier to handle her own grief. She knew exactly what she wanted, and (even more than Shmi Skywalker) she knew it was something she could never have.

After a few moments of letting that comment settle, Padm√© managed, ‚ÄúWas there a reason you came here, Master Kenobi?‚Äù

Sitting up and pulling himself together, the Jedi said, ‚ÄúYes. We had hoped we could go over your statements from yesterday, since they won‚Äôt be released to the Temple for another couple of days. We want to make sure we aren‚Äôt missing anything as we help with the investigation. And,‚Äù he added, glancing over to Leia, ‚Äúwe wanted to make sure that you were alright.‚Äù

It was hard to feel his concern under the flood of emotions pouring off of Anakin, but Leia did notice it. ‚ÄúI think we‚Äôre doing as well as can be expected.‚Äù

He nodded, but didn‚Äôt seemed reassured by the comment. Which actually gave Leia hope. At least he understood how serious this really was.

She looked to Padm√© who said, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre ready to offer anything that will help. Who would you like to go first?‚Äù

‚ÄúLeia, if you don‚Äôt mind,‚Äù Obi-Wan started, but they were interrupted by Captain Typho.

‚ÄúThe Chancellor is trying to reach you, mi‚Äôlady. Something about his condolences, and whether they should expect you at the senate today.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course I‚Äôm going,‚Äù Padm√© stood as she spoke. ‚ÄúWhy would they think I wouldn‚Äôt be coming?‚Äù

‚ÄúI really couldn‚Äôt say,‚Äù the captain answered, gesturing out of the room. ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôd like to ask the Chancellor‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sorry,‚Äù she said to the Jedi. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know how long this will take. If you don‚Äôt mind waiting‚Ä¶‚Äù

Obi-Wan at least minded. He seemed aware that a long fight could be coming. ‚ÄúWe can always wait for the official reports if you‚Äôre busy,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe wouldn‚Äôt want to interfere with Senate business.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe can contact the security force and request copies of our statements,‚Äù Leia suggested, preferring that to having her experiences poked at by someone who might actually notice when she was avoiding things. ‚ÄúAnd forward them on to the Temple, if that would be helpful.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt would,‚Äù Obi-Wan was clearly relieved as he also stood. Anakin didn‚Äôt immediately follow, until his mother started standing as well. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre sorry to have caught you at such a bad time.‚Äù

That one seemed to stump Padm√© as she glanced at Anakin and Shmi, and it was Cord√© that answered, ‚ÄúWe appreciate all your help last night, and you coming by today. We‚Äôre sure the Jedi are also very busy right now, searching for the shooter. We‚Äôll cooperate in any way that we can.‚Äù

It was moments like those when Leia realize why Cord√© was the first choice as body double for Padm√©.

Obi-Wan bowed, and Anakin reluctantly followed suit. ‚ÄúIf you can forward the reports, that will be a great help. I will keep you informed if the Council has any other requests, or if we discover anything else we can do to help. Anakin?‚Äù

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù the padawan said to the group at large. To Padm√©, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad that you‚Äôre okay, Senator.‚Äù And then, to his mother, ‚ÄúMom, I‚Äî‚Äú

She wrapped him in another hug, a short one this time, holding his arms as she stepped back. ‚ÄúYou have responsibilities at the Temple,‚Äù she said calmly, no shame or regret in her voice. ‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôm needed back on Naboo, when this is finished.‚Äù

We might not see each other again, Leia heard her saying. Not for a long time.

Anakin didn‚Äôt look happy about it, but he did nod, holding his mother‚Äôs shoulders and bending to touch his forehead to hers. ‚ÄúI know. I‚ÄîI‚Äôm so glad to see you.‚Äù

He was choking a bit, but Shmi didn‚Äôt say anything, just let him stay there until his breaths were even again and Leia could feel the atmosphere of the room pulling back in around him, still thick with his emotions, but more contained. When he finally stood, Obi-Wan was looking relieved.

‚ÄúI love you, Ani,‚Äù Shmi said, kissing his cheek. ‚ÄúI think‚ÄîI know we are going to see each other again. That is my promise.‚Äù

And one she felt she could keep. Anakin noticed that, smiled, and stepped back, looking slightly guiltily at his teacher. ‚ÄúMaster, I‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúThese last two days have been full of surprises,‚Äù Obi-Wan said, quickly and to the room at large. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure we‚Äôll all have plenty of things to discuss in the days to come.‚Äù

He couldn‚Äôt quite meet Shmi‚Äôs eyes as he said it.

Leia was confident if there were things to discuss, he was hoping that Shmi wouldn‚Äôt be part of them. She couldn‚Äôt blame him. Anakin turned around three times to glance back at his mother as he left.

It was two hours later when Padm√© finally came out of the room, cheeks flushed and eyes snapping. ‚ÄúHe tried to ban me from the senate building,‚Äù she was almost growling. ‚ÄúTo say it wasn‚Äôt safe for me to be there. If the senate isn‚Äôt safe, then where am I supposed to be?‚Äù

Leia came up with a pretty short list of answers, but didn‚Äôt like or mention any of them.

Dorm√© went to work soothing the senator while Captain Typho tried to discuss what the arrangements would be for getting everyone to work. Leia had already made calls to the security force and was on hold with the Temple, trying to find the best way to forward the data. She was almost tempted to go to the senate and just grab the first Jedi she saw there.

‚ÄúDo you know what you are doing today?‚Äù Cord√© asked Leia as the others debated.

Leia shrugged. ‚ÄúI figured I would head to the Executive Building once we have security settled. I wanted to get notes written up on everything I learned last night so that I can compare it to our data as soon as possible.‚Äù

She knew she‚Äôd been sabotaged from being able to show it to the general committee, but her personal relationships were developing enough that she felt she could reach out to Shea and Senator Darsana and a few others and present her ideas. She could probably get Padm√© to lure Senator Onaconda into a meeting as well.

Cord√© tapped her fingers on her leg a few times before she answered. ‚ÄúDo we know that Padm√© was the intended target?‚Äù

She had said it quietly, but she‚Äôd also caught a lull in the general conversation and now all eyes in the room were on Leia. Who was not happy with this sudden turn. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm fairly certain I wasn‚Äôt the one being shot at,‚Äù she said, trying to recall the memory of that moment more clearly. Her eyes hadn‚Äôt really been the sense at work, so it was difficult to say anything for certain.

‚ÄúIf you go in,‚Äù Padm√© said, ‚Äúyou‚Äôre coming and leaving with us. And you should probably stay in our office as well.‚Äù

‚ÄúYour office has windows,‚Äù Leia objected. ‚ÄúMine doesn‚Äôt.‚Äù Never mind that Padm√© would be spending most of her day in the Senate building.

‚ÄúBail is setting up a temporary office in one of the conference rooms. Hopefully it will only be like that for today. They should be making headway on finding the shooter.‚Äù

But not necessarily finding the person that hired them. Or if they had any allies, or worked on a team. Or anything else that was relevant and pertinent.

It was hard to guess how much of this she ought to say, and how much they were already aware of, but weren‚Äôt stating.

‚ÄúWould it be helpful for me to come,‚Äù Shmi asked, ‚Äúor better if I stayed here?‚Äù

That created a whole other layer of uncertainty that shifted its way around the room. Dorm√© said, ‚ÄúI was planning on staying here. We‚Äôre all lacking sleep, and we need at least one of us thinking clearly. It will safest for Shmi to stay here with me. The fewer potential targets the security officers need to watch, the easier it will be.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen I will stay too,‚Äù Shmi accepted. ‚ÄúAnd I will try and contact Ruwee and suggest he stay where he is. It sounds like it will be easier if he and your mother are not present.‚Äù

‚ÄúRemind them that the Senate will be out on recess soon,‚Äù Eirta√© suggested. ‚ÄúAny extra measures we have to take will only be temporary. We‚Äôll all be coming home.‚Äù

Which sounded nice, but wasn‚Äôt something they could actually promise. Still, Leia held out hope. The level of panic (not worry, worry made sense) over one assassination attempt was a little jarring to her, and she was more surprised at Palpatine making such a public move over it. Then again, he seemed to be hovering over the whole Separatist conflict, claiming a supervisory role and sticking his hands into things at every turn.

Which, knowing his real objective, wasn‚Äôt surprising at all. But did create the image, for those not in the know, of him being maybe too idealistic and incompetent.

It was fascinating in a horrifying sort of way.

Once the plans were finished, Leia went to help Shmi unpack and to show her where everything was in the room. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù she said once they were finished. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt realize Obi-Wan was coming. Or that he would bring Anakin. I should have given you some sort of warning.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sorry to have met my son,‚Äù Shmi pointed out. ‚ÄúAnd you are no more responsible than he is for protecting me.‚Äù When Leia would have objected, Shmi pressed on, ‚ÄúIt was a pleasant surprise, Leia. I‚Äôm sorry that his Jedi master was so uncomfortable to see me, but based on my son‚Äôs reaction, it was necessary. And as his mother, I wouldn‚Äôt have it any other way. He may not need me forever, but he needs me now, and‚Ä¶‚Äù

Her gaze drifted out the window, lingering on the lines of traffic flowing between the buildings. Leia put a hand on her shoulder. ‚ÄúIt was meant to be like this.‚Äù

Shmi shook her head, ‚ÄúNot exactly. There are so many ways things could be Leia. We can never know which is the right one. Or that one is the number of paths that could be right. Maybe there are dozens, hundreds of worlds and lives and choices where I never did get to see my son again and he still became a wonderful and happy person. But here and now, I have seen him, and I am his mother, and I will do what I think is right. Because that is what I have to live with.‚Äù

It made a lot more sense, Leia thought, than destiny (or some ‚Äúall powerful Force‚Äù) the way that Shmi put it. Especially from a perspective of doing it all again.

Although it was hard to see a world that Shmi imagined, because as far as Leia knew, her biological father hadn‚Äôt ever gone back to see his mother, and there was nothing about Darth Vader that Leia would claim was right.

‚ÄúThere is a place you can put your anger. I can show you.‚Äù

She shook off that thought, and the memories that came with it, focusing on the here and the now. ‚ÄúI am glad that you got to see him. That was what I promised,‚Äù Leia pointed out.

There was a brief smile before Shmi leaned in and placed a kiss on Leia‚Äôs cheek. ‚ÄúYou did. And in spite of our change of plans, you kept that promise. I just hope, next time, you‚Äôre able to keep it and we can avoid putting anyone in mortal danger.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat would be novel,‚Äù Leia found herself saying before she could think better of it.

Shmi raised her brow, but didn‚Äôt say anything in response. Somehow, Leia had the feeling her grandmother understood.

That wasn‚Äôt really how Skywalkers did things.

Attentive

‚ÄúAre you here alone?‚Äù

Leia looked up from her work, not smiling but trying not to show her frustration to the Jedi Knight. ‚ÄúThis is my office. I am working in it.‚Äù

‚ÄúI meant‚Ä¶ sometimes you have guests.‚Äù Obi-Wan shuffled slightly, looking younger than Leia would have expected.

She couldn‚Äôt help it, her eyes narrowed. ‚ÄúYou thought Shmi would be here.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚ÄîThe thought did cross my mind.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe got shot at last night. She‚Äôs safer where she is.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äù was a loose term. Leia was fairly certain by now that Padm√© had been the only real target. Although she wasn‚Äôt sure why. Frankly, Senator Organa would have made a better one, he was the public face of their movement. Padm√© was certainly outspoken, Senator Onaconda one of the most senior members, Senator Mon Mothma from a system that carried more weight than some of her colleges. But Alderaan falling would have sent the most direct message as to how dangerous and risky these negotiations were going to be.

So why Padm√©?

Obi-Wan took a seat, not waiting for permission. Leia considered being offended, and then realized it meant he trusted her and thought he was welcome. She wouldn‚Äôt jeopardize that, especially not with, ‚ÄúAnakin thought we should volunteer to escort you all home.‚Äù

There was a careful irony in the tone, as if he was inviting her to share a joke. But she could see he didn‚Äôt find it very funny. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs probably unwise to draw more attention to ourselves at this point. And counterproductive to what we are trying to do with the negotiations.‚Äù

‚ÄúI did mention that. And that Padm√© wouldn‚Äôt appreciate it if we damaged what she‚Äôs been working on.‚Äù

His humor was more real this time, and Leia allowed herself a smile, shivering a little at the memory of Anakin‚Äôs attention riveting to her friend.

If he was like this with Padm√©, what would he be like with their mother?

‚ÄúDid he pull out any arguments on that not mattering at the cost of her life?‚Äù Leia asked, jotting down a note of something she remembered from the night before.

‚ÄúOh, quite a few. I don‚Äôt know that I so much managed to convince him as to put down his enthusiasm. I‚Äôll have to try nursing his ego when I get back.‚Äù

She did frown at that, tapping her pen as she looked at him. ‚ÄúIs that the best way to handle it?‚Äù

He seemed surprised that she would question him. ‚ÄúI have known him for more than half his life. I‚Äôm used to doing this.‚Äù

Biting back more criticism, Leia asked, ‚ÄúAre you here to check up on us and give him a comfortable report?‚Äù

‚ÄúSomething like that.‚Äù His hands danced over the arms of his chair before he folded them into his sleeves, frowning at the ground. ‚ÄúDo you know if Shmi Skywalker will be staying here long?‚Äù

There was a strong temptation to beat about the bush and make him work for it, but Leia reigned in her temper. ‚ÄúI doubt it. Ruwee needs her back on Naboo as soon as possible. She‚Äôs been essential in getting their new refugees settled. She built the personnel network that is getting feedback about the new system, and personally vets any new members of it that work directly with refugees.‚Äù

A skill based partially on familiarity of spirit, Leia guessed, mingled with Shmi‚Äôs knowledge of people and her innate Force sense. Not powerful and overwhelming in the way her son‚Äôs was, but not negligible either. Leia wished she knew enough herself to offer to train it.

Obi-Wan looked curious, but she watched him put several questions aside and get straight to the point. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs not here to see Anakin then?‚Äù

‚ÄúShe came because her family was in danger,‚Äù Leia said succinctly. The handmaidens might not technically be as close, but Leia wasn‚Äôt the only reason Shmi had come running. ‚ÄúI doubt she would have sought him out, but if he tries to see her again she won‚Äôt reject him. He‚Äôs her son, Obi-Wan.‚Äù

She tried to place the correct emphasis on that while not being too overwhelming. Was he even able to understand? Did he have any idea what it was to be a mother? A father?

The feeling she got off of him in the Force told her he knew it was serious, but she didn‚Äôt think he understood what it meant. ‚ÄúDo you intend to tell Anakin that?‚Äô

‚ÄúI have no way of contacting him,‚Äù Leia pointed out. ‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôm pretty sure he doesn‚Äôt really know I exist.‚Äù He‚Äôd been far too caught up in his mother and Padm√© to have noticed their brief, almost nonexistent introduction. ‚ÄúIt hardly seems worth the effort.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot even for Shmi‚Äôs sake?‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs a grown woman, Master Kenobi. If she wants to see him, she‚Äôll find him herself.‚Äù

And Force preserve anyone that tried to stop her.

He seemed unsettled by that. ‚ÄúDo you think she will?‚Äù

Fighting the desire to scream, Leia leaned back, rubbed her eyes.

This was‚ÄîThis was too much. She couldn‚Äôt deal with this today. She had an assassin to find and track their contractor, a war to stop or at least materially damage, a Trade Federation to unravel, a Banking Clan to overset, armies to find, a Sith to stop, and she hadn‚Äôt slept last night. On top of having had an adrenalin rush.

She was running on borrowed time and borrowed energy and she did not want to handle this.

‚ÄúLeave her alone, Obi-Wan,‚Äù she grumbled, rubbing her face as well. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs not going to do as you advise and isn‚Äôt the kind of person you can manipulate, any more than I am. Accept what‚Äôs coming and roll with the punches. You‚Äôll be grateful for it later.‚Äù

There was a brief silence before he said, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not especially comforting, you know.‚Äù

And he wasn‚Äôt going to leave well enough alone. She could see that. He couldn‚Äôt stop Shmi and he couldn‚Äôt stop her, but he would try and stop Anakin.

‚ÄúWe aren‚Äôt trying to sabotage you,‚Äù she offered, coming around the desk to crouch in front of him, offering him her hands. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt want you to get hurt, we don‚Äôt want Anakin to get hurt,‚Äù (mostly, as long as he was good like this), ‚Äúwe don‚Äôt want anyone to get hurt.‚Äù

(Palpatine. Palpatine was allowed to get hurt. He was allowed to get hurt to death.)

‚ÄúWe just want to live our lives. And to help people,‚Äù she continued. ‚ÄúMaybe you don‚Äôt like how that looks, but it‚Äôs what we want. And if we can, we are going to help.‚Äù

He stared at her for a moment, pondering. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think you understand what my concern really is. What this means for Anakin, as a Jedi, that his old family has shown up.‚Äù

‚ÄúJedi never see their families?‚Äù Leia asked. She‚Äôd heard the answer from others, but as he nodded her stomach felt like an open pit, her fingers twitching. ‚ÄúNot even on accident?‚Äù

‚ÄúSome probably do,‚Äù he conceded. ‚ÄúBut most of the time, we wouldn‚Äôt even recognize them.‚Äù

She thought of Luke‚Äôs face, trying to imagine what it would mean to not know who he was.

And then, then she was in a cell on the Death Star and a short storm trooper had just rushed in, and his helmet came off and he was blonde hair and blue eyes in a face she had never known (but knew as intimately as her own heart in that moment) and thought about years of walking side by side, shoulder to shoulder, hand in hand, through fight after fight and having no idea, none (except somewhere, in a piece of her heart she always knew and was always reaching, always longing‚Ä¶) and nearly losing each other so. Many. Times.

‚ÄúLeia?‚Äù She came back with a jolt, Obi-Wan almost supporting her by their linked hands, the air thick with his worry. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs wrong? Are you‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt,‚Äù she gasped, fingers clenching, ‚Äúfinish that sentence.‚Äù

He didn‚Äôt, but his worry only swelled.

She took one calming breath. Two. ‚ÄúI know what it‚Äôs like to be separated from family,‚Äù she admitted. ‚ÄúTo see them and have no idea who they really are. It‚Äôs awful. And there are consequences.‚Äù

Hoth. And so many other occasions where she‚Äôd felt things she couldn‚Äôt quite understand and had pursued them, hoping, straining for some semblance of the truth, content in the end with what she could understand and what she could get, with just being closer.

‚ÄúI imagine that, for other people, it can create a lot of stress,‚Äù Obi-Wan said, and she got the impression he was doing the opposite of agreeing with her. ‚ÄúBut for Jedi, it‚Äôs different.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt know that,‚Äù Leia shot back, and seethed when his smile came off as more than a little condescending.

‚ÄúIn this case, I believe I am a bit more knowledgeable than you give me credit.‚Äù

And Luke hadn‚Äôt been a Jedi, not like this, so she couldn‚Äôt really argue, but, ‚ÄúAnakin‚Äôs not like that.‚Äù

And his name still tasted numb and stale on her tongue, awkward from deliberate disuse.

Obi-Wan was frowning, staring at the wall, his hands now twitching in hers. ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he agreed solemnly. ‚ÄúHe isn‚Äôt.‚Äù

Her next interruption left Leia wondering why she had bothered to convince Padm√© to let her work in her own office. If people kept barging in, she‚Äôd never get her notes done. Still, she smiled as she stood. ‚ÄúShea.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou look so happy to see me,‚Äù the Herdessan senator‚Äôs expression was almost conspiratorial and Leia relaxed. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt worry, I won‚Äôt stay long. I know Senator Darsana sent someone by this morning, and you had your Jedi visitor.‚Äù

Her arch tone had Leia glowering, but with little to no effect. ‚ÄúMater Kenobi came by, yes. You made it out before the lock down?‚Äù

It was a clumsy conversation shift, but Shea gave it to her, and Leia was grateful. ‚ÄúWe did. I‚Äôm only sorry you didn‚Äôt.‚Äù

It was hard to tell, in the way she said it, if Shea knew they had been the target. If she didn‚Äôt, Leia wouldn‚Äôt be the one to tell her. No matter how tempting. ‚ÄúWe are too. It had already been such an exciting evening.‚Äù

‚ÄúDid you get any sleep?‚Äù There was so much kindness in the tone, Leia actually lost track of her thoughts for a moment, caught up in the feel of it.

‚ÄúA bit,‚Äù she managed. ‚ÄúSomething of a nap. I‚Äôm planning to finish this and then be done early this evening. I‚Äôll go through it with my data tomorrow, when I‚Äôm more awake.‚Äù

Shea nodded, coming around the desk to glance at the notes, smiling as she saw the short hand code. ‚ÄúThat sounds like a good plan. Well, I‚Äôll leave you to it.‚Äù

Not wanting to seem rude, Leia moved to escort her out. She was surprised when Shea pulled her into a hug, squeezing so tightly for a moment, Leia thought her feet left the ground.

In the next second Shea had pulled back, blinking as she managed a crooked smile. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôd be a shame to lose you, Leia Skywalker. Maybe try to not get shot at?‚Äù

Leia‚Äôs answering smile was just as crooked. ‚ÄúI really am doing my best. I think this was actually a record.‚Äù

She didn‚Äôt have the heart to explain how honest she was being after Shea burst out in a surprised laugh.

‚ÄúSo help me,‚Äù Leia growled, ‚Äúif this isn‚Äôt critically important‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI beg your pardon,‚Äù a familiar voice said from the doorway, soft and concise. ‚ÄúI had just come to see if you were alright after last night‚Äôs events. I‚Äôve been making the rounds to everyone.‚Äù

‚ÄúYour Excellency,‚Äù Leia stood, using a half bow as an excuse to keep her eyes on the ground until she had schooled her expression. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, that was very rude of me.‚Äù

Groveling. She was groveling, and it made her sick (she‚Äôd sworn to herself the first time she‚Äôd met him that she‚Äôd look him in the eye, cow him with her defiance, and she‚Äôd bowed her head like a little girl, ready for scolding), but she had to keep up the pretense.

If he knew, if he ever knew (all of this would be for nothing)‚Ä¶

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs quite alright,‚Äù he wasn‚Äôt exactly jovial in accepting her apology, but there was something bright to his words that was so cheery it was almost cutting. ‚ÄúYou had quite the evening, didn‚Äôt you? And you‚Äôre still very new here, it must have been quite the shock.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve been in stressful situations before, Your Excellency.‚Äù

‚ÄúIndeed? You did quite well at the dinner, you know. I was very impressed.‚Äù

There was something inherently poisonous in that word, Leia thought. As if leaving an impression were the first hint of danger. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre too kind, sir. I was just following Master Kenobi‚Äôs lead and helping where I could.‚Äù

She‚Äôd managed to look up now, and his smile was not too tight, but had more teeth than she was expecting. Mas Amedda was behind him at the door, looking bored, as well as two guards. She had to mentally scold herself for expecting them in red, not dark blue. ‚ÄúWell, we were all very fortunate that he was there, weren‚Äôt we? His quick thinking certainly saved you and the senator.‚Äù

It was a question as much as a statement. Leia, who actually knew this game all too well, demurred. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt imagine what would have happened if a Jedi hadn‚Äôt been present. We owe him so much.‚Äù

‚ÄúAh, but all the Jedi live to serve the Republic,‚Äù Palpatine‚Äôs smile should have been harmless, but Leia was too familiar with the man to ignore the edge to it. ‚ÄúAnd you, my dear, and the senator are the core of the Republic. Do give my regards to Senator Amidala, by the way. I missed her earlier when I went to visit. And I do want her to know how much I appreciate her efforts.‚Äù

Since he hadn‚Äôt actually voiced a quantifying compliment, Leia had to fight to keep the dryness from her voice as she promised, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll pass along your words, Chancellor. Thank you for your visit. I‚Äôm,‚Äù she hesitated, ‚Äúquite undone by your attentiveness.‚Äù

It sounded awful, but was as close to honest as she could get. And she was supposed to be inexperienced. So when he gave her a condescending farewell it grated, but she had to count it as a win.

Reflections

Curled up on the bed next to Shmi, Leia did her best to keep quiet as the tears streamed down her face. She might have gotten away with the slight trembling, but the hiccups interrupted her grandmother‚Äôs sleep, and Shmi blinked awake too quickly for Leia to cover the signs.

‚ÄúOh, Leia.‚Äù It was a breathless whisper, almost no sound. Eirta√© slept through it, but Leia buried her face in her pillow anyway, hiding. ‚ÄúDo you need to get up?‚Äù

Two breaths and a nod and Leia felt Shmi move, sliding silently out from under the comforter. She helped steady Leia as she stood and guided them both out of the room to the sitting area, following Leia‚Äôs lead to the balcony without any hesitation. Shmi also didn‚Äôt object when Leia climbed onto the railing, curling up against the wall as she stared out into the city, watching the blurred lights of the traffic lanes.

Every time she blinked she saw fire.

‚ÄúWas it the shooting, or have you been having dreams again?‚Äù

Leia considered lying, but the word that came out of her mouth was, ‚ÄúBoth.‚Äù

Fingers combing through Leia‚Äôs hair, Shmi hummed a nameless tune, just loud enough to be heard over the outside sounds. Leia leaned into the touch, pretending at odd moments that it was her mother, on Alderaan, humming a familiar lullaby.

When the moon is mirrorbright, take this time to remember

Those you have loved but are gone‚Ä¶

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs stupid, isn‚Äôt it?‚Äù Leia muttered, rubbing her face. ‚ÄúIt never brings them back.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you believe they really left?‚Äù Shmi‚Äôs question had a weight to it, one Leia was certain she would never understand. ‚ÄúThat they‚Äôre truly gone?‚Äù

‚ÄúIf they‚Äôre not, then where are they?‚Äù It wasn‚Äôt a fair response, and Leia felt petulant as she said it. But the sentiment stuck.

‚ÄúIf they are in your memories, have they ever left you?‚Äù

Those you loved are with you still‚Äî

The moon will help you remember

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not the same,‚Äù Leia complained, arms pulling her knees closer to her chest, tucked under her chin. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just not.‚Äù

Shmi‚Äôs hand stilled for a moment, then brushed through Leia‚Äôs hair again. ‚ÄúYou cannot stop the change, any more than you can stop the suns from rising.‚Äù

The words echoed in Leia‚Äôs ears, a different tone, more teaching to it, overlaying with the one Shmi had just used. It tingled up and down Leia‚Äôs spine, shivered in ways she couldn‚Äôt pinpoint. ‚ÄúI wish I didn‚Äôt know that.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to be consumed by it,‚Äù Shmi answered, her head leaning against Leia‚Äôs now. ‚ÄúAny more than you must be consumed by your grief.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know that. It‚Äôs not helping.‚Äù

There was a kiss at Leia‚Äôs temple. ‚ÄúNothing I say will make it better,‚Äù Shmi conceded. ‚ÄúAnd you are not completely paralyzed by it. But it will consume you, if you let it. If you don‚Äôt let living take its place.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve been living quite a bit,‚Äù Leia groused. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve worked extra hard at it.‚Äù

Shmi chuckled. ‚ÄúYou are very good. And very strong. And you don‚Äôt easily give up.‚Äù Her tone turned earnest. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt let your life be stolen by those who stole love from you.‚Äù

The palest face, weathered and cold. Eyes that were blue and yellow in turn, a rotted smile. Cold ships and cold space where there had once been home.

Everything cold. Cold, cold, cold‚Ä¶

‚ÄúHow do you not hate them for taking him away from you?‚Äù her lips were numb as the words tumbled out.

‚ÄúWhat makes you think I don‚Äôt?‚Äù was the immediate answer, which had Leia‚Äôs head whipping around, looking into somber dark eyes. ‚ÄúEven more than I hate myself?‚Äù

(I didn‚Äôt do enough. I didn‚Äôt do enough and I wasn‚Äôt strong and I wasn‚Äôt there and if I‚Äôd just tried harder, just done more‚Ä¶)

‚ÄúWe,‚Äù Leia licked her lips as she stared into those eyes and for the first time in a long time saw her own, ‚Äúreally are Skywalkers, aren‚Äôt we?‚Äù

A hand cradled her cheek. ‚ÄúThe desert brought you to me,‚Äù Shmi whispered. ‚ÄúIn the rage and in the storm. I always knew, always, that you were mine.‚Äù

Resting her forehead against her grandmother‚Äôs Leia leaned into that, not really probing its meaning. Because what Shmi meant literally was not as important as what she was saying‚Ä¶

‚ÄúRight now, it‚Äôs still time to fight,‚Äù Leia answered. ‚ÄúBut someday. Someday I would like to meet peace.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen we will,‚Äù Shmi promised. And it echoed in her soul and Leia‚Äôs bones.

Three days later the Naboo were still working and hosting meetings in the conference room, away from windows and with extra guards checking everyone who left and entered. It was more than obnoxious, and Leia could see how much it was preventing work from getting done.

Especially with the few Outer Rim visitors who had opted to try and stay to see if things could be worked out.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt especially like your people‚Äôs paranoia,‚Äù Cham Syndulla said as he followed Leia down the halls, opting to meet in her office instead of Padm√©‚Äôs temporary one. ‚ÄúNot that the danger wasn‚Äôt real, but if she can‚Äôt handle this threat‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúBlame the Chancellor,‚Äù Leia said before she had really thought about it. She regretted the words, but made herself push through once she had said them. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs been hovering. It‚Äôs extremely inconvenient.‚Äù

She said the last as her door closed behind her. Dorm√© and Shea would be by in a moment, but it was safer to at least try and muffle her words instead of leaving it open for them. Syndulla took a seat, watching her curiously.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt like the Chancellor?‚Äù

His tone was mild, but Leia was at least clever enough for that trap. ‚ÄúI really don‚Äôt know him. He works with Padm√© if he has anything to do with us at all. I think I‚Äôve had more conversations with your senator than with his Excellency.‚Äù

She didn‚Äôt miss his lekku‚Äôs twitch. ‚ÄúSenator Orn Free Ta has a very‚Ä¶ Core World way of viewing things. He seems to believe even more senators should adopt Senator Amidala‚Äôs levels of protection.‚Äù

The temptation was strong, but Leia swallowed the, ‚ÄúOf course he does,‚Äù and instead said, ‚ÄúSenator Amidala is from Naboo, which is Mid Rim. She‚Äôs very familiar with these sorts of tactics, which is why she still works with her handmaidens. She learned her lessons as queen very well.‚Äù

Which was why they‚Äôd used Cord√© on several occasions these last few days to get Padm√© out from under security and to more sensitive meetings that couldn‚Äôt reasonably be held in the converted conference room.

Syndulla understood the reminder of the siege of Naboo. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs very brave, to continue in politics with her life so often in danger.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe knows how much it matters,‚Äù Leia said simply. ‚ÄúShe saw what happened to her people when the Senate got bogged down in politics when she needed quick action. She‚Äôd rather be at the front of the fight than waiting for someone else to win it.‚Äù

‚ÄúI noticed,‚Äù Syndulla admitted, a spark of admiration in his eyes. He glanced over his shoulder as the door opened and Shea and Dorm√© entered. ‚ÄúAnd I see she brings others near her who share her vision.‚Äù

They weren‚Äôt going to solve peace talks, Leia knew as everyone got seated. He didn‚Äôt have the authority or leverage to promise that. But Syndulla‚Äôs presence wasn‚Äôt just a power on Ryloth. People on nearby systems looked to him to be practical, to read the shifting tides.

To mitigate damage done by a negligent government.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôd like to share with you some of our ideas,‚Äù Leia proposed. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been making adjustments to refugee movements, and we‚Äôd like your opinion on whether you‚Äôd think they‚Äôre useful or not in your sector.‚Äù

Noticing Shea‚Äôs smile, Syndulla produced a toothy one of his own. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm listening.‚Äù

‚ÄúI need you to talk to Senator Darsana.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

‚ÄúJust this one time.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

‚ÄúLeia, we need his support.‚Äù

Leia spun, actually angry with Padm√© for the first time in days. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not listening to him. And he won‚Äôt listen to me if I parrot your arguments. It‚Äôs not going to work, and I‚Äôve worked too hard to get his trust to waste it on something like this.‚Äù

For a moment Padm√© looked stunned, then angry. ‚ÄúLeia, this vote is the most important‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNot to him,‚Äù Leia tried to be firm without her temper rising. ‚ÄúHis people are dying Padm√©. Not just in numbers, as a way of life. He‚Äôs being practical about this. Very practical. You won‚Äôt win him over with idealism and how nice the future will be if everyone just stops being who they are and agrees with you.‚Äù

There was a swell from Padm√© and Leia hid a wince. So much for not escalating this. ‚ÄúYou think we should have an army?‚Äù

‚ÄúI think we need to seriously reconsider why so many other systems think we need one. And ask ourselves who‚Äôs dictating the terms of the conversation to make this about the Separatists instead of the needs of the Republic.‚Äù

She hadn‚Äôt meant to pick a fight, especially not with Padm√©. Not right now. But it didn‚Äôt help that Leia had been frustrated and distracted by her own hunt for Padm√©‚Äôs assailant. It was impossible to make any real progress now that Leia was missing all of her old, even most loosely connected contacts. What she really needed was time to sneak out and down into Coruscant‚Äôs underbelly and start making a new network, but with everything that was being done up here, she just wasn‚Äôt finding the time and she didn‚Äôt have anywhere to start and‚Äî

‚ÄúDo you want lunch?‚Äù Leia asked as Padm√© opened her mouth to respond to the last accusation. The senator blinked. ‚ÄúI think we need to get out.‚Äù

‚ÄúFor lunch? No, we‚Äôre busy here.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe need a break,‚Äù Leia insisted. ‚ÄúAnd there‚Äôs a place I‚Äôve been meaning to try.‚Äù Not part of Coruscant‚Äôs underworld, per se, but at least a place to meet a different segment of the population. ‚ÄúObi-Wan recommended it.‚Äù

That had the senator‚Äôs attention. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve heard from him?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Leia rolled her eyes as they started to make their way around the floor, looking for a gap in the guards. ‚ÄúHe mentioned it ages ago, just in passing. I don‚Äôt think he and his padawan are even on planet right now.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow do you know that?‚Äù Padm√© was probably right to be suspicious. She‚Äôd been upset that Shmi hadn‚Äôt been able to see her son again before she had left, and had accused Leia of knowing something and not helping with it.

‚ÄúSomething Master Gallia said when she thanked me for going with Obi-Wan to the dinner. I think they‚Äôre on some sort of diplomatic mission. Maybe to prevent them from getting too involved.‚Äù

She probably shouldn‚Äôt have mentioned that. Padm√© blushed and said, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think we‚Äôre making it off this floor unless we let Cord√© in on the plan.‚Äù

Spotting a pair of droids a little further up the hall, Leia smiled. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs because we‚Äôre not using the right weapons. Come on.‚Äù

It took exactly no convincing and only the tiniest bit of explaining to get Artoo to agree to cause a distraction, effective but harmless. Threepio might have been a problem, but they managed to make him part of the distraction, and Leia didn‚Äôt object when Artoo showed up with the protocol droid outside the building, insisting they both get to come along. She figured they also deserved the break.

Flying in Coruscant traffic required enough attention that Padm√© didn‚Äôt continue their conversation while Leia flew. Which was nice. And with time to think about the arguments without distractions, it felt like the senator was mellowing. Also an improvement.

‚ÄúAre you really eating here?‚Äù Threepio asked as they approached the diner. ‚ÄúI must say, this isn‚Äôt exactly what I expected.‚Äù

‚ÄúA Jedi recommended it,‚Äù Leia told him, and was delighted when his reply was, ‚ÄúWell then it‚Äôs probably safe, but that does explain the questionable taste. This is hardly suitable for a government official.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôll have to tell him that,‚Äù Leia recommended as they went in. A server droid wheeled up, and she had a belated thought. ‚ÄúWill the droids be a problem?‚Äù

‚ÄúNot at all, sweetheart. Just make sure they don‚Äôt leak or anything. First time at Dex‚Äôs?‚Äù

They were definitely overdressed and catching attention. Regretting that a little, Leia took a long look around the room and smiled. ‚ÄúIt was recommended.‚Äù

‚Äú‚ÄòCourse it was. Here, lemme get you a seat.‚Äù

‚ÄúObi-Wan recommended this place?‚Äù Padm√© couldn‚Äôt quite whisper, and Leia couldn‚Äôt resist smiling at the awe and scandal in her voice. She needed to get out more. ‚ÄúReally?‚Äù

‚ÄúHe did. Although, to be fair, I‚Äôm not sure if he knew I‚Äôd bring you he‚Äôd have offered it as something serious.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow did he find it?‚Äù

‚ÄúSomething about knowing the owner. From one of his early missions?‚Äù She‚Äôd have to remember to double check when she ran into him next.

The food was tolerable. She‚Äôd have to also check with Obi-Wan about what he usually got. Maybe there was a house specialty. Padm√© didn‚Äôt complain, and they had fun watching the other guests. And listening to Threepio making comments about everything.

‚ÄúAnd how are we enjoying ourselves?‚Äù the question was jovial, and Leia smiled up at the besalisk, twirling a fork between her fingers.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs delightful.‚Äù The food may not have been to die for, but there was something so light and welcoming in the atmosphere.

And maybe a little threatening too. Which didn‚Äôt diminish Leia‚Äôs enjoyment one bit. It was an honest aggression, mostly coming from Dex, she thought, in the way of a man who was ready to cheerfully roll along unless you interfered with his business.

‚ÄúAnything else we can get for you?‚Äù he asked, two of his hands balancing empty plates on a tray while a third reached adjusted his apron.

Leia looked over at Padm√©, who seemed a little unsure of what was going on. ‚ÄúCould I get a refill?‚Äù she asked.

‚ÄúSame,‚Äù Leia said, tapping her cup. Dex nodded and shouted at the droid as he walked off, who was over in a flash, refilling their cups. Leia took a sip from hers, eyes still wandering around the room.

When the droid finished, Padm√© asked, ‚ÄúAre we looking for something?‚Äù

‚ÄúJust getting the lay of the land,‚Äù Leia shook her head. ‚ÄúTrying to figure out why exactly Obi-Wan recommended this place, aside from knowing the owner. It‚Äôs probably not more than that, but I have my reservations when it comes to Jedi.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt trust them?‚Äù Padm√© didn‚Äôt really sound surprised, but she did sound serious, and that surprised Leia.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs kind of a hard question. I don‚Äôt actually know that many of them.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaster Jinn and Master Kenobi were very helpful during the siege of Naboo,‚Äù Padm√© reminded her. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve found the ones that I‚Äôve interacted with have been very good people.‚Äù

Something about that didn‚Äôt sit right, and it took Leia a moment before she answered, ‚ÄúShmi said something about Master Jinn getting Anakin into that pod race.‚Äù

It was interesting to watch the complicated play of expressions on Padm√©‚Äôs face. ‚ÄúHe‚Äî‚Äú She huffed. ‚ÄúHe did. I was‚ÄîActually I was really angry with him at the time. I insisted on coming with him when we landed, and he kept ignoring me when I disagreed with him. And then‚Ä¶ And then he died. Protecting us.‚Äù

And all was forgiven in light of that sacrifice? Leia frowned. ‚ÄúThat sounds‚ÄîNot to be too callous, but that kind of sounds like exactly what would happen if he insisted on doing things his way and not listening to anyone.‚Äù

‚ÄúProbably,‚Äù the senator poked at her last bites of food, glancing over to the corner where Threepio and Artoo were chatting with some other droids. ‚ÄúI just‚Ä¶ it was such a hard time. I look back and have so many questions about if anything we did was the right thing. But my people‚Ä¶‚Äù

And that, Leia perfectly understood. ‚ÄúWe see a lot more in hindsight,‚Äù she said, shrugging. ‚ÄúBut life isn‚Äôt always clear, for all of that.‚Äù

‚ÄúTell me about it,‚Äù Padm√© grumbled, stabbing at the food left on her plate. She looked up to meet Leia‚Äôs eyes for a second before glancing away again. ‚ÄúI just want to help the Republic.‚Äù

And they were back to this. ‚ÄúOkay, so what do you think the Republic really needs?‚Äù

‚ÄúMore flexibility,‚Äù Padm√© said, sounding more confident than she had earlier. ‚ÄúCircumstances vary from system to system, in terms of import and exports, populations, kinds of goods that are moving, fuel sources available, technology preferences.‚Äù Or access, Leia thought. ‚ÄúAn army of the Republic isn‚Äôt going to solve that. We need system to system negotiation, better Republic wide laws for non-negotiable matters, more diplomats and negotiators for sector and system contracts.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd someone to enforce it?‚Äù Leia asked, taking another bite to avoid a smile.

Padm√© still glared. ‚ÄúSystems have their own enforcement‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúTell the Anselmi that.‚Äù Or the Naboo.

‚ÄúThe Jedi‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúAren‚Äôt an army and aren‚Äôt a police force. There‚Äôre what, several thousand of them? Based here? At best that‚Äôs enough to assign one per a handful of sectors. That‚Äôs enough to add to a negotiating team, or have as a consultant for oversight. Not an army.‚Äù

And where was the army, Leia wondered. Based on Bail Organa‚Äôs age, the Clone Wars had to be starting soon. And would require, as far as she was aware, clones. Which would take time to make. Grow? And no one had mentioned them yet.

Concerning.

‚ÄúSo maybe we need something,‚Äù Padm√© sighed. ‚ÄúBut not‚Ä¶ this.‚Äù

A shrug and a wave of the hand that encompassed the nightmare that had been the past few weeks. The arguing, the numbers, the attempted budgets projections (good news for the Banking Clans, not the Republic), the supply route investigations (oh look, the Trade Federation). Yes, Leia understood exactly why Padm√© was standing in the way of all that.

But when it came to votes, ‚ÄúPeople are hoping that if we make an army it will end any potential conflict with the Separatists. And then we‚Äôll still have an army to do whatever we want with.‚Äù

Maybe defend Republic trade routes. Maybe take Hutt space (that had Leia‚Äôs vote). Or maybe take back some of the systems that might have been, oh, reluctantly conscripted into the Confederacy. Or colonize parts of those systems that had trade goods people wanted. Or‚Äî

Or any number of other unpleasant things.

Yeah, Leia understood why Padm√© didn‚Äôt want an army alright.

So, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll talk to Senator Darsana some more,‚Äù Leia promised. ‚ÄúNot to get his vote, but to see if I can wheedle out what he wants for it. Maybe, if we can find other ways to address his concerns, we‚Äôll have something to work with. But I‚Äôm not going to just ask him to join us.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs fair,‚Äù Padm√© conceded. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll talk to Bail and see if there‚Äôs anyone else he can think of with similar motivation. Not wanting a Republic army, but trade or travel enforcement. Balanced between sectors. I can do that.‚Äù

There was peace between them again, of a sort. That was fine. Leia didn‚Äôt need Padm√© to always agree with her, just for their relationship to work.

And.

And to be a friend. Leia liked Padm√©, how confident and sure she was in every move she made, every choice she stood for. Her queenly bearing, never mind that now she was a senator. Her long suffering patience and her quiet but unrelenting hunt for vengeance against those that had done her wrong. Robed in the civility of justice, chained by necessity to be less than pure rage, but still singing in the Force every time Padm√©‚Äôs eyes landed on Nute Gunray.

That man would pay for what he had done to Padm√©‚Äôs people. If it took the queen a lifetime and a drop by drop extraction of blood for what had been lost. She‚Äôd settle for nothing less.

‚ÄúSo what do you think of this place?‚Äù Leia asked as they finished, reluctant to head back to the Executive Building.

Shaking her head, Padm√© admitted, ‚ÄúI still can‚Äôt believe Obi-Wan recommended it.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a Jedi. And a man. Supposedly they aren‚Äôt picky about such things.‚Äù And if her visual sweeps of the room and casual eavesdropping had been any clue, he probably came here less for the food and more for the information.

‚ÄúCan you imagine him bringing Anakin here though? What would Shmi think?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not that bad,‚Äù Leia protested. It was at least civilized. Not a makeshift bunker with mud and bugs and only ration bars masquerading as food. ‚ÄúAnd I think I could like Dex quite a lot.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh that‚Äôs your type?‚Äù Padm√© giggled and Leia‚Äôs lips twitched. ‚ÄúPoor Shea.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs‚Äî‚Äú No, not going to have that fight. ‚ÄúThink we can convince Obi-Wan that Dex spilled all his darkest childhood secrets?‚Äù

Padm√© let it go. ‚ÄúEven better. I‚Äôll bet we can convince him that Dex told us all the stories of how embarrassing it was when Obi-Wan brought Anakin.‚Äù They both laughed at the thought.

From the corner of her eye, Leia caught a reflection of them off of the glass. But when she turned to look, instead of her own smile, she saw her brother‚Äôs laughing face.

Regroup

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

‚ÄúGo home.‚Äù

It was unusual for Senator Organa to use that tone. Leia had only heard it a few times in her life, right before (or just after) she had done something incredibly reckless and stupid.

‚ÄúBail, I can‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre useless here, Padm√©,‚Äù the firmness in his voice didn‚Äôt leave much room for compassion, but Leia could tell he felt it. ‚ÄúYou know it. You‚Äôve been working the best that you can under these restrictions. It‚Äôs time to stop.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm the senatorial representative of Naboo,‚Äù she snapped back, almost slamming her datapad onto the table. ‚ÄúI was sent here by the directive of the Queen‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúWho was right to choose you,‚Äù Senator Organa cut her off. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve been very brave and very effective in many ways through all of this. But the Senate is out on recess, we aren‚Äôt having any floor votes, and the Chancellor hasn‚Äôt released you to normal security yet.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe moved offices, I‚Äôm not on probation‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúPadm√©.‚Äù

That tone was all compassion, deep understanding. Leia leaned into the feelings that came with it, shoving down jealousy that the kindness and concern were not directed at her. Naboo‚Äôs senator slumped a little, hands tugging at the datapad in front of her as she blinked. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not fair. He can‚Äôt keep doing this.‚Äù

‚ÄúGive him time. They‚Äôre still searching for the bounty hunter. Once they get that pinned down, which should happen in time for the next voting session, you can come back and work as normal.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt feels like we‚Äôre letting them win,‚Äù Padm√© stood and started pacing, her hands swinging back and forth. Leia leaned against the wall, debating whether or not to add her own voice to this. ‚ÄúThat we‚Äôre conceding victory by acting frightened.‚Äù

‚ÄúPadm√©, we don‚Äôt actually know who did this. It could have been about the vote, or someone at the dinner that night, or something not related to our work at all. We have to be cautious.‚Äù

Caution was all well and good, but Leia was more concerned that they didn‚Äôt know what the motive had been. Politically motivated attacks should have a clear line to someone to take the fall at least, so that it would add weight to a message.

No political motive showing up suggested something more personal. And moving to Naboo wouldn‚Äôt change that. Just who ended up being the collateral damage.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs taking too long,‚Äù Padm√© voiced and Senator Organa huffed a little. ‚ÄúBail, you know this isn‚Äôt reasonable. If you could just talk with the Chancellor‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs made it very clear your safety is his highest priority,‚Äù and Senator Organa did not seem thrilled at that fact. ‚ÄúYou are from his home plant, and you were his student. It‚Äôs no surprise that he would react like this.‚Äù

But it was disgusting. And Leia didn‚Äôt trust it. Especially since even she was having a hard time tracking down Padm√©‚Äôs assailant. It didn‚Äôt help being in the wrong time, but Artoo was as good a slicer as ever. She‚Äôd gotten footage from the official investigation, the collection of threats that had been filed against Naboo or the senator. She‚Äôd walked the building the shots had been fired from, once it had been cleared and opened. She knew just enough to hazard a guess at the kind of rifles that would had to have been used, and had Artoo tracking that path as well.

She couldn‚Äôt use him for everything though. It would become too suspicious.

And her own efforts at gaining contacts in Coruscant‚Äôs lower levels had been sketchy at best. She was making headway, but for what she needed now, not enough.

It was a lot. And it was stacked on top of her day to day work.

‚ÄúWhat do you think?‚Äù Padm√© had turned, was suddenly including Leia, who had to take a moment to reorient.

‚ÄúI think we told your parents you would be coming home soon. That Ruwee is looking forward to your help with the next batch of refugees and the queen wants a full report on the project. I think if you are still a target we‚Äôll have an easier time spotting an interloper on Naboo than Coruscant.‚Äù

Eyes narrowing, Padm√© pointed out, ‚ÄúThat puts my people in danger.‚Äù

It was hard to not just shrug off the concern. Leia couldn‚Äôt remember a time in her life where her physical presence wasn‚Äôt a danger to everyone in the room in some way or another. Alderaan had been peaceful, but with it being an open secret that her parents supported the rebellion, as their daughter she was never safe to be around.

That hadn‚Äôt gotten better after Alderaan had been destroyed. If anything, the bounty on her head had made it worse.

‚ÄúYou have to make the choice,‚Äù Leia opted to not openly support Senator Organa, which made him frown and almost made her squirm. ‚ÄúStay here where the Chancellor keeps interfering and you put Coruscant citizens in possible danger, or go home where you can have the Queen‚Äôs mobile protection and finish your work, but potentially risk your own people.‚Äù

She knew it wasn‚Äôt really a choice when she put it that way, and she could see Padm√© looking for the trap. ‚ÄúIf I‚Äôm not a target‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúThen does it matter where you work? You can call in for meetings either direction.‚Äù

But she had promised to go home, and they both knew it. ‚ÄúYou want to see Shmi again?‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù Leia answered, making sure to not check the expression on Senator Organa‚Äôs face. ‚ÄúAnd she‚Äôll feel better if we can fill her in on details that we can‚Äôt share over an unsecured line.‚Äù

Technically, their lines were secure, but Leia was nothing if not paranoid. And in this case, she wasn‚Äôt sure it was wrong.

‚ÄúGo,‚Äù Senator Organa stepped over, placing a hand on Padm√©‚Äôs shoulder. ‚ÄúI promise I‚Äôll keep you fully in the loop. You and your friend have done enough here. We‚Äôll keep things moving while you‚Äôre gone.‚Äù

There was a twist in the Force from Padm√© at those words and Leia wished they‚Äôd been unsaid.

Things hadn‚Äôt been easier between Padm√© and the more militarily ambivalent members of the Loyalist Committee since she and Leia had argued. Sometimes they were even worse. It made Leia‚Äôs project critically important in terms of keeping allies at times, having that one thing to agree about.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll go,‚Äù Padm√© agreed. ‚ÄúBut I want in on all the decisions, Bail. If I feel like I‚Äôm being left out, I‚Äôm sending Representative Binks.‚Äù

Something between a smile and a grimace crossed Senator Organa‚Äôs features. ‚ÄúI will take that under advisement.‚Äù

‚ÄúSenator Darsana,‚Äù Leia looked up from the stack of documents she was trying to shove into a bag. She didn‚Äôt want to have to reprint them again, they had her notes. ‚ÄúTo what do I owe the pleasure?‚Äù

He‚Äôd been sending his aides to speak with her more often recently. She wasn‚Äôt sure if that was a good sign or not.

He made his way across the room slowly, bowing a greeting that Leia managed to match with almost as much grace. ‚ÄúI hear you are leaving. I came to say goodbye.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs very kind,‚Äù Leia said, daring to make a gesture across her chest that she hoped she had correctly remembered. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll only be gone for the recess. Hopefully we will get to meet again soon.‚Äù

She must have gotten it right because he copied it, something lightening around them as it always did when she managed to move properly. ‚ÄúYou will be missed, nonetheless. And I hope that we are still here when you are again present.‚Äù

Blood suddenly cold, Leia tried to remain as neutral as possible as she said, ‚ÄúIs there some reason you wouldn‚Äôt be?‚Äù

He didn‚Äôt voice anything, but the shrug and movement of his arms indicated something she would have to guess meant cataclysmic change. She‚Äôd have to confirm with Threepio on that one. Senator Darsana wasn‚Äôt stupid enough to say they were being approached by, and considering, a Separatist request, and Leia wasn‚Äôt stupid enough to miss the implication.

Her hand rested on her desk and she willed her fingers to stay still, to give away no emotion.

‚ÄúI would miss you,‚Äù she said at last, and knew it was true. The senator really did keep her on her toes, and took her on her own terms. He trusted her too, and she loved to please him. Or perhaps she loved the challenge of pleasing him. Who knew? ‚ÄúIf I weren‚Äôt able to see you anymore.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe senate will always offer you much in the way of experience,‚Äù he suggested, his body language closing off slightly, though whether she had actually offended him or he was just mirroring her reticence, she couldn‚Äôt be sure. She wished she could taste the air like he could, but wasn‚Äôt sure enough in the Force to really know his intention.

‚ÄúBut there is never a good substitute for a true friend.‚Äù

She should have regretted the words as they fell from her lips. She was not Naboo‚Äôs representative and her senator was not friends with this man. She wasn‚Äôt even really sure she was.

But he was loose and languid again, and even smiling in a way that wasn‚Äôt more than slightly threatening. ‚ÄúThat is true. It is possible to promise many things, but one cannot guarantee friendship. And there is much that can be lacked without feeling wanting, if one has real friends.‚Äù

I want to help you, Leia was desperate to say. I want to solve your problems and save your people. I know what it‚Äôs like to watch your way of life be dying and have no way out. To have stop gaps and desperate measures and have it never be truly enough.

Maybe they weren‚Äôt true friends now, but Leia was sure they could be. And that mattered.

This mattered.

‚ÄúI want to see you again,‚Äù Leia admitted freely, allowing her hand to curl into a fist on her desk. ‚ÄúI hope I see you again.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd that when you do, we are still friends?‚Äù

His smile was teasing and something in it reminded her of Han a little (and how would he feel about that?), but even more he reminded her of Lando. Smooth and unflappable, oozing charismatic charm and subtly, underneath, ready to face any danger for his people.

She forgot sometimes (because so many of the memories stopped at Han and Luke and with her not breathing) how much she missed Lando. How he‚Äôd been there for her when it had all ended and she‚Äôd just wanted the whole world, every world, to go away.

He‚Äôd believed in her.

And he‚Äôd betrayed her.

And he‚Äôd helped rescue her, and the person she loved.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm selfish,‚Äù she said at last. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard to make me give up my friends. I‚Äôm very resistant to it.‚Äù

He laughed, rough and low, shaking his head. ‚ÄúWell said, Leia Skywalker. I too, do not easily give up friends. No matter where each of us stands. May you have safe travels. I look forward to seeing you again.‚Äù

It wasn‚Äôt a promise that he would be here, but it would have to do. Leia made a bow of her most formal farewell and he matched it with his usual flair. Tears pricked her eyes, but she smiled as she saw him out and was delighted when he shook and then kissed her hand.

She didn‚Äôt know what would happen, but she was certain she would see him again.

‚ÄúGet your feet down,‚Äù Eirta√© didn‚Äôt normally get that direct, but it was the third time she‚Äôd had to remind Leia. ‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt your ship.‚Äù

‚ÄúI never thought it was,‚Äù Leia retorted. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a distinct lack of footprints on the furniture.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine,‚Äù Padm√© said, taking a seat across the table from both of them and frowning slightly. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs not hurting anyone.‚Äù

‚ÄúSomeone is going to have to clean it,‚Äù Eirta√© sniffed. ‚ÄúAnd it‚Äôs not a footrest.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre going to be grouchy, go to bed,‚Äù Cord√© yawned. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got another two hours before we get there anyway.‚Äù

Enough time to sink into the depths of a nap that would leave any of them more groggy than awake when they were done. Dorm√© had given up hours ago, but Leia was determined to be awake when they landed to adjust as quickly as possible to the planet‚Äôs solar rhythm. And so were the rest of them.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not grouchy,‚Äù Eirta√© grumbled, bracing her chin on her hand. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs just being messy.‚Äù

Taking a look at the papers that were scattered over the table and around Leia on the floor, she couldn‚Äôt completely disagree. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a bit all over the place.‚Äù

But it was helping her organize her thoughts. There was an idea that had been tickling at the edge of her senses for a while now and she just hadn‚Äôt had time to digest it and figure it out.

‚ÄúI thought you were done with your project,‚Äù Cord√© yawned, picking up the nearest document and frowning at it. ‚ÄúYou proved we‚Äôre all doomed.‚Äù

Leia leaned forward and snatched the stack back, whapping the top of Cord√©‚Äôs head with it before she could think it through. ‚ÄúNot doomed. Just exploited. We need to find a way to work around the Trade Federations monopoly on safe trade lanes and practices. And probably kick down the Banking Clan while we‚Äôre at it.‚Äù

There were other groups, she knew, that were just as powerful, but these two seemed the most dangerous so far. Palpatine acknowledged them, and that had to mean something.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt think small, do you?‚Äù Cord√© just grabbed another stack of papers, frowning at it. ‚ÄúWhy are you helping with this?‚Äù

Not expecting the direct attack, Leia was stalled for a moment. ‚ÄúWhy wouldn‚Äôt I help with this?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt had nothing to do with you?‚Äù Cord√© suggested. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs above your pay grade. No one expects it. You‚Äôre not getting wealth or notoriety for it. Padm√© at least is on a crusade to save the galaxy ever since what happened to Naboo with the Trade Federation. We‚Äôre here to save Padm√© from herself,‚Äù there was a splutter at that. ‚ÄúBut you weren‚Äôt even on Naboo when the occupation happened. So what do you care about it?‚Äù

If she made it out of this in one piece, Leia was going to have to remember that Cord√© knew how to use sleep deprivation as a shield and a weapon and was very good at it. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt just want to help?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou could,‚Äù Cord√© shrugged. ‚ÄúSome people do. But I think this is too personal for you for it to be something as altruistic as that. You‚Äôre like Padm√© in that way. She cares, but never as much as when she‚Äôs under attack. Or someone she loves is.‚Äù

Beyond the sleepiness there was a keenness in those eyes and after the initial suspicion and panic had subsided, Leia acknowledged that Cord√©‚Äôs timing was minutely deliberate. She wasn‚Äôt just waiting for when Leia was vulnerable or more likely to talk. She had picked a time when they were isolated and safe.

And when had Leia moved from thinking of them as Padm√©‚Äôs coworkers to thinking of them as her own friends?

Trust. It was being offered. And Leia was startled to realize she was terrified to accept.

‚ÄúI can go,‚Äù Eirta√© offered, and Padm√© frowned while Leia smiled, realizing she‚Äôd been well and truly had.

She shook her head, swallowing a sigh. ‚ÄúIt won‚Äôt make a difference,‚Äù she told Eirta√© and was amused when the other woman looked surprised. ‚ÄúIt is personal. What‚Äôs going on, what‚Äôs happened,‚Äù she swallowed again, this time fighting back tears and the sudden rage that clawed its way out of her chest, yowling at the injustice of it all. ‚ÄúIt destroyed my family.‚Äù

Over and over, from her biological parents to her adopted ones, to her long-lost brother and the man she had almost called husband. The family she‚Äôd been born with, the one that had chosen her, the one she had chosen. All of them stripped away, until there was only darkness left.

And that blue ghost, lurking in that darkness.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sending you to someone safe. Probably the only one who can help you actually fix everything.‚Äù

She looked up and for just one second instead of her own reflection in the wall behind Padm√©, Leia saw her brother, eyes fixed on hers, face grim.

And then he was gone (it wasn‚Äôt supposed to have happened, it wasn‚Äôt supposed to happen again), and she was all that was left.

‚ÄúIt destroyed my family,‚Äù she repeated, ‚Äúand nothing I do will ever bring them back.‚Äù

Little Han, so tiny and sweet, hiding against his mother‚Äôs leg, a far cry from the smuggler and rebel general he could have become. If she knew him, she knew she would love him. But it would never, ever be the same as her Han.

She met Cord√©‚Äôs eyes, unable to even guess at what was shining in her own. ‚ÄúI want to make them pay. And I want to make sure it never happens again.‚Äù

Chapter End Notes

I just wanted to take a moment again to thank everyone who has left comments. It's exciting and entertaining to see your reactions (and your guesses). Your enthusiasm is appreciated and makes it easier to keep going. I, uh, grossly underestimated what I was getting into with this project. I expect it to drain me dry (and then some) before it is over. Your interest makes it easier and more worthwhile to keep going. So thank you to all of you.
And to the silent readers, thank you too. I do watch the numbers creep up each chapter I post. I'm glad you keep coming back. I hope you're also really enjoying this.

Worth Less

Sipping tea and staring out over the city, Leia hummed and tried to pretend that she didn‚Äôt notice anyone coming up behind her.

For all the good that had ever done.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre up early this morning,‚Äù Shmi didn‚Äôt pretend that Leia hadn‚Äôt noticed her (or was she like this with everyone, because she had been used to it with Anakin?), just got straight to the point. ‚ÄúI thought you slept well last night.‚Äù

It was getting really bad if Shmi knew how well Leia was doing even when they weren‚Äôt sharing a room. ‚ÄúI did. Early morning is when I think best.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd what are you thinking about? While you are on vacation?‚Äù

There was something so delightful about Shmi being a nag. Her tone was just too perfect. It had to be proof of their biological relation that Leia liked it so much, even when it was directed at her.

Especially when it was directed at her. ‚ÄúTechnically, Padm√© is on vacation. I‚Äôm just perpetually dubiously employed.‚Äù

‚ÄúIs that how she would put it?‚Äù

The words had so much zing to them. Leia smiled as she took another sip. ‚ÄúNot a bit.‚Äù

‚ÄúWill you at least come inside and help me get breakfast ready?‚Äù

Suddenly the humor was a lot less. Leia grimaced but nodded, accepting that whatever she contributed to this meal would be dubious at best.

She‚Äôd been avoiding practice while she was on Coruscant. And Shmi was bound to notice.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve lost weight,‚Äù her grandmother mentioned as they sat down at their table, Leia proud that not everything that she had touched was now charcoal.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm always skinny,‚Äù she retorted, shoveling food into her mouth and ignoring when it crunched in places it wasn‚Äôt supposed to. ‚ÄúOne of the few gifts of my genetic makeup.‚Äù

She couldn‚Äôt have been tall, no. That would have been too much to have asked to have gotten from her biological father (though Luke had been cheated there too, technically‚Ä¶) in the short list of things she knew she could blame on him.

Like being Force sensitive.

Maybe her mother had been short.

‚ÄúYou have many gifts,‚Äù Shmi countered. ‚ÄúOne of which is access to enough food to take care of yourself.‚Äù

It was dawning on Leia that Shmi was getting more comfortable being pushy. Which was nice, and probably necessary for Leia‚Äôs better health. But was also inconvenient. ‚ÄúI get plenty to eat.‚Äù

She earned a very skeptical look.

They finished their meal in silence, Shmi focused on her food while Leia stared at the far wall and tried to find that happy place she had been visiting earlier where she hadn‚Äôt actually been thinking about anything.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt like you involved in this,‚Äù Shmi said, standing and beginning to clear dishes. She wouldn‚Äôt meet Leia‚Äôs eyes now. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not comfortable with it.‚Äù

Leia first bit back a retort that it didn‚Äôt matter if Shmi was comfortable with it, it was Leia‚Äôs choice, she was an adult. Then she swallowed a series of platitudes where she emptily promised that everything would be fine. And finally Leia closed her eyes so that she didn‚Äôt have to see the look on Shmi‚Äôs face when she said, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt expect it to get better before it gets worse.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know.‚Äù

Closing her eyes hadn‚Äôt really helped. That tone said so much. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt not do it.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù the dry understanding in Shmi‚Äôs tone coaxed Leia‚Äôs eyes back open just in time to catch the tremulous half smile her grandmother offered. ‚ÄúThat doesn‚Äôt mean I can‚Äôt try.‚Äù

Try what, Leia didn‚Äôt know. It was hard to believe Shmi wanted Leia to stop doing what was right. And her grandmother of all people had to know that sometimes that was dangerous. Even before her son had been taken away‚Äî

But that was what this was about, Leia realized, swallowing slowly. What it had always been about. Anakin had only wanted to do the right thing, and the right thing had been‚Äî

‚ÄîTo leave his mother behind.

‚ÄúShmi,‚Äù Leia found herself standing, moving around the table and holding out a hand, again forcing herself to not utter lies for the sake of comfort. ‚ÄúI love you.‚Äù

And that was the most painful truth of all, Leia realized as she looked at Shmi‚Äôs face. That someone could love you and want what‚Äôs best for you and still leave. Because they felt like it was right.

(She‚Äôd hugged him goodbye and demanded he come back and he‚Äôd smiled and stepped away to let Han tug her hair and give her a kiss, and his eyes hadn‚Äôt been smiling because her brother knew what they wanted, and he didn‚Äôt want it, but he was trying to be right‚Ä¶)

‚ÄúI love you too,‚Äù Shmi answered, voice thick with emotion. And it hurt, because loving Leia was hurting Shmi and Leia didn‚Äôt want the people she loved to be hurt by loving her.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no way,‚Äù Leia whispered (a crowded room, dozens of faces staring at her as she screamed, screamed because she couldn‚Äôt breathe, her chest had been ripped out), ‚Äúthat I‚Äôm worth the risk.‚Äù

(He wasn‚Äôt coming back. He was never coming back. He‚Äôd promised and was never coming back and she had to live with it.)

Shmi was brushing away tears and Leia tried to stop it, to say what needed to be said most. Don‚Äôt love me, I‚Äôm not worth it. I‚Äôm not worth the risk.

(Thunder and flames every time she closed her eyes. Never there, never able to unsee.)

‚ÄúLeia,‚Äù she was wrapped up in Shmi‚Äôs arms, her grandmother disgruntled and still so patient. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre already part of me.‚Äù

She couldn‚Äôt close her eyes. She couldn‚Äôt but she needed to because in the glass of the window all she could see was Luke‚Äôs face, staring soulfully back at her, his hand raised as though it was pressed against the glass, trying to reach.

Her eyes squeezed shut and Leia felt the tears and felt her tripping breaths and for a moment the past was present and she could almost feel‚Ä¶

(The touch of a hand on her shoulder, ghostly fingers suddenly pulling back.)

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not worth it,‚Äù she managed.

Shmi snorted. ‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt have come with you if I believed that.‚Äù Warm, brown eyes smiling down at her. Offering peace and comfort and a feeling (in the Force?) that all was right, right here, right now. ‚ÄúYou wouldn‚Äôt have brought me. Not if you believed that.‚Äù

You‚Äôre worth it, she wanted to say. I always knew you were worth it. That‚Äôs why he sent me here, back to you. The only one he could trust.

To keep me safe.

But to admit that out loud would be to admit everything (that he lov‚Äî) and there was no way she could do that.

‚ÄúI want to be worth it,‚Äù Leia managed.
