Shmi kissed her forehead. ‚ÄúYou are a gift, Leia Skywalker. A wish that I never had granted. You may not be safe,‚Äù and that was the look of a woman who had definitely raised Anakin Skywalker, ‚Äúbut you have been given. And for that, I am grateful.‚Äù

‚ÄúMistress Shmi, I believe you have a call.‚Äù

Rolling their eyes, Leia and Shmi turned to Threepio who was hovering in the doorway. ‚ÄúTell them I‚Äôll be right there,‚Äù Shmi said.

As the droid left, Leia chuckled. ‚ÄúHe always had impeccable timing.‚Äù

‚ÄúBlame Anakin for it,‚Äù Shmi tucked Leia‚Äôs hair behind her ear. ‚ÄúHe wanted a droid with peak attentiveness.‚Äù

So Threepio would always know Shmi‚Äôs business and when she needed help, Leia realized with a start as her grandmother left. He wanted her to have a friend, a protector, so she would never be alone.

And Leia had taken him with her to Coruscant.

Damn.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not okay with this.‚Äù

Leia glanced up at Padm√© then back at her desk, making another note on the flimsi in front of her. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt recall asking your permission.‚Äù

It was a sign both their tempers were too high that Leia actually said those words and Padm√© slammed her hands down on the desk in response to them. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not what I meant and you know it.‚Äù

Looking up meant facing the censure in those eyes, and Leia wasn‚Äôt sure that was worth it. But she did say, ‚ÄúI know.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou want to go to Coruscant, alone,‚Äù Padm√©‚Äôs gaze was sharp. ‚ÄúTo find the shooter. By yourself.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt would make the most sense‚Äî‚Äú Leia stopped as Padm√©‚Äôs hand slashed out.

‚ÄúIn what universe does that make sense? The Jedi are working on it. They don‚Äôt need you.‚Äù

It stung, in a place that was soft and vulnerable and tested to breaking by time and misery and ruin. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not doing it for them,‚Äù Leia almost didn‚Äôt recognize her own voice. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm doing it for you.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want it,‚Äù Padm√© snapped back. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not putting you at risk.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Leia agreed. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm putting me at risk.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou do it, I‚Äôm telling Shmi,‚Äù there was almost venom in that threat.

Leia tried to brush it off. ‚ÄúShe knows I take risks. She won‚Äôt like it, but she won‚Äôt stop me doi‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI‚Äôll tell Anakin.‚Äù

Blinking at the weight and absurdity of that particular threat, Leia said, ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt reach him. He‚Äôs on a mission, and it‚Äôs a nightmare to make calls to the Temple‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúIf I ask, they‚Äôll connect me to Obi-Wan, and if I say it‚Äôs scaring Ani‚Äôs mother, they‚Äôll have to listen. They‚Äôll do something about it.‚Äù

Ignore it, probably. The Jedi might be responsible for Padm√©‚Äôs safety, but they had no such obligation to Leia and definitely none to Shmi. They weren‚Äôt the ones under threat. And the Jedi couldn‚Äôt arrest Leia for wandering around seedier parts of Coruscant. Hell, most of them wouldn‚Äôt be able to find her, they wouldn‚Äôt have any idea who she was beyond a name.

But even still, ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt want to bother them with something like that,‚Äù Leia protested. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not important.‚Äù

Well, that had been the wrong thing to say. ‚ÄúSince when is your life not important?‚Äù

Backtracking at this point wasn‚Äôt easy, but Leia had to try. ‚ÄúI meant that I‚Äôm not doing anything that dangerous.‚Äù Padm√©‚Äôs look was withering, but Leia pressed on. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs investigative work. I‚Äôm not planning on confronting the person, just poking around and seeing if I can spot overlooked details.‚Äù

And if she happened to walk into a bar and the shooter was in the room and someone happened to spill a drink and a little fight started and Leia accidentally broke someone‚Äôs arm (or nose, or teeth) and information was coaxed, yanked, and prodded out of the guilty party, that was just a bonus.

It wasn‚Äôt like she was looking for trouble (and Han‚Äôs voice didn‚Äôt whisper in her ear, ‚ÄúSure, your Worship‚Äù) and Leia knew how to handle herself.

‚ÄúYou are an employee of the Naboo Senatorial office. Your job is in no way to be an investigator or a spy.‚Äù

False on all counts. ‚ÄúMy entire job so far has been to be an investigator and it‚Äôs just bad luck that I‚Äôve been stuck at a desk the whole time.‚Äù Trying to stay calm, she added, ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been on the Outer Rim for years, Padm√©. And any number of other nasty places. I know how to take care of myself.‚Äù

She pushed back her chair so she could cross her arms and (more importantly) her legs, so that her holster was in view. She knew Padm√© noticed, but the senator didn‚Äôt seem pleased by the reminder. ‚ÄúThat doesn‚Äôt mean you should go looking for trouble.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not looking for trouble,‚Äù Leia shot back. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm trying to get ahead of trouble finding you.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhich is not your job,‚Äù Padm√© stressed. Leia noticed Eirta√© shift a little at her place by the door. ‚ÄúI have guards and security for that, and Coruscant has security and Jedi for it. You‚Äôll only muddle things by getting in the middle of it.‚Äù

True only if Leia tried to tell them what she knew. That it was probably Palpatine that had indirectly organized the hit and the best method of investigation would be to start at the top and work their way down.

But Leia wasn‚Äôt that stupid, no matter how tempting and appealing it was.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll be gone for a few days,‚Äù she tried dodging around the issue, hoping placating would work. ‚ÄúYou haven‚Äôt given me any new assignments, I‚Äôve been forwards, backwards, and sideways through my data, my presentation is ready the moment anyone will sit down with me‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúThen ask me for another job,‚Äù Padm√© snapped. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt just reassign yourself.‚Äù

Oh, right. Leia wasn‚Äôt in charge here.

Damn it.

‚ÄúWhat would you like me to do?‚Äù Leia asked, praying Padm√© couldn‚Äôt come up with anything that needed doing.

‚ÄúGet Shea a refugee program report. And help Shmi organize proposals to start testing on Herdessa.‚Äù

Well shit, that did need to be done. ‚ÄúWe have the reports already‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúAnd they need to be redacted, and the methods need to be updated for a full-scale industrial planet, and Shmi isn‚Äôt familiar with Herdessa‚Äôs systems but Shea and you are. With both.‚Äù

Damn it, damn it, damn it, damn it‚Ä¶

‚ÄúI can do that from‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYou cannot do it from Coruscant. Shmi needs you, and she needs you here. There‚Äôs too much of a time difference and,‚Äù Padm√©‚Äôs smile was almost nasty in its triumph, ‚Äúthe Senate isn‚Äôt even in session. Shea‚Äôs not there.‚Äù

It had been a while since Leia had been this well routed and it stung. And it didn‚Äôt help that she was still smarting from Padm√©‚Äôs no use to the Jedi (if she‚Äôd just listened to Lu‚Äî) comment.

Taking a deep breath, Leia tried, ‚ÄúGive me three days‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

‚ÄúPadm√©‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

‚ÄúI can do thi‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù Finally leaning back, Padm√© shook her head. ‚ÄúLeia, this isn‚Äôt about your ability, it‚Äôs about keeping you safe. I know you can handle danger. You saved my life.‚Äù And that was still terrifying to think about. ‚ÄúBut I don‚Äôt want to put you in a situation like that again. Definitely not on purpose. And I really don‚Äôt want to have to explain to Shmi why I let you do it.‚Äù

Well, that was fair. ‚ÄúI just‚Ä¶‚Äù Leia turned and looked out the window, gazing at the garden below. The palace rose on all sides, warm and clean and peaceful. If she stepped out now, Leia would be able to smell the pink blooms on the bushes in the thick, warm air. Would be able to feel the overwhelming contentment and purpose that emanated from this building and the people that worked in it.

Like she could feel the worry and despair and sadness from Padm√©, who only wanted to help her and keep her safe.

‚ÄúI just want to do this,‚Äù she couldn‚Äôt bring herself to turn around and say it, just kept staring out the window.

‚ÄúBut you don‚Äôt need to do it,‚Äù Padm√© came around, put a hand on Leia‚Äôs shoulder. ‚ÄúLook, I‚Äôll be heading back for a brief conference next week.‚Äù

Leia spun around so fast she almost took out Padme‚Äôs knees. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

Eirta√© was meeting Leia‚Äôs eyes now, frowning in a way that told Leia the handmaiden was also not pleased with this.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs only for a few days, I won‚Äôt be near the Senate, and I need to talk to Cham Syndulla,‚Äù Padm√© said forcefully. ‚ÄúBefore he heads back to Ryloth. I‚Äôm taking a full guard with me, using three decoys,‚Äù which was actually almost more risky because the decoys were all good, but no one was as good as Cord√©, ‚Äúand keeping my visits brief. He doesn‚Äôt want an army taking over security for Ryloth, Leia. We need that kind of support.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs not a member of the Senate,‚Äù Leia pointed out.

Padm√© sighed. ‚ÄúNo, but he‚Äôs got a lot of influence back on Ryloth, and while I don‚Äôt have time to actually try and unseat Orn Free Ta, we do need to consider the possibility that some of our fights are going to take place outside the senate. Unseating people if we must.‚Äù

Leia knew Padm√© hated the idea of interfering with other systems‚Äô sovereignty. But it was a good point. If you didn‚Äôt like the odds, you had to change them.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to need you in those fights,‚Äù Padm√© added, her hand finding Leia‚Äôs shoulder again. ‚ÄúEirta√© and the others have to stay near me. You may end up being our only envoy we can send on short notice.‚Äù

Which was bad. Hilariously bad. Spectacularly bad. Naboo should have dozens of envoys that they could send for these kinds of matters. But‚Ä¶

But something had happened to the Youth Legislative Program, and there was the debacle of the Trade Federation war to deal with, and a lot of money had gone into those court battles which had lasted for the better part of a decade and had not recouped nearly enough of Naboo‚Äôs losses, and some people had retired and others had just disappeared‚Ä¶

And a bunch were now working for Chancellor Palpatine. And there was nothing Leia or Padm√© could do about that.

They had envoys, technically yes. But they were mostly stationed on Naboo and played a role in the Queen‚Äôs court. Not on Coruscant, interacting with the masses and making a galaxy worth of friends.

‚ÄúI see your point,‚Äù Leia conceded. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just concerned that they haven‚Äôt found anything yet.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis is the Core, not the Outer Rim,‚Äù Padm√© was trying to be gentle, but it just came off as condescending. ‚ÄúThings are a little more complicated here.‚Äù

‚ÄúDense, not complicated,‚Äù Leia disagreed. ‚ÄúAnd we should still know more about this.‚Äù

Neither woman had anything to say to that. It just wasn‚Äôt something they were familiar with.

Road Blocks

‚ÄúI hate waiting,‚Äù Leia grumbled, head tipped back, fingers rubbing at her temples. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just a call and I hate the waiting.‚Äù

‚ÄúSenator Sadashassa doesn‚Äôt normally keep you waiting?‚Äù There was a hint of worry in Shmi‚Äôs tone, but Leia shrugged, the feeling odd with her head still almost upside down.

‚ÄúShe doesn‚Äôt, but she has more control over her schedule in the Senate buildings. Once she‚Äôs off of Coruscant, she‚Äôs not the one in charge. She has to answer to Herdessa‚Äôs guild masters and company heads and union overseers, and fit into their schedules. And they have businesses to run. Her time isn‚Äôt as valuable by their standards.‚Äù

Something tapped against the table. ‚ÄúShe could have told you she‚Äôd be late.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe knows I‚Äôll understand.‚Äù Seeing her grandmother‚Äôs skepticism, Leia added, ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs a friend. She won‚Äôt try and take advantage, and if it‚Äôs too much of an inconvenience she‚Äôll make it up to me. I trust her.‚Äù

It took a few moments before Shmi nodded at that. ‚ÄúAlright then. We‚Äôll see how this goes.‚Äù

It didn‚Äôt. They only had to wait five more minutes, but the person who contacted them was one of Shea‚Äôs assistants, informing them that Shea‚Äôd been scheduled for several emergency meetings that afternoon. She would call and reschedule as soon as they‚Äôd dealt with the problems.

‚ÄúAnything she needs help with?‚Äù Leia asked, knowing no information would be offered. Shea‚Äôs trust didn‚Äôt equal her staff‚Äôs trust. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôd be happy to offer any support‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNo thank you. But we‚Äôll pass your willingness along.‚Äù

Well, the aide was offended, but as long as they mentioned it to Shea, Leia wasn‚Äôt worried. The senator knew it was offered in good faith.

‚ÄúNow what?‚Äù Shmi asked as the call ended. ‚ÄúRuwee was hoping for a report.‚Äù

Leia rubbed the bridge of her nose, humming thoughtfully. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll need to tell him. I don‚Äôt know that he‚Äôll completely understand, but hopefully he‚Äôll get it.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat we‚Äôre being ignored?‚Äù The undercurrent of venom in those words surprised Leia, but she mostly kept those feelings in.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not‚Äî‚Äú

But it was like that. Shmi wasn‚Äôt just angry that Shea hadn‚Äôt called, she was angry that the refugee problem wasn‚Äôt considered important. These were people‚Äôs lives. There were displaced and caught up in the middle of an intergalactic storm and Shmi finally had the power to do something and Shea and her people were now standing in the way instead of helping.

And Shmi didn‚Äôt have tolerance for their excuses. Never mind that they didn‚Äôt own slaves, profiteering didn‚Äôt look that much better outside of the Hutt syndicate than within it. It just sat on the opposite line of legality and you could (hypothetically) be punished for it.

In theory.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt speak for anyone but Shea,‚Äù Leia tried instead, ‚Äúand I‚Äôm limited in what I can say for her. But I know she‚Äôs invested in this. Herdessa has need of more skilled workers, and a better system for dealing with the ones that they have. I don‚Äôt know as much about the organizations that she has to work with, though. She‚Äôs too composed to just sit around and complain about it if they‚Äôre not ideal.‚Äù

Shmi packed her things, ready to leave for the afternoon and start her refugee visits. ‚ÄúI know. But Leia, if she doesn‚Äôt learn to make this matter, it‚Äôs not worth it.‚Äù

Not sure exactly what ‚Äúit‚Äù was supposed to be in that context, Leia frowned. ‚ÄúWe do what we can, Grandmother. Sometimes,‚Äù she had to swallow (Alderaan to dust, Luke curled up on the bed around his missing hand, Han being dragged away to Jabba‚Äôs dungeons), had to close her eyes and bite her lip and take a breath. ‚ÄúSometimes we fail. And we have to try again. And just live with it.‚Äù

‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt fought as many battles as you have,‚Äù Shmi‚Äôs words were slow and deliberate and Leia had to hold back a snort. Just because it wasn‚Äôt combat didn‚Äôt mean most of Shmi‚Äôs life hadn‚Äôt been a fight. ‚ÄúSo I don‚Äôt know exactly what you‚Äôre talking about. But I don‚Äôt mean to give up on this. I just mean‚Ä¶‚Äù Her brow furrowed as she looked down. ‚ÄúWhy do we want to be a part of all of this? The Republic. What good has it ever done us?‚Äù

There‚Äôs enough room in the galaxy, Leia told herself as she refused to have any sort of reaction. Made herself think. Enough for everyone. We don‚Äôt have to fight, we could all just walk away.

So why don‚Äôt we do it?

‚ÄúI like having friends in the Republic,‚Äù she said, tapping a finger on the desk. ‚ÄúShea, Padm√©, Senator Darsana. I don‚Äôt see eye to eye with all of them,‚Äù any of them, really, ‚Äúbut I feel like they‚Äôre worth knowing and that they‚Äôre my friends. A Republic makes it easier to have that.‚Äù

‚ÄúFor you,‚Äù Shmi answered. ‚ÄúIt does.‚Äù

Depth. There was so much depth and breadth to what separated them. Leia had grown up with privilege, intimately connected to places that were not her world.

Shmi had been lucky to escape Mos Espa, much less Tatooine. And so much of that could even be the fault of the Republic.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an ugly world,‚Äù Leia struggled to find the shape of what she remembered and put it into words. It had, in fact, actually been worse. ‚ÄúWhen there is no trust. No agreements. No cooperation. It‚Äôs not like you can‚Äôt live like that, and even find beauty in spite of it, but‚Äî‚Äú

But then your enemies snuck up on you and when they left, your life, your world was all gone.

‚ÄúThere isn‚Äôt a right way, Leia,‚Äù Shmi seemed oddly determined about this and Leia wondered what was bringing it all on. ‚ÄúWe can find a way to be happy without having to save things exactly like this.‚Äù

True, only, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been me against the galaxy before,‚Äù Leia whispered, forcing her fists not to clench. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd rather not‚ÄîI‚Äôm much happier. With this.‚Äù She met her grandmother‚Äôs eyes. ‚ÄúBut you don‚Äôt have to believe in it.‚Äù

You don‚Äôt have to stay, she wanted to say. But less because it was true and more because it was a weapon and Leia knew she could use it. Use it as leverage to influence Shmi‚Äôs choice. And that was wrong and vindictive and selfish. And Shmi didn‚Äôt deserve any more of that in her life. Especially not from Leia, who she should be able to trust.

‚ÄúThe galaxy is a big place,‚Äù Shmi answered, everything about her gentle. ‚ÄúSurely you didn‚Äôt make an enemy of all of it.‚Äù

‚ÄúPretty damn close,‚Äù Leia‚Äôs lips quirked. Then she frowned again. ‚ÄúEnough. We made an enemy of enough of it. By insisting we were right,‚Äù she conceded, the words a bitter, grating sentiment. ‚ÄúAnd by being willing to fight for it. And that‚Äôs really the problem, at the end of all of this. We learn to live together, or to carve out the space to live how we want.‚Äù

And she wasn‚Äôt sure anymore exactly which she had done, or when, and what had been the right of it.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs true,‚Äù Shmi conceded. ‚ÄúYou cannot fight the desert, but that does not mean you always yield to it.‚Äù

Balance. Something about balance.

‚ÄúRight.‚Äù

But Shmi hadn‚Äôt actually agreed with Leia about the Republic. And that was something to remember.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm still angry at you.‚Äù

There was a hint of heat to it, but since Padm√© was also shoveling a slop of meat and fried bread into her mouth around the words, Leia didn‚Äôt take it too personally. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs okay. I‚Äôm still mad at you too.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, but I‚Äôm mad because you‚Äôre wrong, and you‚Äôre mad because I‚Äôm right.‚Äù It was a bit muffled by the food and Padm√© couldn‚Äôt manage a smile unless she wanted to dribble over herself.

Leia giggled. ‚ÄúNo, you only think you‚Äôre right. The only way to prove you‚Äôre right is for me to be on Coruscant and for something bad to happen.‚Äù

‚ÄúIn that case,‚Äù Padm√© swallowed and pointed, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm perfectly happy just assuming I‚Äôm right and ordering you around like this. It‚Äôs better for everyone that way.‚Äù

Except the shooter hadn‚Äôt been found. But Leia hadn‚Äôt given up just because she couldn‚Äôt be on planet. She‚Äôd had Artoo gather some more data for her and check into a few ideas she‚Äôd had while she was stuck here. So far it didn‚Äôt look like he‚Äôd found anything, but Leia was getting a better idea of where the Senate‚Äôs underground network wasn‚Äôt, which was almost as helpful as knowing where it was.

‚ÄúHow was Syndulla?‚Äù

Padm√© grimaced. ‚ÄúNot what I‚Äôd hoped. He‚Äôs not thrilled about having a Republic run military body, but he does want permission to organize more local militias. To deal with any increase in hostilities from the Separatists.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd have access to more weapons?‚Äù Leis suggested, perching on the arm of the chair. ‚ÄúFrom the Trade Federation?‚Äù

Scowling, Padm√© managed to toss her wrapper into a rubbish bin in a perfect arc. Leia‚Äôs lips twitched and she bit back a suggestion to have a contest. The senator rubbed her eyes. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt get it. How can they think that‚Äôs a solution to this?‚Äù

‚ÄúNaboo did increase its fighter count and incorporate the Gungan Army as an official military group after the invasion,‚Äù she tried to say it gently, but knew that wouldn‚Äôt help. ‚ÄúCan you blame him for wanting the same for his people? They probably need it, with all the pirates.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey have trade deals with the pirates,‚Äù Padm√© snapped, and Leia understood why.

But she still pressed, ‚ÄúFor pleasure or under duress?‚Äù

‚ÄúBoth,‚Äù Padm√© grumbled, shifting back into her chair and crossing her arms, her frown a firm crease between her eyes. ‚ÄúDo you really think an army would work?‚Äù

It was tempting to answer quickly (not bringing an army didn‚Äôt mean your enemy wouldn‚Äôt), but technically Leia wasn‚Äôt sure about this. ‚ÄúI think having enforcement of trade and transport law would make a huge difference for disenfranchised systems. I think building an army to ‚Äòdeal with‚Äô the Separatists is the height of lunacy and will only cause more problems than it solves. If it solves any.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe Chancellor agrees with that,‚Äù Padm√© sighed and Leia swallowed an, ‚ÄúOh, I‚Äôll just bet he does,‚Äù to let the senator add, ‚ÄúBut he doesn‚Äôt seem ready to negotiate with any of the systems. Even after the state dinner last month, it‚Äôs like we‚Äôre running on borrowed time and he just isn‚Äôt invested.‚Äù

Since Leia also couldn‚Äôt manage, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure he‚Äôs very invested,‚Äù or any similar comment without slathering it in bitter sarcasm, it took her a minute to say, with as much moderation as she could, ‚ÄúThen we have to find a way to work without him.‚Äù

(Leia had several ideas for how to make that happen. With blasters. Or open windows. Or freak speeder accidents. Or‚Äî)

The suggestion didn‚Äôt seem to thrill Padm√©, but Leia hadn‚Äôt expected much for just saying it. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just‚Ä¶ it seems like it‚Äôs hard to get things done if the Chancellor isn‚Äôt backing them.‚Äù

The words sounded like they had been dragged, kicking and screaming, from Padm√©‚Äôs mouth. Her hand curled into a fist on the desk, she wouldn‚Äôt meet Leia‚Äôs eyes. When she finally did look up, it was as if every line of her expression were begging Leia to say she was wrong. That the weight of that betrayal wasn‚Äôt something she would have to carry.

‚ÄúThen we‚Äôll just have to work harder ourselves.‚Äù

Grief, sadness, aching desperation. Then anger and resolution. ‚ÄúYes. We will.‚Äù

‚ÄúMistress Leia.‚Äù

She looked up from the speeder and braced herself against the side, tools hanging limply in both of her hands. ‚ÄúWhat is it, Threepio?‚Äù

‚ÄúSenator Sadashassa is calling. I told her you were busy but she insists that she wants to speak with you right now.‚Äù

There was a grease streak on her face and more on her hands. Her hair was a mess, she‚Äôd been meaning to finish just one more thing for the past forty minutes before she was going to go in and have lunch. If Shea wanted her now, there wouldn‚Äôt be time for her to change.

‚ÄúCan you put these things away for me? Or tell her I‚Äôll be right in?‚Äù

His arms twitching, Threepio said, ‚ÄúI would be happy to speak with her until you are more presentable.‚Äù

Grinning, Leia shook her head. ‚ÄúNo, she probably doesn‚Äôt have a lot of time. Tell her I‚Äôm coming and then get Shmi please. We may need her.‚Äù

‚ÄúI would be more than happy to keep her‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúPlease, Threepio,‚Äù she tried again, picking things up. ‚ÄúTell her I‚Äôll be right there.‚Äù

It took three minutes to get everything cleaned up and put away. By the time Leia got in, Shmi was already seated in front of the holocall, speaking softly and answering the pointed, direct questions Shea was firing off. Personal questions. Not at all like the dinner she and Leia had had, a meandering conversation with slow, digging queries. This was perfectly straightforward.

‚ÄúAh, and Leia‚Äôs here,‚Äù Shea said as Shmi‚Äôs gaze drifted up and lingered for a moment. ‚ÄúHaving a good day, little friend?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve had better,‚Äù Leia slid in next to Shmi, ignoring the stare her grandmother gave her, eyes catching the mussy, greasy presentation Leia had allowed. ‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôve had worse. How are your guild leaders?‚Äù

Even in the static of the call, Leia could see Shea‚Äôs eyes roll. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like being trapped in a room with a bunch of varyingly attractive versions of Senator Clovis. I wouldn‚Äôt recommend it. Personally.‚Äù

Leia forced her expression to stay blank as she watched Shea‚Äôs face twitch, trying not to laugh at Leia‚Äôs appearance. ‚ÄúYou have a moment for refugee business?‚Äù

‚ÄúFor you,‚Äù she leaned back in her chair, her eyes darting to Shmi for half a moment, ‚Äúalways.‚Äù

Leia leaned forward, bracing her elbows on her knees. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll let Shmi give you the overview of our Naboo project, and you can tell us what you think.‚Äù

Seed of the Lotus

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

A strong breeze was grazing across the rooftop and Leia let herself be caught up in it, leaned into it as she closed her eyes on the pearlescent city sunset that shimmered in front of her.

The smell was wrong.

She‚Äôd been feeling warm, caught up in the beauty of the moment. But once she closed her eyes all she expected was the thin, sharp scent of Aldera, crisp with an evening chill. And what she got was the thick warmth of flowers and water, brushed with old, worn stone.

It was wrong, and she hadn‚Äôt expected it, so she wasn‚Äôt ready when Threepio asked, ‚ÄúAre you ready to come inside, Mistress Leia?‚Äù

Princess. She‚Äôd expected him to say princess, and had to catch her breath before she answered, ‚ÄúIn a minute. I want to see this.‚Äù

Shmi wasn‚Äôt fond of sunsets. She‚Äôd occasionally joke that she‚Äôd seen twice as many of them as any other woman her age and didn‚Äôt respond much to Leia pointing out how different a sunset was when there was only one sun.

Night, it seemed, was not a time to be out of doors for Shmi Skywalker. No matter how much beauty the sky created.

To be fair to Threepio, he was quiet until the sun had dipped below the horizon. There was still a reddish pink glow around the buildings, but Leia accepted his, ‚ÄúI believe it‚Äôs dark now, mistress,‚Äù as she looked straight up and could see more than a handful of stars.

One of the many perks of being away from Coruscant.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm coming,‚Äù Leia told him, lingering as long as she could before accepting it was time to go back inside.

She did have work tomorrow.

The droid kept chatting about the sequence of the day and complaining about Artoo‚Äôs antics. Leia mostly tuned it out, missing what was, for her, the necessary beeps and trills to make the complaints into an amusing banter. But she didn‚Äôt discourage him as they made their way slowly down the stairs. She only rolled her eyes once, and that when she‚Äôd half caught a reflection of herself in a window and could have sworn she‚Äôd seen‚Äî

She had.

The shadow that was her brother blinked back at her, trapped in the light bouncing back off the panes. He stared at her soulfully, a hint of mischief in his eyes, but mostly grief.

She‚Äôd never be sure if it was the grief or mischief that made her believe.

Her lips formed the word, ‚ÄúLuke,‚Äù but no sound escaped as she brought up a hand, achingly slow, watching him mirror her until her fingers touched glass and the image of his palm pressed against hers.

His prosthetic hand.

The faintest line on his wrist to mark her memory, to test if this was right or just some cruel, delusional vision. She looked up again, into his face and there was only kindness there. Or maybe a bit of worry. She watched his mouth say, ‚ÄúLeia,‚Äù but no sound reached her.

It never would. She‚Äôd never hear his voice again.

But he was here. How?

Slowly, so slowly, she almost couldn‚Äôt breathe for how much this hurt, Leia turned on the narrow stairs, bringing her other hand up to meet his. She‚Äôd almost pressed it against the glass when she paused, hesitating. So unsure‚Ä¶

‚ÄúMistress Leia?‚Äù

Her right foot wasn‚Äôt braced right. She jerked, slid, yelped, and thudded on her butt down several of the stairs, throwing her arms behind her head in a desperate flutter.

Threepio‚Äôs, ‚ÄúOh Mistress Leia!‚Äù was echoed by Shmi‚Äôs, ‚ÄúLeia, are you alright?‚Äù as her grandmother dashed around the corner, assessing.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm fine,‚Äù Leia grumbled, taking a moment to catch her breath before she tried to stand. Her tailbone hurt. ‚ÄúI just slipped.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt slip,‚Äù Shmi noted as she helped Leia up, checking for injuries.

Leia snorted. ‚ÄúEverybody slips. I‚Äôm due, I promise.‚Äù

And better here than somewhere else, where someone important might have been watching.

Shmi smiled a little, but Leia could feel an almost probing in the air around her. ‚ÄúAre you alright?‚Äù

There were some things Shmi could do lightly, but looking after someone she loved wasn‚Äôt one of them. The intensity of her words was a balm though, and Leia leaned into it and into Shmi‚Äôs offered hug, taking a moment before she answered. ‚ÄúI keep seeing ghosts.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood ones? Or bad ones?‚Äù

It was such a practical answer Leia almost giggled. ‚ÄúGood ones. One,‚Äù she corrected absently. ‚ÄúJust one.‚Äù

‚ÄúYour brother?‚Äù Shmi asked, and now she was gentle, so very careful.

Blinking tears Leia just nodded into Shmi‚Äôs shoulder, breathing as slowly and evenly as she could. Noticing the smells, the sounds, in the half lit hallway.

Taking nothing for granted.

Shmi‚Äôs quiet, ‚ÄúI‚Äôve got you,‚Äù kept Leia grounded, even as she felt like part of her was slipping away. A warm hand making circles on her back soothed tension, a hum in her ear kept her present and calm.

She‚Äôd pulled back and offered Shmi a weak smile when Threepio said, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sorry Mistress Leia, but I‚Äôve just realized I don‚Äôt know where you‚Äôre from or how you honor your dead. If you tell me I can get you anything you need and make any necessary arrangements for you to‚Äîwell, would it be to release or invite the spirit of your brother? Oh dear‚Ä¶‚Äù

It shouldn‚Äôt have been funny, but Leia chuckled, reaching out to brush her knuckles across his cheek. ‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù she whispered before he could splutter with too much indignation. ‚ÄúI really appreciate you offering that.‚Äù

‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt offer you less,‚Äù he protested. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre part of the family. We have to take care of you. Especially since you‚Äôre always getting yourself into trouble.‚Äù

She could hardly argue with that. ‚ÄúWell, thank you. I really, really do appreciate it.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre quite welcome, I‚Äôm sure. But where exactly are you from?‚Äù

It was‚Ä¶ painful to admit it. She was so careful to guard so many of her secrets. But this was Threepio, and if she‚Äôd learned anything it was that for all his talk, he could keep a secret.

And Shmi would never tell. Not a soul.

Leia whispered, choking over years of memories (and it was real and would never be dead again). ‚ÄúI grew up on Alderaan.‚Äù

It wasn‚Äôt as simple as just sending Threepio out, unfortunately.

First, Leia had to decide what kind of ceremony or memorial she wanted to have, given that most the traditional options for Alderaanian funereal memorials weren‚Äôt really an option in Theed. And that Luke‚Äôs ghost was apparently haunting her in mirrors (that was not how he‚Äôd described dead Obi-Wan and Yoda) and she wasn‚Äôt sure she really wanted to get rid of him and send him peacefully on to the afterlife.

If he would even allow it. She was pretty sure he wouldn‚Äôt.

‚ÄúWhat would you like?‚Äù Shmi asked, sipping her tea and keeping a sharp eye on how often Leia sipped hers.

It was hard. Hard to even think about it. ‚ÄúI feel‚Ä¶‚Äù so hard to say it. ‚ÄúI feel like he has a message for me. But I‚Äôm not sure Alderaan has anything to invite wisdom like that.‚Äù

Once she said it, she knew it was wrong. Knowledge and wisdom of the ancestors was frequently sought on Alderaan. Mostly in old tomes and poetry, bit and pieces of wisdom that had survived ages by process of elimination. But sometimes‚Ä¶

Sometimes you went to the mountains, the temple made by the gods, and asked for a vision.

Not that Leia believed in all that. Even with the Force. And there were no mountains around here. But it was as good a place to start as any.

‚ÄúYou need a sacred space,‚Äù she murmured, turning her mug in her hands. ‚ÄúMaybe a holy one, but more‚Ä¶ private. Personal.‚Äù

Intimate. Quiet.

Meditative.

Damn Jedi, ruining every good, normal thing she had left. Couldn‚Äôt even think about meditating any more without feeling a sense of foreignness to it.

In the end, she and Shmi had come up with something that was a mix of various ideas and cultures, frequently unrelated, and yet‚Ä¶

Cleansing baths were a common tradition between Alderaanian and Naboo culture, with small detail variance. Alderaan favored hot or cold sacred springs, Naboo, elaborate ritual baths with herbs and flowers, each with their own symbolism. Leia wasn‚Äôt intimately familiar with it, but Shmi had been learning about the local flora and was able to prepare a mixture.

Sword lilies, rosemary, and blue salvia for remembrance, wisdom, and healing. Red and white chrysanthemums for love and truth. Basil, thyme, and lion‚Äôs paw (a touch of home) for courage and luck. Hyssop for cleansing and lotus blossoms. For insight and eternity and being reborn.

And salts. Shmi insisted on the salts and Leia only felt that it was right. She wasn‚Äôt visiting one of the sulfurous springs in Alderaan‚Äôs mountains, but she did want to feel grounded. Besides, salts were also cleansing and Shmi said they were the sign of the desert that people carried in them, that bound water in flesh and reminded that the desert could give life just as much as it could take it away.

Leia liked the weight of that promise. The hope it carried with it.

Even in their relative poverty (Leia still hadn‚Äôt been able to get Shmi to relocate, even with both of their improved work situations), they had a good sized bath in their home. Shmi dimmed the lights and insisted on candles, placed at specific intervals around the room.

Leia was pretty sure the pattern if not the candles was a Tatooine feature. Hopefully it would mean something to Luke.

The water wasn‚Äôt just warm, it was hot, and the air was thick with steam as Leia slid in and got comfortable. She made herself relax as Shmi got to work, washing Leia‚Äôs hair and massaging her head and neck until she was almost limp with comfort. Leia didn‚Äôt notice Shmi leaving as she soaked in the silence, the only sound the slight pop of the candles and the steady rhythm of her own breath.

When the water was tepid she forced herself out, shaking a little as she dried, her limbs reluctant to carry her own weight.

The lights in the rest of the house were dim. Shmi met her and gave her tea to drink, warm and spicy. She drained the cup as quickly as she could, accepted her grandmother‚Äôs hug, and slipped into her room to curl up on her bed.

The room smelled of the same flowers that had been in her bath. Leia drifted to sleep half caught up in a memory she knew wasn‚Äôt hers, redolent with the scent of wildflowers.

Luke Skywalker was one of the kindest people Leia had ever met on any world. And even he could be a real ass sometimes.

It was an open field, empty and yellow gold. Not Alderaan, not Tatooine, and (thank goodness) not Coruscant. It almost looked like it could be on Naboo. Wherever it was, Leia had appeared here (only partially voluntarily), and her brother wasn‚Äôt anywhere in sight.

‚ÄúWhat do you want?‚Äù she demanded, lying back on the grass and staring up at the sky. It was bright blue, just after midday she thought. ‚ÄúI know you brought me here, so why won‚Äôt you tell me why?‚Äù

‚ÄúI kinda hoped we could just say hello first.‚Äù

She was sitting before she could think through the motion, reaching out and almost shrieking when he actually caught her hand, pulling and helping her get to him, to crawl into his arms before she screamed and cried like she hadn‚Äôt dared since she was a child. ‚ÄúLuke‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù he whispered, and she almost couldn‚Äôt hear it, it sounded so faded and distant even though she was in his arms, him speaking into her ear. ‚ÄúBelieve me, Leia, I know.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou left me,‚Äù she wasn‚Äôt sure he could hear her, the words were so choked, but he‚Äôd always understood her better than other people, and she knew he had to be feeling her in the Force‚Äî

Everything. Everything here felt real, in ways that almost made it feel fake and false.

He stroked her hair, and she could hear the tears in his faint voice. ‚ÄúI know. I didn‚Äôt mean to. I‚Äôm so sorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt go,‚Äù she was wailing, whining like a small child, and she knew and she refused to stop. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt leave me ever again.‚Äù

She felt more than heard him chuckle. ‚ÄúI won‚Äôt. I promise.‚Äù

The feeling of raw longing was dancing over her skin. Painful, it crawled along the surface of her face, creeped down the back of her neck, licked over her chest and ribs, seeped into her bones, sang down her legs and flicked back up and across her arms, itching into her toes and fingers and burning on the tips of her nails. She almost imagined that her hair was burning too.

It was a surreal sensation.

Damn the Force.

‚ÄúHhng,‚Äù Leia groaned, trying to roll over and only making it about halfway before flopping onto her back again. The pain flared, then faded slightly, leaving a tingling sensation behind. She imagined it would be back to pain the moment she tried to move again.

It was, but this time she made it onto the floor.

The thump summoned Shmi.

‚ÄúLeia? Are you alright?‚Äù

Hints of dawn creeped across the hall floor. Leia watched them for a few moments before forcing her eyes to move and look at her grandmother, unwilling to add dignity to the position of a single one of her other limbs.

It would be too much effort.

‚ÄúHnneh.‚Äù

Shmi actually chuckled, but held back her touch when Leia flinched. ‚ÄúThat good, was it?‚Äù

Voice, she needed to voice‚Äî

‚ÄúI saw him.‚Äù

She sent it out in the Force and felt Shmi‚Äôs shock as the words reached her mind, settled there without invitation or seeming origin. Then her grandmother just sighed, curled up comfortably next to Leia on the floor and gently laid her fingers over Leia‚Äôs, the softest echo of words coming back, ‚ÄúWill you miss him?‚Äù

Which was not what Leia had been expecting. Especially since Shmi‚Äôs mouth at least still worked. But, ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs still there. Somewhere.‚Äù

It was hard to explain, really. Hard to elaborate since she hadn‚Äôt told Shmi about the sky growing in her heart, covered in darkness that had used to be stars. How it felt like one of those stars was now peeking out, shoving back the blackness, making it retreat.

And it sure as hell didn‚Äôt cover why she felt like someone had lit her on fire or dragged her through the desert, leaving her as raw as she had felt the first day that she had arrived on Tatooine. But as sensation came back and pain receded, she knew she didn‚Äôt need to. The words wouldn‚Äôt have been adequate but the feelings, those Shmi understood. Even as they halfheartedly crawled their way across the floor from Leia‚Äôs mind and heart to her grandmother‚Äôs, oozing reluctance all along the way.

Exposing herself was a danger. Leia couldn‚Äôt escape that. But in this moment, she didn‚Äôt want to. It was too right.

‚ÄúMay I see him?‚Äù Shmi whispered when she‚Äôd had time to understand, to absorb. When Leia immediately stiffened she added, ‚ÄúNot right now. But‚Ä¶ someday?‚Äù

It was a reasonable question. And Leia couldn‚Äôt answer it. Because if she showed him, if she introduced him, she would have to tell Shmi the whole truth. And Leia was not ready to do that.

But Shmi wasn‚Äôt just Leia‚Äôs grandmother, she was Luke‚Äôs. The one he had actually known about. Leia had no right to keep Shmi from him.

Not if he really was staying. Wherever he was.

‚ÄúSomeday,‚Äù she managed to force out, the words scraping out of her throat, cutting past her lips. ‚ÄúIf he stays, I‚Äôll introduce him. Someday.‚Äù

If she ever figured out how‚Ä¶

Chapter End Notes

I've maybe been really excited for this chapter. Just a bit.

Resistance

Chapter Notes

As a reminder, this fic has been tagged with "politics" for a reason. You have been warned.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre having trouble maintaining negotiations. Someone leaked that the MCA is still progressing.‚Äù

His voice was calm, but Leia knew her fath‚ÄîSenator Organa‚Äôs expressions well enough to know that her fa‚Äîhe was furious. Probably about the military bill and the leak. The other senators on the call were also showing muted faces, but Leia thought Shea was also very angry, Senator Ta looked more than a little guilty, and Senator Darsana‚Äôs aide more than a little ambivalent.

Senator Darsana hadn‚Äôt been at one of these meetings personally in several weeks. Leia swallowed fears and prepared herself for the worst.

‚ÄúCan we release some of our counter plans?‚Äù Padm√© asked. ‚ÄúMake it clear that we‚Äôre also making progress?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe problem is we aren‚Äôt,‚Äù Shea‚Äôs tone was sharp enough Leia flinched. ‚ÄúThe Chancellor is managing all of our ‚Äònegotiations‚Äô at this point, and he‚Äôs not making doable promises. The Trade Federation isn‚Äôt going to agree to the concessions he‚Äôs implying on their behalf, and if they don‚Äôt we‚Äôre back to square one.‚Äù

Not surprising, but still saddening. Senator Ta felt the need to add, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure he‚Äôs doing the best he can. But these systems are in a state of rebellion. We can‚Äôt expect other members of the Republic to want to make concessions for non-members.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot all of them have technically left,‚Äù Senator Organa pointed out. Leia knew that tone. That was his, ‚ÄúI will not repeat myself again, idiot,‚Äù tone. ‚ÄúMany of them haven‚Äôt. But they know their negotiations with Count Dooku are giving them potential leverage with the Senate. They can‚Äôt afford to relinquish that.‚Äù

‚ÄúEspecially if they‚Äôre being accused of treachery,‚Äù Padm√©‚Äôs disdain was even more clear than Bail‚Äôs. ‚ÄúThey probably fear retaliation from the Republic, losing voting rights or tax exemptions because of their interest.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey are attempting a sort of coup. Surely, there should be consequences.‚Äù Leia always disliked hearing from Senator Aak. He felt like a sleemo no matter how many times she tried revise her opinion.

‚ÄúResisting centralizing power in the Republic is not the same thing as rebellion,‚Äù Senator Dio had been mentioning Uyter‚Äôs concerns about that very fact since this whole mess had started.

Unfortunately, Senator Aak seemed to regard her as much a traitor as any Separatist. ‚ÄúIt is if the Senate agrees that centralizing power is in the best interest of the Republic.‚Äù

‚ÄúLet‚Äôs not confuse treason with disagreement,‚Äù Senator Organa said firmly, leaning forward. Not a good sign. ‚ÄúAs members of the Senate we frequently continue to debate statutes and orders even after they have been signed into law. Rebellion implies something very specific, and does not include negotiations with suspect parties.‚Äù

Actually, that was fundamentally untrue. Leia knew from plenty of personal experience that systems could dabble in rebellion by negotiating trade deals, arms trades, and travel agreements, all without ever lifting a weapon against their central government. The Alliance had relied on that to continue when they hadn‚Äôt been able to get more offensive results.

Before anyone could point that out, Padm√© had added, ‚ÄúAnd the Republic is by nature a governing body where all of its members were, at one point or another, at war with each other. We leave grievances in the past when we welcome new members. There‚Äôs no reason to hold grudges against current ones.‚Äù

‚ÄúLike the Trade Federation?‚Äù Senator Darsana‚Äôs aide suggested softly, the play of his hands warning Leia of the undercurrents of that statement. She couldn‚Äôt reach Padm√©, but made a gesture to Dorm√©, who was standing behind the holo equipment, and who passed the message along.

Caution.

‚ÄúEven you would agree, Senator Amidala, that justice is required for members to completely forgive past grievances?‚Äù Senator Aak was far too smug with that statement.

When Padm√© couldn‚Äôt immediately answer, Senator Mothma stepped in, saying, ‚ÄúWe do have a desire for justice. But not all justice is punishment. Sometimes justice is forgiving the unconventional, because they are the ones who have been wronged. The Chancellor‚Äôs negotiations more than suggest the dissenting members have valid concerns that require redress.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe also insists the matter will not come to war,‚Äù Senator Darsana‚Äôs aide was cool and remote, still in a way that made Leia more nervous than movement would have. ‚ÄúAs if war were not already a reality for many of our people.‚Äù

‚ÄúMany of our systems are suffering in violent conflicts,‚Äù Padm√© agreed. ‚ÄúBut that doesn‚Äôt mean we can‚Äôt act to prevent a civil war. Which is the matter of discussion before the Senate.‚Äù

Senator Aak shook his head. ‚ÄúThe matter before the Senate is the development of an army to keep the peace. To support the Jedi. No one said anything about building one to ignite a civil conflict.‚Äù

But that was what it would do, especially at this point in the negotiations. Suggest that the Republic was willing to enforce their points by more violence, rather than solving the underlying problems. Problems that could be aided by first passing more restrictive legislation for certain trade guilds and commerce unions, and then having the physical organizations to enforce them.

As much as she wanted to simply vote no against any army, Leia knew they couldn‚Äôt. Which probably made it a good thing that she wasn‚Äôt in this senate. She would only cause rifts between her and the people she valued the most.

‚ÄúThe issue still stands that an army of the Republic would be underfunded and undertrained,‚Äù Padm√© had made it through a list of points in retaliation to Senator Aak and was getting frustrated. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt have the infrastructure right now, or the personnel. We‚Äôd be better suited using our time to improve our refugee efforts and by reaching out to one another to see if we can meet other needs.‚Äù

Sliding in with a smile, Shea added, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been implementing some measures suggested by and tested on Naboo for integrating and placing refugees. The preliminary results have been more successful than I had hoped. I would recommend that each of us on this committee review the program and see if we can‚Äôt make adjustments.‚Äù She cut off Senator Ta‚Äôs spluttered objections with, ‚ÄúEven if all our negotiations fail and we do eventually go to war, having the ability to move more refugees can only be an asset in that situation, not a burden. Better to test it now rather than later.‚Äù

Bless Shea, she really understood. It had taken some time and a few more meetings, but she‚Äôd won Shmi over with her persistence and straightforward acknowledgment of the problems most refugees faced. Being unwanted. Being foreign. Being displaced.

They were having a good deal of success on Herdessa, placing people in jobs more quickly than they had on Naboo. It was harder for families with children, the education options were more restricted. But there was real promise. And the more kinds of systems that entered the project, the more easily they could cover for each other‚Ä¶

Shmi had been delighted when Shea had presented a list of systems she thought should be approached next and had promised to strong arm some of them into cooperating if needed. It was a relief. Shmi and Shea were both far too stubborn to be at odds with each other and not have it impact Leia‚Äôs life.

And speaking of at odds. There was a palpable tension in the room when the call ended.

‚ÄúWell that could have gone better,‚Äù Governor Bibble was an interesting mix of occasional optimism and persistent pessimism. Leia tried not to roll her eyes. ‚ÄúDo you think they listened to you at all?‚Äù

‚ÄúA few of them,‚Äù Padm√© said, her posture an almost perfect match to the queen‚Äôs, sitting across the room. Old habits. ‚ÄúBail‚Äôs insisted‚ÄîSenator Organa that is‚Äîthat I take point on this. And I think it‚Äôs been a big help. I‚Äôm not stepping on his toes nearly as much and he says I have the passion to carry this through where more placid tempers could look like complacency.‚Äù

Leia didn‚Äôt giggle, but she couldn‚Äôt look at Cord√©‚Äôs face. If she did they would both laugh. The queen only smiled. ‚ÄúHe trusts you to seek justice, not simply have your way. That is bold of him.‚Äù

Brave too, Leia thought. Padm√© lacked experience as a senator. She was a brilliant strategist, had firm morals and ethics, and believed government existed for the support of the people. But she did not have a lot of experience being a part of senatorial style committees, and for all of her awareness of Mid and Outer Rim problems, she could sometimes be short sighted.

Her open disdain for the Trade Federation being the easiest example. Leia agreed with Padm√©‚Äôs sentiments, but knew Senator Organa had made better progress recruiting from the Federation‚Äôs allies by keeping certain caustic opinions to himself.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll do our best to honor that trust,‚Äù Cord√© actually spoke up. ‚ÄúWe could use some assistance from the council. If the refugee program is going to be offered as an official alternative focus, we‚Äôll need more data and reports on what sectors the refugees are succeeding in right now verses where we can make improvements.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll discuss moving funds,‚Äù the queen couldn‚Äôt have missed the winces on several faces, but she was as calm as ever. ‚ÄúCity beautification can be adjusted, we‚Äôve repaired the worst of the damage from ten years ago. And we may be able to access monies from our security forces if we send promising refugee recruits their way. Any other suggestions?‚Äù

As fun as it would be to watch council members volunteering each other‚Äôs budgets, Leia was glad when Padm√© stood and gestured for her handmaidens to follow her.

‚ÄúWell, that was exciting.‚Äù Leia‚Äôs sarcasm won a smile from Padm√©, but also a shake of the head.

‚ÄúWe need more to be getting done, and we need it fast. The refugee settlement will help with some backlogged problems, but it doesn‚Äôt change the terms of negotiation as far as the Chancellor has laid them out.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt mention the mining guild disputes,‚Äù Cord√©‚Äôs voice was soft, but the condemnation in those words was powerful.

Padm√© only sniffed. ‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt relevant.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou promised to keep Senator Organa aware of any political motives that might have led to the shooting.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe guild members aren‚Äôt that angry.‚Äù

The palace didn‚Äôt lend itself to bickering, and so the conversation stopped, but Leia found herself torn on which side to come down on. Cord√© was right in that there was some evidence of discontent, with the refugee situation and higher restrictions with new safety protocols, and something was better than nothing since they still hadn‚Äôt found the shooter yet.

But‚Ä¶ assassination? Of a favored and revered queen? Unlikely. There was nothing in the incident to suggest the threat was related to problems on Naboo. At all.

‚ÄúMistress Leia, there‚Äôs been an explosion near the palace!‚Äù

She hadn‚Äôt needed Threepio‚Äôs panicked words to tell her something was wrong. Leia‚Äôs heart had suddenly jolted in a very unpleasant way only an hour ago, and she hadn‚Äôt been able to reach anyone on planet for just as long, to get reassurances and an explanation.

‚ÄúWhere?‚Äù

The grey and black of the station walls was the wrong shape, but only the hint of similarity was needed for Leia to remember, to regret. To be dragged back into stillness and silence in her own soul, shoving aside panic to make room for reason and action.

Panic would come later, after the battle had stopped.

Crisp steps down the hallway, measured so that Threepio could keep up and give her the news, ‚ÄúCaptain Typho won‚Äôt report any casualties, but there‚Äôs been serious damage to the several of the Gungan/Naboo peace structures near the gardens. The senator‚Äôs party was supposed to go there today and no one will tell me if they stuck to their original schedule.‚Äù

They had, Leia knew it as she flew down a flight of stairs and ignored the looks she was getting from the miners watching her. If there had been an explosion someone had confirmed Padm√©‚Äôs presence (Leia had told them the senator was the real target) before they struck. There was no other reason to hit that target at this time.

Shmi.

The thought made Leia pause, long enough Threepio almost crashed into her. She ignored his yelp and concerned questions as she followed the logic of that thought.

No, Shmi wouldn‚Äôt have been a target. She‚Äôd been very careful not to let her name be listed as a voting member of the RRM committee. Because she technically wasn‚Äôt. Ruwee might have been a secondary objective if the goal had been to harm Padm√©. Or any of the other committee members could have been. Master Zapalo had a sister there, and he‚Äôd voiced concerns about the new budget. How it might hamper further exploration and settlement of the moons by slowing the needed research. If family were harmed as well‚Ä¶

The problem was that the more Leia thought about the attack, the more unclear it became who might be the target. Or possibly, the more clear it became that everyone had been an excellent target in one way or another.

The people of Naboo might have smaller gaps between some of their classes, but the government in particular was run by a close knit community of family and old friends. Padm√©‚Äôs coronation had been significant for that reason. Not that she had no connections, but no one would have said they were the right ones. Not for being Queen.

Damn Palpatine. He must have known that.

‚ÄúIs something the matter?‚Äù Joff Kareen hadn‚Äôt been happy to see Leia and seemed more than happy to see she might be going, but he could read situations as well as any dubious entrepreneur could. His frowned deepened the more he studied her face. ‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt had a report of any accidents in the mine.‚Äù

Which was where Leia was supposed to be while he was supposedly helping trainees (she suspected he was actually checking his books, but‚Ä¶). ‚ÄúNot in the mine. In Theed. I need to return to the planet.‚Äù

His blanch was an interesting response and part of Leia‚Äôs mind registered it while the other part was figuring out how she was going to convince her pilot to let her take over without incapacitating him.

She wasn‚Äôt Luke, but she could fly better than that slug.

‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt heard anything from the planet,‚Äù Joff had fallen into step beside her and was checking for messages, sending a few of his own. ‚ÄúHas the senator been harmed?‚Äù

He sounded certain and worried. Leia filed that away too, wishing he wasn‚Äôt distracting her. Should she threaten Myleen or try and bribe him? How much cash did Leia have on her anyway? ‚ÄúThe message I received was short. I don‚Äôt have confirmation on which parties were involved, just the time and the location. But I do need to be there.‚Äù

It was too much of an ingrained reflex to not throw Joff into the nearest wall when he grabbed her arm, leveraging him in a way that he had not been prepared for and keeping him there. But when he‚Äôd taken a moment to be surprised, he surprised her by saying, ‚ÄúShe was our queen too. We disagree with the restrictions that she‚Äôs suggesting, but we wouldn‚Äôt hurt her. You know that, don‚Äôt you?‚Äù

Leverage. Leia was being used as leverage, as a witness. Was she being conned or‚Äî

No.

No, his expression was one of fear. He leaked surprise and reluctance, and he sure as hell didn‚Äôt want her going over his books, not before he‚Äôd thoroughly cooked and cleaned them. But he didn‚Äôt want Padm√© dead.

His people however‚Ä¶

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure the guard will look into it,‚Äù Leia said, easing back and letting him get his feet under him again. ‚ÄúMy concern right now is getting back to the planet.‚Äù

‚ÄúTake my ship.‚Äù He seemed almost as shocked that he‚Äôd offered as she was. But he persisted. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a newer class than yours, one that‚Äôs still technically in testing and development. She‚Äôll get you there faster, and she‚Äôs easier to maneuver in city traffic.‚Äù

Meaning it was a small enough ship to be allowed into city traffic, meaning not the clunky transport Leia had come in, and not one she would have to leave at the outskirt docks and catch another transport from.

‚ÄúThank you, I appreciate it.‚Äù

And she did. But it didn‚Äôt mean she was going to go easy on him when she did get her hands on his books.

She hadn‚Äôt been studying the Trade Federation for the last months for nothing.

‚ÄúMy pilot will meet you in hangar three,‚Äù he told her, and Leia sighed as she turned. But that wasn‚Äôt fair. Joff was an efficient person. He‚Äôd probably hired someone who could actually fly.

The blackness of space was speckled with stars. Stars that didn‚Äôt blur together nearly enough for how fast they were going. Leia watched, taking the time to breathe and try not to panic. It would do no good to panic. The ship would go only as fast as the ship would go, the pilot did know what she was doing. Leia‚Äôs comms would tell her if anyone was trying to reach her with news‚Ä¶

There was a white blue sheen reflecting off of Threepio and Leia tried to see if she could spot Luke in it. He wasn‚Äôt consistent with the surfaces he appeared on, or when, but she‚Äôd seen him a few more times since that night, always with a smile, maybe with a wink or a nod.

Just for a moment, and then he was gone again.

She hadn‚Äôt dreamed of him since that first time. But she knew she could again. She just needed to be not busy and with so much else to think about.

Or something.

‚ÄúOh definitely or something.‚Äù

It was the faintest echo of an echo. But in the cold and dark of space, when Leia was finally taking a moment to just be, she heard it.

It was definitely him. The brat.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre approaching atmo,‚Äù the pilot said, flipping switches and easing back into their seat. Leia shuffled a bit and let her head fall back, going limp rather than bracing for the transition. She found it easier on her ears during reentry.

And she wanted to hear her brother again.

‚ÄúCould‚Äôve fooled me.‚Äù

It was still so distant, but this time she saw him too, as the ship arced and a sliver of sunlight caught the view port. He was smiling, but there was a tightness to his eyes. Mild, not panicking. Something had happened. Something not good, but not unspeakably bad either.

Not something he had to baby her by showing up for, hopefully.

‚ÄúI promised.‚Äù

His mouth didn‚Äôt move, but the words were a little more clear this time, as if seeing him had brought him a bit closer.

He had promised. Promised he wouldn‚Äôt leave her again. And that made her wonder just where exactly he was when she couldn‚Äôt see him.

But that was a mystery she would have to unravel later, Leia realized as the angle of their descent sharpened. Right now, she needed to give her attention here.

Fishing

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre supposed to be on Ohma-D‚Äôun,‚Äù Padm√©‚Äôs scathing comment would have carried more weight if she weren‚Äôt buried under a pile of blankets, cautiously balancing a steaming cup in her hands. There was also Shmi standing over the senator, hands propped on her hips.

Her no nonsense gaze didn‚Äôt ease when it found Leia though, only narrowed further.

Oh well.

‚ÄúThreepio said there had been an incident. I had to come back.‚Äù Which was true, but it didn‚Äôt seem like either woman was thrilled by the excuse.

Shmi looked especially disappointed. ‚ÄúYou were examining the mines to see if they had good refugee working conditions‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt,‚Äù Leia said, and felt guilty even as she said it. ‚ÄúNot for the reasons that the council has suggested.‚Äù Some people just couldn‚Äôt believe spice miners weren‚Äôt always high on the stuff. Which was stupid. First, it had to be processed, and second they worked in a mine. Not that no one tried it, but they never managed for long. ‚ÄúThe labor is too hard for at least half of them in the condition we are getting them, and we don‚Äôt have enough protective gear for species other than humans. Not to mention most of the moon is inhabited by gungans and wildlife that they imported. Aquatic and semiaquatic based diseases are a huge problem in the mines already, along with other parasitically transmitted disease. And the medical staff is only used to‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúHumans,‚Äù Shmi was almost vibrating with frustration in the Force. For all of the changes that had come to Naboo in the last decade, the lack of diversity in the population was a hold out. The refugees were helping to tip the balance, but there were limits.

Shmi sighed and looked down at Padm√©, who looked guilty but didn‚Äôt say anything. It was a problem, but it wasn‚Äôt one she‚Äôd ever seen a need to solve and the senator was smarter than making excuses.

Leia didn‚Äôt say anything either, but she did take a moment to remember the human biased Empire and found herself unsurprised if disappointed. It had to start somewhere.

‚ÄúWe can work on getting a medical droid that‚Äôs programmed cross species,‚Äù Padm√© said after a moment. ‚ÄúIf we have even one, we can get a small test group approved to start working. It may not be the offload point we hoped it would, but that doesn‚Äôt mean we can‚Äôt use it.‚Äù

Which was all well and good, but, ‚ÄúAnd of course you‚Äôll be doing this from the safety of where, exactly?‚Äù

It had been a rough few weeks between the two of them, but Leia didn‚Äôt let the sudden spike of anger from Padm√© disturb her. She wished things had mellowed out, but without anyone finding the shooter and Padm√© insisting on keeping Leia on a short leash, the tensions just persisted.

Her trip to Ohma-D‚Äôun was supposed to have been a treat of sorts. For good behavior.

As if she needed one.

‚ÄúThey followed us here,‚Äù Padm√© spoke softly and Leia slid closer, taking a seat next to the senator and trying to ignore the growing anxiety. ‚ÄúWe made a bet on my people‚Äôs lives.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd we lost,‚Äù was left unsaid, but Leia could read it in Padm√©‚Äôs eyes. ‚ÄúHow many casualties?‚Äù

‚ÄúSix dead,‚Äù Shmi said, and Leia nearly choked. She hadn‚Äôt expected any collateral damage. She should have known better. ‚ÄúTwo in the initial blast, four more under falling debris, one of those when he came to help get others out.‚Äù

Bad, but it could have been worse. Still, ‚ÄúAnyone we know?‚Äù

There was a brief glance to Padm√© before Shmi said, ‚ÄúAll of them. At least, I knew the ones from the committee. None of the council or the senator‚Äôs party were killed.‚Äù A pause. ‚ÄúAnd Ruwee was injured.‚Äù

Which explained why Padm√© was still on site when her handmaidens had probably tried to drag her from the scene. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre acting as bait.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe know they want me,‚Äù Padm√© said, but it sounded more like desperation than certainty. ‚ÄúIf they come after me again, right now, there‚Äôs enough people watching we should be able to catch them. Violence isn‚Äôt a standard form of political protest here, so we know it has to be‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt,‚Äù Leia corrected gently. Although it was a reasonable assumption. Just not a certain one. ‚ÄúThe refugees come from other systems and could bring any number of behaviors or prejudices with them,‚Äù Shmi and Padm√© both looked ready to jump down her throat for that, ‚Äúand they make very convenient scapegoats for anyone who‚Äôs been wanting to try it. Not to mention bringing them here hasn‚Äôt been universally accepted.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut the dissent is small,‚Äù Shmi protested. ‚ÄúAnd quiet. Certainly rude, but not‚ÄîThey wouldn‚Äôt attack their own people over it.‚Äù

No, probably not. ‚ÄúBut we also proposed the program to the Loyalist Committee. And anyone there who doesn‚Äôt like it has good reason to try and see it fail now, while it‚Äôs mostly just on Naboo and can be easily stopped. Has anyone reached out to Shea? To see if they‚Äôve heard of something similar on Herdessa in the last few days?‚Äù

Shmi offered to make that call, letting Leia take over watching Padm√©. Who got very agitated when Leia shuffled to get right next to her. They bickered over the relative safety of the move, but Leia won when she pointed out if Padm√© was worried about safety she would have already allowed herself to be moved to another location.

It wouldn‚Äôt have been terribly surprising if Padm√© had said she just didn‚Äôt want to be trapped in another lockdown. Leia really understood that feeling.

Arm around the senator‚Äôs shoulders, Leia surveyed the damage. Three statues had been targeted, all ones of gungans (the real target, or a misdirect?), if she remembered correctly. They seemed more disintegrated than exploded, the majority of the debris not quite reaching the seared black edges of the blast zone.

Leia frowned.

She was intimately familiar with explosives. Being kept from the front lines of most major battles (for stupid, paltry, political reasons) meant she‚Äôd instead been assigned to a lot of saboteur missions instead. She knew the difference between equipment to short computing systems, punch holes in durasteel walls, and shatter armaments and bases.

To say nothing of the destructive capacity of variously sized shots from hand blasters to cruisers (and karking moon sized space stations).

This‚Ä¶ this was deliberate and contained. Deliberately contained.

And Padm√© hadn‚Äôt been killed by it.

Which, while a relief, was also very concerning.

The scorch marks gave a vague impression of where people had been standing, but a few gentle questions to Padm√© weren‚Äôt enough to come to any conclusions. The senator couldn‚Äôt even remember if the explosions had been simultaneous or in succession. Leia would have to see if there was a security feed so that she could get a layout and determine what had happened.

Was that technically the palace guard‚Äôs job? Yes. Was that going to stop Leia?

Absolutely not.

‚ÄúDo you think this was about the gungans?‚Äù Padm√©‚Äôs questions felt like a distraction and Leia only shook her head. There had been objections to the peace following the invasion, but most of the citizens had been relieved to have access to the gungans‚Äô subterranean waterways. It made moving goods across planet much faster. The rich and the lawless had always had connections, of course, but that prosperity spread during Padm√©‚Äôs reign and helped mitigate some of the damage done by the invasion.

Not to mention that peaceful relations with the gungans meant access to more territory and more opportunities to harvest the plasma that was Naboo‚Äôs main export.

And that was before a large number of gungans had settled Ohma-D‚Äôun, which had brought its own benefits, including the related technology discoveries that had improved spacecraft and environmental control system.

No, it was not the gungans, but that would certainly be a piece that was explored. Most likely at the Chancellor‚Äôs (quiet but insistent) request. Why just kill a target when you could sow dissent and uproot lives and traditions?

That was a much easier question to answer than Padm√©‚Äôs quiet, ‚ÄúDo you think more people would have died if I were on Coruscant?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou wouldn‚Äôt have felt less guilty even if it had been fewer,‚Äù Leia said, intimately familiar with this particular pain. ‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt matter how many people die or how few. When you realize you‚Äôre the reason even one life was lost, that doesn‚Äôt leave you.‚Äù

It had changed her. Every single decision she made. And it wasn‚Äôt Alderaan being destroyed that had done it. Her years as princess had been marked by more than one life lost in her defense.

It was one thing that had made the rebellion so much easier. They were so finicky about her being the surviving Alderaanian princess, especially when they had been pushing for her to help with recruiting. But most of the people she had lost in the Alliance had died for the cause, not for her.

It was part of what had made Vader‚Äôs torture of Han so devastating. She knew he was being sacrificed in her place. And then he‚Äôd had to go and be all noble about it.

The bastard.

Hells and star fire, she still loved him for it.

At least Padm√© had taken Leia‚Äôs words to heart. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre right. And it doesn‚Äôt make me feel less guilty now, to think some of them have been spared.‚Äù

Serious reflection was deteriorating into moping. ‚ÄúWe should go and see Ruwee. If he isn‚Äôt awake enough to be worried about you, Jobal will be.‚Äù

‚ÄúMy mother will understand,‚Äù Padm√© said, and Leia snorted. ‚ÄúAlright, she‚Äôll be upset. But if we can lure out our target‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúIf they haven‚Äôt come, they‚Äôre not going to. Not today at least. And we‚Äôd free up a lot more people for cleanup and investigation if they didn‚Äôt have to worry about covering you.‚Äù

By the time Shmi met up with them, Leia had almost loaded Padm√© onto Joff‚Äôs ship and was more than happy for the distraction of Shmi‚Äôs report. Nothing had happened on Herdessa so far, but Shmi had passed on as many details as she could and Shea would be on the lookout for any incidents.

‚ÄúSo it was directed at us,‚Äù Padm√© sighed as she collapsed into a seat. ‚ÄúAnd probably not about the refugee movement.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù Leia hedged, vacillating on the issue. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not convinced any of this is a simple one or the other motivation. The build up of refugees in general is related to the growing tensions across the galaxy. Anyone who is taking advantage of that, so they could justify a full scale army even, would be able to use both to obscure the other.‚Äù

Which was not what Padm√© or Shmi wanted to hear. And it didn‚Äôt get them any closer to figuring out who the shooter had been, or if they were related to this newest incident.

But the ship was docking and Padm√© was being escorted to her father by a small contingent of guards who wanted no distractions, so the conversation was finished.

For now.

Ruwee was sleeping, but it was not because his injuries were particularly severe. He had some burns, all carefully treated and likely to fully heal in the next two to three days. Not too much smoke or dust inhalation, but he was a bit older and there was concern over how much he had been shocked by the incident.

His wife wasn‚Äôt doing any better on that, and Leia could see that the doctors wanted to have her lie down as well.

But as long as her hand remained stubbornly entwined with her husband‚Äôs it was an unlikely outcome.

Leia watched from outside the room, keeping an ear tuned to the security comms and the regular updates the guards were getting. They tried to be quiet, but there wasn‚Äôt really much else to listen to. And Leia‚Äôd had practice listening in on conversations at Imperial galas and banquets.

An empty hall was practically a joke.

She was surprised to see Shmi returning. Her grandmother had spoken briefly to Jobal before stepping in to make sure accurate information was reaching the RRM, and the refugees. Especially the ones that had just arrived three days ago. No one needed to be overwhelmed with rumors that the organization that had just moved them between systems had lost its top officials. It was an important task and while Shmi was an efficient delegator, there was no way she was finished yet.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs wrong?‚Äù

Unlike the guards, Shmi did know how to pitch her voice so that it did not carry in an empty hall. Scary skill, that. ‚ÄúPadm√© is receiving a call, but Dorm√© is being evasive about who it is from. She doesn‚Äôt want to make the caller wait, but says Padm√© will need to take it in private.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe didn‚Äôt give any other information?‚Äù That wasn‚Äôt like Dorm√©.

‚ÄúShe said something about a fish? That Padm√© would remember?‚Äù

Well, that didn‚Äôt help Leia, but Padm√©‚Äôs whispered, ‚ÄúMina,‚Äù was a good sign when Leia slipped into the room to pass the message on. Padm√© kissed both her mother and her father‚Äôs cheek before ducking out, checking with Leia to make sure they could set up a secure line.

It wasn‚Äôt ideal, but Leia‚Äôd had to make do with much worse in the past. And hopefully the short notice on this message meant that no one had had time to inform Palpatine or any of his spies.

‚ÄúSenator Bonteri,‚Äù the warmth in Padme‚Äôs voice spoke volumes of her respect for this stranger. Leia tried to place if she‚Äôd ever seen the woman in the senate and was concerned when nothing in her memory stirred.

She also didn‚Äôt know the name from her father, which was even more odd. He‚Äôd always told her, at least in whispers, of the friends he‚Äôd had in the Old Republic. But if Mina Bonteri wasn‚Äôt a Republic senator‚Ä¶

Oh dear.

‚ÄúPadm√©,‚Äù the older woman was warmth and love and respect and it showed, even through the holocall. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad that you‚Äôre alright. I‚Äôve been hearing frightening stories out here.‚Äù

‚ÄúHave you?‚Äù Padm√© was trying for a light tone, but something like suspicion crept through. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt realize you‚Äôd been keeping track of me.‚Äù

Senator Bonteri rolled her eyes, her expression shifting to just shy of annoyed. ‚ÄúWe have been keeping an eye on the Republic senate, you know. And you in particular. Since you need so much watching.‚Äù

It could have been offensive, but the tone showed only concern, and something in Padm√© relaxed. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt think we‚Äôd end up on opposing sides. I don‚Äôt want to lose you, Mina.‚Äù

‚ÄúMy people come first, Padm√©, just like yours do for you. Ondera wasn‚Äôt made to be a Republic wellspring that they could wring slowly dry while we try and pretend there isn‚Äôt a jungle full of monsters just outside our walls. We need help, not just empty promises.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know. Believe me, I know,‚Äù Padm√© rubbed her forehead, and gestured for Leia to come into view. ‚ÄúFull disclosure, I don‚Äôt know if in keeping tabs on things you‚Äôve heard about Leia‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúCount Dooku mentioned her when he spoke of you. It‚Äôs a pleasure to meet you,‚Äù Senator Bonteri addressed Leia with a smile, but her eyes were assessing. Leia matched the expression, though she hoped her eyes were giving less away.

‚ÄúThank you. I didn‚Äôt realize I‚Äôd received any sort of official mention in the Confederacy‚Äôs reports.‚Äù And more disturbing that the mysterious Count Dooku had been the one mentioning. There was something about him, something important that Leia had forgotten.

‚ÄúYour work has impressed no small number of our members. And Senator Darsana speaks highly of you.‚Äù

The bottom of her stomach fell out and Leia prayed her expression stayed neutral. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm honored. I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve heard him speak highly of many people.‚Äù If any. And she hoped the conversation had been a casual one, not official.

She didn‚Äôt want to lose him yet.

‚ÄúWhy did Count Dooku mention Leia? He isn‚Äôt invested in the Senate‚Äôs work, is he? I thought his objections to the Republic were centered on the Jedi.‚Äù Padm√© was very good about asking questions that filled in gaps for Leia.

Senator Bonteri hesitated. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs true that he left the Jedi Order, but his concerns have always been with the greater systematic corruption in the Republic.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey can do that?‚Äù Leia asked, flabbergasted. ‚ÄúJedi can just‚Ä¶ leave?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs rare,‚Äù Senator Bonteri said, ‚Äúbut it does happen. Usually for philosophical reasons, like the Count‚Äôs.‚Äù

Leave. Jedi could just leave the Order if they didn‚Äôt want to be there. If they didn‚Äôt agree with the Jedi‚Äôs way of life or standards. If they, oh, wanted to raise a child or, or‚Ä¶

What the hell had Vader been thinking?

And what was this ‚Äúusually‚Äù nonsense? Did it happen often, or not? And if the philosophical differences were so great that Dooku had formed his own government to counter the Republic, should Senator Bonteri be treating them so casually?

‚ÄúHe could have petitioned for a seat on the Jedi Council,‚Äù Padm√© said, ‚Äúinstead of leaving the Order and the Republic. Or left the Order and taken Serenno‚Äôs senate seat. As Count, he would have had that right.‚Äù

More to the point, he would have had the power. A seat in the Senate wasn‚Äôt a guarantee by itself, but the Counts of Serenno had vast wealth and deep pockets of power throughout the galaxy. To say nothing of the power Dooku could wield through the Force. Especially if he were willing to use it unscrupulously.

That thought tugged in an uncomfortable way and Leia felt she might have found part of her answer.

Philosophical disagreements.

Right.

Well, maybe working in the Senate where a bunch of Jedi were constantly wandering the halls might have put a damper on some of the Count‚Äôs plans.

Lovely.

‚ÄúYou know what the Senate is like,‚Äù Senator Bonteri wasn‚Äôt inflexible, but her gaze was hard. ‚ÄúYou and your people have experienced it first hand.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhich is why I‚Äôm working so hard to represent our ideals in the Senate. Just because it‚Äôs come to a fight doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs come to a war!‚Äù

‚ÄúThe Confederacy of Independent Systems isn‚Äôt looking for a fight,‚Äù Senator Bonteri looked worried now. ‚ÄúOr a war. We‚Äôve established our own constitution and our members have joined us freely. And left the Republic freely, if they were members of that body. We‚Äôd be willing to negotiate with the Republic on trade matters, but we will not,‚Äù her whole body stiffened, ‚Äúbe accepting the standard contracts offered by the Trade Federation or Banking Clans or Commerce Guild.‚Äù

It was a moment before Padm√© could answer. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry Mina. It‚Äôs just‚Ä¶ been a rough day.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe Count said he was worried,‚Äù Senator Bonteri was all solicitation now. ‚ÄúHe said there were disturbances in the balance of the Force.‚Äù

And the woman clearly had no idea what that meant, not really, but something about her saying it made Padm√© even more stiff. ‚ÄúHe said he was worried about me? Or about the Republic?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou,‚Äù Padm√©‚Äôs friend was trying to be soothing, but while Padm√©‚Äôs muscles were relaxing, her tension was seeping into the room. ‚ÄúHe knows we were good friends, that I was one of your mentors. He‚Äôs concerned for you and Senator Organa.‚Äù

That was a threat.

Not from Senator Bonteri, Leia thought. But Count Dooku picking out the names of the two most important people standing against the Military Creation Act. A very deliberate choice on his part.

And what a convenient excuse, to be able to say the Force said it.

Leia didn‚Äôt know that it was a lie. Not for sure. But her uneasiness left it as a strong possibility.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs been in frequent contact with you?‚Äù Padm√© asked, not responding to the Count‚Äôs supposed concern directly.

Senator Bonteri nodded. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs in contact with all of us. It‚Äôs a small voting body, Padm√©. It‚Äôs so much easier to speak to everyone and negotiate. The Outer Rim desperately needs this.‚Äù

Which was an easy thing to say given that Ondera was actually Inner Rim. But the wildness of the planet had always made its reputation sharp edged. How nice it probably felt, Leia thought, to have the attention of a man as powerful and smooth as a once Jedi.

How heady and disarming.

How convenient.

Someday, Leia would outgrow her innate suspicion of everything and everyone. But it was not going to be tonight.

Padm√© didn‚Äôt admit what had happened to her father, but did tell her friend to listen for news of dissent from Naboo, and thanked Senator Bonteri for her well wishes.
