‚ÄúIf there‚Äôs anything we can do, Padm√©, let me know. We may be in different governments, but we‚Äôre still friends. My people are willing to help your people.‚Äù

It wasn‚Äôt fair of Leia to assume that was a lure, or a subtle threat, trying to pull Naboo out of the Republic. But she hadn‚Äôt survived this long by being complacent. And if Padm√©‚Äôs mood by the end of the call was any indication, Leia was going to have to be vigilant for both of them this time.

As Our Dreams

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

It was two weeks before Ruwee was released from the hospital, less because of his injuries and more because of concern over the lingering threat. Like with the shooting, no one stepped forward to claim credit for the garden attack.

Leia had given up on sleep.

Instead, she was working full time in the Refugee Relief Movement offices, helping cover for Padm√©‚Äôs father and doing her part to make sure the project expansion was ready for its new trial phases.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre just wearing yourself out.‚Äù

It was‚Ä¶ incredibly annoying how her brother could be silent for so long, not bothering to talk to her, and then just show up whenever he felt like it and start being a nag.

Then again, if dreaming was where she heard him clearest, it probably wasn‚Äôt the best sign that he was now always around.

‚ÄúSomeone has to do this,‚Äù Leia grumbled, making sure no one else in the room thought she was doing more than swear at her work. ‚ÄúAnd I don‚Äôt see you‚Äî‚Äú

The words caught in her throat and Leia had to swallow when nothing she did brought them out. She didn‚Äôt see him, not often. Even when she could hear him. She knew Luke was there, in an intangible way. But she couldn‚Äôt see him and sometimes‚Ä¶

Sometimes she thought she was crazy.

‚ÄúI love you,‚Äù the whisper wasn‚Äôt in her ears or exactly in her mind. It was a thread that vibrated in her soul, sang in her heart, songs she‚Äôd forgotten she knew how to sing. Cut and dragged around her spirit like sand carried by a desert wind. A relief and a warning.

Well, she may not be ready to go to sleep, but sleep should probably happen at this point.

It only took a minute to save her documents and pack her things. She stopped to talk to Master Zapalo‚Äôs sister, Klara, carefully not focusing on the fine sliver scar that ran from the center of the woman‚Äôs forehead, clipping the edge of her brow and the corner of her eye and scraping the top of her cheekbone.

Not noticing the three times Klara reached to touch it and stopped midway. ‚ÄúWill you need anything else for tomorrow?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo. I‚Äôm still working on a way to present the species specific data that doesn‚Äôt make it too obvious we don‚Äôt have a large enough pool to be statistically valuable while making it clear that they shouldn‚Äôt base their efforts on our results. Especially not in education. Naboo citizens almost exclusively speak Basic.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd many of the children brought here speak mostly the language of their native planet,‚Äù Klara agreed, shaking her head. ‚ÄúYour mother and Threepio have been indispensable.‚Äù

Ignoring Shmi‚Äôs misclassification, and the variety of dialects that Leia herself had at least recognized as she had met refugees, she said, ‚ÄúHopefully we will find a better method for teaching Basic to those whose native tongue is a complete grammatical and tonal mismatch.‚Äù

There had been some serious problems with a few groups in particular.

‚ÄúA problem for another day,‚Äù Klara suggested, offering Leia a tentative smile. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll see you here tomorrow?‚Äù

‚ÄúAs always. Try and get some sleep tonight.‚Äù

She ignored the way Klara‚Äôs lip trembled, her hands tightened, how every muscle contracted to not touch her face, the almost palpable fear and frustration that seeped into the Force‚Ä¶

Almost without thinking Leia reached out, pressing her thumb to Klara‚Äôs forehead and closing her eyes for a moment, breathing and reaching for peace. Peace and a blessing.

‚ÄúSweet rest.‚Äù

She said it using words Han had taught her, had whispered when he had been there to try and ease her own dreams away from haunting nightmares of pain and death. Felt, as her breath carried the words and the calm she‚Äôd tried to gather, and they lifted something around Klara, who was blinking back tears when Leia opened her eyes.

‚ÄúI‚Äîthank you,‚Äù Klara whispered, dabbing at tiny drops. ‚ÄúMaybe‚ÄîMaybe tonight will be better.‚Äù

Dreams of thunder and fire. Leia knew how hard it was to escape from that, even once you‚Äôd gotten used to it.

‚ÄúGood plan.‚Äù The words weren‚Äôt cocky, they stumbled too much for that. But Leia did manage a solid smile as she turned to leave.

Nodding to the staring staffers in the room, Leia slipped out, tapped a blinking Shmi on the shoulder as Leia walked past Shmi‚Äôs desk, and waited at the front door for her grandmother to join her.

Really, even if she couldn‚Äôt sleep, she should have left hours ago. Shea had her data and Syndulla could wait and Shmi needed sleep and could probably actually get it.

They let Threepio fly them home. He made anxious noises every time the speeder thunked or wheezed, but didn‚Äôt doze off on Leia‚Äôs shoulder or black out for two straight minutes between the government and the residential districts. He wasn‚Äôt the best pilot, but tonight it was definitely safer for him to be navigating them through Theed.

Stumbling and swearing, Shmi and Leia made their way into the house. Stairs weren‚Äôt an option. They both collapsed on the couch. Shmi‚Äôs breathing was almost snores in seconds, but Leia was awake long enough to feel Threepio arrange a blanket over them with an almost whispered, ‚ÄúPleasant dreams.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe have to go back.‚Äù

Padm√©‚Äôs voice didn‚Äôt shake, but Leia could feel the tension, the fear, ripple through the throne room carried by those words. Shmi had tensed and Leia couldn‚Äôt stop herself from biting at her lip. Dorm√© and Vers√© exchanged a glance, Sab√©‚Äôs hand had found Padm√© shoulder, and Cord√© had relaxed into a posture so perfectly mirrored to Padm√©‚Äôs it was a worry unto itself.

Eirta√© was staring resolutely ahead, hands not clenched but fingers twitching.

Leia didn‚Äôt blame her. Not one bit.

The queen was calm as she asked, ‚ÄúAnd the threats?‚Äù

Growing up, Leia‚Äôs dream had always been to be as good a queen as her mother. But if she couldn‚Äôt be Breha, Leia would be perfectly happy being Queen Jamillia instead. The woman was a stream of calm, calamity just washing off her and drifting away. She wanted nothing to do with it.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to have to be careful,‚Äù Padm√© answered, eyes flicking to Cord√© and away so quickly Leia almost missed it. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll want to be flying understaffed.‚Äù

‚ÄúAbsolutely not!‚Äù Captain Typho cut in. ‚ÄúMy lady, that isn‚Äôt reasonable‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúReducing casualties,‚Äù Leia cut him off, willing to carry a bit of his ire for Padm√©‚Äôs sake. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs almost no possibility of coming out of this unscathed. We need every advantage we can get. A smaller team is more compact, requires fewer guards, and is more mobile.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd makes the senator a greater target,‚Äù he snapped.

Leia shrugged, catching Padm√©‚Äôs half smile. ‚ÄúOnly if we do our job poorly. Are you saying you can‚Äôt provide adequate coverage?‚Äù

She really ought to stop baiting these people, but it was so hard sometimes. Their sense of impending doom was just too much to carry in these situations. It was jarring to Leia, to have such a fundamentally different scale of what complete disaster looked like (even discounting losing the Falcon and Alderaan).

Not that she wanted Padm√© harmed. Not that she was okay with the complete lack of trail that these crimes had left. Not that she wasn‚Äôt planning on solving that particular problem.

But death was ever present in her world. You couldn‚Äôt stop making the decision to act just because something was dangerous. Otherwise you‚Äôd never steal Death Star plans. Or rescue a friend from Hutts. Or hold a fledgling government together in the teeth of well-armed, well-disciplined opposition.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll need to come up with a new plan,‚Äù Captain Typho was emphatic. ‚ÄúThere are too many people in the senate who are familiar with our old ones.‚Äù

Governor Bibble sputtered. ‚ÄúSurely none of our friends have turned against us!‚Äù

It was a minor miracle that Leia didn‚Äôt snort, but she did twitch and that caught Shmi‚Äôs attention. Not ideal.

‚ÄúOur friends are as trustworthy as ever,‚Äù Padm√© said, her tone soothing. ‚ÄúBut our patterns are more predictable. While not everyone knows the details of my guard, there are more than a few who know I sometimes have a body double. Not who. I‚Äôve never revealed as much. But,‚Äù she didn‚Äôt grimace, but there was a tightness in her face, ‚Äúthe Chancellor has mentioned, in company, that my handmaidens are highly trained in combat and espionage. It wouldn‚Äôt take a huge leap to realize that when so many of them are my age and size‚Ä¶‚Äù

Unease rose again and there were awkward glances around the room. Advisor Brandes tittered, ‚ÄúA new plan does seem to be in order. I assume, for safety reasons, we don‚Äôt need to be involved?‚Äù

The nervous energy had Leia on edge, but she did agree with Advisor Brandes. Having made the decision to go, the fewer people knew what their plans were, the better.

Especially, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think we need to inform Coruscant of any changes,‚Äù Leia suggested the moment the door to Padme‚Äôs office had slid shut and only her handmaidens, head of security, and Shmi were inside. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre already aware that our shuttle is going to have an escort for additional security. Leaving things looking the same on the outside will make it harder to notice we‚Äôve made adjustments within.‚Äù

And would prevent news from reaching a certain madman.

‚ÄúI‚Äôd already thought of that,‚Äù Padm√© admitted, settling into her chair. Her posture was still a fairly close mirror to the queen and as she looked out the window Leia wondered what her friend was thinking. Her feelings didn‚Äôt reveal much, held too close for Leia to really parse them. ‚ÄúI want to leave Theed without cover and land with a double active.‚Äù

Frowning, Captain Typho said, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a fairly obvious move Mi‚Äôlady. And it doesn‚Äôt actually increase your security.‚Äù

Leia only partially agreed, but she tried to keep quiet as Cord√© and Dorm√© suggested steps that could be taken to contact Coruscant mid-flight, to further layer the deception. Captain Typho agreed to all of them, but insisted they needed at least two more guards, if not four, to act as cover.

‚ÄúThey tried to shoot you and there was an explosion. Even wearing armored gowns isn‚Äôt going to be enough if they try similar tactics.‚Äù

And what Leia wouldn‚Äôt give to have a chance to take a look at some of those. She‚Äôd always been impressed that Padm√© could wear clothing that was so heavy. It had been thrilling to know some of that weight was subtle and practical.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not putting more people than I need to in the line of fire,‚Äù Padm√© made each word a clipped decree. ‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôm not showing up looking scared. Bail‚Äôs at the head of our part of the committee, but some of the votes that we need to secure rely on me since he gave me this project. If I‚Äôm cowering behind guards, that undermines the entire message we‚Äôre presenting.‚Äù

Long past exasperated, Captain Typho growled, ‚ÄúMaybe it should.‚Äù

For a moment no one in the room moved. Then Padm√© was up and out of her chair, restrained by Eirta√©, who was giving the captain a quelling look. But it was Shmi that said, ‚ÄúThe message that Senator Amidala is trying to send to the Senate is to meet action for action, to balance reprisal for reprisal. What is needed is not for the wealthy and the wise to stand behind poor men who die, but for the Republic to take responsibility for its own fate. Danger may be present, but it will not diminish by refusing to face it.‚Äù

Her mouth wasn‚Äôt hanging open, but Leia knew her eyes were wide as she stared at her grandmother, who was now blushing and looking at the floor. Shmi, who hated the Republic in a cold and distant way that remembered only what it had taken, who would have dismantled it if she could.

Alright, Leia didn‚Äôt know that Shmi would have done that. But sometimes, when Shmi spoke, Leia did wonder.

Shmi was a Skywalker. They did nothing halfway.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to start a conflict,‚Äù Padm√© added, looking a little awed. ‚ÄúBut I do want to point out that refusing to escalate the situation isn‚Äôt a sign of weakness. Isn‚Äôt foolhardy. I don‚Äôt think the efforts against me represent the feelings of a large population. This feels like a very direct target.‚Äù

‚ÄúWith collateral damage for a smokescreen,‚Äù Leia felt the need to add. ‚ÄúThe source may be narrow, but they‚Äôre willing to fire scatter shots.‚Äù

Padm√© nodded. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve had more suggestions from some members of the Council that these are actions from the mining guild.‚Äù Utter nonsense. ‚ÄúBut I believe we‚Äôre looking for someone much more subtle and much more dangerous.‚Äù

Dooku. Padm√© hadn‚Äôt asked Leia to look into him, but she knew how to work Artoo around, and he had been helping Dorm√© and Vers√© on that investigation. A few personal requests and small adventures were enough to get Artoo to tell Leia the whole tale, such as it was.

Count Dooku was charismatic, convivial, passionate, and making promises to his senate to build a government that would never see corruption.

And at one point his apprentice had been Qui-Gon Jinn.

It had taken Leia a while to put the pieces together, but once she had the link between Jinn and Kenobi, it had been a short leap to Anakin Skywalker, who Leia knew, knew, was going to end up in the middle of this even if he hadn‚Äôt been dragged there yet.

And before you even got there, Dooku had left the Jedi Order. For philosophical differences. After his once apprentice had been murdered. By a Sith. Who the Jedi apparently were not informing people about.

Yeah, if that wasn‚Äôt the beginning of a nice revenge plot, Leia didn‚Äôt know what fit.

It was a little harder to pin down why Dooku would want to start a new government. Unless he was aware that the Sith were already ingrained in the current Senate. But no, there was no way that this new Confederacy was being led and guided by a former Jedi out of the generosity and kindness of his heart.

Especially since he hadn‚Äôt renounced his title on Serenno, but reclaimed it. Leveraged it.

The rest of the galaxy might be blind, but Leia wasn‚Äôt stupid.

And it looked like Padm√© wasn‚Äôt either. Thank goodness.

Although, ‚ÄúIf we‚Äôre going for subtle, instead of four guards, you could take me.‚Äù

That earned a lot of dirty looks. Actually, yup, she‚Äôd managed to get everyone in the room. Lovely. But it was Padm√© who said. ‚ÄúOver my dead body.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat would be what we are trying to avoid,‚Äù Leia stressed before anyone else could object. ‚ÄúAnd, like it or not, I‚Äôm trained enough to be a bodyguard. And people will expect me to be with you, but not to be your cover.‚Äù

She wouldn‚Äôt suggest taking Padm√©‚Äôs place. Surface similarities aside, Leia might be good at mimicry on occasion, but no one was better at imitating Padm√© than Cord√©. No point in wasting that.

‚ÄúSince when are you trained as a bodyguard?‚Äù Captain Typho objected.

Leia was within an inch of answering when she realized, well, bodyguard might not be the most accurate. But, ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt say I trained as a bodyguard. I said I was trained enough to be one. I‚Äôm a good shot, I‚Äôm observant, and I know Coruscant well enough to be aware of its particular dangers.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

Trying not to roll her eyes, Leia looked back to Padm√© who looked ready to throw things. ‚ÄúI can‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúHow many times,‚Äù Padm√© demanded, ‚Äúdo I have to tell you that you are not allowed to risk your life in place of mine?‚Äù

Which wasn‚Äôt fair. Anyone else in the room would be allowed. ‚ÄúWhy not? Cord√© does.‚Äù

‚ÄúCord√© has been with me for years,‚Äù Padm√© shot back. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve trained to take risks together. In ways that mitigate them for both of us. We have plans and counter-plans and hand signals, and eyebrow wiggles, and can practically read each others minds. Cord√© risks her life with me, not instead of me.‚Äù

Well, fine then. But, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not asking to take Cord√©‚Äôs spot. I‚Äôm asking to come with you. Because it‚Äôs a good idea and I can help.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôd love to believe you,‚Äù Dorm√© was speaking now, and it was scary how gentle she was. ‚ÄúBut we don‚Äôt have any proof you‚Äôd be up to the task.‚Äù

What? What? What? ‚ÄúSince when‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúLeia,‚Äù even Eirta√© was trying to be gentle, and that, that‚Äînothing could be worse. ‚ÄúDuring the shooting. You froze.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú

I saved her, Leia wanted to scream. I felt it in the Force and saved Padm√© and don‚Äôt you tell me‚Äî

Only she had. She had tackled Padm√© and then‚Ä¶

Then the world had slowed around her and everything was on top of her and she couldn‚Äôt think and she couldn‚Äôt breathe and she may have thrown them away from that first shot, but it was Kenobi that had gotten them out of the line of fire, and Dorm√© and Eirta√© that had stood guard, and Leia had just sat there and shivered and hid and‚Äî

And they had no reason to believe she wouldn‚Äôt do that again.

Hell, thinking about now, calm and away from it, Leia didn‚Äôt know that she wouldn‚Äôt freeze again. Didn‚Äôt know why she had in the first place.

It hadn‚Äôt happened before. Only when‚Äî

Vader.

Not the first time she had confronted him, she‚Äôd been snarky and vicious and stubborn then. But on Bespin?

It was like she‚Äôd been trying to move through sludge. Every moment after those doors opened and behind them was darkness and a mask and that terrible, terrible (how did he live like that for so long?), terrible breathing.

Han had gotten a whole handful of shots off before Leia had been ready to act.

But Vader hadn‚Äôt been there at the shooting. Hell, even Anakin hadn‚Äôt shown up until after things were under control.

So how could she just freeze?

‚ÄúI won‚Äôt,‚Äù died on her tongue before she could force it out. Her mouth moved, but words stayed locked inside, chained to a place she could see but couldn‚Äôt explain. Couldn‚Äôt admit was real.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure you are capable of taking care of yourself.‚Äù Eirta√© was wretched at comforting people. ‚ÄúBut we need this to work.‚Äù

Cord√© had buried her face in her hands and when she met Leia‚Äôs eyes there was humor and sympathy in them. It was Padm√© who added, ‚ÄúI need you here more than I need you on Coruscant. Your work with the RRM is going to be critical, however this vote falls out.‚Äù

Her soul lurching as she bit back a protest, Leia gripped her temper with years of practice and‚Ä¶ accepted the inevitable.

She had failed. There was something she had meant to do, a place she had meant to be, and she had failed to prove that she should be there.

(Again. Again and again, she wasn‚Äôt enough, never enough‚Ä¶)

‚ÄúStrength now.‚Äù Shmi‚Äôs hand was on Leia‚Äôs arm, offering support, her voice a gentle whisper in Leia‚Äôs mind. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm with you.‚Äù

‚ÄúI understand,‚Äù Leia managed to say. And then (so much harder), ‚ÄúIn that case, we should probably leave you to your plans.‚Äù

Safety in ignorance, what she couldn‚Äôt know she couldn‚Äôt give away (why they‚Äôd never told her, told her about her biological relations), and above all else Padm√© had to be safe.

It wasn‚Äôt a fight, she wasn‚Äôt on a battlefield. But it felt like one, and if she just shut it all away, put it someplace where it couldn‚Äôt hurt her, she‚Äôd pick it up later and let it shatter her to pieces.

She‚Äôd already turned and was five steps to the door when Padm√© called, ‚ÄúLeia!‚Äù

Turn, look, no accusation in the eyes, they were right, ‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

Not good enough. Padm√© hesitated before saying, ‚ÄúWe could still use your help.‚Äù

‚ÄúPlanning for something I won‚Äôt be a part of makes me a liability. Besides,‚Äù she would not look at Eirta√©, ‚Äúif something goes wrong, if there is a leak, then you know it wasn‚Äôt us.‚Äù

Shmi was here too, standing with her. Leia wasn‚Äôt alone, there was someone at her back. Still, the look of anguish on Padm√©‚Äôs face hurt. ‚ÄúWe know you would never‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúDo we?‚Äù Captain Typho was a threat. His whole aura was sharp and pointed at Leia. At Shmi. And she wouldn‚Äôt let him hurt Shmi. ‚ÄúSeems like these attacks didn‚Äôt start happening until after they showed up.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat isn‚Äôt fair,‚Äù and it was Eirta√© that came to their defense. A surprise. ‚ÄúThings have been escalating in the Senate that have nothing to do with Leia. And she has no Separatist contacts.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat we know of,‚Äù the captain objected, and while Leia was angry she saw his point.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll leave,‚Äù she said, looping her arm through Shmi‚Äôs. Solidarity. Strength. ‚ÄúIf the captain needs proof, he can work on finding some.‚Äù

She knew her tone was cold, as sharp as the mistrust he was sending towards her. Sharper. She cut through it, made him wince. Good. He should know, he didn‚Äôt threaten her. She wouldn‚Äôt abide it.

‚ÄúBy your leave, Senator,‚Äù Leia offered a half bow, still holding Shmi‚Äôs arm. Shmi made her own farewells and let Leia lead her out, saying nothing as they wandered the halls.

Leia didn‚Äôt look at the windows as she walked. The sun was past its zenith, dragging reflections of light everywhere. She knew if she looked she would see him, following their steps, worried as he watched her.

But there. When he hadn‚Äôt been there before. Shmi on her right, her brother on her left, Leia at least knew that she didn‚Äôt walk alone.

Chapter End Notes

I mentioned this when I first posted, but my knowledge of the Star Wars EU is dubious at best and if you recognize things from it, it's either a complete accident, or I know just barely enough about whatever I've mentioned to borrow the loose outlines and then make changes for the purpose of this fic. I appreciate the details that people share or corrections they make. I like knowing what my readers expect and new things I learn may (but probably won't) impact the fic. If you notice I go off the rails a lot, well, you've been warned. Again.

On a completely different note, it's always fun to read your guesses about what things are going on and what may happen next. It helps me keep up my own enthusiasm. Thank you all for taking your time to read this. I'm glad you're enjoying it.

Taste of Ashes

Making food was hard, but right now that helped. It gave Leia something to focus on so she could ignore the turmoil just under her skin, inexplicable in its intensity, jealous and enraged at being excluded.

Which was stupid. She‚Äôd practically kicked herself out.

‚ÄúYou want to stir it,‚Äù Shmi murmured from where she was cutting vegetables. ‚ÄúNot beat it.‚Äù

Well, so much for containing her mood. ‚ÄúYes, Grandmother.‚Äù

There was a spark of pleasure from Shmi as Leia said the word, as there always was, and it was a relief and a balm to her soul. A touch of the anger dissipated, leaving humiliation in its wake.

She‚Äôd thrown a tantrum. In the middle of Padm√©‚Äôs office. Like a spoiled child, all because she hadn‚Äôt been allowed to chase danger. Never mind that Padm√© and the handmaidens were right. Ignore that if she kept being in the wrong place at the wrong time Captain Typho‚Äôs accusations might become justified as suspicions.

She‚Äôd whined like a petty princess because she‚Äôd wanted an adventure and she couldn‚Äôt have it.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs more than that.‚Äù Luke‚Äôs voice was only the barest brush against her senses, and she was almost petulant enough to ignore it. She knew herself better than he did.

Except.

Except that Luke did understand her. Sometimes because they were similar, and others because they were different. Opposites even. He made himself understand her because he loved her, and he forgave her because he saw her as worthy of that love.

Even when she doubted herself.

Well, if she needed someone to bounce ideas off of, ‚ÄúI should have just kept my mouth shut, shouldn‚Äôt I?‚Äù

Sliding the vegetables into the pot, Shmi flicked a half glance at Leia before saying, ‚ÄúMaybe.‚Äù Well, there it wa‚Äî ‚ÄúOr maybe not.‚Äù A hum. ‚ÄúI hadn‚Äôt realized that Captain Typho felt so strongly about our presence.‚Äù

Leia hadn‚Äôt either, and that bothered her. She should be better than this. Not being in the Empire was making her slip. The stakes were just as high, higher here. She couldn‚Äôt afford a misstep. ‚ÄúMaybe he‚Äôs right. At least‚Ä¶ maybe being here puts Padm√© in more danger.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow?‚Äù

Since discussing time travel was out of the question, ‚ÄúWe both are sensitive to the Force. It responds to us. Things‚Ä¶ happen.‚Äù

But it didn‚Äôt feel right as she thought about it. Padm√© was surrounded by people that manipulated the Force. Even if she wasn‚Äôt especially close to any of the Jedi (and Leia wasn‚Äôt sure where exactly to put Obi-Wan on that scale), the Chancellor was a Sith and very powerful.

So even if Leia had just left Padm√© alone‚Ä¶

‚ÄúI cannot think of a single thing,‚Äù Shmi said solemnly, ‚Äúthat you or I have done to bring Padm√© misfortune, by our presence or our acts. She is brave and capable and dangerous. And more than happy to be a target without any input from us.‚Äù

Fair enough. Bail would have put Padm√© in charge of fighting the Military Creation Act even if Leia hadn‚Äôt arrived. It was something Leia‚Äôs father had spoken of a few times, that Padm√© had been deeply involved, even in that other life.

And she was making plenty of people mad with her position on it, regardless of Leia‚Äôs existence.

Still, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre right. But I still should have kept my mouth shut.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you think it is wrong to want to come to her defense?‚Äù

No. Leia had been raised with at least as strong a sense of responsibility as Padm√©. Alderaan was gone, it had been a long time since she‚Äôd functionally carried the full weight and burden of a princess. But putting other people‚Äôs lives before her own‚Ä¶

She‚Äôd been doing that on instinct her whole life.

‚ÄúWhat I want doesn‚Äôt matter.‚Äù

The words carried a cadence that was so flat is was almost numb. She rarely said them out loud, but in her mind? They circled over and over and over. For every fallen ally, every lost battle, every dream of Alderaan.

Of Luke and Chewie and Han.

What she wanted was often impossible. What was more important was what she had.

And what she didn‚Äôt.

And she didn‚Äôt have Padm√©‚Äôs trust. Or the handmaidens‚Äô. Definitely not Captain Typho‚Äôs.

‚ÄúLeia‚Ä¶‚Äù Shmi wiped her hands, watching Leia and being watched in return. The frown wasn‚Äôt just on her mouth or in her eyes. Something about it had settled into her spirit. ‚ÄúWhere do you go when you are lost?‚Äù

Home.

At least, that was where she had used to go. To her parent‚Äôs room to hide under their blankets, even when she was too old to need such a thing. To the Falcon, and to Han and Luke and Chewie directly when it wasn‚Äôt enough to just be on the ship.

To Lando, those last few days before she‚Äôd come here, trying to find in him the peace that she had known.

To Shmi.

‚ÄúYou,‚Äù she whispered, and Shmi‚Äôs eyes softened.

She stepped forward, taking Leia‚Äôs hands, bringing each one to her lips and then pressing them to her forehead. There was a whisper of words Leia recognized but didn‚Äôt know, some sort of blessing. And then Shmi spoke. ‚ÄúI will always be here for you. You may come to me whenever you need. But there are things you carry that you haven‚Äôt shared. That you need to face. And to be reminded of, because they are part of who you are. Where do you go when that is what you have lost?‚Äù

‚ÄúThere is a place you can put your anger. I can show you.‚Äù

The memory of those words made her shiver, almost wrench. He‚Äôd said he‚Äôd be gone, gone and gone and finally for forever. But she still remembered, still couldn‚Äôt forget.

But Shmi‚Äôs hands held hers and Leia knew what she had to do.

‚ÄúI should probably talk to my brother,‚Äù she admitted in a whisper, and Shmi smiled. Sweet and sad.

‚ÄúDo we need to send Threepio for more flowers?‚Äù

Leia shook her head, moving to stir their food. ‚ÄúNo, I should be okay without them. Now that I know where to go.‚Äù

But she‚Äôd take time this evening to calm down before she went to bed. Keep her own council while they ate, maybe watch‚Äîwell, it was too late for watching the sunset, but she could stare up at the stars. Find Alderaan, remember it was still there. That would bring peace.

The last spices had just been added when the door chimed. Leia froze, tasting spoon halfway to her mouth.

At this time of night. After what had happened.

‚ÄúShmi, don‚Äôt,‚Äù Leia hissed, but her grandmother just leveled a Look and headed straight for the door.

In spite of her best efforts, Leia couldn‚Äôt miss the hiss of it sliding open, or the soft murmur of Padm√©‚Äôs voice (of course it was Padm√© herself, she couldn‚Äôt have just sent a handmaiden to handle this?), or Shmi‚Äôs chuckle that sounded like it was heading back this way. ‚ÄúWe just finished making dinner. You‚Äôre more than welcome to join us.‚Äù

Since she was avoiding looking behind her, Leia couldn‚Äôt shoot Shmi a return look, so she kept her eyes focused on the pot. One more minute of simmering, and if Padm√© was going to eat it then Leia couldn‚Äôt actually let it burn.

Although it might chase Padm√© off if Leia did. Especially if she set off the alarms.

So tempting.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry to intrude,‚Äù Padm√© had to be directing her comments to Shmi because Leia hadn‚Äôt even turned around to say hello yet. How could Padm√© know for sure that Leia knew Padm√© was there?

Alright, maybe she was being a little petty.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs no trouble,‚Äù Shmi seemed to be willing to put up with the tantrum for now. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs always a pleasure to share a meal. And we know you haven‚Äôt eaten yet.‚Äù

Well, that was one way to force Leia into the conversation.

But the food was also done and it was time to start serving, and it was only polite to serve guests first, and Leia would never disgrace Shmi by being ungracious under her grandmother‚Äôs roof (well, not more ungracious). ‚ÄúHow much would you like?‚Äù

‚ÄúHowever much you‚Äôre having is fine.‚Äù

An excellent, polished, diplomatic reply for a situation where she couldn‚Äôt be sure enough food had been made for three people. So professional.

Padm√© was clearly searching Leia‚Äôs face for answers, but Leia had trained to survive the Imperial Senate. She had tricked (alright, mostly on accident) the Emperor himself and Darth Vader into not realizing who she really was. Padm√© was good, but she wasn‚Äôt going to read Leia if Leia didn‚Äôt want her to.

Even Luke couldn‚Äôt when she‚Äôd really shut him out.

Leia placed Padm√©‚Äôs bowl and got drinks while Shmi served for the two of them. Threepio was around, offering assistance, but Leia knew Shmi preferred to serve guests herself. He was invited to join them at the table though, and several times throughout the meal had Padm√© giggling over the tales he told of small children swarming him while he and Shmi made their visits, trying to outsmart the shiny man with all the bad words they knew.

Apparently, they knew quite a lot. But (and this made Leia giggle) not more than Threepio.

It wasn‚Äôt exactly a fight for Padm√© to get Shmi‚Äôs permission to help with the cleanup, but there was some wrangling over what needed doing, and if Padm√© really needed to do so much.

‚ÄúPlease,‚Äù had finally won over, along with, ‚ÄúI always help my family when I‚Äôm at home.‚Äù

Padm√© was really, really good with her words. Leia was a little jealous.

And that didn‚Äôt exactly help when Padm√© paused in the middle of drying the bowls to say, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry about today. I wasn‚Äôt trying to make you feel like you had to leave. I meant it when I said we need your help.‚Äù

When Shmi didn‚Äôt answer for them, Leia braced herself and said, ‚ÄúI know. But Captain Typho was serious too. And it did make more sense for us to leave if we weren‚Äôt going to be involved. It was Senate business at that point, not ours.‚Äù

It hurt, and Leia couldn‚Äôt be sure all the pain she was feeling was just her own. But she had put in so much effort on Coruscant and she‚Äôd thought it had been enough to seal her place working with Padm√©. In the Senate, not just helping Shmi back at home.

‚ÄúI know you‚Äôre working with the RRM, but unlike Shmi, you are still on our payroll.‚Äù Padm√©‚Äôs voice was carefully even. ‚ÄúAnd even if you weren‚Äôt‚ÄîLeia I know you froze after the shooting, but you didn‚Äôt at the banquet. Or any number of times before that. You catch things, notice little details that could be the difference between us successfully tricking someone and us not getting away. And it was you who noticed the sniper in the first place.‚Äù

Well, at least someone had acknowledged it. But, ‚ÄúI did freeze under fire.‚Äù

And dammit, why, why had she done it?

‚ÄúThat doesn‚Äôt mean we don‚Äôt need you.‚Äù

Leia heard the words, but noticed a catch as Padm√© said them. ‚ÄúAre you asking me to come with you? Because you have a plan?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Padm√© admitted, putting the last of the bowls away. ‚ÄúBut I was hoping I could run what we have by you and see what you think.‚Äù

Dishes were clean, leftover food was put away, Shmi was doing a final pass over the tabletop. Leia leaned against the counters and made herself look Padm√© in the eyes. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to say no. And I‚Äôm going to do it because Captain Typho doesn‚Äôt know you‚Äôre here.‚Äù

She didn‚Äôt flinch, but Leia had been around Padm√© enough know to know what that particular set of the chin with four quick blinks meant. She‚Äôd been caught, and she knew it. ‚ÄúHe was against it when I suggested we get your opinion.‚Äù

‚ÄúFor a good reason.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not going to betray us. It‚Äôs never even occurred to you, you aren‚Äôt a plant‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúAnd he‚Äôs still right,‚Äù Leia sighed, rubbing her face. ‚ÄúLook, I‚Äôm pretty sure no one‚Äôs bugged our apartment. I‚Äôm pretty thorough and I regularly check.‚Äù And wasn‚Äôt that a great look on both Shmi and Padm√©‚Äôs faces. Maybe she should have mentioned that to her grandmother before now. ‚ÄúBut this isn‚Äôt a secure space and you shouldn‚Äôt be sharing official plans in it.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo come to the office,‚Äù Padm√© shifted, settling in for a fight.

Leia hesitated, and then decided not to give it to her. As tempting as it was. ‚ÄúNo. We‚Äôre not going and you‚Äôre not telling us.‚Äù When Padm√© opened her mouth, Leia added, ‚ÄúCaptain Typho is head of your security for a reason. I‚Äôll admit, I sometimes wish he were a bit more imaginative, but if you act against him, purposefully and willfully, Shmi and I will have to be investigated if something goes wrong. And even if they don‚Äôt find anything, it could cost me my job.‚Äù

‚ÄúI decide who‚Äôs on my staff,‚Äù Padm√© protested.

‚ÄúBut the Queen can veto your choices, if not directly then by threatening to remove you from your seat for poor judgement. And you‚Äôre right, you are important to this upcoming vote. And any others related to it. There‚Äôs no point in sabotaging both of our careers and the anti-military movement just so I don‚Äôt get my feelings hurt.‚Äù

It ached to say the words, haunted her. By stepping back she was making a deliberate choice. If something went wrong she wouldn‚Äôt be there. Would never know if it would have been different if she‚Äôd come to help.

If she did go, everything could still go wrong. And there was no way to know which would be worse in advance.

Alderaan. Alderaan and choices, and every choice she had made to be a spy, a damn good one, up to that point. Every choice to antagonize Tarkin (and there was every evidence things would have been worse if she hadn‚Äôt pushed him), the decision to accept the mission to Scarif, lying to Darth Vader, sending Artoo off with the plans, letting the Imperials follow them back to Yavin.

Fighters had died. The Larses had died. Alderaan had died. Part of Leia had died with it.

And if she had to go back and do it all again?

Well, she‚Äôd certainly try and change it. She was responsible like that. But she knew better than to assume that doing the right thing always got you what you wanted. Or the best outcomes.

Or that you could guess what someone evil would use to hurt you, if given the chance.

She watched Padm√© consider her arguments and cross her arms. ‚ÄúI hate it when you make a good point.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt lie, that‚Äôs the only reason you like me.‚Äù

Everything around Padm√© softened. ‚ÄúNot the only reason. But it‚Äôs a good one.‚Äù A deep breath. ‚ÄúAre you sure?‚Äù

No, dammit, she was never sure. And she wasn‚Äôt like Luke who could not only use the Force but had an uncanny knack to walk down paths with unnaturally low casualties (minus himself, of course). Any reaching or feeling Leia did only extended so far, and while her general sense of everything to do with this trip and this vote was ominous, it wasn‚Äôt like she had a clear vision of what could be done to change that.

It was almost tempting to ask the Jedi. Almost.

But even Luke‚Äôs visions hadn‚Äôt been perfect, and, again, you never knew what someone evil could pull out of nowhere to hurt you.

She‚Äôd been ready to be tortured again on Bespin. She hadn‚Äôt been ready for what he‚Äôd done to Han.

Leia said, ‚ÄúSince you don‚Äôt have permission to ask my opinion, I‚Äôm going to say no.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat scared of Captain Typho?‚Äù Padm√© was trying to be teasing, or maybe goading, but Leia wasn‚Äôt nearly amateur enough to fall for that one.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want him coming after Shmi because he decides we are a threat,‚Äù Leia admitted. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not fair to her. Naboo is supposed to be safe.‚Äù

And Anakin would probably throw a fit if he found out Padm√©‚Äôs guards had arrested his mother. Which, while possibly interesting was not a path that Leia wanted to send him down if she could avoid it. Never mind what it would do to Shmi, and how little Leia‚Äôs grandmother deserved that.

Leia taking risks was fine. But she wasn‚Äôt threatening the security and home of her family ever again if she could avoid it.

And she could. No matter how much it galled.

‚ÄúPoint,‚Äù Padm√© was staring out the window again, tension building between her eyebrows. ‚ÄúDo you think Count Dooku did it?‚Äù

Tricky territory, but Padm√© did keep her word, so probably not something they had discussed as part of her plans. At least, not as a group. With Cord√©? ‚ÄúI do.‚Äù

It was a simple answer, and Padm√© looked surprised Leia had given it. ‚ÄúReally? I mean, we don‚Äôt really have evidence, and he was a Jedi.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe most damning things against him,‚Äù Leia said firmly. ‚ÄúHow much do you think Jedi get away with?‚Äù

And wasn‚Äôt that a complicated face. But Padm√© did look at Shmi, and then past her, remembering‚Ä¶ Well, probably remembering her own trip to Tatooine. ‚ÄúMore than they should,‚Äù came out in a slow, heavy confession.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have proof either,‚Äù Leia admitted. ‚ÄúBut I am concerned that he seems to be keeping an eye on you. And he‚Äôd have to be doing that through the Senate. And if no one you know in the Republic has mentioned, even privately, him asking about you, that doesn‚Äôt leave a lot of good options for where he‚Äôs getting his information.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe Force?‚Äù Padm√© suggested.

‚ÄúIf that was how it worked,‚Äù Leia snorted, ‚Äúwe‚Äôd already have the shooter. The Jedi are handling that.‚Äù

That earned an awkward shift. ‚ÄúActually, mostly they‚Äôre not. The Chancellor asked them to hand it over to the local security forces and his personal guards since,‚Äù she rolled her eyes, ‚Äúit may have been directed at him and it clearly wasn‚Äôt a foe the Jedi needed to concern themselves with.‚Äù

So that was how he‚Äôd been getting away with it. Leia‚Äôd wondered. Still, ‚ÄúAn attack on him?‚Äù Really?

‚ÄúWell,‚Äù Padm√©‚Äôs smile was thin and her eyes were cold, ‚ÄúI am his prot√©g√©e.‚Äù

If she didn‚Äôt already have a planet sized list of reasons, Leia would have killed him just for that. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll bet he thinks he‚Äôs really funny.‚Äù

That‚Ä¶ had been the wrong reaction. Padm√© thought he was corrupt, not evil and just frowned, before shrugging it off. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs insisting that I shouldn‚Äôt come back for the vote. That I can send someone in my place. Jar Jar‚Äôs willing, but‚Äî‚Äú

But no one really took the gungan seriously. It was hard, as Leia knew personally. He was, in so many ways, a walking disaster. But when he learned things he knew them. And he was very loyal to Padm√© and her ideals. As far as Leia could tell, he was also impossible to corrupt. Fairly easy to trick, but not corrupt.

Having him there would be better than nothing, but even if he could stand in for the Senator in a pinch, Padm√© was right that her actual presence meant the most.

And she‚Äôd been promising to come back.

‚ÄúWell, he‚Äôs wrong. And you know it. And you have a plan.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe do,‚Äù Padm√© agreed. ‚ÄúAnd it should work.‚Äù

If Leia knew nothing else about Cord√©, she knew the woman was more than competent to keep Padm√© safe. ‚ÄúIt will. And you‚Äôll be able to do your job. I promise.‚Äù

‚ÄúCan you also promise not to get into any trouble while I‚Äôm gone?‚Äù

Well, that one would be harder, but, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll see what I can do.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd you‚Äôll be taking Artoo,‚Äù Shmi pointed out. ‚ÄúSo there will be a limit to how much she can get herself into trouble.‚Äù

Half a breath away from panic, Leia was shocked when Padm√© just rolled her eyes. ‚ÄúI cannot believe she is the only one who‚Äôs figured out how to bribe him besides me. He has to be the worst junkie for trouble this side of the galaxy.‚Äù

Oh, she already knew. Damn it, Leia‚Äôd forgotten to tell Artoo not to mention his errands to Padm√©. Well, and he probably wouldn‚Äôt have promised. He was pretty loyal too. ‚ÄúYou should have met my brother. He was worse.‚Äù

The sharp snap of shock from the other women resonated with her own as Leia realized what she had just said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs right,‚Äù Padm√© was trying very, very hard to be casual. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve mentioned him. The Jedi?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah.‚Äù Leia wished she could just bury herself under something. She had not meant to open this conversation. ‚ÄúHe, uh, well. Jedi, you know how they are.‚Äù

Hopefully. Leia certainly didn‚Äôt know if all of them were as bad as Luke had been. Although, if the only ones Padm√© knew well were Anakin and Kenobi, that was probably close enough to the truth to slide by.

‚ÄúI can only imagine the kind of trouble Artoo would find if he was regularly with Jedi,‚Äù Padm√©, bless her, seemed to know the conversation needed a sharp redirect.

A pity Leia couldn‚Äôt make that observation really work as one. When she faltered, Shmi said, ‚ÄúThen we‚Äôd best keep him away from Anakin. They‚Äôve already gotten themselves into more than enough trouble.‚Äù

Right. The space battle over Naboo. How did this conversation just keep getting worse?

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure it‚Äôll be fine,‚Äù Padm√©‚Äôs cheer seemed a little less forced as she let them lead her out to her speeder. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not like Anakin needs an astromech.‚Äù

It could have been just Luke, but Leia was pretty sure there were a whole lot of ghosts right now that were laughing at her.

Shades of Memory

‚ÄúThat could have gone better.‚Äù

Given how well it did go, Leia was a little surprised at Shmi‚Äôs comment. ‚ÄúReally?‚Äù

‚ÄúShe didn‚Äôt promise to come back.‚Äù

Oh. Oh that was‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúShe made me promise,‚Äù Leia couldn‚Äôt decide if she was embarrassed or proud, enraged or entertained, ‚Äúbut she didn‚Äôt promise that she would stay out of trouble.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe can‚Äôt,‚Äù Shmi led them back inside, uneasy gaze towards the stars. ‚ÄúWhere she is going is by its very nature dangerous. She can‚Äôt promise not to take risks. Or to come back.‚Äù

Like Shmi and Anakin‚Äôs first parting, Leia realized. He may, may, have been going somewhere safe. But there was no promise his mother would still be there when he returned.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs nothing we can do,‚Äù Leia made herself say out loud. ‚ÄúWe chose not to be involved.‚Äù The arch look Shmi gave her made Leia correct that to, ‚ÄúI decided. And you didn‚Äôt say one way or another‚Ä¶ Are you? Doing something?‚Äù

Shmi‚Äôs gaze settled on Threepio. ‚ÄúI would prefer if she took someone with her. Someone I trust. To keep her safe.‚Äù

And Threepio was pretty much an important member of the senatorial staff. His presence could also disguise Leia not being there, make certain parties move with more caution. ‚ÄúWould you mind?‚Äù Leia asked the droid.

‚ÄúOf course not,‚Äù Threepio said, before adding, ‚ÄúThat is, I‚Äôd be happy to, I‚Äôm sure. What is it I‚Äôm doing? Getting the flowers?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Leia said, smiling because really, this was just like him. ‚ÄúShmi and I were hoping you could go with Padm√© and the handmaidens. Keep an eye on things and make sure she doesn‚Äôt get into trouble.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd let us know if she needs help,‚Äù Shmi added. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt want her to feel like she‚Äôs alone.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course I‚Äôd be happy to travel with the senator,‚Äù Threepio said. ‚ÄúOnly, do you think she is bringing Artoo? I‚Äôm not sure, if we‚Äôre trying to stay out of trouble, that he‚Äôs the best choice. I‚Äôm only a droid, you know. I can‚Äôt keep an eye on both of them.‚Äù

Already calling Cord√©, Leia said, ‚ÄúDo what Padm√© tells you to. They have a plan for keeping everyone safe and if you can help‚ÄîHello.‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease tell me she didn‚Äôt see you.‚Äù Cord√© sounded resigned.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù Leia said. ‚ÄúBut I did tell her not to go leaking state secrets in public houses.‚Äù

A snort. ‚ÄúYou would be worried about that aspect of it.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe wanted to make you an offer. Shmi and I.‚Äù

She had Cord√©‚Äôs full attention. ‚ÄúOh?‚Äù

‚ÄúThreepio.‚Äù

It took a few minutes for Cord√© to consider it. ‚ÄúAnd you‚Äôre not asking Padm√© because?‚Äù

‚ÄúShe just left and she‚Äôs flying. And if I ask you and you say no we can pretend this never happened and she doesn‚Äôt have to know about it.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd here I thought you knew her.‚Äù

Well, Padm√© would want to know. Might later find out. But they could at least keep it from her until she was back on Coruscant and unable to reverse Cord√©‚Äôs order. ‚ÄúDo you want him or not?‚Äù

‚ÄúDo.‚Äù No hesitation. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôll have to go through the usual pre-flight scans for malware and incendiaries. And we have a few days to prepare. We can use him without worrying Typho, at least too much. And he‚Äôs got the subtleties of Outer Rim mannerisms practically hardwired. We can‚Äôt afford to not take him. Especially since‚Äî‚Äú

Since Leia wouldn‚Äôt be there. And there would be people bound to notice, she realized. People like Senator Darsana who had stopped attending committee meetings when Leia hadn‚Äôt been brought with Padm√© on her short trips back to the Senate. The lone voice that had suggested not everyone in the Naboo delegation was completely anti-military, suddenly absent and silent.

It wouldn‚Äôt fix everything, but yes, Leia did need to have Threepio go. ‚ÄúIf I prepare some messages and have you pre-screen them, can I have him deliver them? I‚Äôd like to at least say good luck to Shea. And thank you.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood idea,‚Äù Cord√© agreed. ‚ÄúGet your messages ready and we‚Äôll have Eirta√©, the Queen, and Minister Tane review them. That should be enough for the good captain.‚Äù

But not invasive enough that Leia couldn‚Äôt send a personal message. Especially if she crafted it correctly. ‚ÄúThank you. I‚Äôll have those to you first thing tomorrow morning.‚Äù At Shmi‚Äôs cough, Leia corrected that to, ‚ÄúWell, early tomorrow. If I can. Maybe midday at the latest.‚Äù

‚ÄúGet some sleep,‚Äù was Cord√©‚Äôs cheerful answer. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre here for a few more days, there‚Äôs no rush.‚Äù

Well, that would depend on how well Leia could craft her message for Senator Darsana, and how subtle she could be. How much she could convey with written words as well as Threepio‚Äôs presentation. Maybe Threepio was familiar with Anselmian script and they had marks for more tonal or gestured aspects of their language.

Hopefully.

After a bit of chatting with Shmi, Cord√© hung up. Leia could feel plans working in circles in her mind, trying to pinpoint exactly what she wanted to say, when Shmi‚Äôs hands framed her face, waiting for Leia to resurface. ‚ÄúYes?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt is time for sleep,‚Äù Shmi said. ‚ÄúWhat must be said and what must be written can wait until tomorrow. Tonight, you need rest. And to find yourself.‚Äù

‚ÄúI have something to do,‚Äù Leia protested. ‚ÄúThat always helps‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúIt is a distraction,‚Äù Shmi gave no ground. ‚ÄúYou are avoiding what you feel to think. How can you reach out to your friends if you are not honest with yourself?‚Äù

Senator Darsana appreciated Leia‚Äôs frankness He might have a liquid temper, rising and falling with every push and pull of emotion, but he‚Äôd always met her honesty with honesty of his own. If she couldn‚Äôt be there, couldn‚Äôt gage his reactions to make sure she was conveying the right tone of respect‚Ä¶ She needed to be completely honest. In any way that she could.

And she really shouldn‚Äôt be trying to mediate conflict third hand on this little sleep. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre right.‚Äù

Placing a kiss on Leia‚Äôs forehead, Shmi said, ‚ÄúYou are a bright and hopeful star. Don‚Äôt stay lost in the darkness.‚Äù

Dreams were funny things. The sun was at its peak, the sky a painful shade of blue. Leia felt something that should have been a breeze but was more like the memory of one. And it was quiet. Normally in a meadow this peaceful Leia would have expected the chirping of birds or the buzz of insects. The sound of the wind that was moving the grass at the very least.

But in spite of the lovely scene, everything was silent. As if someone had stolen its voice.

‚ÄúNot quite. But it‚Äôs not real, so you have to be really trying to hear it.‚Äù

This time she didn‚Äôt move right away. Leia took a moment to breathe, to settle before she turned to find her brother.

It sort of helped. She did throw herself at him again, burrowing up against his side until she was comfortable under his arm, her head half tucked under his chin. ‚ÄúHi Luke.‚Äù

‚ÄúHey Leia.‚Äù

She didn‚Äôt remember waking last time. At least, she didn‚Äôt remember what had happened between turning into a sobbing mess and then waking suddenly, a mass of stiff muscles, locked bones, and skin that felt like it had been flayed. This time she would. ‚ÄúDo I owe you an apology?‚Äù

‚ÄúFor what? I mean,‚Äù she felt him smiling, ‚Äúyou never really give those out, so I‚Äôd be happy to have one, but‚Äîoof.‚Äù

She couldn‚Äôt elbow him from this angle, but she could throw a weak punch with her off hand into his gut. He seemed to get the picture. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù

And now he was sad. ‚ÄúNot for that,‚Äù he whispered, his hand stroking her hair. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to apologize for that Leia.‚Äù

‚ÄúFor letting you die?‚Äù For not being enough?

‚ÄúNothing would have stopped it.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf I had seen‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúLeia, I didn‚Äôt see it.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou never see when you hurt yourself.‚Äù

He stilled. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not true.‚Äù She looked up, shocked. He‚Äôd never mentioned. ‚ÄúI had a‚Ä¶ well what was sort of a vision. Before Bespin.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou saw Han and I,‚Äù Leia said. ‚ÄúYou saw that we were hurt.‚Äù

‚ÄúI did,‚Äù he agreed. ‚ÄúI saw that while I was training with Yoda. But there was another time, when I went off alone. He said the place was strong in the Dark side of the Force.‚Äù

And now it was Leia‚Äôs turn to be carefully still. ‚ÄúHe sent you there alone.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Luke was amused again, which was better than him being serious. Things were usually broken if he was being serious. ‚ÄúHe told me not to go and I ignored him. He also told me to go unarmed, and I didn‚Äôt listen.‚Äù

Well that was just practical. ‚ÄúSo what happened? Did the Dark side‚Ä¶ get you?‚Äù

A half laugh. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not really how it works. No, it showed me something. Something that was real, part of myself.‚Äù His hand covered hers. ‚ÄúIt showed me Vader.‚Äù

Leia froze. Something about the meadow greyed, darkened. ‚ÄúYou had a vision of Vader?‚Äù

‚ÄúNot like my other ones,‚Äù Luke said. ‚ÄúThose are more like dreams, or flashes. You‚Äôve seen them.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúThey aren‚Äôt always the future, Leia. I know you‚Äôve seen things from the past. Like Qui-Gon dying.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat was the lightsaber.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt was an impression. Of a memory. It was a trigger, Leia. You being curious, being powerful, listening. You did the rest.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo‚Ä¶ you wanted to see Vader?‚Äù

Luke shrugged. ‚ÄúI expected a fight. Yoda said there was evil there, darkness. Vader was the darkest thing I could think of in the whole galaxy. He stole my father, he hurt you, he killed people in the rebellion. He was dismissive of me and then tried to chase me into the ground. If a place was going to be evil, it made sense that Vader would be in it.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe Force connects things. Even when we don‚Äôt know those connections exist. I fought Vader. Not the real one, a sort of phantom, I guess. Menacing and real to me, but when I beat him‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúYou beat him?‚Äù Of course he would have. Luke always believed he could be a proper Jedi and defeat Vader. Only her brother.

‚ÄúI cut his head off.‚Äù Grim and serious again. ‚ÄúLike he did to Ben.‚Äù A sigh. ‚ÄúBut when I saw inside‚Ä¶ it was me.‚Äù

Still, frozen, unable to move for several heartbeats. ‚ÄúHow the hell were you supposed to figure that out?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt trying to tell me anything,‚Äù Luke laughed. ‚ÄúThe Force is, Leia. Everywhere and everything is bound by it. To it. And to other things through it. I went into a dark swamp pit looking for a fight, for an enemy, for evil. And the Force showed it to me, obeyed my will. Only in that desire was something I knew nothing about.‚Äù His fingers tightened over hers. ‚ÄúHe was my father. And by trying to fight him, I was fighting against myself. To my own destruction.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe was evil. You weren‚Äôt going to let him keep doing that, that‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúI wanted to stop him,‚Äù Luke agreed. ‚ÄúBut in the end, I wasn‚Äôt fighting him.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know. The Emperor killed him.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, Leia, you don‚Äôt know. You haven‚Äôt listened. I didn‚Äôt just forgive Vader, I stopped fighting him.‚Äù

And this time she heard it. Heard it and heard with it the truth. That Luke could have died. Killed by Vader, killed by the Emperor. Either of them. He‚Äôd given up the fight. Because he‚Äôd found something more important than that. More important to him. But, ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause the only thing I ever wanted, my whole life, was to have my father back. To believe he was still out there, somewhere. And one day, he was going to come for me. And maybe part of that dream had already died, but I couldn‚Äôt fight it, couldn‚Äôt kill it with my own two hands.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, he‚Äôd already taken care of that problem,‚Äù Leia grumbled, and Luke‚Äôs right hand twitched as he chuckled.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not saying what I did was right,‚Äù Luke told her, keeping her pulled against him. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure if I had died I‚Äôd have gotten an earful from you. Among other things.‚Äù Oh would he ever. ‚ÄúBut it was my choice. And I had to live or die by the consequences.‚Äù

And he‚Äôd lived. Because, ‚ÄúHe loved you.‚Äù Maybe not much, but, ‚ÄúIt was enough.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe loves you too.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs gone.‚Äù Finally, finally nothing but her dreams could haunt her‚Äî

‚ÄúI know. And I also know why. And so do you.‚Äù

She choked. ‚ÄúHe wanted me to fix thi‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNo Leia. He wanted you kept safe. So he sent you to the one place, the one person in the whole galaxy he knew would do it. The only way he knew how.‚Äù

Snorting, Leia said, ‚ÄúTatooine isn‚Äôt safe.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, but Grandmother is. And she could keep you safe on Tatooine. You could keep yourself safe there. We already know you can deal with Hutts.‚Äù

And maybe she was looking forward to killing Jabba again a little too much. ‚ÄúHe did want me to fix things. He said so.‚Äù

‚ÄúDid he?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sending you to someone safe. Probably the only one who can help you actually fix everything.‚Äù

The words echoed in the wind, whispered across the grass and slid over her skin like a promise. ‚ÄúNo. Not really.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat did he say?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou heard it,‚Äù Leia grumbled.

‚ÄúDid you?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

A long-suffering sigh, a kiss on her head. ‚ÄúI love you Leia. You‚Äôre my sister and you‚Äôre amazing and I wish I could be half as strong as you are.‚Äù Before she could respond he added, ‚ÄúBut you have got to meditate more.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe Jedi solution to every problem‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Luke flicked her ear and she pinched his knee back, making him wince. ‚ÄúBut part of how we deal with the Force. You‚Äôre using it now Leia, but if you‚Äôre not careful, it‚Äôll start using you too. Meditating doesn‚Äôt solve problems. But it does give you space to think about them. You taught me that.‚Äù

Before he‚Äôd ever made it to Dagoba. Not that he‚Äôd listened to her, not really. But when he‚Äôd talked about struggling to clear his mind like Ben had told him, she‚Äôd tried to step him through what she knew. Minus the Force stuff. ‚ÄúSo if the Force is my problem?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not,‚Äù Luke almost seemed exasperated. Well, they couldn‚Äôt both be insufferable know-it-alls all the time. ‚ÄúAt least, not how you mean it. If the Force is connections, then the more you use it‚Ä¶‚Äù

It took her a moment to realize he wanted her to fill in the blank, ‚ÄúThe more things are connected to me,‚Äù Leia realized, mind stumbling back to that night on the stairs. When she‚Äôd been frozen, scared. Surrounded by dozens of helpless civilians‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúThe more I feel the Force, the more I feel them.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou always keep your head in a fight,‚Äù Luke said. ‚ÄúMostly. But if you don‚Äôt train how to listen, and then how to tune it out‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI‚Äôll keep freezing. When other people freeze.‚Äù

Or her shots would be off, or she would just be distracted. It could be thousands of things. It could be anger, she realized. It could be hate. She could get pulled in by any of it if she thought she was in danger and just reached out and didn‚Äôt have any boundaries in place.

‚ÄúHow do I fix it?‚Äù She had to face him now, this was too serious for her to be distracted by comfort. ‚ÄúHow do I stop it?‚Äù

Luke looked thoughtful. ‚ÄúYou know most of what Yoda and Ben told me. I think you can figure it out.‚Äù

Something clenched in her. ‚ÄúIf this is about attachment‚Ä¶‚Äù

He poked her forehead and Leia grabbed his finger, scowling. ‚ÄúIt is and it isn‚Äôt. I chose to be a Jedi. And I got to choose what that would mean, because there were no other Jedi to tell me no. At least, not and make it stick. Ben tried.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe wanted you to kill Vader.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe wanted me to kill my father,‚Äù Luke said. ‚ÄúAnd he wasn‚Äôt very sympathetic when I said I couldn‚Äôt.‚Äù

Leia could have done it. If the damn ghost had ever bothered to come and see her.

Men.

‚ÄúThe point is,‚Äù Luke continued, ‚ÄúI chose to be a Jedi. And to handle my problem the way I thought a Jedi should handle it. You‚Äôre Leia. You get to make a different choice. Whichever one you want.‚Äù

As long as she accepted the consequences.

And that was what this was really about, wasn‚Äôt it? That last night in her past, she‚Äôd cried because she‚Äôd found her resolve. Lando had said that they needed her, not because she was a Jedi but because she was herself. So while she‚Äôd wanted to scream and cry and rage into forever, she let herself weep, ready to buck up and just do it, and then‚Ä¶

‚ÄúDo whatever is necessary.‚Äù

Jumped through time and space, left them, and their government and all the work she‚Äôd tried to do and still needed to accomplish.

‚ÄúAnd don‚Äôt look back.‚Äù

And she hadn‚Äôt.

She‚Äôd landed in sand and storm, let Shmi help her put her feet under herself, and had moved forward. To a future she was determined to make better than her past.

And her brother was smiling now, and she could almost hear the sounds of birds and the wind felt a little more real, and‚Ä¶

Luke stood, pulled her to her feet. Stepped close, forehead to forehead, hands holding hers like she was fragile and precious. ‚ÄúThe Force is always with you Leia. You have to decide what to do with it.‚Äù

‚ÄúAlright,‚Äù she whispered, stray tears escaping. ‚ÄúBut you have to always be with me too. You promised.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know.‚Äù

He did. And he would be with her. And no matter what happened, everything would be alright.

She‚Äôd make sure of it.

Wounds of Treachery

Waking up hadn‚Äôt been as painful this morning, but Leia‚Äôd still been stiff and uncomfortable until she had showered, and her skin still felt raw. Like every stray breeze was blowing just under the first layer.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre jumpy.‚Äù Padm√© was reviewing Leia‚Äôs notes, frowning at the one to Senator Darsana and glancing up at Leia every so often. ‚ÄúIs something wrong?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo more than usual,‚Äù Leia sighed, leaning against the wall and refusing to wince. Sitting wasn‚Äôt happening, but standing wasn‚Äôt that much more comfortable. Her feet hurt. ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause you‚Äôre jumpy,‚Äù Padm√© didn‚Äôt roll her eyes, but it was a near thing. ‚ÄúDid you actually sleep last night?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù Sort of. ‚ÄúDidn‚Äôt Shmi tell you?‚Äù

Finger moving across the lines in front of her, Padm√© said, ‚ÄúShe claimed you were in bed for eight hours. While I‚Äôm sure that‚Äôs technically true, I have suspicions about what you were doing in there.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs only so many things you can do in a bed,‚Äù Leia objected.

That earned a smirk. ‚ÄúDepends on how creative you get.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo I want to know?‚Äù

‚ÄúI was twelve,‚Äù Padm√© wasn‚Äôt blushing or even slightly embarrassed. ‚ÄúMy friends and I were off planet for the first time as part of the Legislative Youth Program. They had our doors monitored pretty closely so we couldn‚Äôt sneak out and accidentally end up in the lower levels. But no one spends their first week on Coruscant able to sleep.‚Äù

Leia had, but then she had grown up in Aldera, not Theed. And she‚Äôd had people with her, people she knew would keep her safe.

And she‚Äôd always been pretty adaptable. ‚ÄúSo what did your creative twelve-year-old selves get up to?‚Äù

‚ÄúMostly mischief,‚Äù Padm√© admitted. ‚ÄúWe had access to the net and several boards for politicians. Some of us figured out how to get into more. We shared gossip, boring stuff. The way people responded, it probably happened every year.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs it? You just proved my point.‚Äù

A lighthearted smile soothed things Leia hadn‚Äôt realized were broken. She had been antagonizing people too much this week (month?). It was a good thing she‚Äôd finally gotten sleep. ‚ÄúI said that‚Äôs what we got up to. Together. I didn‚Äôt say that was the only thing I did.‚Äù

Something about that look‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúPlease tell me you started a coup. Somewhere.‚Äù

Padm√© laughed. ‚ÄúNot a coup. But I may have helped unseat a local judge from a mid-level district.‚Äù When Leia started choking on her giggles, Padm√© added, ‚ÄúHe was corrupt!‚Äù

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù Leia said. ‚ÄúBelieve, me I know.‚Äù More chuckles. ‚ÄúBut yeah, it‚Äôs pretty creative to overthrow a local government from your bed.‚Äù

They spent a few more minutes bickering over semantics, Padm√© adamant that she hadn‚Äôt overthrown the government just because she‚Äôd displaced one man. Leia didn‚Äôt have time to pin her down before Cord√© and Queen Jamillia arrived, both amused at the tone and topic of conversation.

‚ÄúIt was good practice,‚Äù Queen Jamillia said thoughtfully, ‚Äúfor when you had to fight for your own people. Against men who were cruel and corrupt.‚Äù

From the face Padm√© made, that comment had cemented Leia‚Äôs victory, but she didn‚Äôt gloat. Just waved as she left them to go over local matters that Padm√© was to bring before the Senate.

Leia already knew what they were. Advisor Brandes was a dreadful gossip.

She walked along the halls, quiet enough that she could hear herself think. And what thoughts they were. She remembered, vaguely, coming here several months ago. How everything had felt big and bright and polished. A little foreign, a little frustrating.

Shmi had been afraid.

Now she was walking these halls on her own, or with her own friends, arguing with Council ministers and proposing budgets and legislation. It was a startling difference if Leia let herself think about it. Shmi had adapted very, very quickly.

Which shouldn‚Äôt have been a surprise. She‚Äôd traded hands many times as a slave. Her grounded, focused nature had to also be flexible. It was a matter of survival.

"Lost?"

The tone was earnest, but Leia knew Rani was teasing. As the guard approached Leia slowed, ignoring the subtle wave of hostile curiosity Rani carried. Captain Typho was being much more careful about letting Leia wander around unaccompanied. She should have seen his accusations coming.

Sloppy.

Still, he was willing to let her be watched by a potentially friendly party. "Just wandering. The gardens are bit‚Ä¶ off-putting right now."

To say the least.

Rani considered that as they walked the halls, Leia occasionally waving at people she recognized or nodding. There was an air of tension in the building, the city really, that hadn't settled over the last few weeks. "Do you think we should be afraid?"

"No," Leia tasted the truth of the words as she spoke and wished they had been reassuring to her companion. "Not yet. One incident is reason for caution and action. Two is reason to hunt. More than that‚Ä¶ then you should be worried. Especially if you don't have any hints of how it happened."

"The senator was targeted on Coruscant."

A casual observation, but it did mean they were up to two, if that was how you were counting.

Leia certainly was. "Which is why we're hunting."

"Senator Amidala says the hunt for the shooter has been taken from the Jedi. And we don't have the resources to look off planet here."

Which was almost as embarrassing as it was frightening. "Even after the invasion?"

Rani shrugged. "We've been rebuilding."

Which was fine. But that didn't mean you left your backdoor open for an enemy to just walk through again. "Well, you may need to redirect some of that effort. Because off planet is probably where you'll need to look. More likely off system," she added before Rani could make a comment about the miners on Ohma-D'un.

"You think so?"

"If they're after the senator? That would be my best guess. We'd hear more restlessness from the civilians if it were coming from here."

"The people love her here."

Leia bit back words until she could use an even tone. "Yes. Which is why we would be hearing about any danger if there were murmurs floating around. Someone would have noticed and reported it, especially with there already being attempts on her life."

"Unless they were being silenced," Rani suggested. And there was more than a hint of suspicion now, and that surprised Leia. What the hell had Typho been saying about her?

"In which case," she reached for calm, calm that was a defense and a weapon when she walked among enemies, everything contained and tight, wrapped like safety around her, "you would have bodies or missing persons reports. I'm not asking," she added when Rani's silence became sullen. "The work I'm doing here isn't the chase."

"The Captain says you volunteered to do a solo hunt on Coruscant."

Yeah, definitely an accusation. Well, "Because I'm very good at finding things and people that are trying to be hidden," Leia said calmly. "I've had practice."

"Where?"

So many places. "Mostly Mid and Outer Rim, but the underbelly of Coruscant is at least fifty percent refugees from those zones, living in squalor and surviving by introducing old habits. Have you ever been there? It not like the seedier parts of Theed, or some of the cities further out from here where there's still more agriculture than industry and they listen more to local noble lines than the central government. It's layers and layers of skyscrapers slowly descending into darkness. Roads that open up into chasms and pits where you can't always see the bottom. They have no daylight, they get no rain. Everything is piped down through old industry that wasn't pretty enough for the top dwellers anymore. And every year, the corruption grows higher, because why replace when you can just keep building up and painting over it?"

Why run a local government to solve problems when you want to corrupt the whole galaxy? Why not let the Jedi sit on a hive of death and despair, so wrapped up in their peace and their comfort that they couldn't feel that the very ground that they were built on was crumbling away, seeping into darkness and ash?

Why kill a man when you could sit back and watch him kill himself? Just take what he loved.

"You hate it." Rani sounded so surprised.

Leia stopped, met Rani's gaze full on. "It's a pattern. A pattern you use to break people, to exploit them, to beat them into submission. You don't fight them, you make them fight the world. You make them fight themselves. Yes, I hate it. I hate it with everything that I am. That's why I came here. To fight it."

"Padm√© wants to help people," and now Rani sounded uncertain.

"Which is why I'm helping her. The senator is a good person. We don't always agree on how things need to be done, but she wants to make the galaxy better. To stop people from being murdered and exploited. So yes, I volunteered to go on the hunt. The first time she was threatened. Because she wants to fix things, not paint over them. And that makes her a target."

One of many, so many, and still not enough. And Leia's efforts would only get her so far. She needed a better network (not that Shmi wasn't already helping Leia with that one, even while they were stuck here) and she needed better allies, and she needed‚Äî

She needed Alderaan.

She was intimately familiar with their resources and their connections. She would be devastating if she could use them as leverage.

Unfortunately, to do that, she'd need to approach (Pa‚Äî) Senator Organa.

And right now, that was not going to happen.

Something in Rani was easing. Her smile was more relaxed as they started walking again. "I think you underestimate the handmaidens. They've been with the Senator for years. Many of them were with her during the invasion. They're nothing to scoff at."

"Oh, I'm not scoffing. As far as a dedicated personal guard, they're pretty much the best."

"But you're still worried?"

Shoving her hands into her pockets, Leia looked up at the ceiling. Studied the stone arches and crests that supported tons and tons or architecture, that had for at least hundreds of years. "Someone has to be."

"Generally," Rani was sober now, following Leia's gaze, trying to guess what she was thinking, "that's the Guard's job. Or just Security's in general."

Leia couldn't help but smile. "I like worrying. It keeps me sane."

It was clear Rani didn't understand or share the sentiment, but Leia had won over another ally. One who would hopefully convince Captain Typho to stop acting like an idiot.

Even if it was to keep Padm√© safe.

The hardest part of Padm√© leaving two days later wasn't being excluded from the crew, or knowing that there was danger, or wondering how the vote would go.

No, the hardest part was that Leia wasn't allowed to be on the landing platform to say goodbye. For‚Ä¶ security reasons.

Cord√© and Eirta√© had overruled Typho's concern about letting Padm√© visit Shmi and Leia the night before, sharing another meal and doing their formal farewells then. But he'd been adamant that he didn't want either of them near the ship before it took off.

Especially Leia.

Well, fine then.

"You're not amused." She was on a call with Senator Organa and Senator Mothma, going over notes on things she'd been working on that weren't directly related to the MCA vote. Another sop Padm√© had offered as a peace offering.

A rather bitter one, in Leia's opinion. "I don't think he's being unreasonably cautious," she admitted, biting back the desire to confide in Senator Organa even more (a habit as natural as breathing, even when for years he'd been dea‚Äî). "Padm√©'s been vacillating on how serious she thinks this is, at least when she talks about it. But she knows, and that's why she didn't fight the captain. Better to be safe than sorry."

"Even if it means being offensive?" Damn, it was so hard to concentrate when he did things that were too familiar. He was testing her, and she knew only one way to respond.

"That depends on how much trust you have, and shared ideals. The senator knows even if I'm being implicated that I understand, under the circumstance, and can be patient."

"How generous." It was hard to tell if Senator Mothma's mouth was twitching towards amused or irritated. She'd always had excellent facial control. "You will not be joining us then, this session?"

"We're not sure yet," Leia said, although in reality the answer was at some point she would be going back to Coruscant, with Padm√©'s permission or without. There was too much that needed to be done. And‚Ä¶ She needed an in with the Jedi. More than just casually knowing Master Kenobi, as convenient as that had been. "We'll have to see how things go with the vote and if my expertise will be of value, or if I'm better placed here."

She wasn't. Everyone knew it. Queen Jamillia had made several comments about it, in her own subtle way, when Captain Typho had explained that Leia would be remaining. She may have been focusing her research on trade routes and supplies (a not irrelevant topic with impending war on the horizon), but Leia's experience was broad and deep. And she had good political habits.

Most of the time.

"Senator Darsana was asking after you," Senator Organa said. And his expression was closed enough Leia had a hard time parsing it. "He seemed disappointed that you weren't coming back."

"I asked Threepio to pass along a message," Leia answered, wishing she could get the meeting back on track. "I'm hoping they get there in time for him to receive it before the vote."

Who knew what would happen after. If Padm√© and her contingent in the Loyalist Committee managed to stop the war efforts, there could be seriously bad blood between Naboo and many systems. And Leia knew, knew, that any number were waiting for the results in order to decide if they were going to leave or not.

What the Republic implied would make a huge difference.

"I'll see if I can reach out to him and let him know to expect a visit," Senator Organa promised, and Leia was worried to see there was something of relief in his answer. "He's been very busy these past weeks, and it might help to speed things along."

Or just open up the path. "Thank you. I would appreciate that." She hesitated. "Were there any messages you needed delivered here? I'd be happy to pass them along."

A stupid offer. He was only an associate to Padm√©, and while respectful enough to know details of her culture wasn't friends with her government.

But, "Actually, yes. If you could pass a message to Shmi Skywalker or Ruwee Naberrie," and wasn't that an interesting order, "I'd appreciate some additional details on the kinds of craft they have access to for moving refugees. We've already got a pretty robust system for handling refugees to Alderaan, but we have flight schools, pilots and ships that we can offer to any other systems, if they meet your standards."

Which would win Shmi over, Leia knew. And realized in that moment that she hadn't introduced them, had actively avoided it, because she wanted Shmi to think well of Bail Organa. Because Leia loved him and couldn't say it and didn't want Shmi to look at him and dismiss him as an idealist, passive Core-worlder.

"I'd be happy to pass that along. Should they reach out to you directly, or to one of your organizations?‚Äù

"Me," Senator Organa said firmly, which made Leia jealous and warm all at once. He was being protective again. Of people she loved. "I know enough of what we have to offer to process the relevant information. And to make sure if we have what you need that they get in touch with the right people as quickly as possible." He hesitated and Leia tasted fear, even through the call. "Whether or not the Senate approves the formation of an army, we need better connections between systems for moving people, especially in an emergency. I'd rather not delay helping with that."

And as streamlined as many organizations were on Alderaan, it never hurt to have a little pressure coming from the top to move things along. "I'll make sure they know to reach out to you as soon as possible. Now, did you want to go over pirating rates on major versus minor hyperlanes? Or price variance on common trade goods in the last twelve years?‚Äù

The two senators exchanged a brief look before Senator Organa said, "Both."

Where Our Scars

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

It was the middle of the night, the depths of darkness, when Leia woke, gasping for breath, drowning in a vision of fire.

Trying to calm her racing heart, she breathed, pushed on her face, forcing the tears to stay just under her lashes. Luke, Chewie, Han‚Ä¶ She breathed and breathed and breathed and tried not to remember the exact details of the dream. The green toned light from the view port under heavy laser fire. The screech of Artoo skidding, his wheels jerked across the floor. The sound of blast after blast from the guns, and the more muted sounds of what had to be Han shouting, Han swearing.

The feel of heat and pressure as everything had exploded around her, too hot and loud to survive, too fake to actually take her life.

She couldn‚Äôt handle more tears, but it was so hard to forget if she wouldn‚Äôt open her eyes. She just kept seeing it, again and again.

‚ÄúLeia, let it go.‚Äù

The words were almost too quiet, the sentiment unwanted, the tone‚Ä¶

He knew, he understood. But she had to move on. She was needed here, now. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs wrong?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou're upset.‚Äù

Simple, quiet fact. Enough to bring him to her side. She could do this. She could face this.

‚ÄúLeia?‚Äù

Shmi‚Äôs voice from outside the door. Leia made herself stand, cross the room, open up. Step into the waiting hug, let one, maybe two tears out. Just to clear the poison of the memory. Just so she could still breathe. ‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt even there. I shouldn‚Äôt keep seeing it.‚Äù

There was a spike of fear, a moment of hesitation. ‚ÄúWhat do you see?‚Äù

‚ÄúThem dying.‚Äù It ground out of her throat, hurt in every imaginable way. And why was Shmi afraid?

But she wasn‚Äôt anymore. Fear turned to sorrow, empathy. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry. That must be‚Ä¶ so hard.‚Äù

It was, but now there was a secret in front of her and Leia was willing to pursue anything else to avoid her own feelings. ‚ÄúYou thought it was something else.‚Äù

This wasn‚Äôt like Shmi‚Äôs normal hesitations, waiting to get the right placement of words, or to make a point. It was actual fear and‚Ä¶ maybe embarrassment? Humiliation? Closer to humiliation, Leia thought. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to‚Äî‚Äú
