‚ÄúWhen Anakin was little, he would share dreams with me,‚Äù Shmi said, the words more rushed than Leia had ever heard from her grandmother. ‚ÄúNot always, but when he did‚Ä¶ it was never the good ones.‚Äù

And beyond that, Leia had the feeling that there hadn‚Äôt been many good dreams to share. And the bad ones? Leia was sure‚Äîvery, very sure‚Äîthat they were like hers. Dreams of the past. Visions of what could not be undone.

For Shmi? ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry. I shouldn‚Äôt have‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI worried you‚Äôd seen the same,‚Äù Shmi continued, more stable now. ‚ÄúYou carry enough with your own burdens. I would not put mine on you.‚Äù

It was horrible to think about. To even begin to imagine. Shmi never, never spoke of the difficulties or indignities that she‚Äôd suffered being a slave. Not in anything more than broad strokes and generalities.

But Leia had spent time in a Hutt palace. In other seedy, undesirable places. They‚Äôd rescued slaves as part of the rebellion. She‚Äôd known about others from the work her father had done outside of Alderaan for years during the Empire. He‚Äôd tried to keep her away from it as much as she could, but‚Ä¶ Leia had always wanted to be a spy. Or a solider. Or someone who was fighting, not just being royalty. She‚Äôd made herself learn things even before she‚Äôd been allowed formal training.

So Leia didn‚Äôt know, but she knew. So many horrible possibilities.

Worse, because Anakin Skywalker had been a slave until he was nine years old. And even if that was less than half his life at this point, it was plenty of time for him to personally experience plenty of terrible things.

If he‚Äôd lived the dreams of his mother‚ÄîLeia couldn‚Äôt imagine what he‚Äôd found or how it might have hurt him.

And she wasn‚Äôt going to ask.

‚ÄúMy nightmares are mine,‚Äù Leia promised. ‚ÄúI have plenty of them, I don‚Äôt plan on borrowing any others.‚Äù

Not that it had been voluntary. Was it Anakin‚Äôs power that had pulled him in, or his mother‚Äôs mind reaching out? It wasn‚Äôt like Leia had any formal training, just her own efforts with meditating and feeling things around her.

Although, ‚ÄúYou said when he was little. Did it stop before he left?‚Äù

Shmi nodded as she led them downstairs and started making tea. ‚ÄúOnce I realized it was happening I‚ÄîWell, I suppose I prayed. To the desert. To our gods. To whoever was listening. That even if I had to dream them every night, that his pain at least would stop. I don‚Äôt remember anything changing. Just‚Ä¶ days went by and then weeks. He didn‚Äôt wake up with me, wasn‚Äôt crying, or speaking of things he shouldn‚Äôt have known.‚Äù

Accepting a cup, Leia thought about that. ‚ÄúPrayer?‚Äù

Not skeptical. Just curious.

‚ÄúNot unlike your meditation,‚Äù Shmi said. ‚ÄúOur people‚ÄîWe have our songs, our stories. Our memories. We know there is more in the world than just the power that makes some masters. I had my son by those powers, and I knew he was gifted with more of them than I could imagine.‚Äù

She stopped talking and Leia was grateful. She needed to know, but couldn‚Äôt ask. It wasn‚Äôt possible. ‚ÄúYou‚Ä¶ made him?‚Äù

Sliding into her own seat at the table, Shmi shook her head. ‚ÄúNot‚Ä¶ constructed. He is my son. I carried him and gave birth. But he has no biological father. Not as any sentient would understand it.‚Äù

Holy hells, their family tree was so messed up. ‚ÄúYou‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúWanted a child,‚Äù Shmi said simply. ‚ÄúI had lost some. Several. To various circumstances. I wanted another, one strong enough to live and breathe in the world that I endured. The desert gave me Anakin.‚Äù She paused, hands wrapped tightly around her cup. ‚ÄúAnd when he was gone, in the storm, it gave me you.‚Äù

Oh. Oh. Oh.

Oh no.

This was.

No.

Where was Han? She needed good Corellian smuggler swears and they‚Äôd all gone missing.

Son of a‚ÄîForce.

Taking a deep breath, Leia asked, ‚ÄúJust Anakin?‚Äù

Shmi nodded as she sipped. ‚ÄúHe was the only one I carried. That didn‚Äôt have a father,‚Äù she amended. ‚ÄúMy last.‚Äù

Which didn‚Äôt make sense, except‚ÄîRight. Cliegg. No children from her marriage.

But, ‚ÄúOwen?‚Äù

A warm smile, but also grief. ‚ÄúMy joy these last several years. A very sweet boy. Very willing, to have me as his second mother.‚Äù Her jaw clenched as she looked out the window. ‚ÄúA mother does not leave her children. Not as easily as I left mine. I cannot claim him.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know he would have strong objections to that,‚Äù Leia said. Her memories of those weeks on Tatooine only covered a brief time, but it was painfully clear that Owen had loved his stepmother. Had honored her and looked up to her and wanted her in his life as much as his father or Beru. ‚ÄúWe should at least go back to see his children.‚Äù

And now it was Leia‚Äôs turn to feel guilty at how much that startled her grandmother. ‚ÄúWe have obligations here. And‚ÄîI might be able to afford the trip, once or twice. My pay is generous. But we‚Äôd have no way to let them know we‚Äôre coming or see if we‚Äôre welcome, or‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúShmi,‚Äù Leia needed to remember how different their views on space travel were, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a pilot. Not a great one, but a good one. I‚Äôm sure Padm√© would let us borrow a ship. I know her family has access to them. Or we could book passage, and we make plenty to go more than just twice. And your work with the RRM is expanding. It‚Äôs not just possible, it‚Äôs likely you‚Äôll travel near or to Tatooine as part of your work. And,‚Äù Leia leaned back, taking a sip of her tea, ‚Äúthe Larses let me stay when I showed up out of nowhere and they had no idea who I was. They‚Äôll be happy to see you. Especially if you tell them you got to see Anakin.‚Äù

It took a moment for Shmi to answer, ‚ÄúThey might want me to stay.‚Äù

Ah, right. That. Um.

‚ÄúAnd I couldn‚Äôt,‚Äù Shmi continued, rushing again. ‚ÄúI‚ÄîI would love to. To see them regularly. To be part of their lives. But I can‚Äôt stay there. Not anymore.‚Äù A deep breath, and now her words were slow, measured. ‚ÄúIt isn‚Äôt home. Not anymore.‚Äù

Not the deserts that had been her mother and father, when blood relations had been a dream. Not the suns that had scorched, but had also lit the path of every step she had taken, showing with violent, stark clarity the world that was in front of her. Not the secret springs of water, or the wheezing machines that desperately pulled moisture from the air. Not the boy who loved her in place of his mother. Not the man that she called husband.

None of it was home anymore. Even though those things still held the biggest places in her heart.

And she felt guilty for that, Leia guessed. That the people who had loved her, who set her free, weren‚Äôt her home anymore.

Like Alderaan, Leia thought bleakly. She would always wander blind into a memory of that place that had raised her, shaped her, been her cage and her shelter in turn. That had held all the people that mattered to her most.

She had lost it, and couldn‚Äôt go back for so long.

And now she could, but it wouldn‚Äôt be the same and so she didn‚Äôt. Wouldn‚Äôt. Not instinctively, not compulsively. She didn‚Äôt belong there anymore. Not with the people that had once been her home.

It was‚Ä¶ very different. But just a little, Leia understood.

‚ÄúI won‚Äôt make you go. I can‚Äôt make you go,‚Äù Leia said. ‚ÄúBut I think you would be happier if you considered it. Or considered sending me once we get them a holoprojector and then you can just call them whenever you feel like it.‚Äù

Shmi blanched. ‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt afford‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúWe can,‚Äù Leia said calmly. ‚ÄúNot immediately. But we could save for one and give it to them so that they can stay in touch with you.‚Äù

It looked like Shmi was going to object, but she took a moment before saying, ‚ÄúWe could. That is an option.‚Äù

And a good one as far as compromise was concerned. Taking Shmi had felt like the right thing at the time. It still felt right. But‚Ä¶

But Luke Skywalker had been raised by his aunt and uncle, who had taken him in, no questions asked, when they knew his father was a Jedi and that the galaxy was a very dangerous place for Force sensitives and people who hid them. He‚Äôd felt guilty about being a whiny teenager before they died, but when he could be convinced to talk about them, it was always with fondness and love.

Owen had considered Anakin Skywalker family, close enough to protect Anakin‚Äôs son. Leia didn‚Äôt know for sure if it was because Anakin had gotten close to his stepbrother later in life, or if Owen was just that dedicated to Shmi as his mother. Either way, Leia didn‚Äôt want to steal all of that from him.

Besides, he‚Äôd been kind to her too. And she liked him. She wouldn‚Äôt mind seeing him again. And Beru. Even Cleigg.

‚ÄúYou were asking about prayers,‚Äù Shmi interrupted Leia‚Äôs thoughts, and being yanked back to that point in the conversation, Leia had to wince.

‚ÄúJust trying to understand. Alder‚ÄîMy home world, we had mythologies and beliefs. But the closest thing we knew to magic was the Force. And that was a Jedi thing.‚Äù

And practically a myth of its own at that point. Leia knew, tangentially, of people other than Luke that had been Force users, ex-Jedi and not, in the rebellion or passing through it, at different points. But her father and mother had kept her carefully away from them (and no wonder). So they were just another story.

Shmi ran her fingers along the edge of the table. ‚ÄúWe had tales of the Jedi, but until I met them I believed they were a Core World myth, of sorts. A dream or a fantasy. A wish.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd when they came,‚Äù Leia realized, ‚Äúthey weren‚Äôt what you expected.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe wasn‚Äôt like the stories,‚Äù Shmi agreed. ‚ÄúBut he was more real, and I think that I expected, if I was going to believe in Jedi to begin with.‚Äù Fair enough. ‚ÄúAnakin wanted to fight. To have power to free the slaves.‚Äù Her eyes were dark and distant. ‚ÄúI knew I couldn‚Äôt teach him. I had no power over the desert‚Äôs gifts. I thought‚Ä¶‚Äù

Until now, Leia realized. Until here and now where they were touching each other‚Äôs minds and hearts. And there was no desert and Shmi still had her gifts.

‚ÄúThe Force‚Äî‚Äú Leia tried. Stopped, thought about it. ‚ÄúLuke says the Force is what connects everything. Binds it together. So if you‚Äôre in a desert, then I guess‚Ä¶ the Force is a desert?‚Äù

She didn‚Äôt think she‚Äôd said anything profound, but Shmi was staring at her. And then, ‚ÄúYour brother‚Äôs name is Luke?‚Äù

Fuck.

Deep breath (don‚Äôt think about it, don‚Äôt think about it, don‚Äôt think about it), eyes open, ‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

‚ÄúSays?‚Äù

Fuck.

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù She tried not to wince. She thought she‚Äôd managed. But maybe not.

Shmi already knew. Already knew that Leia could talk to her brother‚Äôs‚Ä¶ ghost? Spirit? Memory. But Leia had not been expansive about it, and did not want to start heading that way tonight.

If Shmi asked though‚Ä¶

She didn‚Äôt. ‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúFor telling me.‚Äù And then. ‚ÄúDo you think you will be able to sleep tonight?‚Äù

Barely an hour since she‚Äôd woken and still many hours to dawn. But no, Leia would not be going back to sleep. Still, as long as she was up, ‚ÄúI doubt it, but I think I will try and meditate. It‚Äôs supposed to be‚Ä¶ good. I guess.‚Äù

Shmi considered that and smiled. ‚ÄúIt sounds wise. I will write a letter to Owen, one you can take with you when you go.‚Äù And boy, she‚Äôd turned from ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure‚Äù to ‚Äúwe have a plan‚Äù really fast. ‚ÄúAnd then I will start on breakfast. Do you want to help?‚Äù

‚ÄúIf meditating goes badly,‚Äù Leia opted to be honest, ‚Äúyes. And no, but I will. If it goes well, I may need you to come get me so I‚Äôm not late for work.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course.‚Äù

It used to be that when Leia meditated, she tucked all of herself away into a tiny ball, and anything that escaped she poked and wrestled with until she could get it back in. Not exactly what she had been taught, but meditating was supposed to help with her temper, and she‚Äôd figured this worked, so why not.

Then she‚Äôd met Luke and she hadn‚Äôt known she could use the Force, but explaining meditating to him had changed things a little. Also, she wasn‚Äôt trying to be a perfect little neat and tidy princess anymore, so while she did need to keep some things under wraps, she mostly tried to reconcile Alderaan. And what she was going to do with her life.

And not killing Han. He was obnoxious.

When Luke had told her they were siblings‚Ä¶

Well, after he‚Äôd survived the Emperor, she‚Äôd tried to really think about it. To sit down with Luke and listen to what he advised and even work with him on it.

But when you had to piece together a galactic government, you didn‚Äôt always get to be in the same place as your sibling that had a very different skill set and role than you did.

And she‚Äôd gone back to shoving things away, all away, to be a good and proper government for a desperate people.

Here?

Here she‚Äôd been a mess. And still was.

Several hours later Leia could sense dawn coming. Which was new. Time hadn‚Äôt generally meant much when she was meditating before. Still didn‚Äôt, exactly. But whatever she‚Äôd been doing, she knew the sun was coming up and it was time to get going.

She‚Äôd called downstairs to ask if Shmi needed help, been given permission to slack off on cooking practice, and gone to clean up for the day.

She was just putting the finishing touches on her hair when a scream in the Force came from downstairs. Not pain, but anguish.

Leia was at the door before she had even thought, gasping, ‚ÄúShmi?‚Äù

Her grandmother turned, face hopelessly blank, comlink on the floor at her feet. ‚ÄúCord√©‚Äôs dead.‚Äù

Chapter End Notes

I am very aware I have disappointed some people. I'm sorry. It just... wasn't avoidable.

Marred by Memories

It wasn‚Äôt true. It wasn‚Äôt possible.

‚Äú‚Äîhmi?‚Äù

There was a buzz from the comm on the floor and Leia had summoned it before she could think the action through. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre here,‚Äù the words were breathless, but they did come. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre‚ÄîCan you repeat?‚Äù

There was a pause before Sab√©‚Äôs voice asked, ‚ÄúCan you please verify your clearance?‚Äù

The tone, the words, flipped that switch that Leia had so often relied on. Part of her was wailing, consumed with disbelief and grief. The other stepped forward and recited the necessary codes, no hesitation in her voice. ‚ÄúCan you please repeat the report?‚Äù

Shmi winced at every word. Leia didn‚Äôt know why (military, Shmi wasn‚Äôt military), but she couldn‚Äôt solve that right now. There was a more immediate crisis. ‚ÄúWe have a report from Coruscant. And they weren‚Äôt saying it was Cord√©. Shmi had just assumed. But‚Äî

But it was Cord√©. They both knew. ‚ÄúWhy have we been contacted?‚Äù

She wanted to know. She was‚Ä¶ not glad, but needed to know. But that they were telling her, when she wasn‚Äôt part of the security crew, ‚ÄúPadm√© needs you to come in. Both of you.‚Äù The slightest hesitation. ‚ÄúAnd bring any communications devices with you.‚Äù

They were suspects. Leia had known this would happen.

It still hurt.

‚ÄúWhen we‚Äôre cleared‚Ä¶‚Äù Leia answered, almost surprised at the evenness of her own tone. Her heart was in turmoil, ‚ÄúWill we be given more details?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat can be discussed on site. Please report to the Security Force docking bay at your earliest convenience.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll need to make some calls first. To the RRM,‚Äù Leia added when the silence on the other end suddenly had an oppressive feel. ‚ÄúTo let them know we‚Äôll be late.‚Äù

The next silence was more thoughtful, and Leia suspected they had also been briefly muted. ‚ÄúPlease request the day off. We can‚Äôt provide a hard timeline for how long any questioning will take.‚Äù

Palpatine, Leia thought as she signed off. It wasn‚Äôt just Captain Typho. This was as good an opportunity as any for the Chancellor to stick his hand in and have them investigated. Well, he was going to be in for a surprise. Shmi was exactly what she seemed, and Leia‚Ä¶

The Force didn‚Äôt feel the need to submit transfer documents.

A thousand thoughts were whirring around her head (creating a shield, keeping the grief out), but Leia stopped tapping the comm against her lips when she realized Shmi was staring at her, wide eyed and frightened. ‚ÄúGrandmother?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou,‚Äù Shmi wasn‚Äôt just baffled. She was terrified. ‚ÄúWhere are your feelings?‚Äù

Something lurched in Leia, and she had to yank it back, to strain to hold it. She couldn‚Äôt, couldn‚Äôt fall apart. Not here, not now. ‚ÄúI‚Ä¶ where they always are?‚Äù

But the lurch had softened something in Shmi‚Äôs features. She almost reached out, but stopped. Bowed her head, moved her hands. A prayer, Leia thought. Or a blessing. A memorial. Luke had‚Äî

Something inside her screamed then and Leia had to close her eyes to focus. To hold it back.

When she opened them again, Shmi was a more muted presence in the room, her own face more composed, more restrained. Not hardened, the way Leia was used to from pilots and soldiers. Or spies. This look had more humility, more absence to it. A fading.

A slave‚Äôs grief, Leia realized. Different than a soldier‚Äôs, but no less imperative to stay in the here and now, to feel later. When it was safe, safer, to remember.

‚ÄúWe need to go.‚Äù She didn‚Äôt want to. Shmi didn‚Äôt want to. But they were expected and they had promised.

‚ÄúWe need to eat first.‚Äù

It was rushed, but they did eat. Did finish getting dressed, getting ready. Grabbed both their comms, checked the house for any other devices they might need. Didn‚Äôt speak, not with more than meaningful looks and shrugs.

If either of them spoke, they might not make it.

Cord√© was dead.

Flying to their meeting in silence was good, but it did give Leia too much time to think. To worry. To plan possibilities and try and think of ways that they could mitigate the damage done by suspicion and betrayal.

They were being made targets. Scapegoats.

She would kill him for this. For each and every ounce of grief she and Shmi and Padm√© and the others felt. She would make him suffer, like she was suffering. She would break him.

And Leia would enjoy every minute of it.

You want to steal my family, she thought, fingers tightening around the controls, you want to make me weak? I‚Äôll show you. I‚Äôll take your victories, your dreams, from you. Piece by piece. I‚Äôll teach you what it means to suffer.

And she would get to watch. And that would be the greatest vengeance of all.

Sab√© and Vers√© were waiting for them at the landing bay, along with Jar Jar Binks and Captain Panaka. The captain was looking grim, Sab√© and Vers√© uneasy, and Jar Jar was so forlorn every inch of him drooped.

He was the first to approach, with a Gungan mourning croak, his arms outstretched to them. Shmi hugged him first, burying her face in his shoulder for a moment before responding to his cry with a phrase of her own, one Leia half recognized, as the Tatooine woman patted his head. Then Leia was swept up in an embrace, much stronger than she‚Äôd imagined. She answered it as best she could, laying a hand on his shoulder as he pulled back. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú He stopped, looking anxiously over his shoulder to Captain Panaka. The man shook his head and Jar Jar sighed. ‚ÄúWe be needing you to hand over the comms.‚Äù

Well, at least they had one ally.

Already prepared, Leia offered them to the Captain who took them away, probably to run a diagnostic somewhere they couldn‚Äôt watch.

As if Leia didn‚Äôt already know all the Naboo slicing protocols for things like this.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll also need to ask you a few questions,‚Äù Sab√© was almost unreadable and Leia was more than a bit envious. It was impossible to tell if it was a skill Sab√© had, or just Leia‚Äôs lack of experience in the Force. ‚ÄúCould you come with us?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúRepresentative Binks,‚Äù Sab√© was firm, but not unkind, ‚Äúyou were already told to wait here.‚Äù

That earned a flopping shrug and a grumbled, ‚ÄúYes, mi‚Äôlady,‚Äù but he did stay as Leia and Shmi were led off. Vers√© disappeared with Leia‚Äôs grandmother almost right away, and Sab√© didn‚Äôt lead them into one of the many offices off of the docking bay. Instead she took them to a secondary hangar, not too far away, and walked them through it, out past the transports and to the very edge of the landing zone.

The sun shone behind them, illuminating the stark drop and the cascading water around them with harsh, white light. Sab√© made her way to the corner, not even looking at Leia as she went, taking a seat on the narrow ledge and leaning back against the hangar wall. She gave Leia an almost provocative look when she didn‚Äôt immediately follow.

Well, it wasn‚Äôt as if it was more or less dangerous to either of them (although Leia might survive a drop with the Force‚Ä¶).

‚ÄúPadm√© said she went to see you and you refused to let her tell you their plans.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

Leia hadn‚Äôt expected to start with hard questions, but she might have guessed Sab√© would have started with something a little less fraught. But then, Sab√© was one of the handmaidens that didn‚Äôt know Leia as well. ‚ÄúBut you did hear them talking about using a body double.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, and changing midflight, if I remember correctly.‚Äù

No one had said Padm√© was dead. No one had said and Leia wasn‚Äôt going to believe it until someone said it. Probably not even then.

But they also hadn‚Äôt said how many other people had died. Leia knew it couldn‚Äôt have been just Cord√©.

‚ÄúAnd you left after they said that was their plan?‚Äù

An interesting turn of phrase. Probably not one Sab√© had meant to use, if her glance to the left was any indication. Because it implied that plan had changed, and Leia probably wasn‚Äôt supposed to know that. ‚ÄúYes, Shmi and I both left together.‚Äù

‚ÄúAfter an argument.‚Äù

Leia leaned back against the wall as well, closing her eyes and listening for the sound of the water below. ‚ÄúYes. I disagreed about being left out of the returning party. I was overruled.‚Äù

‚ÄúDid you really want to go?‚Äù

This was‚Ä¶ a very strange line of questioning. ‚ÄúYes. I wanted to speak to Senator Darsana, and help with final preparations for the vote.‚Äù

‚ÄúLiaising directly with senators wasn‚Äôt a part of your mandate,‚Äù Sab√© observed calmly, lightly brushing her tunic. ‚ÄúIt was‚Ä¶ outside of your duties.‚Äù

Well, yes. Leia shrugged, but her mind was chasing the significance of that. ‚ÄúI spoke with him a few times when he showed an interest in my project. I like him. He‚Äôs an interesting person.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs close to the Chancellor.‚Äù

Was he? Leia didn‚Äôt think so. Not in the way that some of the other senators were. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs on the Loyalist Committee. I thought being close to the Chancellor was a prerequisite.‚Äù

They were wandering, and Leia didn‚Äôt like where this was going. ‚ÄúDid you fail to convey messages from the Chancellor to the Senator?‚Äù

What? ‚ÄúNo. I only spoke to him‚Ä¶ twice? Once while Padm√© was present and once after the shooting. He asked me to convey his compliments or something like that.‚Äù

And now Sab√© was really looking at her. ‚ÄúAnd he never spoke to you, or sent a messenger, other than that?‚Äù

‚ÄúNot unless I missed the message,‚Äù Leia took a moment to be utterly perplexed, and then‚Äî

And then she was enraged. Again.

‚ÄúDid he tell you I had failed to forward his communications?‚Äù Leia asked, trying to modulate her voice and knowing there was a clipped edge to it. The bastard. The scheming, conniving‚Äî

‚ÄúNot in so many words,‚Äù Sab√© admitted, leaning back again. ‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt sure if his implication was that you had directly sabotaged communication, or if he was just worried that Padm√© listened to you more than she did to him.‚Äù

Leia snorted. ‚ÄúShe doesn‚Äôt listen to anyone if she doesn‚Äôt want to. If he wanted to get her to do things, he should have found a way to work with that, not against it.‚Äù

Well that had caught Sab√©‚Äôs attention. ‚ÄúYou found a way?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôd like to think I figured out how to help her balance her responsibilities with her personal safety better. But I couldn‚Äôt tell you that she heeded my advice more than anyone else‚Äôs. Senator Organa had feelings about her security, and it was a daily fight she had with Captain Typho and the handmaidens.‚Äù

Spread the blame around generously and maybe Sab√© wouldn‚Äôt keep following this train of thought. Or maybe she hadn‚Äôt really been worried about it because the explanation seemed to appease her. She inspected her nails. ‚ÄúPadm√© trusts you.‚Äù

‚ÄúI should hope so,‚Äù Leia said before she could think better of it. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve spent months trying to help.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd that deserves trust?‚Äù Leia could feel that reaction, and it was definitely disdain. Joy.

‚ÄúWhat, did you want me to sit here and brag about saving her life one time? I‚Äôm sure that‚Äôs nothing compared to how often you‚Äôve done it.‚Äù

Alright, the snark was probably not necessary, but it did catch Padm√©‚Äôs friend off guard. And, somehow, eased the tension. ‚ÄúPadm√© does care about actions,‚Äù Sab√© admitted. ‚ÄúShe says everything you‚Äôve done has been for the good of the Republic.‚Äù

Well, wasn‚Äôt that nice of her. And odd. Leia didn‚Äôt think of what she was doing in that context. She was just trying to get a handle on the MCA vote and figure out which way Palpatine wanted it to fall. And what to do about it if they couldn‚Äôt stop him. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs kind of her.‚Äù

Sab√© snorted. Gave Leia half a glance. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt seem jealous of her.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt take her job for anything,‚Äù Leia said emphatically. Working with Palpatine, being nice to him (or at least not violently hostile), almost every day? No thank you. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm very content where I am?‚Äù

For now.

Sab√© seemed to catch that, but didn‚Äôt pursue it. ‚ÄúSo you‚Äôre not jealous, but you did want to go. You were angry, but you are trying to help.‚Äù She sighed. ‚ÄúFrom where I‚Äôm standing, that just doesn‚Äôt add up to a motive.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you believe me,‚Äù Leia felt compelled to add. She hadn‚Äôt been pressed very hard. She could be very good at lying.

Sab√© shook her head. ‚ÄúI do. I‚Äôve read the reports, Leia. Not just listened to the tall tales people have been telling. The way you took Padm√© down, you were potentially moving into the shot, not out of it. I checked. If you had planned it, that would have been beyond stupid. And if you‚Äôre stupid‚Ä¶‚Äù her eyes drifted towards the dense green of the forests. ‚ÄúYou wouldn‚Äôt be giving us this much trouble if you were that stupid.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd that‚Äôs it?‚Äù This really had been too easy.

Smiling, Sab√© said, ‚ÄúI could walk you through all of the dead-end motives and ideas I‚Äôve had, but I‚Äôll spare us both. We know you didn‚Äôt do this, and that you wouldn‚Äôt have if you‚Äôd had the chance. You and Shmi are just convenient targets, convenient refugee targets that are new and exciting and around when we‚Äôve been dealing with changes. I know Captain Typho worries about it, and Panaka backs him, probably because they‚Äôre related and Padm√© is not careful with her life.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo kidding,‚Äù Leia grumped.

There was a calm look, and a shake of the head. ‚ÄúShe isn‚Äôt. But she is careful with ours.‚Äù And now it was Sab√©‚Äôs turn to take a breath, and for the undercurrent of grief and sorrow she was carrying to seep out into the Force. ‚ÄúIf she thought, even a little, that you were responsible for Cord√©‚Äôs death, she‚Äôd already be back here. She‚Äôd take care of you herself.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd forget the vote,‚Äù Leia agreed. Sighed. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry. I don‚Äôt mean to be difficult. I assume there are other questions you need me to answer?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe standard ones,‚Äù Sab√© agreed. ‚ÄúWhere you‚Äôve been, who you‚Äôve talked to, the usual. But I‚Äôll take you inside for those. We‚Äôll need a written statement.‚Äù

And that was apparently that. Leia was disoriented as she stood, not from the height, but from the abrupt end to the conversation. She watched Sab√© carefully, curious. The handmaiden smiled, and the gesture was so much like Padm√© (like Cord√©), it hurt. ‚ÄúI know. You expected more. But I have been watching you, you know.‚Äù

She hadn‚Äôt, but she should have suspected. Should have guessed when she came back and Sab√© had quietly accepted her presence among Padm√©‚Äôs people. ‚ÄúAnd what do you see?‚Äù

‚ÄúSomeone strange,‚Äù Sab√© admitted. ‚ÄúSomeone different. Someone dangerous.‚Äù And it was almost a relief to hear her say it. ‚ÄúBut someone who‚Äôs on our side. Someone we can trust.‚Äù Her look was grim again. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll tell you what we know once we have your statement. What happened‚Ä¶ it can‚Äôt happen again.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd somebody needs to pay for it,‚Äù Leia agreed, glad to see the carefully contained rage in Sab√©‚Äôs eyes.

‚ÄúThey took one of ours,‚Äù she almost hissed. ‚ÄúNo one takes one of ours. Not without a price.‚Äù

Collide

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Anakin shivered slightly as the ship entered the atmosphere, and had to tense to make sure it didn‚Äôt shake his hands. Obi-Wan had been giving him enough grief today.

‚ÄúCold?‚Äù his frequently too observant master asked, and Anakin forced a smile.

‚ÄúYou know me, master. I never quite adjusted to all this space stuff.‚Äù

It earned a chuckle, but Obi-Wan didn‚Äôt make any other movements as he‚Äôd used to when Anakin had joked while flying. It said much more than words about the Jedi‚Äôs trust in his padawan and warmed Anakin a little.

Space was still too cold for him sometimes.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll be reporting as soon as we land,‚Äù Obi-Wan broke the silence after a few moments. ‚ÄúI heard from the Council, they want something from us. We‚Äôll need to be debriefed right away.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnother mission?‚Äù It wasn‚Äôt quite a moan. Anakin loved most of the missions that they went on. It was exciting. But he‚Äôd been looking forward to a few days at the temple, and some rest.

The tension must have reached his master. ‚ÄúDreams again?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Anakin replied firmly, but not too quickly. If he got too defensive Obi-Wan would mistake it for a lie instead of just irritation. ‚ÄúI just‚Ä¶ wanted some time to meditate.‚Äù

There was an uncanny pause before Obi-Wan repeated, ‚ÄúMeditate. You wanted‚Ä¶ to meditate? Padawan, are you ill?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Anakin answered with a roll of his eyes as he guided their ship through the light traffic of others entering from space. ‚ÄúI just‚Ä¶ I have something I‚Äôve been thinking about. And I was hoping for some quiet.‚Äù

A lot of things, actually. Like why Obi-Wan hadn‚Äôt recommended him for knighthood yet. Or what was going on with his mother right now. Or whether Padm√© was safe. Or why for months this past year he had practically forgotten about her and his mother, when he‚Äôd sworn to himself to never forget either one of them.

A brief, sharp memory of something unraveling inside of him made his hands actually twitch, and the ship jerked slightly.

There was a reflexive, ‚ÄúCareful,‚Äù from Obi-Wan, but the Jedi seemed more intent on watching Anakin‚Äôs face than worrying about their landing. Which was disconcerting and comforting all at once. Then, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll talk to the Council. If the mission can be handed off to someone else, we can stay here for at least a few days.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou think they‚Äôll listen?‚Äù

‚ÄúIf they don‚Äôt,‚Äù Anakin could hear the smile in Obi-Wan‚Äôs tone, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll tell them you requested extra time for meditation. That way, at the very least, we‚Äôll be grounded until you‚Äôve passed a very thorough medical examination.‚Äù

He managed a short laugh in answer, but Anakin wasn‚Äôt sure that wouldn‚Äôt be the exact result if Obi-Wan did have to resort to that tactic. And a medical exam was the last thing that he wanted to deal with right now.

They‚Äôd figure out right away that he wasn‚Äôt sleeping.

A hand rested on his shoulder as he readied to approach their landing platform. Obi-Wan normally never did anything to distract him at this point of the flight, so Anakin glanced in his master‚Äôs direction allowing his attention to split, just for a moment. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre doing well,‚Äù his master said reassuringly. ‚ÄúThe fact that they want us for so many missions means they trust you. Whatever you‚Äôre worrying about, remember that.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, master.‚Äù

It was even mostly believable. Many of the masters did trust Anakin, and some even liked him now. At least, he was pretty sure that was what they were implying when they told Obi-Wan it looked like he had gotten a just reward for his own years as a padawan, their eyes dancing with laughter, the air around them shimmering in the Force with humor.

Except Master Windu. He never laughed when Anakin was around. And Anakin had definitely noticed.

The ship touched down with feather lightness and Anakin smiled at another perfect landing.

Leia tapped the edge of the desk, waiting for the call to end. Padm√©‚Äôs frustration was understandable, but she was working around to a third time of repeating herself. Beyond the irritation, Leia knew it was a grief and exhaustion response. Padm√© needed to sleep. And to take a moment to process her feelings.

And she would probably laugh herself sick if she heard Leia say that, knowing it was advice that wasn‚Äôt being followed by the giver.

‚ÄúWe can have more of us out there by the end of the day,‚Äù Sab√© said again, wincing as she realized she wasn‚Äôt accounting for time difference.

They all needed a break.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want you here,‚Äù Padm√© was firm on this point at least. ‚ÄúI have plenty of security on site.‚Äù

‚ÄúWith all due respect, mi‚Äôlady‚Äî‚Äú Captain Typho looked about half a breath away from having an aneurism.

‚ÄúEndangering more of my people is not going to make me more safe,‚Äù she cut him off. And sneered, ‚ÄúBesides, they‚Äôre giving me Jedi protectors.‚Äù

Oh no.

No, he wouldn‚Äôt.

‚ÄúThe Chancellor recommended Jedi?‚Äù Sab√© asked, her hands flexing out of sight of the holo. ‚ÄúHe thinks it‚Äôs that serious?‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs overreacting,‚Äù Padm√© tossed her head in a way that Leia was uncomfortably familiar with. ‚ÄúHe thinks‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúThat she won‚Äôt listen and take other necessary protective measures,‚Äù Captain Typho seemed to be done being rigidly polite. ‚ÄúAnd that having someone familiar will help keep‚Ä¶ things‚Ä¶‚Äù

He did. Oh, Leia was going to‚Äî

‚ÄúFamiliar?‚Äù Sab√© seemed slightly confused. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt have regular interactions with any Jedi.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut Master Kenobi is known to our people,‚Äù the captain said, and Leia stifled a groan. ‚ÄúAnd is a Jedi we can place confidence in.‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause he‚Äôs done this before,‚Äù Sab√© mused. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a good choice. Popular with our people, a reputation for having saved Padm√© twice.‚Äù

‚ÄúLeia saved me the second time,‚Äù Padm√© griped, and Leia wished she hadn‚Äôt said it. It meant Sab√©‚Äôs eyes flicked to her for a moment, which meant Padm√© noticed and demanded, ‚ÄúIs she there?‚Äù

And now Captain Typho knew. Lovely.

Knowing it was pointless to pretend, Leia walked around and joined Sab√©, waving at Captain Typho with a grin she knew she had learned from Han. It was annoying, that was the point of it. It made Padm√© laugh a little and the captain frown, and sent a subtle but certain message to the senator.

I‚Äôm on your side.

‚ÄúWhat can I help you with?‚Äù Leia asked, not seeing any reason to waste time on pleasantries.

Which suited Padm√© just fine. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not being locked up like a display piece. I have work I need to do to get ready for this vote.‚Äù

‚ÄúYour personal appearance‚Äî‚Äú Captain Typho tried.

‚ÄúIs essential,‚Äù Padm√© snapped. ‚ÄúEspecially since‚Ä¶ my messenger‚Ä¶‚Äù

Threepio. Leia forced herself to stay still. To not breathe. To not think. Sab√© had mentioned him first after Cord√© on the list of casualties, not because he was the most important, but because she knew he would be the most important to Leia. Blasted, scattered. Fairly resilient, mostly in large component pieces, parts of him might be salvageable. They might be able to at least physically rebuild him.

His memories‚Ä¶ No one could even begin to guess what might have happened there. His internal composition was a mechanical mystery.

‚ÄúAccept the Jedi bodyguards for now,‚Äù Leia said, trying to have her tone make it a suggestion. ‚ÄúMaster Kenobi at least knows how to behave himself in the Senate building. And you may be able to turn his presence to your advantage. Have him follow up on questions he asked at the banquet, or something.‚Äù

She could almost feel Captain Typho‚Äôs relief as Padm√© visibly relaxed, considering this. She did feel Sab√©‚Äôs. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs not part of our delegation.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe Chancellor claims that the role of the Jedi is to serve the Republic. And that the Senate is its core. He‚Äôs just earning his keep, really.‚Äù

Padm√© snickered again, in spite of the pain in her eyes. Leia understood. You had to keep living. No matter how much it hurt. ‚ÄúShould I tell him to expect you?‚Äù

It was more than a little teasing, and Leia allowed it, knowing the distraction was necessary. She had to really think about the answer though. ‚ÄúNo. I don‚Äôt think we‚Äôre better off sending more staff down there. The Jedi protection will work as a deterrent or it won‚Äôt. And if they aren‚Äôt enough to protect you if someone does try again, there‚Äôs no way any of us would manage. Not without risking a similar cost.‚Äù

And half the battle right now was keeping Padm√© sane and standing. She was tough, Leia knew. Eirta√© had spoken a few times of the horrors they had faced, fleeing the invasion. How Padm√©‚Äôs hardest decision hadn‚Äôt been to run, or to ask for help, or to risk landing in Hutt space. It hadn‚Äôt even been dealing with the Sith.

It had been the day she had been told to stand by and ignore the pain and suffering of her people. Because it was a trap.

So Padm√© was resilient and could do this. But losing Cord√© was a close cutting wound, and all of them were feeling it.

And they couldn‚Äôt afford to make mistakes.

‚ÄúThe Senator‚Äôs safety‚Äî‚Äú Captain Typho objected.

‚ÄúIs in your hands,‚Äù Leia said, keeping a tight rein on the vicious smile that wanted to peek out. ‚ÄúAre you suggesting you aren‚Äôt up to the challenge?‚Äù

Mean, downright cruel. He had worked so hard.

But losing Kenobi wouldn‚Äôt be nearly as painful as losing another person from Naboo, if it came to that. And Leia had every (unfortunate) confidence that nothing coming after the Senator would kill Anakin.

He had a (notorious) fascinating ability to dodge danger and bounce back.

So no, Leia was not going to spare the captain‚Äôs feelings right now. She needed him out of the way so that she could deal with this.

And she could. Probably better than he had. Because she knew the kinds of tactics that were coming. ‚ÄúYou still have Artoo?‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood, keep him close. He‚Äôs worth a small army.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe already have a plan.‚Äù

Even better. ‚ÄúWhoever our opponent is, they‚Äôve tried a variety of attempts so far, not sticking to one method. Can you give me the list of the other ones that you expect? I may be able to add to it.‚Äù

Sabotage was a healthy portion of her career.

In the teeth of the Captain‚Äôs pained response, Padm√© nodded and started listing their ideas.

‚ÄúSenator Amidala?‚Äù Obi-Wan said in surprise. ‚ÄúWhy does she need Jedi protection? Her personal guard is excellent.‚Äù

The councilors looked solemn and Anakin found himself holding his breath. It was the only way to prevent something from screaming out of his mouth.

‚ÄúA great tragedy, the senator has experienced,‚Äù Master Yoda said gravely. ‚ÄúCompromised, her ship was. Killed, one of her bodyguards was. Insistent, the Chancellor is that Jedi protection is needed.‚Äù

‚ÄúA vote is coming up this week, concerning possible war and the Separatists,‚Äù Master Windu clarified. ‚ÄúThe senator has been very clear about her position and has apparently made enemies of some of her opponents. Again.‚Äù

The last bit was added with a degree of irritation that made Anakin want to giggle and also roll his eyes. Padm√© always did what was right. Of course people made enemies that way. Any Jedi should know that.

‚ÄúOur presence is specifically at the Chancellor‚Äôs request?‚Äù Anakin eyed Obi-Wan closely hearing that tone. It meant his master was disturbed by something, but Anakin couldn‚Äôt guess what. There was nothing odd in the Chancellor asking for their help. He at least knew that Anakin was capable.

‚ÄúHe mentioned you specifically when he proposed the idea to the senator,‚Äù Master Windu confirmed. ‚ÄúI think he hoped if she knew who the guard would be, she would be more likely to accept the help. She was very resistant to the idea of needing more security.‚Äù

‚ÄúNaturally,‚Äù Obi-Wan answered, with the smallest hint of a smile. ‚ÄúThe senator does like things to go‚Ä¶ her way.‚Äù

‚ÄúTake this mission, you and your padawan will,‚Äù Master Yoda said firmly. ‚ÄúAdvise the senator, help her see reason you must.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe was very distressed by her body double‚Äôs death,‚Äù Master Mundi added calmly. ‚ÄúIt might be a good way to help her see reason, if she does resist your advice.‚Äù

Shifting carefully from foot to foot while trying to make it look like he was being still, Anakin managed not to frown. But it was close. The usual oppression of the council room seemed to sit more heavily than usual.

Why didn‚Äôt they consider that Padm√© might be right?

‚ÄúWe will of course do our best to protect the senator. You say the vote is this week?‚Äù Obi-Wan was good at not committing to anything he didn‚Äôt want to and while Anakin couldn‚Äôt always tell what his master did want, at least in this case he knew that Obi-Wan hadn‚Äôt promised one way or another.

‚ÄúIn just a few days,‚Äù Master Windu confirmed. ‚ÄúAnd depending on how the vote goes, she may need even more protection.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe will keep that in mind,‚Äù Obi-Wan promised.

They exited the room in silence, but it wasn‚Äôt long before Obi-Wan said, ‚ÄúI hope you don‚Äôt mind that I didn‚Äôt mention your request for a few days off.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course not,‚Äù Anakin answered quickly, unsure if Obi-Wan‚Äôs tone had been teasing or questioning. Sometimes it was just too hard to tell. ‚ÄúPa‚ÄîSenator Amidala needs protection now. And we can‚Äôt refuse a request from the Chancellor.‚Äù

‚ÄúCan‚Äôt we?‚Äù Obi-Wan murmured, but he didn‚Äôt seem to expect and answer. His gaze was already unfocused as if he were mediating while walking. Which he could be. They both knew these halls well enough now that it was probably an easy exercise for Anakin‚Äôs master.

Anakin felt doubly sure when Obi-Wan‚Äôs focus reappeared as they approached a speeder, his gaze landing on Anakin with an all too knowing smile.

‚ÄúDo try and not get us pulled over this time. We want to be punctual to our assignment.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know how to fly,‚Äù Anakin muttered, fighting a grin.

Chapter End Notes

Oh look, it's the return of the Jedi...

Remembering

Shmi had dinner ready by the time Leia got home. The house smelled of wildflowers and incense, which seemed odd to Leia until she remembered how thoroughly Shmi had researched Naboo grief rituals. She‚Äôd probably already performed her own Tatooine remembrances. These were respect to Cord√© in a form that would have been familiar to the woman.

That didn‚Äôt diminish the tears that pricked at Leia‚Äôs eyes as she spotted the small bouquets in each room, near windows or doors.

She needed to hurry and eat before grief demanded her full attention.

‚ÄúLeia?‚Äù

Shmi seemed better and worse now. Her rituals had calmed her, but that just left space to feel the empty hole where a person was supposed to be and‚Äî

Later. Hold. Just for a few more minutes, hold.

‚ÄúDo you need me to set the table?‚Äù

Mundane tasks to act as a shield for a few more minutes. Food to mouth. Dishes washed. Kitchen cleaned, everything put away.

It was stupid, but the moment they finished, Leia felt the emptiness of the room and it was oppressive. Task finished and done, now to rest, empty and silent‚Ä¶

She‚Äôd been putting this off too long.

No tears while she lit her own sticks of incense, mind reciting the prayers for the dead, violently carried away (and how appropriate, that the Naboo had a separate remembrance for that). No tears as she made her way to the couch, stopping to touch the blossoms Shmi had bought, fingering silk soft petals and catching the scent of summer and sun and gentleness.

Cord√© had been hard, Leia thought as she curled up on the couch, knees pulled up and in, making a barrier between her and the world. Hard, beneath the soft beauty that had so closely imitated Padm√©. Not unkind, but strong. Resilient. She‚Äôd joined the handmaidens after the invasion, resolve and competence covering for the lack of experience she had compared to the others. Sab√© had told story after story that day as they‚Äôd processed data coming in from Coruscant, as they‚Äôd prepared letters for grieving families, made calls, arranged for financial compensation, began preliminary work on memorials. It wasn‚Äôt just Cord√© they had lost, there were four others that had been on the landing ramp, two pilots, almost a half dozen droids on the ship.

And between each task, Leia had allowed herself to be an outlet for a grief so personal, it had almost stolen her breath away. Sab√© had stepped aside as Padm√©‚Äôs primary double when Cord√© had proved to be up to the task. Two hands, a right and a left, one more suited to Naboo, the other to the Senate. The relationship that Padm√© had described when she had shut down Leia‚Äôs attempts to join their retuning party wasn‚Äôt just a two-person partnership. It had been three people, one always apart from the others, standing a little distant to watch what couldn‚Äôt be seen from up close.

Sab√© had missed the attack. From what she didn‚Äôt say, it was clear that she saw Cord√©‚Äôs death as her fault. Her cowardice. Her incompetence.

And Cord√© and Padm√© had paid for it.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre wandering,‚Äù Shmi said, invading Leia‚Äôs space and sitting right next to her, wrapping an arm around her shoulders. ‚ÄúIt will still be here, no matter where you go.‚Äù

Right, it was time to face her grief, not avoid it by empathizing with Sab√©‚Äôs. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve only known her a few months,‚Äù Leia whispered. ‚ÄúAnd still‚Ä¶‚Äù

It wasn‚Äôt the grief of losing her brother, or her parents (or Han). But stars and fire, it hurt. Hurt because.

Because the moment she looked, that she was honest, she didn‚Äôt just see grief. The darkness she expected was intertwined, interwoven, with red bright as blood.

Rage.

Twisted together with her sadness, with the truth of ‚Äúis gone‚Äù was a spite and malice that almost took her breath away.

It was shameful, to not make a pure space for Cord√©‚Äôs grief. But Leia couldn‚Äôt do it. Couldn‚Äôt let go of the rage and the fire that coiled around her, seeped into her bones.

Or maybe‚Ä¶ maybe the fire had always been there. Banked sometimes by grief or hopelessness, reduced to the slightest flickering embers. But always to return. When grief had passed, or more blood was spilled.

Or when the cold coalesced in the darkness, shimmering blue, offering revenge.

Offering peace. Offering purpose.

‚ÄúFamily,‚Äù Luke‚Äôs voice was the barest, faintest whisper. ‚ÄúOffering family.‚Äù

Damn him, he was right. And she couldn‚Äôt deal with that, on top of everything else.

‚ÄúYou should talk about it,‚Äù Shmi‚Äôs voice cut through the spiral, grounded Leia like the arm around her shoulders, the warm weight pressed against her side. ‚ÄúYou need to talk about it.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot now,‚Äù Leia whispered. ‚ÄúNot yet.‚Äù

She thought Shmi would stay silent, but her grandmother asked, ‚ÄúAre you sure?‚Äù

And Leia wasn‚Äôt. Wasn‚Äôt, because, ‚ÄúI hate them. I hate them all. All of them, taking people away from me.‚Äù

It was so easy to blame Palpatine. But if he were the only one‚Ä¶

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not fair,‚Äù she continued, burying her face in Shmi‚Äôs shoulder, seeking comfort and refusing to be comforted. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not fair that I keep losing them. What‚Äôs the point of even trying if‚Äîif‚Äî‚Äú

Gods and storms, she was her father‚Äôs daughter.

And she hated herself even more.

Because Cord√©‚Äôs death wasn‚Äôt Sab√©‚Äôs fault, or Padm√©‚Äôs, or even the Emperor‚Äôs.

It was Leia‚Äôs.

She just hadn‚Äôt figured out how yet.

The lift to Padm√©‚Äôs floor wasn‚Äôt actually unnaturally slow, but Anakin felt stifled anyway. Away from the Council and no longer flying, now he could fidget, and so he did.

‚ÄúNervous?‚Äù Obi-Wan asked with no small amount of amusement.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been ten years. What if she‚Äôs forgotten me?‚Äù He had almost forgotten her, hadn‚Äôt he? And how had that happened?

Chuckling, Obi-Wan answered, ‚ÄúPadawan, we saw her only a few weeks ago. I‚Äôm sure she remembers you. She did then.‚Äù

Anakin managed a smile in return, but felt little comfort. He hadn‚Äôt exactly made a great impression then, he was sure, crying all over his mother and constantly getting lost in the conversation.

‚ÄúRelax,‚Äù his master urged, sensing the growing tension. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre here as bodyguards, not guests. Our priority is her safety, not her good opinion. You can win her over later, when we‚Äôve saved her life a few times.‚Äù

‚ÄúA few?‚Äù Anakin responded with more heat than he‚Äôd meant to. It earned him a quirked brow and that superior, teacherly look.

‚ÄúWere you listening to the Council? Yes, I expect there will be a few.‚Äù

But before Anakin could demand that Obi-Wan elaborate, the doors hissed open and the Jedi was stepping out to greet their welcoming committee.

‚ÄúMaster Jedi,‚Äù a security guard with an eye patch greeted them, oozing enough skepticism to make Anakin nervous. Did he just not trust Jedi, or was there that much danger to Padm√©‚Äôs life?

‚ÄúThis way,‚Äù he said, leading them through the door and into a sitting room where several more Naboo security officers were already stationed. Their placement was good, but Anakin reached out with the Force anyway, feeling Obi-Wan do the same.

Which is how he felt Padm√© before he actually saw her, and was surprised at how familiar she felt. Not just like the Padm√© he remembered, but somehow even more‚Ä¶ connected.

‚ÄúMaster Kenobi,‚Äù she came into view with no smile, and Anakin almost thought he could detect a hint of red in her eyes. ‚ÄúI understand the Council has sent you to protect me.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey have,‚Äù his master answered with a gracious nod. ‚ÄúAnd I promise that Anakin and I will do our best to take care of you, and your people.‚Äù

A tension Anakin hadn‚Äôt been aware of lightened at those last words, but it evaporated completely to be replaced by unguarded surprise as Padm√© saw him. ‚ÄúYou brought Anakin? I‚Äôm sorry, of course. I just‚Äî ‚Äú She floundered and Anakin felt his stomach sinking. ‚ÄúI forgot, Anakin, how did you get so tall?‚Äù

She had forgotten. And she was nervous, which was not the reaction Anakin had been looking for. ‚ÄúWell, Master Obi-Wan will tell you it‚Äôs gravity fighting a losing battle to keep my feet on the ground. Against my space head, I mean. No, I mean‚Äî‚Äú

They were all the wrong words, but Padm√©‚Äôs laugh echoed with surprised delight, not mockery, and Anakin promised himself his next words would be better. Much, much better.

Still, he‚Äôd gotten a smile. That was something.

"I just can't believe it. I‚Äôm still so used to thinking of you as so small. But you‚Äôve been with the Jedi for almost ten years now.‚Äú

Despair. She really had forgotten him. In just a few short days.

‚ÄúI fear he may still be growing,‚Äù Obi-Wan‚Äôs voice was laughing for him. ‚ÄúWhat am I to do with a padawan twice as tall as I am?‚Äù

‚ÄúMake him a coat rack,‚Äù was the muttered reply from the eyepatch guard. Anakin almost missed it.

‚ÄúYou could knight me.‚Äù He hadn‚Äôt meant for it to sound like an accusation, but apparently the guard had bothered him more than he‚Äôd thought. Obi-Wan was upset now. Great.

‚ÄúThat decision is up to the Council,‚Äù his master said pointedly. ‚ÄúBut I‚Äôm sure they‚Äôll be interested in your performance during this mission.‚Äù

Get in line, was that message. And Padm√© was frowning now. Only a little, just between her eyes. But Anakin spotted it as she looked between him and Obi-Wan.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll do everything in our power to protect you, Padm√©,‚Äù he promised. He wanted to joke again, but if Obi-Wan meant that, if he could get knighted if he just took this seriously‚Ä¶

She didn‚Äôt look reassured. It wasn‚Äôt fair.

Padm√© turned back to Obi-Wan. ‚ÄúNot that I don‚Äôt appreciate your willingness, but I don‚Äôt need extra guards. I need someone to find out who did this, before more of my people are put in danger.‚Äù

That‚Ä¶ was a very real fear. Anakin felt it spike in the Force and without thinking reached out with soothing. A prod in the Force from Obi-Wan reminded him that was rude. He hadn‚Äôt asked. But he didn‚Äôt release it right away, and noticed Padm√©‚Äôs shoulders relax slightly.

Good.

‚ÄúWe weren‚Äôt assigned to find the perpetrator,‚Äù Obi-Wan cautioned gently. ‚ÄúOur mandate is to protect you.‚Äù

Yes but, ‚ÄúSo we should focus on finding the perpetrator. She‚Äôll be safe if we do that.‚Äù Not to mention it had been weeks since the shooting and the perpetrator hadn‚Äôt been found. That was just sloppy.

He was getting glares from Obi-Wan and the eye-patch guard now. It wasn‚Äôt fair. He‚Äôd had a good idea.

‚ÄúWe stick to our mandate, Anakin. Our objective is to keep the senator safe until the vote has taken place. There‚Äôs no guarantee we can find this person in three days, and Padm√© would be left unguarded while we tried.‚Äù

Hunching slightly, Anakin nodded. It was a good point. But Padm√© wanted‚Äî

‚ÄúAgain, I appreciate your concern, but I‚Äôm more worried now for my people. Some of them are taking this threat‚Ä¶ too seriously.‚Äù

That earned an eye roll from Eye-Patch, but it didn‚Äôt seem directed at Padm√© ‚ÄúYou can order her to stand down,‚Äù he said in a tone that knew it was going to be ignored.

Padm√© actually snorted. ‚ÄúRight. You try that. Tell me how it goes.‚Äù

It was dry, but Anakin felt affection leaking off her, and fondness. Something twisted in him and he said, ‚ÄúWe can always protect them too.‚Äù

Maybe he‚Äôd come across as too defensive. Padm√© blinked before answering. ‚ÄúActually, she‚Äôs on Naboo right now. And I think we can keep her there for at least few more days. Leia‚Äôs always practical. She won‚Äôt put me in more danger by showing up and being a distraction.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe tried to go after them alone,‚Äù Eye-Patch muttered, and Padm√©‚Äôs ease spiked into fear again, her lips pressed together.

‚ÄúThen maybe you should be keeping an eye on her, Captain.‚Äù

That was cold. And made the captain flinch. ‚ÄúCaptain Panaka has her in hand. My duty is to protect you, Senator.‚Äù

Something was‚Ä¶ wrong. Anakin couldn‚Äôt put his finger on it, but it was more than just the tension of nervous people in this room. Floundering for something to fix it, he almost missed Obi-Wan asking, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre worried about Leia?‚Äù

Padm√© blinked. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs always been an open question as to whether or not she was a target of the shooting too. It seems less likely, given‚Ä¶ well, what‚Äôs happened. But since we haven‚Äôt caught anyone, we can‚Äôt rule it out.‚Äù

Obi-Wan frowned. ‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt bring her with you?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, she was helping with‚Ä¶ another project.‚Äù Padm√©‚Äôs eyes flicked to Anakin and his heart jumped into his throat. Why had she looked at him just then? ‚ÄúAnd with the incident on Naboo, we were trying to keep staff here to a minimum.‚Äù

‚ÄúIncident on Naboo?‚Äù Anakin demanded. His master looked surprised too. The Council hadn‚Äôt mentioned‚Äî

‚ÄúThere was a terrorist attack,‚Äù Eye-Patch said, leaking almost as much frustration as Padm√© at this point. ‚ÄúThe Senator‚Äôs contingent, some members of the Royal Advisory Council, and members of the RRM were targeted in an explosion.‚Äù His eye narrowed as he looked at Padm√©. ‚ÄúThe Senator‚Äôs father was only recently released from the hospital.‚Äù

‚ÄúYour father was hurt?‚Äù Anakin wasn‚Äôt panicking, but he could only imagine how awful that was. His mother‚Äî

No, he couldn‚Äôt think about that. Those times were behind them.

‚ÄúHe was injured,‚Äù Padm√© was a mess of emotions when she said that. But she relaxed a bit as she added, ‚ÄúThey kept him for observation longer than usual to make sure he didn‚Äôt tire himself out at work while he was recovering.‚Äù

‚ÄúA family trait?‚Äù Obi-Wan suggested with a smile.

For a second it looked like Padm√© was offended, but then she smiled back. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a good way to put it.‚Äù

Anakin‚Äôs master thought for a moment before asking, ‚ÄúLeia was part of the contingent caught in the attack?‚Äù

Padm√© shook her head. ‚ÄúNo, she was off planet at the time, on one of our moons.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd she was or wasn‚Äôt expected as part of your party when you returned for the vote?‚Äù Obi-Wan seemed anxious. It was a subtle thing, but Anakin had been trapped in a nest of gundarks with the man. You learned the signs really quick that way.

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

Folding his arms, Obi-Wan said, ‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt seem like she is much of a target if two of the three attacks she wasn‚Äôt involved. I think you can rest easy where she is concerned.‚Äù

Padm√© arched a brow. ‚ÄúAre we talking about the same person?‚Äù

That made his master think, then wince. ‚ÄúPossibly‚Ä¶ she might get herself into trouble. If she thought that was‚Ä¶ needed.‚Äù

Who was this Leia? Except‚Ä¶ right, she had been Obi-Wan‚Äôs dinner partner. ‚ÄúDoes she have security on Naboo?‚Äù Anakin asked. If Padm√© was still worried, better to deal with that first. After all, they were here to take care of her.

‚ÄúNot formal,‚Äù Padm√© said, looking over to Eye-Patch. ‚ÄúWe should probably arrange it. If only to keep her out of trouble.‚Äù

‚ÄúHer mother won‚Äôt like it,‚Äù Eye-Patch said. ‚ÄúAnd we‚Äôll have to get them both for it to work.‚Äù

‚ÄúShmi‚Äôs not‚Äî‚Äú Padm√© started and Anakin felt the galaxy tilt around him. Only half noticed Padm√© glancing at him, then Obi-Wan. ‚ÄúShmi isn‚Äôt Leia‚Äôs mother.‚Äù

Eye-patch had somehow managed more frowning and he looked at Anakin, ‚ÄúA cousin then?‚Äù

What? That wasn‚Äôt‚ÄîThey didn‚Äôt have family. Not like‚Ä¶ not like blood ties in the Core. ‚ÄúNo? I don‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúLeia took the name Skywalker when they arrived on Naboo,‚Äù Padm√© did not look happy about having to explain this. Anakin wasn‚Äôt happy hearing it. Why hadn‚Äôt his mother told him? ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know the details, they don‚Äôt talk about it.‚Äù

That did sound like his mom, Anakin had to admit. And Leia, Leia Skywalker, well, he shouldn‚Äôt be surprised. If she‚Äôd lost a home, a family‚Ä¶ Mom always wanted more kids.

Still, he hadn‚Äôt actually thought she‚Äôd replace him.

(It hurt.)

‚ÄúI‚Äôd be happy to discuss this further at a later time,‚Äù Obi-Wan was definitely lying about that. Wait, he knew Leia. This whole time, did he know? ‚ÄúBut for right now, I think we need to discuss what safety measures are already in place and where we can be of most use.‚Äù

‚ÄúIn the Senate‚Äî‚Äú Padm√© started to say before Eye-Patch guy said, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll take you around the buildi‚ÄîNo, my lady. You aren‚Äôt going in.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat is the point,‚Äù Padm√© demanded, rage rolling out into the room like a tidal wave, ‚Äúof being stuck on this planet if I‚Äôm not allowed to do my job?‚Äù

‚ÄúPerhaps,‚Äù Obi-Wan stepped physically between them, addressing Padm√©, ‚Äúif we can take a look around the building and discuss the current measures. Then Anakin and I can decide if making a trip to the Executive Building or the Senate is within reason.‚Äù

Oh right, it was rude when Anakin offered comfort without asking, but Obi-Wan was allowed to be empathetic all over the place whenever he wanted. Of course.

‚ÄúAlright,‚Äù Padm√© agreed. ‚ÄúBut the final decision is mine.‚Äù She glared at Eye-Patch. ‚ÄúAre we clear?‚Äù

That face said no, but the guard only nodded. ‚ÄúIf the two of you will come with me.‚Äù

Oh great, they were going back to the lift. Well, Anakin could at least be glad he had made Padm√© smile once. Looking back over his shoulder as they left, he couldn‚Äôt help but notice how stiff and scared she looked.

He would have to do something about that.

Escalations

The building was quiet. Oddly quiet.

Anakin was used to the constant hum of the Jedi Temple, which had its lulls of course. But there were nocturnal inhabitants of the Temple as well as those that were coming and going on missions on the schedule of other planets and systems. The communication lines were always manned, and Anakin remembered the few times he and Obi-Wan had been asked to take an overnight shift, probably as punishment for something. Master Windu said it was to get Anakin familiar with the kinds of requests the Jedi got, but Anakin was pretty sure they had also done something Master Windu hadn‚Äôt liked. Something‚Ä¶ about the starships? He couldn‚Äôt remember.

‚ÄúCaptain Typho has settled in downstairs,‚Äù Obi-Wan didn‚Äôt announce his arrival, but it wasn‚Äôt like Anakin hadn‚Äôt noticed his master zipping up to this floor. He was paying attention. No one would get Padm√©. ‚ÄúHow is the senator doing?‚Äù

‚ÄúAsleep,‚Äù Anakin answered, feeling the fretful rest coming from the various rooms. Padm√© and her friend were both having disturbed nights. ‚ÄúThey went down a little while ago.‚Äù

Obi-Wan frowned as he tried to check the cameras, ‚ÄúWhat‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúShe covered them,‚Äù Anakin sighed, turning to his master. And grinned. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think she liked me watching her.‚Äù

That got a mixed look from Obi-Wan, something possibly along the lines of, ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt say,‚Äù and also, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt disagree with her.‚Äù

Which was completely unfair. Anakin was being very professional.

His master reached out in the Force, wondering, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know how she thinks we‚Äôll keep her‚ÄîIs she using herself as bait?‚Äù

Squirming, Anakin said, ‚ÄúNo harm will come to her. I can‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt depend on her to be making sound judgements about risks to herself,‚Äù Obi-Wan‚Äôs expression was tighter than Anakin had been expecting. ‚ÄúThe dangers‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI can sense everything going on in that room,‚Äù Anakin protested. ‚ÄúYou know I can.‚Äù

‚ÄúEven if that is true,‚Äù Obi-Wan was definitely grumpy about being interrupted, ‚Äúthat doesn‚Äôt change that the senator is under a lot of stress and aiming for unreasonable goals.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs so unreasonable about wanting to catch the killer? The Jedi should have found them already.‚Äù

His master wanted to agree with him on that one. But then he‚Äôd have to admit that Anakin was right, and obviously that wasn‚Äôt going to happen. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not unreasonable that she wants the threat eliminated. But if there have been three attempts on her life already and the perpetrator hasn‚Äôt been caught, our primary concern needs to be seeing her through the night, and then the next few days. She‚Äôs placed a lot of importance on this vote.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo we protect her and catch the person after her.‚Äù It was so simple.

Frowning, but in a way that made Anakin uncomfortable because it was trying to be gentle, ‚ÄúYou aren‚Äôt at your best either, Padawan.‚Äù

What? ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre saying I can‚Äôt do this‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI‚Äôm saying no such thing,‚Äù Obi-Wan stepped closer, trying to smile. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd much rather have you here with me than anywhere else. But I need you to trust my judgement, and Captain Typho‚Äôs. If we try and take down the assassin by tracking them we‚Äôre splitting our attention. And the senator has insisted that she needs to be at this vote. Which means our priority is getting her there. Do you understand?‚Äù

He did understand, ‚ÄúBut if we catch them she won‚Äôt be in danger,‚Äù Anakin insisted. It was just logic.

Obi-Wan drifted away, his arms crossed for a moment, and then running a hand through his hair. He did that more now that it was short. It bothered Anakin, reminded him that‚Äîwell that he had been wrong. In thinking Obi-Wan cared. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt suppose you‚Äôre going to tell me why you need more time to meditate?‚Äù

The conversation shift was abrupt and Anakin didn‚Äôt like it. ‚ÄúI just‚Ä¶ I wanted time to think about things.‚Äù

‚ÄúLike what?‚Äù His master was in full on long-suffering mode, and looked too much like he was humoring Anakin.

But he was all Anakin had, so, ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been thinking about my mother.‚Äù Which reminded him, ‚ÄúDid you know about Leia?‚Äù

That was a flinch. ‚ÄúI did,‚Äù Obi-Wan at least had the decency not to lie after giving it away so easily. ‚ÄúNot‚Ä¶ Not when I first met her. Not even when I invited her to the dinner with me.‚Äù He huffed a laugh. ‚ÄúWe were being introduced to some guests by Senator Organa when I heard her full name for the first time. I‚Ä¶ very nearly embarrassed myself.‚Äù

There was a twist of glee at imagining Obi-Wan almost fainting that was edged with suspicion. ‚ÄúSo when my mom came here, you knew who Leia was.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs‚Äî‚Äú

He froze for half a second, and they both pivoted towards Padm√©‚Äôs door, moving before Anakin had fully processed that he had sensed danger. Whipped around the hall, lightsaber out as the door slid open, half a breath to spot the‚Ä¶ bugs? And then they were against the far wall, dead.

His eyes moved up, caught Padm√©‚Äôs gaze and he was lost there for a moment before there was the sound of shattered glass and he turned to see that his master had jumped out the window, latching on to some droid.

‚ÄúOur mandate is to protect the senator,‚Äù Anakin muttered under his breath, nose scrunched, tone high. ‚ÄúNot to catch anything. Stay here,‚Äù he told Padm√© as he ran out of the room. Her friend was already coming, so Padm√© wouldn‚Äôt be alone. Which was good. Anakin needed to go and rescue Obi-Wan again.

A mad speeder chase, a high jump, a slight crash, an embarrassingly short bar fight, and a briefly lost lightsaber later, Anakin and Obi-Wan were hauling a one-armed shapeshifter into a dark alley, and Anakin was pretty pleased. One bounty hunter caught, one question she needed to answer, one senator that was now saved. And Obi-Wan had said this was a bad idea.

‚ÄúWho hired you?‚Äù wasn‚Äôt getting them very far the first few times they asked, but Anakin knew how to pull the Force around him to intimidate as much as hide. He knew Obi-Wan didn‚Äôt like it, but they didn‚Äôt have time and‚Äî

‚ÄúIt was a bounty hunter named‚Äî‚Äú

Too late Anakin noticed a flash in the Force, heard a swish and a small thunk, and then the bounty hunter was fading, slipping away in a string of profanity directed at an armored shadow with a jet pack, flying off into the night.

Obi-Wan swore as he removed the poisoned dart and Anakin blinked. ‚ÄúHey, you said I couldn‚Äôt use those words because they weren‚Äôt fitting for a Jedi!‚Äù

Blinking, his master looked over. ‚ÄúI think we‚Äôre entitled tonight.‚Äù

And that was new. Obi-Wan was mostly holding together, but part of him seemed shaken. Almost‚Ä¶ unsure. ‚ÄúBut we caught her.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe said she was hired by another bounty hunter,‚Äù Obi-Wan said, handing the dart to Anakin while he scooped up the body. ‚ÄúBounty hunter hires another bounty hunter, that means two things. One, the trail is twice as obscure to the actual client. And two,‚Äù he paused at the mouth of the alley, trying to gauge if they could make it back to the speeder without getting noticed (that was a definite no), ‚Äúit means the hit was worth enough to pay someone else to do some of the dirty work.‚Äù

And if the base cost of hiring someone to kill a senator was around what Anakin thought it was, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs‚Ä¶ a lot of money, master.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot only that,‚Äù Obi-Wan accepted the inevitable and walked out, trying to deflect people‚Äôs attention without much success, ‚Äúbut we haven‚Äôt caught the people we need to yet. And the bounty hunter may hire more bounty hunters again. Which means this could take a while.‚Äù

Which meant they needed to stay close to Padm√©. Anakin looked down at the three-pronged dart, frowning. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve never seen one like this.‚Äù

‚ÄúNeither have I,‚Äù Obi-Wan did not like how tonight was turning out. ‚ÄúBut with any luck, that means it‚Äôs very unique and once we pull the data on it from the archives, we‚Äôll know exactly who we‚Äôre looking for.‚Äù

That was a cheering thought. ‚ÄúWhere are we taking the body?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe Temple,‚Äù Obi-Wan was firm. ‚ÄúWhen the hunt for the shooter got moved to Coruscant‚Äôs security force, they lost the whole trail. This one we‚Äôre taking care of personally.‚Äù

Anakin didn‚Äôt envy the Jedi that had to deal with this sort of thing. It didn‚Äôt happen often, but some things you could only find in the Force, and he was glad Obi-Wan had thought of that. ‚ÄúWhat about Padm√©?‚Äù

The body now dropped in the back, Obi-Wan turned, a single raised brow saying instead of words that Anakin was the one who had left her unguarded.

‚ÄúHer handmaiden was with her when I left,‚Äù Anakin hunched his shoulders, wishing he had his cloak so he could hide in it. He hated getting that look. ‚ÄúShe should have called the guards.‚Äù

Obi-Wan sighed. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll drop you off with them on my way. So no one can say we weren‚Äôt doing our job.‚Äù

Which meant Anakin could spend time with Padm√© and Obi-Wan wouldn‚Äôt be there to embarrass him. It was a real relief.

Leia was pissed. Leia was pissed because the last few days had been a cosmic horror and joke, all in one go, and because Padm√© was pissed and even systems away Leia was fully prepared to channel that as far as it would go because she was not above being pissed on behalf of two people.

Or twenty.

At a guess, Queen Jamillia was pissed too, but was too good at her job to say anything about it. Leia really wanted to be Queen Jamillia when she grew up.

Sab√© was also pissed, and so was Captain Panaka, but Sab√© was pissed because she didn‚Äôt think a couple of Jedi were good enough at their job and Captain Panaka was pissed because Sab√© kept letting Leia come to updates and overruled anyone who suggested it should be otherwise.

One plus to the last few days, Leia and Sab√© were becoming fast friends.

‚ÄúYou remind me of Padm√©,‚Äù Sab√© had said at one point. ‚ÄúBut with more proactive intentions of punching people in the face.‚Äù

Which was an impressive observation because Leia, in point of fact, hadn‚Äôt actually punched anybody yet. But it was probably true. Padm√© had something of an exponential violence scale where she mostly just wanted to yell at people louder and louder until she wanted to shoot them dead. Leia took her time getting to that point, knowing there was a lot of satisfaction to be had breaking someone‚Äôs nose before you got to shooting them.

In any event, Leia‚Äôs frustration now was directed very specifically at the Jedi Council.

‚ÄúWhat do you mean they‚Äôre sending her back?‚Äù

Captain Typho winced, glancing over his shoulder. Padm√© had apparently just gone back to sleep when first word came from the Temple that their recommendation was to have her escorted back to Naboo. They would make an official change to their mandate in the morning (on Coruscant) and it was quite possible they would try and make their suggestion an order.

Leia hoped they choked on it.

‚ÄúThey haven‚Äôt told us much, but what they do know is there is still a bounty hunter loose, and one who may be able to hire others. The planet just isn‚Äôt safe‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúThe whole point of having Jedi,‚Äù Leia didn‚Äôt grind her teeth, but it was a near thing, ‚Äúis to protect her, on Coruscant, so that she can go to the vote. We‚Äôre all very aware that, here or there, Padm√© isn‚Äôt safe.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut she‚Äôd be safer on Naboo,‚Äù Typho insisted, his voice still low. There was a skeptical look shared by Vers√© and Sab√©, which made Leia feel slightly less alone. It was tempting to just throw up her hands and storm out, but if Padm√© was too tired to defend herself and her job, someone had to do it. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll be talking to her tomorrow about the plans.‚Äù

‚ÄúCan you even get her off planet without getting her blown up?‚Äù Leia demanded, and the man actually flinched before narrowing his eye at her.

‚ÄúYes, I think we can.‚Äù

Based on nothing, as far as Leia could tell, but then her confidence that it would be better for Padm√© to just stay wasn‚Äôt really based on anything either. In fact, it probably wasn‚Äôt the safer move. It was just the only politically smart one.

Padm√©‚Äôs main point against a grand army for the Republic was that it would destroy any negotiating power the Senate had by being a live and ominous threat to the Separatist worlds. Aside from the expense, the poor regulation, the training that would be required, the time it would take‚Ä¶ But really, the point was, in her view, we can still talk to them. It‚Äôs still safe.

If Padm√© wasn‚Äôt at the vote, what would be lost wasn‚Äôt just her voice. It was her conviction. And if she wasn‚Äôt at the vote because of unknown violence threatened against her? It wouldn‚Äôt just be bad for the anti-military movement, it would be a bloodbath.

And no one was paying attention to that.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll need to get Padm√©‚Äôs permission before we try and move her,‚Äù Sab√© reminded the captain, folding her arms and looking as stern as Leia had ever seen anyone. ‚ÄúI know her safety is your concern, but Leia is right that there were reasons we took these risks.‚Äù A very hard look. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs already cost Cord√© her life to get Padm√© back there. We‚Äôre not going to waste it.‚Äù

And that argument made Captain Typho‚Äôs face do all sorts of interesting things. It was clear now, to Leia, that his team and the handmaidens frequently worked at cross purposes. As an extension of Padm√©‚Äôs authority, their priority was to keep her safe, but in the context of always being able to do her job.

Captain Typho was there to protect Padm√© from harm, like the Royal Security Forces who trained him. To protect her as a symbol and an icon. Even if it meant sometimes making other people step into her place to actually get things done.

Before things could escalate, Queen Jamillia added, ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt want to be hasty, and we don‚Äôt want to be careless with Padm√©‚Äôs life. But if the Jedi were able to stop this last assassination, let‚Äôs put our trust in them for now and speak with Padm√© in the morning.‚Äù

Padm√©‚Äôs morning. They would have to reconvene for another late night meeting here on Naboo. It wasn‚Äôt quite opposite schedules between the planets‚Äô rotations right now, but it wasn‚Äôt a neat overlap.

Captain Typho bowed to the queen and signed off, and everyone in the room slumped a little. Captain Panaka was looking at Leia with no small amount of dislike. Well too bad. Leia didn‚Äôt like the people she loved being in danger any more than he did, but she did know, unlike him, that there were serious consequences to small actions when you were playing on the galactic stage, not just the local one.

At least the queen seemed to realize it. ‚ÄúDo we have the appropriate measures here to keep her safe if she does come?‚Äù Queen Jamillia had the bonus protection of thick makeup to hide her weariness, but Leia could sense that the woman was at the end of today‚Äôs rope.

‚ÄúThere are options,‚Äù Captain Panaka said. ‚ÄúSafe homes in the city, bunkers in more private locations. Honestly, our best bet is probably the gungans. Not that bounty hunters can‚Äôt reach them, but they‚Äôll have a much harder time under water. And they‚Äôll stand out.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôd have more freedom of movement there,‚Äù Sab√© agreed, ‚Äúwhich might make her easier to contain. Although,‚Äù a frown, ‚Äúit might be harder to disguise where she is on any calls. And she‚Äôll want to keep working.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe may need to take a break,‚Äù Captain Panaka looked almost furious at the soft laughs that sounded all around the room at those words. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the best‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúI try to ask what is within reason,‚Äù the queen said, her voice kind but firm. ‚ÄúPadm√© was chosen for her strong sense of duty. I will not waste her life, but I will not entrap it either. If we are talking a few days, perhaps that will work. More than that,‚Äù Jamillia shook her head. ‚ÄúWe need to consider hiring outside security if this looks to be long term. The Jedi cannot watch her forever. They are needed elsewhere. And we have the resources to upgrade her security ourselves, if needed.‚Äù

A risky move, but a good one to think about.

‚ÄúDo we have confirmation that Representative Binks will be arriving on time tomorrow?‚Äù Leia asked. The gungan had been sent, knowing that Padm√© might have trouble getting to work while the danger was highest. They couldn‚Äôt rule out that something might happen to him, but the quick decision to send him along shouldn‚Äôt have reached general channels. The Chancellor wouldn‚Äôt be told until after Jar Jar had landed, and Leia at least knew that improved his safety quite a bit.

‚ÄúAs far as we can tell, yes,‚Äù Captain Panaka said, relaxing just a bit. ‚ÄúAnd he‚Äôs willing and ready to stay as long as we need him there.‚Äù

Really not ideal. Senator Organa could mostly keep an eye on him, but it was always better to have Jar Jar supervised by someone from his own delegation. ‚ÄúThen we‚Äôre as ready as we can be. For now.‚Äù

Sab√© and the queen nodded and Vers√© moved to open the room. Leia thanked Sab√© for an offer of staying in the Senator‚Äôs suite, but she wanted to at least try and get home and see Shmi one time today.

They were both still a little on edge.

Tip the Scales

In the silence between dusk and dawn, anything could happen, Luke had once told her.

Which had bewildered Leia, because she hadn‚Äôt lived in places where the night was a time of quiet. Having been on Tatooine, she wasn‚Äôt sure it was actually silent there either.

But she got the message.

Which was why she was awake in the middle of the night, curled up on the edge of her roof, warm drink in hand, counting the stars. Waiting for something to happen. Sab√© hadn‚Äôt called Leia yet, but it was only a matter of time. Padm√© should be up by now, and while Captain Typho would try and delay the argument, Dorm√© at least would make sure that things moved along as quickly as possible.

Not to mention at some point the Jedi would have to explain what they wanted.

All Leia had to do was wait, and try not to fall asleep.

Not like that was hard. She‚Äôd been channeling so much energy in the last few days it was a miracle she had gotten any sleep at all. Although Shmi‚Äôs presence was naturally soothing enough it shouldn‚Äôt have been that much of a surprise. And the rest was good, because it meant Leia was ready for now, much more than she would have been if she hadn‚Äôt slept at all.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre gonna get yourself into trouble,‚Äù Luke sounded far too smug for Leia to be worried.

‚ÄúAnd where did I learn that?‚Äù

‚ÄúUh, who rescued whom off a moon sized space station? I did not teach you how to get into trouble.‚Äù

Leia smiled, the first real smile she‚Äôd managed in days. ‚ÄúAnd who exactly had ended up on the station in a position to rescue me?‚Äù

"The guy whose sister got herself suck on a moon sized space station. I wouldn't have been there if you weren't."

"Yes you would have."
