"I'd have flown with the fighters to blow it up, later. I was on the station because I had to rescue you."

"Don't lie. Han complained for years that you never would have ended up on that thing if anyone had told him what was going on. You were heading for Alderaan, not me."

"I was coming for you," Leia could imagine Luke pulling a mock version of the face he'd used to make at her, when they'd first met and she could tell she was the first pretty girl he‚Äôd met that he hadn't grown up with. "Ben's job was to get to Alderaan."

"The point is‚Äî"

"The point is you were a rebel spy trying to steal plans for the Empire's secret weapon right out from under them. You were going to be there regardless of if I was coming.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe I wasn't‚Ä¶‚Äù Leia muttered, sipping thoughtfully. It was so hard to parse, in retrospect, how much of her life had been influenced by her connection with the Force, and to Luke.

There were some things she could be sure of. The longing during her childhood for someone to be standing beside her, someone she knew she missed. The dreams, nightmares really, that were so real and painful she couldn‚Äôt remember them when she woke. The edge of fear in her life that they had brought had been real. She may have attributed it to the undercurrent of her parents running a rebellion, but with hindsight, Leia knew better.

Normal people didn‚Äôt go around that afraid of fire jumping out at them from shadows.

But her violent dislike of the Emperor, her discontent at the unfairness in the galaxy, her friendship with Pooja Naberrie, her tendency to occasionally leap without looking or even to plan ahead and still end up in catastrophically life threatening situations, those weren‚Äôt Force things. At least, she couldn‚Äôt prove it.

Luke still had opinions. ‚ÄúYou would have been there. You don‚Äôt only do hard things when you know someone‚Äôs coming to save you.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf the two of us,‚Äù Leia mused, frustrated and sad, ‚ÄúI was the one who grew up in a giant palace with a full security force, overprotective parents, and the knowledge of a network of spies and insurgents who would have done just about anything to spit in the eyes of the Empire. You could say I grew up knowing someone would always come for me.‚Äù

And they had, which was the funnier part. But her brother‚Äôs voice was actually getting clearer, sharper now, as he voiced his disagreement. ‚ÄúAnd here? Who‚Äôs going to come for you?‚Äù

‚ÄúShmi would,‚Äù Leia said, although she could still see his point. Shmi would come, but what could she do? ‚ÄúPadm√©‚Äî‚Äú

Padm√© might come. Probably would. If she knew where to find Leia. If it wasn‚Äôt more important for Padm√© to be somewhere else, doing something else. If she was available, then she would come.

‚ÄúYou know they would come, if they could. But you‚Äôre not counting on it. If you get trapped, stuck alone with him, you won‚Äôt hesitate. You‚Äôll do what needs to be done.‚Äù

Unsure if that was a comforting thought or not, Leia at least had to admit that it was true. Probably. ‚ÄúWhat if it‚Äôs not enough?‚Äù

What if‚Ä¶ what if she couldn‚Äôt do it?

‚ÄúLeia,‚Äù Luke‚Äôs voice was quieter, but not fainter. It was solid. Serious. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll do whatever is necessary.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd don‚Äôt look back.‚Äù

In the dim glow of the stars, Leia could almost imagine she was back on that ship, locked in her own quarters, the afterimage of her past watching her with the deepest (saddest) eyes. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know why you believe that. Either of you.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou stood up to Father,‚Äù Luke was so gentle, even when she couldn‚Äôt see him. ‚ÄúYou stood up to Jabba. You stood up to anybody.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo I will now?‚Äù She was so tired. Not in her body, which was still buzzing, waiting for the next moment to move, to attack. But in her soul. She just‚Ä¶ she just wanted to rest.

Nowhere was safe enough.

‚ÄúYou still haven‚Äôt stopped. I don‚Äôt think anything can make you.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat makes one of us,‚Äù she muttered, hitching the blanket back over her shoulders.

He just chuckled. ‚ÄúWe both know I‚Äôm right.‚Äù

Sure he was. But instead of rolling her eyes, Leia allowed herself to smile. To think about a world where she would never give up, where nothing would ever stop her. Not from doing what was right.

It looked‚Ä¶ kind of a lot like the world she was currently in, actually.

‚ÄúDammit.‚Äù

Luke laughed.

Two visits to the Council in two days was two visits too many. Anakin was sure of it. But at least they‚Äôd done one thing right.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not thinking I‚Äôm going to fail this mission?‚Äù Anakin demanded, watching the sour look on his master‚Äôs face.

Obi-Wan grimaced as he came out of his thoughts and Anakin didn‚Äôt like that any better. ‚ÄúI doubt you‚Äôll fail. But I am concerned about this aggressive targeting of the senator. And what the consequences will be if we remove her from Coruscant.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou think she should stay?‚Äù Anakin didn‚Äôt care one way or another as long as no one was stupid enough to try and tell him to stop protecting her. And the Council had actually given him this assignment to do alone. As far as preparing for knighthood, that was a good thing. Right?

‚ÄúI think we don‚Äôt know who hired the killers, and she‚Äôs been targeted on Naboo before.‚Äù At Anakin‚Äôs twitch in the Force, Obi-Wan carefully added, ‚ÄúShe didn‚Äôt have you then, and she did survive all the attempts. But it would be inconvenient for her to be attacked again.‚Äù

Long experience told Anakin not to trust the smooth gloss of his master‚Äôs feelings. Obi-Wan could be tricky when he wanted too, and calm wasn‚Äôt the same as confident. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt think she‚Äôll be safer on Naboo?‚Äù

A sigh, but it didn‚Äôt seem directed at Anakin. Maybe. ‚ÄúI think making her disappear for a few days is safest. As long as she is disappearing, Naboo works as well as anywhere else. The problem will be getting her there.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not that hard to get room on refugee transports.‚Äù Anakin had looked into it a few times when, well, when being at the Temple had been hard (and when he‚Äôd seen the desert in his dreams, but couldn‚Äôt find his mother‚Ä¶).

Obi-Wan was almost smiling now. ‚ÄúOf course.‚Äù And then, ‚ÄúSince this is your assignment, it will be your job to tell the senator the Chancellor‚Äôs decision.‚Äù

Oh fu‚Äî

The call from Sab√© came when Leia was just about to break all sorts of rules about calling people in the middle of the night looking for trouble. It wasn't what she expected.

"He did what?"

"I'm dealing with things here at the palace. Can you make sure they've covered their bases on her transport?"

Leia nibbled her lip, then took the plunge. "If I'm not satisfied, can I have complete authority to reroute?"

"Yes."

The answer came so fast, Leia almost slid off the roof. "You're serious."

"We tried being reasonable. We tried being rational. We tried being cautious. It's time to try something else."

"Something risky?"

"Whatever it takes."

"And don't look back." Leia took a deep breath. "I'll take care of it. I've already got a secure line."

A snort from Sab√©. "Who do you think I am?"

‚ÄúThis. Is. Ridiculous.‚Äù

Anakin couldn‚Äôt help but agree, but he didn‚Äôt think Padm√© was referring to the silky dresses she had just shoved into the cases that she would be taking with her. While disguised. As a refugee.

He knew better than to make a comment about the dress she was wearing, though. She‚Äôd already told him that after she packed she would change.

‚ÄúThe Council thinks you‚Äôll be safer on Naboo.‚Äù He wandered towards the window, keeping himself between her and the repair droids there. Subtly.

‚ÄúI am so sick and tired,‚Äù each word was matched with a jerking motion of her hands as she grabbed, folded, and stowed more garments (it had to be ‚Äúgarments,‚Äù those were not normal clothes), ‚Äúof people telling me it would be better if I were just out of the way. Not doing anything.‚Äù More jerky movements. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been working on fighting this bill for over a year. A year! I was personally put in charge of it and now they‚Äôre just‚Ä¶‚Äù She groped at the air for a moment, then swung in arm in a gesture that said ‚Äúbanishment‚Äù twice as well as any words could. Then she sighed, pinched her nose, shuddered. ‚ÄúOh. This was how Leia felt. Lovely.‚Äù

Anger had morphed so quickly into guilt, Anakin was blindsided. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure you didn‚Äôt mean‚Äî‚Äú

He stopped at the look in here eyes when she faced him. He couldn‚Äôt. Just‚Ä¶ couldn‚Äôt. ‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt matter what I meant or not. It‚Äôs what I did.‚Äù Another heavy sigh. ‚ÄúAt least she didn‚Äôt see me begging to be allowed to do my job.‚Äù

Apparently there had been some sort of small coup arranged by Captain Eye-Patch and a similar looking man, who Anakin almost remembered, on Naboo. A security personnel only meeting that hadn‚Äôt even had the rumored Sab√©, who would eat Anakin alive if she ever caught him in Padm√©‚Äôs rooms, lucky it had been Dorm√© (and seriously, he‚Äôd been saving her) who had been the one to catch him. And the meeting had been all about, well let‚Äôs get you off planet quick before they have time to catch us running away with you.

And in principle, Anakin agreed but‚Ä¶

He also understood Padm√©. He thought. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt worry, now that Obi-Wan is allowed to investigate, he‚Äôll catch the culprit in no time.‚Äù

‚ÄúTwo days?‚Äù Padm√© asked, already shaking her head. ‚ÄúI have every faith in Master Kenobi‚Äôs abilities, but that‚Ä¶ I can‚Äôt depend on that kind of miracle.‚Äù

Okay, that was fair. ‚ÄúI could help him.‚Äù

That earned an eyebrow, and he couldn‚Äôt help but smile. ‚ÄúWhile you‚Äôre on Naboo, protecting me?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy not? There has to be something that I can do.‚Äù

She hummed for a moment, and the focus in her feelings was its own kind of relief. ‚ÄúMaybe you can talk to Leia. She‚Äôs already been doing some of her own investigating. And then there‚Äôs what I‚Äôve got from Artoo. If we tug from two directions‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs worth a try,‚Äù Anakin was really smiling now, glad that the atmosphere had brightened. Although, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know how easy it will be to work with Leia.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs quick,‚Äù Padm√© was folding things again, still with sharp movements, but this was focus, not anger. ‚ÄúShe won‚Äôt have any trouble keeping up with you.‚Äù

He got the impression, half from her shimmering feelings and half from her sidelong look, that she thought he would be the slow one. ‚ÄúGood. Because there won‚Äôt be any point in me helping if I have to keep waiting on her.‚Äù

And what was that look? ‚ÄúI seriously doubt you‚Äôll have to worry about that.‚Äù And then, ‚ÄúNo one told you about her?‚Äù

It was a careful question, laced with sympathy, he thought, and hesitance. He didn‚Äôt want to talk about it, but if Padm√© asked, he could only answer. ‚ÄúObi-Wan did, after yesterday. Not‚Ä¶ he didn‚Äôt say much.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs not much to say,‚Äù Padm√© admitted, staring at the bed. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt really know that much about what happened, and Shmi told you about how she and Leia made it to Naboo.‚Äù

A short version. He still had questions, especially about Cliegg Lars. He knew his mom. He knew Tatooine. He could only be glad she‚Äôd gotten out of there. ‚ÄúDo you know why she‚Äôs here?‚Äù

No, that wasn‚Äôt the right question. Was it?

Padm√© frowned. ‚ÄúLeia has goals for what she‚Äôd like to accomplish by working with the Senate. I think she‚Äôs on Naboo and working with us because Shmi liked it there, Leia feels responsible for her, and she also agrees with our politics. For the most part.‚Äù A shrug. ‚ÄúSorry, I know that‚Äôs not very useful.‚Äù

No, but at least he knew Leia cared about his mom. Hopefully. ‚ÄúWell, I guess we‚Äôll just have to see how it works out.‚Äù

"Obi-Wan got along with her," Padm√© said, poking at the contents of her case, frowning. "I think if she can walk circles around him, you'll probably be okay."

Walk circles around Obi-Wan? That wasn't how his master had put it. Although, he wouldn't have. "Her getting along with Obi-Wan doesn't mean we'll get along," he said instead.

That startled her. "You‚Ä¶ don't like Obi-Wan?"

"No, that's not‚Äî" Anakin huffed, turning to the window. He couldn't press his face against it, hope the glass stole some of the heat from his feelings. He needed to focus. There were decorations on the sill. He lifted them with the Force, spinning them in a half tilted orbit around him. "We don't always agree on things, but I do lo‚Äîlike him."

He couldn't look at her face, so he wasn't sure what she was thinking when she said, "Do you disagree a lot?"

"Yeah," Anakin mumbled. "More now than‚Äî" He swallowed, burying the hurt. He couldn't let it get out, hurt Padm√©. "He doesn't think I'm ready to be knighted. He keeps saying things, things I have to learn, that weren't important before. I used to agree with him, about the Jedi, and the Force. Now‚Ä¶"

"He surprises you," Padm√© said, and he still couldn't look at her, but he could feel her sympathy reaching out to him. "And not in ways you wanted."

"I know I have a lot to learn," Anakin tried to pull back. "He's not wrong about that. It's just‚Ä¶ he tells me that and then won't let me learn it. He‚Äôll tell me I don't know enough and then he won't give me space, let me try new things. Gets angry when I do it."

At least, that was how it felt. Obi-Wan was angry about something, Anakin knew. He wasn't sure if it was directed at him in those moments, or at something (or someone) else, but the Chancellor had told Anakin to trust his instincts, and‚Äî

"It's hard," Padm√© agreed, "when our mentors disappoint us. Sometimes‚Ä¶ we outgrow them."

At least she understood that. "I do still like him," Anakin said, placing everything back as carefully as he could. He was calm now. "Sometimes, when he's not being all profound and stuffy, he can be really fun." And then his eyes burned, because, "I miss that."

Padm√© had come over next to him, had set her hand on his arm, so he couldn't avoid looking at her now. And now, with her this close, on purpose, he could give her his full attention, look his fill. Just‚Ä¶ see her. Right next to him.

Her expression shifted from sympathetic to frowning just as her comm went off. Anakin took a step back as she answered with a cheerful, ‚ÄúHello, Leia. Shouldn‚Äôt you be sleeping?‚Äù

Oh great. Seriously?

‚ÄúSab√© beat me to murdering Panaka, so I‚Äôm left with the consolation prize of commiserating with you. How are you doing?‚Äù

There was a pause as Padm√©‚Äôs eyes flicked to him for a moment. ‚ÄúOh, you know me. Dutiful daughter of Naboo. I never complain.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis is a terrible idea and it‚Äôs going to get you killed. I have a better one.‚Äù

Anakin did not like her tone, and Padm√© seemed uneasy too. He stepped into the line of the call to loom ominously. At least, he hoped that was what he was doing. She didn‚Äôt seem surprised to see him. Or that impressed.

What was wrong with her?

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve already made plans‚Äî‚Äú

Leia cut Padm√© off with a sharp gesture. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre ruining your hard-won politics because they‚Äôre reacting, not thinking.‚Äù She paused, sounded pained. ‚ÄúPlease tell me that‚Äôs not what you‚Äôre wearing on a refugee ship.‚Äù

Anakin was glad he was standing behind Padm√© so she couldn‚Äôt see him smile a bit, but given how embarrassed she felt, he was probably missing her blush, which was‚Ä¶ well. ‚ÄúNo. I had another outfit picked out.‚Äù

‚ÄúPicked out. From your wardrobe?‚Äù Padm√© nodded and there was something between a sigh and a whine from the call as Leia buried her face in her hands. ‚ÄúPadm√©, you do not own a single piece of clothing that won‚Äôt make you stick out like a sore thumb around refugees.‚Äù Her gaze found Anakin. ‚ÄúAnd is that what he‚Äôs wearing?‚Äù

Padm√© turned to look up at him, not knowing, and that was kind of nice because she was really close again and maybe he took just one second to enjoy it before he answered, ‚ÄúI have something else. Pulled out of storage. We keep things at the Temple that we might need for missions, for ourselves or people who need help.‚Äù

‚ÄúNormal clothes?‚Äù she stressed, and Anakin nodded, making sure not to look at Padm√© so he could be serious.

‚ÄúI‚Äôd pass as successful if not profitable merchant on‚Ä¶ Tatooine,‚Äù he picked, hoping she knew it well enough. ‚ÄúOr close enough.‚Äù

And she did seem to know what that meant because she just nodded at him. ‚ÄúRight, Anakin knows how to dress like a normal, mid-level human. What are you going to do?‚Äù

Padm√© nearly bumped into him as she shifted. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt exactly have time for me to go shopping.‚Äù

That was a groan. Full throated and with a head shake. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll talk to Shmi, she has to have contacts. You can‚Äôt‚ÄîIf you‚Äôre coming here, that means an RRM transport, right?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù Padm√© seemed uneasy suddenly.

‚ÄúThe same RRM that had several of its board members caught in an explosion. On Naboo.‚Äù

Anakin did not like where this was going. ‚ÄúWe can arrange another‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNot to Naboo,‚Äù Padm√© cut him off, rubbing her forehead. ‚ÄúLeia, the Jedi Council has already decided, and the Chancellor ordered‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúIgnore him,‚Äù Leia said, and Anakin stiffened with anger. ‚ÄúHe can say he wants to protect you all he wants. If that‚Äôs his goal, he should leave this to the experts.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe Jedi‚Äî‚Äú Padm√© began again.

‚ÄúAre being stupid. If they want you to disappear, they either have to take you somewhere no one would ever guess you would go, which means all of Naboo is out, or somewhere so inconvenient to look for you it will take more effort than they can manage in two days to find you.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe don't have time to find a place like that," Padm√© sighed. "Leia, I know‚Äî"

"What exactly is your mandate?" Leia was looking at him now, and Anakin wasn't prepared for the shift.

"Uh, to protect the senator." Oh great, that sounded professional.

Leia nodded. "Do you think you'll be able to do that, to your fullest capacity, on Naboo?"

"Master Obi-Wan said it's as good as anywhere," Anakin recited before wincing. He was in charge here, not Obi-Wan. "But he did say it would be hard to move us safely, and I agree. I just don't have anywhere else to go."

It wasn't like he knew anywhere other than the Jedi Temp‚ÄîActually, that would be a great idea. If the Jedi were even remotely flexible enough to allow it.

Probably not.

"I have a simple solution for where to go," Leia said, somehow catching both of them in her gaze. Neat trick, he'd seen Master Koon do that. "As long as you feel like your mandate allows for a bit of‚Ä¶ creative interpretation of instructions."

Oh, he did like that look. That was the look of someone who knew how to have fun. "How creative are we getting?"

"We'll need to keep this a secret from everyone else," Leia, and now her focus was back on him. "Everyone."

"Except Artoo," Padm√© objected.

"Except Artoo," Leia agreed. "And Shmi. We'll need her help and her contacts."

His mom? Anakin looked between the two of the, baffled. "What does she‚Äî"

"We're going to reroute on one of the refugee ships?" Padm√© asked, and Leia just smiled.

"Even better. Get Artoo in there and set up your scrambler. This is going to get interesting."

"We don't need a‚Äî"

"Humor me," Leia said, and Anakin watched as Padm√© huffed, rolled her eyes, and then did what Leia told her.

Weird. "What am I going to do?‚Äù

‚ÄúKeep your mouth shut,‚Äù was her immediate answer, and okay, that was just a little pretentious. ‚ÄúAnd get ready to do exactly what I tell you.‚Äù

Off the Leash

‚ÄúDo you think he‚Äôll do?‚Äù Leia asked when Padm√©‚Äôs relaxed posture said Anakin had left.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs been standing between me and the window most of the time he was in here.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, I‚Äôm sure you look prettier when you‚Äôre not backlit.‚Äù

That was an eye roll. Leia was almost relieved to see it. ‚ÄúThere were droids up here, fixing my window.‚Äù The one that Obi-Wan had thrown himself out of to grab a droid in mid-air and get carried away into Coruscanti traffic. Leia and Luke were still giggling about that one, and Leia had no plans to let Obi-Wan live it down. ‚ÄúHe was being cautious. He‚Äôs not inattentive.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh, I‚Äôm sure he‚Äôs paying attention.‚Äù

‚ÄúLeia‚Ä¶‚Äù

Right, she needed to reign it in. If she didn‚Äôt, she‚Äôd have to explain her unfounded dislike of Anakin Skywalker, especially in the teeth of all the nice things Shmi and Padm√© always said about him, and explaining time travel was still not an option. Besides, it wasn‚Äôt like Anakin‚Äôs attention to Padm√© was going to get him anywhere. ‚ÄúDoes it bother you? I have plenty of tricks for getting guys to stop staring and get back to work.‚Äù

She wished she could say she‚Äôd only ever used them on Han, or strangers. But there were a couple she had perfected for handling Luke. If Padm√© saw Anakin as more of an innocent, floundering admirer.

Leia did not.

‚ÄúNo, it‚Äôs fine. Actually it‚Äôs‚Ä¶ kind of nice? Don‚Äôt tell him I said that.‚Äù

There was a part of Leia‚Äôs brain that processed those words logically. That said, Padm√© was stressed, she‚Äôd been feeling beaten and unwanted. It was reassuring to have uncomplicated, unwavering admiration. Stabilizing even. Teenage crushes being directed at you was not an inherently bad thing.

Another part of Leia‚Ä¶ twisted.

Since she couldn‚Äôt get a handle on it, couldn‚Äôt wrap her mind around it to figure out what it was and why exactly it bothered her, Leia let it go. Tucked it away into a corner of her brain to figure out on another day.

‚ÄúI won‚Äôt.‚Äù

When she didn‚Äôt hang up, Padm√© asked Leia, ‚ÄúShould you be seeing Shmi?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh, I, uh‚Ä¶‚Äù Actually she‚Äôd gotten her grandmother‚Äôs attention and made her requests already, through the Force. Shmi was working on them and should be done soon. Hopefully. But Leia wasn‚Äôt about to admit to being Force sensitive, to Shmi being sensitive, even on a secured comm line. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs still a bit early here.‚Äù

Padm√© frowned. ‚ÄúYou won‚Äôt have much time.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll have enough. You worry about you, and getting to safety without dragging a politically unblooded, trainee Jedi into a sordid love scandal right before the biggest vote of your political career to date.‚Äù

It was funny to see Padm√©‚Äôs face caught between laughter and horror. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt worry. If I‚Äôm going to allow rumors like that to start, I‚Äôll at least make sure I get something out of it.‚Äù

‚ÄúI did not need to know that,‚Äù Leia said, which did make Padm√© laugh.

‚ÄúSince when are you prudish?‚Äù

Since, since‚Äî No. That thought was still too twisted and wired to grab hold of. But Leia had a much better idea of what it might be now and was not sure she liked it. ‚ÄúCan I talk to Artoo for a minute? I have an idea and I‚Äôll need his help.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt get to know what it is?‚Äù

Given that Leia wasn‚Äôt sure it would work and didn‚Äôt want to get Padm√©‚Äôs hopes up, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a surprise. A good one,‚Äù she added at Padm√©‚Äôs grimace.

‚ÄúI suppose I‚Äôll have to take your word for it.‚Äù

It was hard to admit, but half of the reason that Anakin was staring at Padm√© right now was because she was wearing the outfit she had picked out as her best option for in transit as a refugee, and it‚Ä¶ It wasn‚Äôt exactly‚Ä¶

He understood why Leia had laughed. Even if it was rude.

‚ÄúBe careful, mi‚Äôlady,‚Äù Captain Eye-Patch was saying, as the train was coming to a stop. ‚ÄúMake sure you stay safe.‚Äù

Anakin tried not to roll his eyes. That was the whole point of him being here.

‚ÄúI will,‚Äù Padm√© said, and Anakin thought her eyes sparkled a bit, even as she answered seriously. ‚ÄúThank you, Captain. And you‚Äôll make sure Dorm√© stays safe?‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù the captain replied, even more serious than Padm√©.

‚ÄúAnd you‚Äôll make sure Leia stays out of trouble?‚Äù

At her arch look Anakin had to swallow his mirth in the Force and bit his lips on a giggle. It was even better when Captain Eye-Patch‚Äôs face pinched. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure Captain Panaka has things well in hand on Naboo. We‚Äôll make sure she doesn‚Äôt take any drastic steps to make herself a target here.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood.‚Äù And it seemed like Padm√© had actually been serious, not just baiting her guard. Why was everyone so worried about Leia? ‚ÄúUse your best judgement,‚Äù Padm√© was saying to Dorm√©. ‚ÄúWhatever you need to do to stay safe, do it.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to regret that when I get creative,‚Äù Dorm√© said, and she smiled for a moment, looking to the captain, but when she turned back to Padm√© her face fell, and a tear escaped. Anakin almost flinched at the sudden pain.

‚ÄúI have faith in you,‚Äù Padm√© said, her fingers reaching out and just brushing the handmaiden‚Äôs. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll be fine.‚Äù

A split second half smile. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not worried about us.‚Äù

Something happened then, something Anakin hadn‚Äôt expected. He and Obi-Wan were the only Force users in the train car. Padm√© wasn‚Äôt Force sensitive, and Dorm√© definitely wasn‚Äôt. But it was as if something around them twisted, and in that moment they shared something between them. Not with words, but with trust and experience.

Anakin loved it when that happened. He didn‚Äôt get to see it often, and almost never outside the Temple. But there was a rightness to it. Like being pulled into a hug by his mother, or the songs their neighbors used to sing together. Not magic, not mystic. Just‚Ä¶ being.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll try to keep up,‚Äù Dorm√© was saying, ‚Äúbut if I make too many appearances they‚Äôll know you‚Äôve left the capital.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what Jar Jar‚Äôs for,‚Äù Padm√© said. ‚ÄúTo be your cover. He‚Äôll consult with you, you‚Äôll pretend on audio lines to be me. You can do this.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know.‚Äù

There were a hundred things not being said in those words, and so many things being spoken in Dorm√©‚Äôs eyes.

‚ÄúAnakin.‚Äù He turned towards his master, wishing he could keep following the other conversation. ‚ÄúYou be careful too. Don‚Äôt do anything without first consulting either myself or the Council.‚Äù

Right, as if that were practical. But Anakin knew what was expected and his, ‚ÄúYes, master,‚Äù was all Obi-Wan needed before he was turning to Padm√©.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll try and get to the bottom of this as quickly as possible, mi‚Äôlady‚Äù he told her. ‚ÄúI know you and your people are in need of justice.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd speed,‚Äù Padm√© insisted, nodding. ‚ÄúThank you. I know you‚Äôll do your best.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôll be back here in no time,‚Äù Obi-Wan promised. ‚ÄúAnd then you can let Leia off her leash without fretting about it.‚Äù

Padm√© was grinning. "I think we're talking about different people again."

Obi-Wan just smiled.

"It's time to go," Anakin said, watching the people loading onto the ship. They needed to hurry. There was only a small window where they could pull this off.

"I know," Padm√© was composed, nothing showing in her face. It made it easier for Anakin to stay calm, to not let off a hint of what they were doing that Obi-Wan might catch.

"Anakin." Oh no, had he slipped? Anakin turned to face his master. "May the Force be with you."

"May the Force be with you, Master." And let it help Obi-Wan catch these people before Anakin was subjected to another of Leia's plans. He was starting to get jitters.

They were off the train, just out of earshot of the guards, but not Obi-Wan if he was determined, when Padm√© said, "Suddenly I'm afraid."

Scrambling for something, they didn't have a code and he couldn't say he thought Obi-Wan might still be listening, "It's alright. It's my first time away from my master for an assignment." Lie, but he thought the look she shot him conveyed that she understood. "I'm nervous too." That was true. When they were far enough it should be safe he added, "Don't worry, we have Artoo with us."

She actually laughed.

Now for the tricky part.

They boarded the ship at the first open hatch, had their documents scanned (there would be a trail, if there was a leak it would look like they'd gone along with the original plan), and instead of heading for the lifts down, Anakin maneuvered them sideways, towards a hatch further along, halting them at the exit, tucked where they wouldn‚Äôt interfere with the line.

They were cutting it close. They had to move soon or the hatch would close (and Leia might kill him, and Jedi training or not sometimes he thought she'd find it easy to do) and all of this extra planning would have been for nothing.

He'd promised Padm√© he‚Äôd make it work. He wouldn't fail.

"Now."

It was a half whisper, but he could feel that Obi-Wan's attention had turned, shifted from being focused on Anakin's presence. Hopefully the train was getting ready to move.

They made it off the ship and Anakin had them stop behind some empty storage containers, waiting until the train had pulled fully away (taking no chances, Obi-Wan would definitely look back) before having them head to the shadows around the corner of the platform. They tried to move at the crowd's pace, like Leia had coached them, while sticking close to the wall and avoiding any attention.

Luckily Anakin was taller than Padm√© and he could partially cover her.

Unluckily they had a droid with them. Leia was right. As useful as Artoo was, he was in too good of condition to belong to a refugee. Especially as an astromech. Who had their own astromech and not their own ship? Or other property that required maintenance?

Their ship took off behind them and Anakin knew even if they weren't safe, they were committed.

"You're Shmi's people?"

The question came from a human female, closely followed by a female zabrak, who eyed the crowed around them with clear mistrust. Her focus and her stance told Anakin she was here as much as protection for the first woman as to help them.

"Yes," Anakin answered, offering a half bow and extending his hand. "I'm her son."

Which had both women looking more confused and uncomfortable for a moment before the zabrak shrugged and the human nodded. "Come with us."

Artoo may have been the slowest, but the women set a pace he could match and Anakin took advantage of that to drop to the back, letting the zabrak watch their front as she led them. The human woman fell into step with Padm√©, not speaking but offering an arm. Anakin was grateful. It eased some of Padm√©'s tension and made it easier for Anakin to sense what danger might be around them.

"In here."

It looked like, well not an abandoned building. No buildings were abandoned on Coruscant. But this one didn't seem completely structurally sound, and was definitely very dirty. The lift they entered was small and cramped with the five of them. Artoo chirped profanities at the state of things, especially when the lift jerked awkwardly about halfway down. Padm√© was startled enough to grab Anakin, but their guides only oozed irritation, not surprise.

Not an uncommon feature then.

Their path wound on probably for about another hour. It seemed very circuitous, looping around buildings with more lights and noises, wending through back alleys and tripping further and further down. Padm√© was almost visibly sagging by the time they made it to a door (off a side road, not a main one) where the women stopped and keyed in a code.

Anakin knew then that they didn't understand binary. Artoo's comments about how easy it would be to break in were completely inappropriate. Anakin told him so, also in binary. Which earned him some looks, even from Padm√©.

"What?"

She blinked. "I didn't know‚Äî"

"Inside, flirt later." The zabrak woman didn't look amused, but Anakin felt like she might be so he grinned. Padm√© may have been blushing, it was hard to tell in the dim light.

Inside there were probably twenty people in the front room, mostly women and children of various species. Halls and doors were faint in the background, but Anakin was busy searching with the Force rather than with his eyes. When he determined that there wasn't any immediate threat he nodded to Padm√© who nodded back, but seemed more than a little lost.

"We were told almost nothing," the human woman said, after introducing herself as Hailee, and her partner as Oobra. "But we have your change of clothes and will help with the droid."

At that Artoo whistled nervously, something about Leia getting carried away. Anakin asked Hailee, "What can we do to help?" hoping to get more details.

Hailee shook her head. "It will go faster if we take him. Don't worry," she added, seeing the look on Padm√©'s face. "He will be returned, and with all of his working pieces."

"Can he keep the broken ones too?" Anakin asked, aiming for an impish smile. He hoped it was covering Padm√©'s embarrassed look. "I like to collect those and make little speeders out of them."

Oobra smiled at that and Hailee hid her mouth behind her hand, her eyes dancing. "Yes, we will bring you the broken pieces too."

Good. He wasn't kidding about the mini-speeders. He wouldn't get in trouble for making them here and giving them to some of these kids. Some Jedi had no sense of humor about small gadgets getting caught in trailing robes.

Including his master.

Padm√© was led away by Oobra and one of the other women in the room and Anakin was invited to sit near the wall after his clothing was closely inspected by one of the room‚Äôs matrons and given a thoughtfully approving nod.

He was glad he'd gone for the poncho with the stain on it.

A few of the kids wandered up to him and it had been a while since he'd had to translate between four languages at once to follow a conversation, but after a few minutes he picked up the hang of it again. He delighted them by responding to each of them in their own tongue, instead of using Basic, and had two on his lap, tugging at his Padawan braid when Padm√© was led back into the room.

He recognized her because he'd seen her on Tatooine, dressed as a commoner, all those years ago, and because she was a light in the Force that he was always able to pinpoint when he was looking for it. But her fancy dress was gone and her hair was mostly down and he didn't think they'd actually rubbed dirt or grease on her face, but she seemed smudgy.

They'd taken her makeup off, he realized. And they hadn't worried about leaving stains and smears with it.

She'd gone from looking like a pristine statue, all wrapped and gilded in courage and fine robes, crowned with confidence, to looking almost like she had ten years ago, when she was just a displaced queen and he was‚Ä¶ not who he was now.

This time, he wouldn't just help her. This time he would keep her safe.

Her fingers were rubbing the hem of her sleeves and Hailee led her over, a calm kindness radiating off of her. "Here she is. We have a transport for you, for the next stage. You won't be traveling far. You‚Äôre to be within two hours of the Senate building, in case of emergency." Her tone was reciting a message, one she didn't really understand. "We have a place prepared, as was asked."

"Thank you," Anakin said, extracting himself from the pile of children who complained that he was going. "Is there anything‚Äî"

‚ÄúCompensation has been seen to," Oobra said solemnly. "Anything you do not need or want can be left at your residence when you are finished. We will take care of it."

He‚Äôd make sure to leave something for the kids, Anakin promised himself. They were playing games with each other, pretend stuff with little dolls and some well-worn figures. A few, maybe two people, had old datapads that flickered in ways Anakin wished he had time to fix. "We're very grateful," he said as they were led out of the house, through a back door this time, to a waiting speeder that Anakin wished, again, he could have fifteen minutes with. He knew what those noises meant, they didn't even need replacement parts yet‚Ä¶

Padm√© gasped under her breath when Artoo rolled out, painted yellow and brown and streaked with dirt and grease stains. When he got really close, Anakin could see something that imitated rust on some of his joints.

Anakin liked these people. They were thorough.

"Travel safely," Hailee said once Artoo had been loaded. It may have been directed to him and Padm√© or the driver. Anakin wasn't sure.

They were dropped off another level or two down on the side of a building that was speckled with doors. They were given an access card and made their way down a hallway lined with yet more doors, all battered and filthy.

If it wasn't to protect Padm√©'s life, Anakin would never have brought her here. He wasn't sure he should have brought her here anyway. Surely there was somewhere better.

"We should get inside," Padm√© whispered, eyes drifting to the other doors, scanning them for any sign someone was watching.

"Right," Anakin said, and he reached out with the Force, confirming there was no one inside, before opening the door.

Diagnosis

Anakin had expected an empty room and was surprised when they stepped in and several crates were scattered across the floor. They made him hesitate.

"Stand in the corner," he told Padm√©, pointing to where a half wall created some cover for a kitchenette. "I need to check this."

"Leia wouldn't‚Äî"

"We don't know why they're here," he said, stepping forward, reaching out with his senses as best as he could. The Force could help him find ill intention easily, but machines didn't usually project those sorts of things. He could find the right kinds of explosives if the way they stored energy was active enough, but he wasn't getting anything from the boxes. ‚ÄúShe might not have left them.‚Äù

Couldn‚Äôt have dropped them off personally, in any event. So he did need to make sure there weren‚Äôt any unexpected surprises.

There was a note on top of one of the crates and Anakin called it over, not willing to get closer yet. It read, ‚ÄúThought you might need something to keep you occupied while you‚Äôre locked up. And he needs help.‚Äù

What?

‚ÄúWhat is it?‚Äù Padm√© asked, and he could tell she was trying not to be impatient. He read her the note, but she seemed as confused as he was.

Artoo, though. Artoo trilled, and zipped in a small circle, all but shouting, ‚ÄúI know it! I know it! She did promise. She did!‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù Anakin asked, trying not to trip in the small space. ‚ÄúArtoo, she promised what?‚Äù

‚ÄúThreepio!‚Äù the droid beeped.

Anakin blinked. ‚ÄúThreepio?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh.‚Äù Padm√©‚Äôs sudden burst of hope as she looked towards the crates was distracting enough Anakin almost missed her saying, ‚ÄúShe must have sent him.‚Äù

‚ÄúIn pieces?‚Äù Anakin was horrified. ‚ÄúWhy would she‚Äî‚Äú

But Padm√© was blanching, and he hadn‚Äôt meant‚Äî She opened her mouth, to try and explain he thought, but the words never came. After a moment, she gestured and Anakin turned back to the crates, taking another hesitant step forward.

Open them with the Force and try and redirect any surprises, or inspect the box up close?

In the end, he opted for up close, running his fingers over everything, checking at different angles. If there was something hidden, it was completely inside. There was a faint smell of smoke, he thought. Almost like a grease fire, but also charred wires and‚Äî

Padm√©‚Äôs ship had blown up. The only reason Padm√© wasn‚Äôt dead was because Padm√© hadn‚Äôt been on it.

Hole into eternity open in the bottom of his stomach, Anakin eased the lid off the first crate and had to fight back tears at what he saw inside. Part of an arm, a cracked and blasted torso, half a foot. And that was just the bits he could see on top.

‚ÄúHe was in the explosion,‚Äù Anakin whispered, picking the foot up, running his thumb along the scorched, warped metal. ‚ÄúHe was on your ship.‚Äù

‚ÄúShmi wanted him to come with us. To help keep an eye on things.‚Äù Anakin didn‚Äôt need to look to know guilt was written all over her face. ‚ÄúWe tried to have him looked at after, but everyone we consulted‚Ä¶ They said he was too customized. They didn‚Äôt recognize any of his inner layout.‚Äù

Well, yeah. Anakin had built him to be functional on Tatooine, not in ballrooms. You had to move certain pieces around to make sure they wouldn‚Äôt overheat each other, and then there was the wiring, insulated differently and mismatched because he‚Äôd been hunting for scraps out of Watto‚Äôs junk pile, the stuff he was sure they couldn‚Äôt sell, would never be useful. Not to mention the little extra bits Anakin had added to fix broken parts, or upgrade them.

Also, Threepio‚Äôd been reconstructed when Anakin was nine.

‚ÄúIs this all of him?‚Äù Anakin asked, unwilling to look back in the crate.

Padm√© came over, knelt next to him on the floor. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know. Leia didn‚Äôt tell me she was doing this. I know we had all of the pieces of him that we could find collected and kept at the apartment. I assume she arranged for all of them to be sent here.‚Äù

Her hand was on his shoulder. It was warm and kind and Anakin made himself look up and smile at her, knowing the look was more brave than happy and not caring about that right now. ‚ÄúIf she did, I can probably at least get started on fixing him.‚Äù

He wasn‚Äôt sure he would get very far. This was a lot of pieces, all of them seriously damaged. He‚Äôd need replacements for a lot of it. And tools‚Ä¶

‚ÄúI should check the other crates,‚Äù he said, standing and offering her a hand. She accepted and he pulled her straight up, so that she would still be right next to him. ‚ÄúAnd the other rooms. If they‚Äôre safe, you can stand in one until I‚Äôve got everything cleared.‚Äù

Not a grimace, not quite a frown, but Padm√© didn‚Äôt look enthusiastic. ‚ÄúAre you sure that‚Äôs necessary? We already know that Leia sent these, and what‚Äôs in them.‚Äù

Anakin nodded. ‚ÄúThey got explosives onto your ship. I have to check.‚Äù

He would do this job right. Padm√©‚Äôs life was at stake and Obi-Wan thought it might sway the Council to think about knighting him and‚Äî

He checked the other two rooms. They were small, tiny really. One had a bed and maybe an arm‚Äôs length of space on three sides of the thing, the other was the refresher and Anakin thought it only looked mildly suspect. He let Padm√© pick which one she preferred for waiting and was zero percent surprised when she picked the bedroom.

None of the other boxes exploded on him when he opened them. Which was nice.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt think he took up this much space,‚Äù Padm√© commented when she came back out. ‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt look like there‚Äôs a lot of packing material either.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs covering a bunch of other stuff,‚Äù Anakin said, refusing to think too hard as he removed different sections of the droid and laid them carefully on the floor. ‚ÄúSome of it‚Äôs food. Sort of.‚Äù

Travel rations and instant meals. Not the good stuff either. The stuff you got when it was just you and your master and you weren‚Äôt part of an official negotiating team where you got real food because all politicians had weak stomachs.

Well, he hoped not all of them. He didn‚Äôt exactly have anything else to offer Padm√© if she couldn‚Äôt eat this. ‚ÄúDid she think you can‚Äôt cook?‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe,‚Äù Padm√© said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt really talk about it. And I don‚Äôt do it much anymore. Leia can‚Äôt cook, so I don‚Äôt know that she would know what to send aside from this.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe can‚Äôt cook at all?‚Äù Anakin couldn‚Äôt imagine it. Hadn‚Äôt she come from the Outer Rim? You had to at least know the basics so that you could tell if someone was cooking something that wasn‚Äôt safe for your species. ‚ÄúHow does she survive?‚Äù

Padm√© giggled as she took a seat on the (dubiously creaking) couch. ‚ÄúShmi helps her. I think she‚Äôs learning, but she won‚Äôt talk about it. I can only imagine‚Äî‚Äú Padm√© stopped, shrugged. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôd rather not talk about it.‚Äù

‚ÄúAt least she knows droids okay,‚Äù he muttered as he started sorting through some of the other things in the crate. Apparently Leia‚Äôd had it stocked with all sorts of bits and pieces, plenty of spare wires, and a very well assembled tool kit. ‚ÄúAlthough, I think there‚Äôs twice as much stuff in here as what we need.‚Äù

Artoo was happy to explain that they hadn‚Äôt known the details of the damage and had erred on the side of safety. Anakin nodded, and then smiled. He could make a bunch of little toys from the extras, he thought.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt suppose she left anything for me in there?‚Äù Padm√© asked as Anakin was just starting to pull apart the wrecked metal of Threepio‚Äôs chest. He blinked, already half lost in ideas of what he needed to do, then blushed, because really? How could he forget Padm√© when she was right there?

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt see anything,‚Äù Anakin said, peering inside. ‚ÄúWait, no. There‚Äôs a datapad.‚Äù He tossed it over, catching it again in the Force when Padm√© almost dropped it. ‚ÄúSorry.‚Äù

She just smiled, grabbing it out of the air after studying it curiously for a moment. ‚ÄúNo, I missed it. Thank you.‚Äù

He decided to wait a few minutes to see if she needed anything else before going back to his task.

‚ÄúOh for the love of‚Äî‚Äú Padm√© sounded irritated, but her lips were fighting a smile.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

‚ÄúNovels,‚Äù Padm√© sighed. ‚ÄúShe left me some of our notes on the MCA too, to keep me refreshed. But most of this is,‚Äù she hesitated, and this time Anakin did get to see her blushing, ‚Äúromance novels.‚Äù

Anakin stared. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù

He had to stop saying that. He wouldn‚Äôt sound smart if he kept saying just that.

‚ÄúAnd a note that I am apparently to treat this as a forced vacation, and not only read the work documents,‚Äù Padm√© did not bother to explain more about the stories that Leia had left her, but her avoidance told Anakin most of what he needed to know.

‚ÄúDo you like them?‚Äù he asked, trying to decide if he should be offended on her behalf. Leia was being pretty high handed in all of this.

A shrug. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt mind them, but I usually read historical records in my free time, especially about political figures from allied systems. I‚Äôm pretty young for a senator and I don‚Äôt know as much about the history of my colleagues as I would like.‚Äù

She was uncomfortable as she said it, as if it was reminding her of something she didn‚Äôt want to think about. So Anakin opted for the first distraction he could think of and asked, ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs your favorite?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have one,‚Äù Padm√© confessed. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre all interesting in terms of content, but the presentation is usually very dry. Although,‚Äù she scrolled a bit and smiled at the screen, ‚Äúit looks like Leia has selected historical, political romances for me to read. So maybe this will be educational and interesting.‚Äù

He‚Äôd have to take her word for it. Anakin liked reading, liked learning, but he‚Äôd always preferred that any stories were spoken and signed, rather than just written down. You were missing something when someone didn‚Äôt put their voice, their body, into the tale. ‚ÄúAre you‚Äî Is it okay if I focus on this for a while? If you‚Äôre reading?‚Äù

He felt unsure again. The morning had been a tight dance of lying to and escaping from Obi-Wan, which had given all of this the taste of an adventure. He‚Äôd planned to be hyper-vigilant, all of his focus on Padm√© and their surroundings at all times, no mistakes.

Now‚Ä¶

Now Threepio needed to be repaired, and he felt much safer in the anonymity of this frankly disgusting apartment than he had as they had approached the refugee ship. It felt like they had actually escaped from danger, that all they had to do now was to spend a couple of days waiting before Padm√© returned to do her job. It should be easy, maybe even nice.

But Padm√©‚Äôs comfort and safety came first, and if she needed his attention‚Ä¶

‚ÄúTake a look at Threepio,‚Äù she insisted. ‚ÄúI doubt you can get him all back together in two days, but it‚Äôs worth a try. And if he‚Äôs even only in partly working condition, having him would be a big help.‚Äù She smiled, and everything in the room went warm with the light of it. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad Leia thought of this. You‚Äôre definitely the best person to try and fix him.‚Äù

Well, if she needed Threepio, the droid Anakin had built, he would definitely start the repairs. Especially since, ‚ÄúI think I can at least get him pieced together and moving in two days. I‚Äôve got enough spare parts, which wasn‚Äôt true when I built him, and plenty of free time.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou do that,‚Äù she didn‚Äôt believe him, but was willing to humor him. Anakin knew what to do with a challenge like that. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll start on some of these and see if they‚Äôre any good.‚Äù

He‚Äôd just found his focus when he heard the first of her giggles. He glanced up, but she wasn‚Äôt looking at him, so probably she didn‚Äôt want to share.

The second and third time he was a little irritated, but she was happy and so Anakin made himself settled down again and refocus.

The fourth time Padm√© burst out laughing, almost doubled over, actual tears in the corners of her eyes as she almost choked.

‚ÄúThat good?‚Äù he asked, half sighing and trying not to sound whiny.

She shook her head. ‚ÄúOh no, it‚Äôs‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs awful. Unbelievably awful.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd that makes it funny?‚Äù It sort of made sense, but he wouldn‚Äôt have expected her to laugh this much.

Padm√© sat up and primly recited the most atrocious description of a trandoshan, apparently from the perspective of someone who found him salaciously appealing, Anakin had ever been forced to process. It had been written by someone who had clearly never met a trandoshan and did not do nearly enough research into their culture or biology. It was appalling, and because of the way Padm√© was reading it, it was also hilarious.

‚ÄúStop,‚Äù he begged, his sides hurting from trying not to laugh. ‚ÄúPlease, just stop.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt want to know why this fine and unattainable specimen has caught the attention of our impressionable, highly reliable narrator?‚Äù She almost made it through the sentence with a straight face, but not quite. Anakin couldn‚Äôt stop his giggles.

‚ÄúI thought this was a story about politics.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh it is,‚Äù Padm√©‚Äôs smile was bright and happy, and her look was adorably conspiratorial as she leaned forward and said, ‚Äúbut I‚Äôd have to read you those bits too. I can‚Äôt do them justice.‚Äù

Anakin looked at the mess that was in front of him, thought about the previous moments where he had been thinking about Threepio, about how he had been damaged and how it would have happened and how it must have hurt and been so frightening. And how that made it hard to focus on just fixing him.

‚ÄúDo you want to read it out loud?‚Äù It would be awful, and it would take him a bit more time to find the right rhythm, the right tenor in the Force to let him work and listen at the same time. But if Padm√© was going to be giggling over fantastically awful literature the whole time anyway, it was probably better to join a lost cause than fight it.

‚ÄúReally?‚Äù she asked, and seemed hesitant. ‚ÄúI mean, I can‚Äôt promise it won‚Äôt get worse. Or better.‚Äù

‚ÄúI like listening to you,‚Äù Anakin said, and had to look away, had to pick at the wires in his lap, because he‚Äôd meant to say it better than that. ‚ÄúI like hearing stories, and you can‚Ä¶ you can really read.‚Äù

How had he actually managed to get worse? In one sentence?

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Padm√© said, not quite believing him, but getting more comfortable on the couch again. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll just start from the beginning.‚Äù

Anakin nodded rather than looking at her and trusting his traitor mouth. How did Obi-Wan make talking to people always look so easy?

‚ÄúYou had no right‚Äî‚Äú

Captain Panaka‚Äôs almost scream was cut off by Sab√©‚Äôs dangerously even, ‚ÄúI gave her permission to adjust the plans as needed.‚Äù It was so cold and sharp other members of the Council flinched.

Leia wished they weren‚Äôt speaking to the full Advisory Council. The queen, she trusted, and even Captain Panaka, although he would probably tell Captain Typho, who would probably give it away, at least to the Chancellor, by sheer irrepressible emotive panic.

‚ÄúWhat are the plans now?‚Äù Advisor Vancil seemed remote and collected, but the way his steepled fingers tapped against each other gave Leia pause. Thoughtful, or conniving?

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve rerouted her without consulting‚Äî‚Äú Panaka was cut off again, this time by a gesture from the queen. It wasn‚Äôt sharp, just the gentlest raising of her hand, one finger held up in a slight curve. She didn‚Äôt even look at the captain, just at Sab√© and Leia, the closest thing to a frown Leia had ever seen on her face.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre deliberately limiting the number of people with access to her location?‚Äù the queen asked, no particular inflection to the question to suggest either suspicion or real curiosity. Just a confirmation of fact.

Leia nodded rather than trusting herself to speak when Sab√© didn‚Äôt answer.

The queen considered the two of them for a minute, silent and calm, her gaze slightly unfocused, almost as if she was seeing through them. ‚ÄúWe will table the matter of Senator Amidala‚Äôs security for the time being,‚Äù she said, and Captain Panaka spluttered a faint protest. ‚ÄúIf we are asked, she arrived as planned, and has been moved to a safe location which we are unable to disclose. For safety reasons. Although,‚Äù and her thoughtful tone took on an edge that Leia hadn‚Äôt heard before, ‚ÄúI hope our friends are wise enough not to ask.‚Äù

It occurred to Leia that Queen Jamillia was still very angry about people being blown up on her planet. And no one taking responsibility for it so that the perpetrator would be caught. She still held most of her placidity, turning the conversation to other important matters and soothing her council, who, in turn, did manage to have a productive meeting. About swamp sludge and its inconveniences and uses.

Very dull, but Leia had no regrets about them staying when she and Sab√© were invited to follow the queen and her handmaidens out of the room.

Leia was even more impressed when the queen didn‚Äôt speak until they had been led back into her chambers, all the way to her dressing room, where the handmaidens did a very thorough check for bugs before the queen settled down in front of her vanity, saying, ‚ÄúYou believe we have a leak in our security detail.‚Äù

It was an almost heartbroken statement, enough that Leia tried to sooth it with, ‚ÄúI think there‚Äôs a leak somewhere and Padm√© is involved in the Senate, not just with Naboo. And it‚Äôs difficult but not impossible to intercept our messages. If someone is interested.‚Äù

The handmaidens were removing the queen‚Äôs elaborate hair pieces, her jewelry and shoes, with a tender efficiency that had Leia almost jealous. She‚Äôd never needed someone to fully dress her, although she‚Äôd had plenty of help with her hair, especially when she was young. The casual intimacy of it in combination with the fact that Queen Jamillia had not dismissed these women spoke volumes of her love and trust for them.

And explained the trust she gave Sab√©, and by extension Leia, when it came to Padm√©.

‚ÄúFour attacks,‚Äù Queen Jamillia said softly, standing to be extracted from outer layers, watching Sab√© and Leia in her mirror. ‚ÄúEach with Senator Amidala present, once with Leia, once with members of the Advisory Council and RRM, once with just Padm√©‚Äôs staff, once her alone. Four times.‚Äù

In only two months Leia realized. It was‚Ä¶ an absurdly high number. ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt want her at the vote.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe won‚Äôt be,‚Äù Queen Jamillia said, then blinked at the look on Leia‚Äôs face. Which wasn‚Äôt fair. Leia hadn‚Äôt so much as twitched. The queen smiled. ‚ÄúGiven that she is expected to be on Naboo, if excluding her from the vote was their intention, it is a great pity that they will still get what they want.‚Äù

Her tone was even, her words precise, but her eyes were dancing with a laugh. Leia almost grinned. ‚ÄúThe senator is technically still present on Coruscant,‚Äù Leia said, not naming Dorm√© because even if you‚Äôd checked for bugs, you couldn‚Äôt be sure. ‚ÄúTaking great risk in the course of her duty.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe is unwavering and brave,‚Äù Queen Jamillia was still smiling, but her voice held more sorrow now. ‚ÄúI am glad Representative Binks is with her. For all that he has a knack for getting into trouble, he has always gotten out of it. He will be a great asset.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe vote is important,‚Äù Leia said, not willing to comment on Jar Jar. No need to tempt fate any more than they already had. ‚ÄúBut it won‚Äôt be the end of this. Whether the MCA succeeds or fails, there will be more votes about making a military and what to do with it. Setting aside the negotiations with the Separatists.‚Äù

Queen Jamillia nodded and earned a tut from one of her handmaidens who was trying to touch up her makeup. ‚ÄúThis is only the beginning of a conflict. We may yet have to take more drastic measures to keep the senator safe.‚Äù

‚ÄúOr simply have contingencies more in line with a higher risk,‚Äù Leia said gently. She didn‚Äôt want to think about it, wouldn‚Äôt allow it. But they needed someone else who could step into Padm√©‚Äôs shoes. Someone who wouldn‚Äôt be swayed by the whims of powerful men who were well spoken and devious as snakes.

‚ÄúDid you have a recommendation?‚Äù the queen asked, turning to look at Leia full on.

And Leia realized what she might have accidentally implied, so she scrambled for, ‚ÄúWe need actual spies. People who can move and not grab any attention. Who can ask questions that don‚Äôt come back to your people, or you.‚Äù

‚ÄúI will consider it,‚Äù Queen Jamillia said, and Leia read in her stance and in her tone that spies were not something the queen knew how to ask for or instigate. But she would find out.

For now, they would have to live with that.

Anakin had thought everything was going well because they spent the evening laughing over trashy dialogue and he was making good progress on Threepio. Artoo did not understand what was amusing the organics, but he was willing to help where he could with repairs, and his running commentary on the illogical behavior in the story was almost as good as the awful writing.

But when a soft noise woke him in the middle of the night and he sat up, Anakin could tell even in the darkness that Padm√© had been crying. It was in the soft halo of pain that was around her, and the way her voice was rough even as she whispered, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry. I‚Äôm just getting some water.‚Äù

The couch was just barely too small to be comfortable, so Anakin didn‚Äôt mind popping up and saying, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll get it. Or would you like some tea? I think Leia‚Äî‚Äú

Something wobbled in Padm√© when he said that name and he tried to backtrack, to read her in the Force because he couldn‚Äôt see her face in the darkness (not that seeing it would necessarily tell him anything), but nothing he was getting off her made sense. So he just ended with, ‚ÄúSorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, it‚Äôs fine,‚Äù Padm√© was still whispering. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt mean to wake you. I‚Äôll just get some water and go right back.‚Äù

She was moving around him as she spoke and he had to stop himself from trying to grab her when she almost bumped into Artoo, who beeped a sharp warning. She jumped a little at the sound and Anakin could feel her embarrassment. ‚ÄúSorry.‚Äù

In the darkness, everything was fragile and broken and Anakin didn‚Äôt know what to do. He wanted to hold her, but for all that she was oozing with feelings, he thought she might break, shatter, if he tried to touch her right now.

So he just stood and watched, as much as he could in the dim light cast by the machines humming in the room. Swaying slightly as she worked by feel and took long moments to get a cup, to get water, to gulp it down.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù she said again as she moved back, but this time right past Anakin, placing the tips of her fingers on his arm for just a moment. Almost without thinking he grabbed them, gently, and gave a little squeeze.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine. I was only half asleep anyway.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you need the bed?‚Äù her voice was cut with shame and worry. ‚Äú I can‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine,‚Äù and if he ever learned to stop repeating himself around her, it would be fantastic, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs safer for me to be here. Between you and the door.‚Äù

In case they were discovered. In case anyone broke in. In case‚Äî

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù she finally managed. ‚ÄúI really‚ÄîThank you for being here. It helps.‚Äù

He could only see the rough outline of her face, but he felt the sincerity from her and nearly sighed with relief. ‚ÄúGood. That‚Äôs‚ÄîI‚Äôm glad. Glad I could help.‚Äù

She was still raw and throbbing when she said goodnight, and he thought it was a while before she fell back asleep. Anakin didn‚Äôt bother. He folded himself up on the couch, half meditating, half reaching for strength and reassurance and comfort. And hoping he was enough to finish this job.

He hadn‚Äôt expected it to be like this.

Plausible Deniability

Anakin had been up and working on Threepio for a couple of hours when Padm√© came out of her room. He was pretty sure she‚Äôd been awake for a while, but managed to not look like a complete idiot by saying something about it. She still hadn‚Äôt been expecting him to be awake by the look on her face when she spotted him, and there were an awkward few minutes as they negotiated breakfast and getting ready for the day.

Their day of sitting inside. Not being noticed.

‚ÄúIs there anything I can do to help?‚Äù Padm√© asked as she watched him prepare breakfast, such as it was.

‚ÄúNo, I‚Äôm just waiting for water to boil,‚Äù he told her as he opened and closed the few cupboards, hoping beyond hope there would be more things on the shelves than a couple of plates and cups. It was futile, but easier than just watching the water. ‚ÄúAny preference on tea?‚Äù

He‚Äôd picked out a spicy blend that reminded him of the tea his mother used to make him, but he hadn‚Äôt recognized the others and wasn‚Äôt sure what Padm√© would prefer.

She browsed through the choices, frowning, before tapping the one that he had picked. ‚ÄúThis one is fine.‚Äù

Fine. Not what she wanted, fine.

‚ÄúDo‚Ä¶ do we need to go out and find another?‚Äù

He was hesitant to suggest it because while they hadn‚Äôt been outright forbidden from leaving the apartment, they had been explicitly told to move as little as possible. And Anakin wasn‚Äôt sure if Padm√© would think it was safe to go if he suggested it.

She didn‚Äôt, and the look on her face said so, which was embarrassing and a relief. ‚ÄúThese are fine. I don‚Äôt think we should be risking getting caught over a cup of tea.‚Äù

In a desperate bid for a recover, Anakin tried for an arch look and said, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre right. It‚Äôs not like the tri-colored bloom magically planted on the third biggest asteroid on the fourth ring of the second moon orbiting‚Äî‚Äú

Padm√© actually smacked his arm, grinning. ‚ÄúObi-Wan is going to get me in so much trouble for reading you those.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh no,‚Äù Anakin promised. ‚ÄúHe wouldn‚Äôt dare. Then I might tell you about the stuff he‚Äôs read to me.‚Äù

The grin made her eyes crinkle and helped cover the tired lines around them. ‚ÄúYou like to have people read to you?‚Äù she asked, and Anakin was thrilled that she was interested. Interested in him.

‚ÄúI prefer stories out loud,‚Äù he admitted. ‚ÄúHow my mother used to tell them. And the aunts.‚Äù

And the grandmothers and the grandfathers. The other children telling stories to each other. The new mothers, who told sweet tales to their infants of the lights that were the stars, what their names were and who they represented. The men who talked of the day‚Äôs work not as if it had been mucking or cleaning or heaving things across storage rooms, but as if they‚Äôd carried the burdens of worlds and brought hope home with them. Stories of courage, of valor. And of everyday things.

Anakin remembered all of them.

‚ÄúDo you have any favorites?‚Äù

‚ÄúUhhh‚Ä¶‚Äù He had a lot. Well, at least a few. But she probably hadn‚Äôt heard any of them before, so if he just tried to tell her what they were called, which was really what they were about, she‚Äôd ask him to tell her the story next, and it wasn‚Äôt that he didn‚Äôt want to, but‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúAfter breakfast? Stories are‚Ä¶ they need your attention.‚Äù

Not all of them. Not all the time. But for his favorites, for her first ones, Anakin had to do it right. To tell them right, so she could see the pictures in her mind when he changed his voice and moved his hands and‚Äî

Maybe she wouldn‚Äôt like them. Wouldn‚Äôt think they were magical. What if he did them wrong? He hadn‚Äôt told stories to anyone since that first time to Obi-Wan, who had smiled but hadn‚Äôt gotten it, and maybe that was because Anakin hadn‚Äôt learned right, he should have asked his mom‚Äî

‚ÄúAnakin?‚Äù She was just brushing his sleeve, wanting his attention but trying to leave space, worried. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry. I didn‚Äôt mean to‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Anakin almost shouted, winced at his voice, took a breath. Two. He didn‚Äôt know why Obi-Wan told him to meditate, half the time it didn‚Äôt help anything‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúNo, I just. It‚Äôs been a while. Since I‚Äôve told anyone. I might‚Ä¶‚Äù he hated to say it, but she had to know. Just in case. ‚ÄúI might not get them quite right.‚Äù

She hadn‚Äôt let go of his sleeve, wasn‚Äôt coming any closer. She was just staring at him, and Anakin‚Äôs gaze dropped to her mouth. He was just about to lean in when she said, softly, ‚ÄúI wish Shmi were here.‚Äù

Mom.

Anakin took a deep breath, tried for a smile. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôd be nice. Although we‚Äôd need another bed. Or couch. Or‚Ä¶ something.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe,‚Äù Padm√© was trying to smile, but something was wobbling around her, ‚Äúwhen this is over, when it‚Äôs safer, she can come here. And tell stories to both of us.‚Äù

It was like a spark had just combusted into a fireball in Anakin‚Äôs chest. Hope (and pain and sorrow and regret) burned, swallowing his words and he knew he looked like an idiot, his mouth just working up and down, trying to come up with, ‚ÄúReally?‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs busy with the RRM, but she‚Äôs allowed to take a vacation,‚Äù Padm√© was rallying from whatever had worried her. ‚ÄúAnd if she knew you wanted it, she‚Äôd come right away, even if she was busy.‚Äù

She had confidence in that, Anakin realized. Padm√© believed his mom would come, even if she had other responsibilities, just because he wanted it. He could see her. He could hug her. She could come.

Mom was free. And she wanted to be with him.

‚ÄúNot right now,‚Äù he managed, trembling a little. It was real again, like that day that she‚Äôd been there, standing in the same room. She‚Äôd disappeared so quickly, hadn‚Äôt said anything, he‚Äôd thought it was almost a dream. But Padm√© had made it real again. Real and certain. ‚ÄúBut yeah, when it‚Äôs safe.‚Äù Now he could really smile. ‚ÄúMom tells the best stories.‚Äù

And there was that smile that he loved, where half of her mouth twitched up and she was all mischievous and‚Äî

The water hissed as it boiled over and Anakin yelped, trying to ignore Padm√© giggling behind him. ‚ÄúYou sure you don‚Äôt need help?‚Äù

Straightening, pulling his shoulders back, using every extra inch he had on her to try and protect his dignity, Anakin just said, ‚ÄúCan you get the cups? We‚Äôll start the tea first.‚Äù

Leia hadn‚Äôt heard anything from Anakin or Padm√©, which she was taking as a good sign. She knew it hadn‚Äôt been quite a standard day yet since they had left Obi-Wan and Captain Typho, duped and nervous, assuming a trip to Naboo. Shmi had gotten a message about eight hours later that their wayward baby Jedi and senator had at least been met and spirited off properly. And Leia‚Äôs packages for them had been delivered.

That had been her biggest worry. If anyone found out she had moved Threepio, they could have used that, either to track Padm√© or to plant another explosive. Leia‚Äôd had to trust that Shmi‚Äôs network and Artoo‚Äôs skills had covered that trail.

If she investigated it, to test its opacity, then it was just another trail left open.

Nursing a headache but avoiding rest, Leia read through Jar Jar‚Äôs update on how things were going in preparation for the vote and tried not to feel sick. His natural perspective was optimistic and he‚Äôd been sent to interact with people that were familiar with him. To spread reassurances that Padm√© was alright, that they were just being cautious. That soon the assassin would be caught, the Jedi were taking care of it.

Between the lines, Leia could read the corruption and fear. Those who liked Padm√© were worried the perpetrator hadn‚Äôt been caught yet, that more Jedi interference was needed. Those who disliked her (barely mentioned but present) were using the chance to gloat and to undermine the senator‚Äôs message of confidence in the Republic‚Äôs ability to negotiate to a peaceful solution. Those who were undecided were‚Ä¶ undecided. And seemed stuck that way.

‚ÄúNow that‚Äôs a face,‚Äù Sab√©, wasn‚Äôt supposed to be here, Leia thought. This was her house. ‚ÄúCare to share?‚Äù

‚ÄúJust reading Jar Jar‚Äôs report.‚Äù

Sab√©‚Äôs hum was followed by a, ‚ÄúDid I give you that?‚Äù

‚ÄúI received it from the senator,‚Äù Leia said, her eyes wide and unblinking. ‚ÄúWho is dutifully staying in her apartment, with her head of security, not making any fuss and passing along instructions only when she‚Äôs asked.‚Äù

Laughing, Sab√© took a seat on the couch. ‚ÄúI hope not. Then everyone will know‚Äî‚Äú Leia raised an eyebrow and Sab√© sighed at the paranoia but changed whatever she was saying to, ‚Äúshe‚Äôs not doing well.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre all doing the best we can,‚Äù was Leia‚Äôs immediate answer, tasteless as it rolled off her tongue. A lie (a half-truth) she‚Äôd told so many times, the polish was a veneer that made the sentiment shine in a way that almost seemed valuable.

‚ÄúSome of us better than others,‚Äù Sab√© shrugged. ‚ÄúCan I let Obi-Wan Kenobi contact you? He apparently had Captain Typho ask what you were up to, and if you were available.‚Äù

What? ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù

‚ÄúHe didn‚Äôt say,‚Äù Sab√© was trying to grin in a suggestive way, but it wasn‚Äôt working. She was too curious. ‚ÄúDid you offer to consult with him?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Leia said, shaking her head. ‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt spoken to him since the day after the banquet. And he has my statement from that. I can‚Äôt think what he‚Äôd need.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt object, I‚Äôll shuffle him along to you,‚Äù Sab√© was already standing and Leia missed the company, no matter how busy the handmaiden was. ‚ÄúThen we can solve this mystery and you can have a handsome Jedi cheer you up.‚Äù

Since there was nothing dignified to say to this (and the teasing hit on too many Cord√© memories), Leia just escorted her friend to the door, earning an inquisitive look from Shmi at the short visit.

Sab√© could have called. She probably just wanted an excuse to get out.

‚ÄúFly safe,‚Äù Leia said before the door closed and Sab√©‚Äôs wave was cut off from view.

‚ÄúShe didn‚Äôt want dinner?‚Äù Shmi asked.

‚ÄúJust needed to ask a question,‚Äù Leia dodged admitting she hadn‚Äôt asked. ‚ÄúI might need to take a call in a little bit.‚Äù

All that got was a nod and a dark look, possibly because Shmi had guessed Leia hadn‚Äôt asked Sab√© about dinner or possibly because Leia might be planning to cut out in the middle of dinner for work.

Shmi had feelings about interrupting mealtimes.

Unfortunately, Leia did get the call right in the middle of eating. Her rushed explanation of, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Kenobi,‚Äù only earned a confused look from Shmi before Leia moved up to her room to take the call.

She wasn‚Äôt sure how private he wanted this to be and she knew her room was clean. She‚Äôd checked it when she got home. ‚ÄúWell this is a surprise.‚Äù

‚ÄúI was under the impression I‚Äôd been given permission to call. Or was that a polite fabrication to foist the duty of unearthing my secrets onto you?‚Äù

‚ÄúSab√© stopped by,‚Äù Leia smiled, leaning against the wall as she settled on her bed. ‚ÄúShe said you might need something. I can‚Äôt think of what though.‚Äù

Obi-Wan hesitated for a moment, almost looking abashed. ‚ÄúI‚Ä¶ hadn‚Äôt realized you‚Äôd visited Dex.‚Äù

Now that was interesting. ‚ÄúWas I not supposed to?‚Äù Perfecting that tone, only the barest hint of taunting with mostly innocent inquiry had taken her most of her months working in the senate. The Imperial Senate. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot even a little bit,‚Äù he countered, folding his arms into his sleeves. Leia wondered if it was to hold his hands still. ‚ÄúNo, I meant to recommend it, I usually do. At least, if people ask for a halfway decent place to eat outside of the Temple. But I was‚Ä¶ surprised you‚Äôd gone.‚Äù

There was something else to that, but Leia wasn‚Äôt sure what, so she went with, ‚ÄúWhat, because I didn‚Äôt immediately start pumping him for your deepest, darkest secrets?‚Äù

‚ÄúI thought those were only for second meetings,‚Äù the Jedi was smiling now. Leia wondered if he was always this easily distracted.

‚ÄúI‚Äôd met you twice by then. But I did promise I wouldn‚Äôt ask other people if you offered your secrets first. I figured I should give you a chance to defend yourself.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs greatly appreciated.‚Äù The smile was slipping. ‚ÄúAre you‚Ä¶ and Shmi doing alright?‚Äù

Anakin‚Äôs mother. The arse. He wanted to know if Anakin and Padm√© were staying here. ‚ÄúAs well as can be expected,‚Äù Leia answered, stalling for the best comeback. ‚ÄúShmi‚Äôs been busier since Ruwee was injured, and keeping things together for Padm√© without Cord√© has been‚Äî‚Äú She couldn‚Äôt finish that thought. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre dealing with it. It‚Äôll take a few more days before we know if we‚Äôre doing it well.‚Äù

Yeah, he‚Äôd been trying to pump her for Padm√©‚Äôs location. And now he felt super guilty, if she wasn‚Äôt misreading that expression. Which she wasn‚Äôt. He‚Äôd better feel it. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sorry. I can only imagine‚Ä¶‚Äù At least he knew better than to keep going on that note. ‚ÄúI wish I could offer my services in some way, but unfortunately I‚Äôve been given a new assignment. I‚Äôm afraid I can only offer my condolences. And the hope that you avoid any more tragedy.‚Äù

It was gracious enough that she‚Äôd throw him a bone. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre hoping so too. I think, this time, we‚Äôll manage.‚Äù And then, because she too could be an arse, ‚ÄúIs your new assignment diplomatic? I know that‚Äôs your specialty. How‚Äôs your padawan taking it?‚Äù

The contortions of his face were pure gold. ‚ÄúI‚ÄîHe‚ÄîWell, when it comes to Anakin‚Äî‚Äú Something in her face must have changed. He stiffened, part offended, part caught out. ‚ÄúHis enthusiasm for this assignment does make one worry, but I suppose he must learn the‚Ä¶ intricacies and disappointments of politics at some point. If he is to be a good Jedi.‚Äù

And wasn‚Äôt that a landmine of potential implications. And she was still feeling petty and mean about him trying to use her, so, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure, in the hands of the right mentor, he could learn the pleasantries and payoffs of diplomacy as well.‚Äù

Obi-Wan looked almost as appalled at her words as Leia felt, beneath the almost sneering with which she said them. Obi-Wan‚Äôs little baby Jedi had better keep his hands off Padm√©, because as far as Leia was concerned there was no way, in this universe or any other‚Äî

The thing, the one she had been ignoring, waiting to deal with later, twisted inside her again.

‚ÄúGiven the seriousness of this mission,‚Äù Obi-Wan eventually said when he had recovered, ‚ÄúI simply hope that he does his best to complete his mandate. No matter the distractions.‚Äù

‚ÄúMe too,‚Äù Leia agreed, done with the teasing. She was too tired, and the twisting thing was too ugly in her mind, too distracting, to keep trying to outwit anyone. ‚ÄúIs there anything I can do for you?‚Äù

‚ÄúStay safe,‚Äù and Leia was surprised at how serious he sounded. ‚ÄúYou make a great many people nervous, young Skywalker. Try not to cause too much trouble before I get back.‚Äù

It was a good thing Obi-Wan hadn‚Äôt been in the room when he‚Äôd called her ‚Äúyoung Skywalker‚Äù because there was no way he would have missed the cacophony of emotions that poured off her in that moment. She was almost surprised he hadn‚Äôt felt them anyway. ‚ÄúSince when have I ever caused you trouble?‚Äù Leia demanded, knowing full well this was a lie.

The look on Obi-Wan‚Äôs face fit there so neatly, he had to have been making it for years. Which meant he‚Äôd probably used it a lot on a person Leia wished she would never be compared with. ‚ÄúI have every faith in your ability to make my life as troublesome or boring as you see fit. With or without my permission.‚Äù

She wondered from time to time if Obi-Wan was like this with everyone, was like this with Jedi, or was like this only around Leia. She got the feeling, sometimes, that when he spoke to her, he surprised himself. ‚ÄúJust don‚Äôt forget to keep your hair trimmed. Appearances are everything in diplomacy.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhich makes it a wonder that my padawan is so bad at it,‚Äù Obi-Wan chuckled. ‚ÄúWell, he‚Äôs had a few successes.‚Äù

And Leia did not want to know about that. ‚ÄúHopefully they didn‚Äôt give him a swelled head.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe next time you see him you‚Äôll have to decide for yourself.‚Äù And Leia gave him the benefit of the doubt and didn‚Äôt assume that was another fishing attempt. ‚ÄúMay the Force be with you, Leia Skywalker.‚Äù

‚ÄúMay the Force be with you, Obi-Wan Kenobi. Thank you for calling.‚Äù

He bowed and flickered out. Leia sat against the wall for another twenty minutes, wondering if she had really understood him, and why he had actually called before Shmi came up to remind Leia to finish her dinner.

Muddy Waters

Padm√© was right about one thing. There were a lot of interesting things that you could do from a bed. Leia was currently virtually stalking Senator Darsana via the open chat channel for the senatorial aides, a complex conversation of shorthand codes, inside jokes, and half-truths meant to deliberately confuse the enemy.

Because the enemy was doing the same thing on the same chat channel.

It was a recruiting forum as much as anything else, so you had to risk exposure in order to catch the prize.

In this case, it really wasn‚Äôt hard because the Neimoidians were obviously pursuing the senator (probably at least indirectly Leia‚Äôs fault) and were doing a terrible job of it because they thought the result of the vote was inevitable and it oozed off of their every word, not unlike the film that covered their skin.

In comparison, Senator Darsana was being painfully subtle and giving nothing away (through his aides). But the general atmosphere Leia was picking up on was ‚Äúnot good.‚Äù

She wanted to actively not think about the comments being made by Senator Organa and Senator Mothma‚Äôs offices. But her need to know would not allow her to avoid that well of information.

Apparently the codes hadn‚Äôt changed that much over two decades. Bottom line, we don‚Äôt know for sure we‚Äôre losing, but it‚Äôs going to be close.

And someone please stop Jar Jar Binks.

The problem, Leia thought as she rubbed her face and adjusted herself against her pillows, was that all Jar Jar wanted was to be helpful. And Padm√©‚Äôs idea of a baseline work ethic ran most people into the ground in less than a day, but not the gungan, so he‚Äôd kept the job partly on virtue of being able to keep up. But while he had the energy and the desire, Jar Jar did not have an ounce of the deviousness in him needed to manipulate the Senate.
