The obliviousness to resist its poison, yes. The tenacity to keep bouncing back after mistakes and fallout, certainly. The genuine goodness to baffle, confuse, and almost trick some people with its authenticity.

But not the duplicity. Not the conniving. Not the rage or the drive for power.

And when it came down to it, getting votes was a fight.

‚ÄúGo to sleep.‚Äù Shmi‚Äôs voice in Leia‚Äôs head was sleepy, but there was still an edge of affectionate sharpness to it. The voice of a mother, expecting to be heeded.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm worried about my friend,‚Äù Leia thought back, softly, trying for a lull. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll sleep soon.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you make me get out of this bed‚Ä¶‚Äù

Leia had no idea what Shmi would do as a follow-up to that threat. But she did not want to find out. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll sleep, I‚Äôll sleep.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood.‚Äù

The reality was she didn‚Äôt. Not for a while. Not looking at the screen didn‚Äôt stop her brain from spinning round and round, trying to find solutions to problems she was systems too far away to solve.

And when she finally forced them to be quiet, pushed them to dark and hidden places in her mind where they would wait for her to need them again, she found the thought that had twisted, had been waiting for her all day, wanting her to look at it. To see it, as it really was.

What if‚Ä¶ what if something did happen between Anakin Skywalker and Padm√© Amidala?

In the soft blanket of darkness, Leia thought she knew the truth.

‚ÄúShe really gave us plenty of spares,‚Äù Padm√© had taken a break from reading, her voice going hoarse, even with breaks for water. Anakin almost felt bad, but there was an aura of lazy contentment around her that hadn‚Äôt been there this morning, and he leaned into it, taking the joy of it and letting the feelings guide his fingers as he lovingly put his friend back together, piece by piece.

‚ÄúSpare whats?‚Äù Anakin asked, reaching for‚Ä¶ something. His fingers brushed it as he stayed focused on Threepio‚Äôs guts, laid out in front of him, placed it without really thinking. It looked right, felt right.

Padm√© was leaning over the crate next to him, touching his shoulder to keep her balance. ‚ÄúEverything, it looks like. That has to be, what, seven spare fingers on top of the number needed for replacement.‚Äù

‚ÄúOnly ten work,‚Äù Anakin replied without looking. ‚ÄúAnd they aren‚Äôt whole fingers. They need to be put together. Properly.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh, okay.‚Äù

Padm√© was withdrawing, her contentment becoming more focused, her hand pulling away. Anakin grabbed it without thinking, holding it to his shoulder. Her fingers twitched under his, but she stopped pulling away. She even leaned into the hand after a moment, watching him closely.

If she just leaned down a bit more‚Ä¶

‚ÄúAnakin?‚Äù

She was frowning, something was fluttering around her. Anakin let go, hunching back over his project, taking a deep breath. He couldn‚Äôt get distracted, he had to finish‚Äî

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs wrong?‚Äù Padm√© had sunk down next to him, was touching his arm again, wasn‚Äôt leaning into his space but had crowded close, and now‚ÄîNow when he looked over she was at eye level and he was‚Ä¶ completely distracted.

He‚Äôd let his fingers reach up and brush across her cheek when a sharp blat made them both jump. Artoo whistled a string of insults and profanities, demanding to know when Anakin would be finished doing stupid organic things so they could fix Threepio.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not‚Äî‚Äú Anakin almost protested, then realized Padm√© hadn‚Äôt understood, and he wasn‚Äôt going to give it away by responding. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm working as fast as I can.‚Äù

Artoo objected. Rudely. Anakin wished he could turn Threepio on so the protocol droid could teach Artoo some manners.

And Padm√© had moved back across the room, settled onto the couch, was messing with the datapad and saying something about reviewing her work notes.

Anakin shrugged and went back to work. The sooner he got this done‚Ä¶

The silence should have made for a perfect work environment, but after Padm√©‚Äôs reading, it felt oppressive. Not to mention the more that Padm√© read, the more frustrated she became and while Anakin would normally have shut that out, the reason he usually worked on projects alone was because when he got like this he couldn‚Äôt always keep things out, and when they reached him they were louder and more clear and‚Äî

‚ÄúWhy do you do it?‚Äù he asked suddenly, the frustration finding a voice through a random question he‚Äôd only ever partly wanted answered. ‚ÄúWhy do you even try?‚Äù

‚ÄúTry what?‚Äù Padm√© asked, only half listening.

Which was more irritating at this point. ‚ÄúArguing with these people. Reasoning with them. They‚Äôre not listening to you.‚Äù

There was a dangerous blankness from Padm√© before the anger came, hot and fast and sharp. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs my job,‚Äù was out of her mouth before Anakin could apologize and he flinched. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs how our government works.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut it doesn‚Äôt,‚Äù he was objecting before he had really thought about it. ‚ÄúPeople in the senate are corrupt, they‚Äôre controlled by the bureaucrats. They do evil things and they just get away with it. Arguing with them doesn‚Äôt stop them.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat doesn‚Äôt mean we shouldn‚Äôt try,‚Äù there was something in the way Padm√© said it that reminded Anakin of Obi-Wan quoting lessons over and over again. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs difficult to fight the corruption, but if we don‚Äôt give people an equal voice then we won‚Äôt have a democracy anymore. And the government would be even easier to corrupt.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot if you had the right person,‚Äù Anakin protested, ‚Äútelling everyone what to do. Someone wise and strong, who couldn‚Äôt be bullied by the business guilds and the bureaucrats. Who‚Äôll stand up to them.‚Äù

She was giving him the weirdest look, and her voice sounded almost faint as she asked, ‚ÄúLike who?‚Äù

Well, the Chancellor obviously had the guts to stand up to people. He said Anakin was, would be, the greatest Jedi he had ever known, and Anakin still always felt small in the Chancellor‚Äôs presence. If Anakin was‚Ä¶ humbled by being around the Chancellor, then he was a really great man. But Anakin was also humbled by being around Padm√© and thought she‚Äôd do a really great job if someone, like the Chancellor, was smart enough to put her in charge. So he just shrugged and said, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know. Somebody. Somebody wise.‚Äù

A beat and then, ‚ÄúMaster Yoda?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo!‚Äù Master Yoda was very wise, but, ‚ÄúJedi don‚Äôt deal with politics. They‚Äôre powerful, but they wouldn‚Äôt know how‚Äî Anyway, not Master Yoda. Besides,‚Äù he knew he shouldn‚Äôt smile so he cocked his head, ‚Äúhe‚Äôs pretty old and will probably be dead soon. So that wouldn‚Äôt work.‚Äù

‚ÄúIs he?‚Äù Padm√© sounded surprised and sad, which was weird. He didn‚Äôt think she knew the grandmaster that well. ‚ÄúI hadn‚Äôt heard.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe Chancellor says that Master Yoda has been at the head of the Order for over 700 years. No one knows how long he‚Äôll live for sure, but I guess he‚Äôs talked about stepping down for a while. Or something. And he looks much, much older than Master Yaddle.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you‚Ä¶ talk to the Chancellor often?‚Äù

Anakin couldn‚Äôt explain why he found that such a weird question. He‚Äôd thought that Padm√© and the Chancellor talked often. It was one of the reasons he was so worried he‚Äôd let slip how much he had thought about her. Sometimes‚Ä¶ sometimes it felt like the Chancellor just said things that other people might not want him to say. But Padm√© didn‚Äôt know that Anakin and the Chancellor had been talking, which was weird because surely it came up since she‚Äôd been made Senator of Naboo. The Chancellor was her mentor and‚Äî

And sometimes‚Ä¶ people outgrew their mentors.

Oh.

‚ÄúI‚Ä¶ don‚Äôt know?‚Äù Anakin said, bringing himself back to the question. ‚ÄúI guess so. I see him more now that I don‚Äôt need to be in the Temple or with Obi-Wan all the time. Every few months when we have missions. More, when we‚Äôre at home. He likes to talk to me.‚Äù

He didn‚Äôt mean for the last bit to come out so defensive, but the weirdness of Padm√©‚Äôs question was a haze that wouldn‚Äôt clear from the room. She shifted, like she felt it too. ‚ÄúDo you talk about politics a lot?‚Äù

‚ÄúI ask him if Obi-Wan can‚Äôt explain something. Or if he explains it and it doesn‚Äôt make sense. The Chancellor is an amazing politician. And a good man,‚Äù he felt compelled to add.

And that didn‚Äôt make the haze better, it made it worse. Padm√© opened her mouth a few times, but seemed to be at a loss for words. Eventually she said, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad he‚Äôs been kind to you. I thought‚Äî‚Äú

But she didn‚Äôt finish, just looked down at the datapad, scrolling a few times, frowning. When she looked back up and he was still watching she asked, ‚ÄúIs there anything I can do to help? With Threepio?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Anakin said, because Padm√© was keeping something from him and he was upset. And‚Ä¶ she‚Äôd lied to him. When she‚Äôd said she was glad, that was the wrong word. She didn‚Äôt mean it. And he wasn‚Äôt going to let a liar touch Threepio.

She didn‚Äôt deserve him. Maybe Anakin should say he couldn‚Äôt do it, should take Threepio back to the Temple and finish him and‚Äî

Mom. Threepio was meant for Mom. Who was on Naboo, who had lent Threepio to Padm√©. Because Padm√© needed him so she could do her job of arguing with people that weren‚Äôt listening to her.

He hated it. But Mom had promised, and Anakin had promised, and he could get Threepio finished by the end of today. Or tonight. Probably.

So he‚Äôd do it. Anakin wasn‚Äôt a liar.

When Padm√©‚Äôs only response was a tiny, ‚ÄúOh,‚Äù to stand, drop her datapad, and almost run to her room, Anakin‚Äôs anger fled with her. That wasn‚Äôt. He hadn‚Äôt meant‚Äî

Artoo called Anakin something belligerent and foul and Anakin just stared at the droid for a moment. ‚ÄúWhere did you learn that one?‚Äù

When Artoo‚Äôs claimed he‚Äôd found it in one of Anakin‚Äôs disgusting, inefficient biological orifices, Anakin threw up his hands. ‚ÄúYou keep talking like that, and I‚Äôm installing Threepio‚Äôs protocol processor in you.‚Äù

The angry response from Artoo, that if Anakin was going to hurt Padm√© with Threepio then Artoo would stop helping Anakin and run away, was jarring even if it wasn‚Äôt believable. His threat to run away to Leia and have her come and shoot Anakin was completely believable and terrifying.

‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt trying to hurt her,‚Äù Anakin protested, worried that he might have been too loud. That Padm√© might have heard him. Although, if she knew, maybe she would come back out.

‚ÄúStupid,‚Äù Artoo called him, along with, ‚ÄúIdiot,‚Äù and, ‚ÄúInsensitive, illogical Jedi.‚Äù

Somehow, even in binary, the Jedi part came across as the most offensive.

‚ÄúWhat would you know about being insensitive?‚Äù Anakin demanded, moving parts around to avoid looking at the droid. ‚ÄúYou were making fun of the lock‚Äôs on Hailee‚Äôs door.‚Äù

Artoo‚Äôs explanation that they were, in fact, bad locks, and not knowing that didn‚Äôt make them better, but just put Hailee in danger, did not improve Anakin‚Äôs mood.

He managed another twenty minutes of working, a cold (embarrassed) fury lurking in his gut, making a comfortable nest there, while he painstakingly examined his work. He knew all the parts and pieces in front of him, could name them, list their functions, identify what they were doing in their placement. Could almost see the next steps he had been so naturally taking before.

But the feelings, the good ones, were gone.

Truce

Sab√© and Vers√© were arguing over the merits of various coded messages to try and send Dorm√©, so that when Padm√© showed up at the vote it wouldn‚Äôt be too much of a surprise. The largest points of conflict apparently surrounded using old language (from her queen days), which Captain Typho wasn‚Äôt familiar with, verses a completely new made up on the spot code, which the good captain also would not recognize.

Hopefully. Since they would have to frame the code to let Dorm√© know that was what they were doing.

Leia sat and listened, half an ear on what they were saying and the other half trained towards the door, waiting for the warning of Captain Panaka‚Äôs tread.

Only he didn‚Äôt come. Today, he sent Rani, and Leia wasn‚Äôt sure if that was a good sign or not.

‚ÄúAre you here to scold us? Or to pump me for more information?‚Äù Leia asked as she opened the door just ahead of the guard.

Rani blinked in surprise, and Leia‚Äôs move gave Sab√© and Vers√© time to hide what they were working on and pull up the latest of Jar Jar‚Äôs reports (still bad). Rani said, ‚ÄúCaptain Panaka wants you to know he‚Äôs considering taking Shmi Skywalker into custody.‚Äù

‚ÄúAbsolutely not!‚Äù

Three voices lashed out at once, but Leia assumed hers was the reason that Rani actually stumbled back a step, eyes wide. She recovered quickly though. ‚ÄúHe says he wants to speak with you,‚Äù Rani told Leia. ‚ÄúAnd if she insists, Sab√© may come too.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh if I insist.‚Äù Sab√©‚Äôs tone was all silk, saving her poison for someone not just the messenger. ‚ÄúWhy, yes. Yes, I think I do.‚Äù

Leia had known it was going to be bad based on the message. That was a threat, aimed directly at her, and potentially threatening Sab√©‚Äôs position as well. It got worse though, when Leia realized they weren‚Äôt being led to the throne room, or to the queen‚Äôs office. They were headed to Panaka‚Äôs.

Which meant he didn‚Äôt want an audience. Or interference.

The Captain was standing in front of his desk when they arrived, reviewing something, or at least pretending to. His desk was clear enough and the room so orderly that Leia suspected a prop, rather than him catching up on something while he was waiting. If he‚Äôd summoned them now, he was ready for them, and wouldn‚Äôt want to be distracted.

‚ÄúI hope you have a very good reason for targeting one of the most important organizers in the RRM. Especially when she‚Äôs been covering for Ruwee while he‚Äôs still recovering.‚Äù

Sab√© at least waited until the door had slid shut before she started her assault. Leia wished she would have waited for Captain Panaka to speak first. Being on the attack so soon could come across as too defensive.

‚ÄúI needed to get you down here,‚Äù he said, leaning against his desk as he looked between the two of them. ‚ÄúWe need to be back on the same page, and I don‚Äôt like someone who isn‚Äôt even a member of our Security Force being the only person in the galaxy who knows where our senator is.‚Äù

Before Sab√© could answer, Leia put up a hand. All attention on her, she considered the best way to go about suggesting that she didn‚Äôt trust the security of this room. Without admitting it was because she suspected the Chancellor had had it bugged. ‚ÄúDoes this conversation have to happen right now?‚Äù

Not a good start, but she could tell from Sab√©‚Äôs narrowed eyes that Leia‚Äôs paranoia was getting through. Captain Panaka gave a short, ‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you want to discuss the exact details,‚Äù Sab√© said, stepping so she stood slightly in front of Leia, ‚Äúit would be easier to bring you up to speed with a visual. Follow me.‚Äù

She didn‚Äôt wait for his answer, just turned and swept back out of the room. Leia paused in the doorway to make sure that the captain was following rather than immediately marching with Sab√© through the halls.

They didn‚Äôt go to the gardens, which Leia was grateful for. Too easy for general staff to access, too likely they would be overheard. They also avoided most of the offices in the palace, the conference rooms, the private studies, the training rooms. Sab√© passed them all, leading their small party up and up, down long pillared halls and through open archways. She moved past formal balconies, up and beyond the gilded marble to stairs that were less grand and less beautiful. Past rooms that were smaller, spaces that looked more like closets than meeting spaces.¬† Their final ascent was up a ladder and through a hatch, up and onto one of the larger domed roofs.

The wind was sharper up here, the view breathtaking. Leia took a moment while Captain Panaka came up behind her to just enjoy it.

When he had closed the hatch, Sab√© said, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry for the sudden relocation. But if you want us to speak freely, this conversation needs to remain private.‚Äù

Her voice wasn‚Äôt loud. Captain Panaka had to lean in to catch her words. They ended up in a sort of huddle, blocking the worst of the wind together. ‚ÄúAnd there was something wrong with my office because?‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause we don‚Äôt know what your procedure is for checking it to make sure no one is listening in. And it‚Äôs clear, based on the attacks that have happened, that we have at least one leak in our security.‚Äù

Captain Panaka took a moment to grind his teeth at Sab√©‚Äôs words, but once the anger had passed, mostly his look was one of resignation. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not going to listen to me on this, are you?‚Äù

Something passed between the two of them then, Leia thought. A shift in their posture, a twitch of their eyes. A shared understanding of danger, and what could be done about it. ‚ÄúOnly if you‚Äôre willing to listen back,‚Äù Sab√© said. ‚ÄúYou fought us every step of the way during the invasion. We‚Äôve been working around you ever since.‚Äù

A truce, Leia thought as she watched the captain‚Äôs jaw twitch. Sab√© was offering something, seeing if Captain Panaka was willing to take it. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs my duty to protect the monarch, regardless of how inconvenient it is for her.‚Äù

‚ÄúPadm√© isn‚Äôt the queen,‚Äù Sab√© wasn‚Äôt harsh, but she was unyielding. ‚ÄúAnd Captain Typho does not have the same responsibilities you did. The role of senator is different.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs not less important just because she‚Äôs not queen anymore,‚Äù Captain Panaka said, but Leia could see him giving way.

She held her peace. This was a fight that didn‚Äôt actually have anything to do with her. Sab√© said, ‚ÄúNo, but her responsibilities are different, and the risks she has to take are too.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf she dies,‚Äù the captain said, ‚Äúand it‚Äôs even suggested that the Separatists did it, never mind if anyone proves it, it‚Äôll be all out war.‚Äù

Sab√© glanced to Leia, who took a turn to say, ‚ÄúIf she isn‚Äôt at the vote, it could be anyway.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs one senator‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs an icon,‚Äù Leia continued. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs a symbol and she‚Äôs a warning. Naboo is peaceful and prosperous. Isolated and not directly on a major hyperlane. It‚Äôs represented in the Senate, has produced politicians that are capable and wise. And if something happens to it, the larger body will take that as a sign of what‚Äôs to come. What could happen to anyone, if they don‚Äôt fall in line. Especially anyone not a Core world.‚Äù

He looked grumpy as he said, ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs still on Coruscant.‚Äù

Technically, not even Sab√© knew that for certain. It was supposed to stay contained. Leia asked, ‚ÄúIs the queen still having us keep the information on lockdown?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been instructed only to say that the plans were carried out. Successfully,‚Äù Captain Panaka was forcing the words through his teeth. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve sent two parties out from the palace, neither with any of Padm√©‚Äôs staff in them. Discretely but not unnoticed. One was sent to the gungans, the other to the lake country.‚Äù

To give the cover credence to anyone who might be watching. Bitter he may be, but the captain was good. ‚ÄúThis cannot, cannot, get back to Coruscant, for the next two days.‚Äù Leia stressed it not because she thought he didn‚Äôt know this was serious, but because this had to be agreed to or she would jump off this roof if she had to, to keep the secret safe.

‚ÄúI got that,‚Äù Captain Panaka said. ‚ÄúBut frankly, it isn‚Äôt that hard to guess since she isn‚Äôt here and the Advisory Council knows you rerouted her.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey aren‚Äôt all great liars,‚Äù Sab√© said, ‚Äúbut we gave them loose facts to repeat, not a story. Under the queen‚Äôs command.‚Äù

Yes, but anyone could have heard them. The throne room didn‚Äôt exactly have sound proofing. ‚ÄúWe can only mitigate, not eliminate risk,‚Äù Leia said. She looked at the Captain. ‚ÄúThreatening Shmi is a really big risk.‚Äù

He actually winced. ‚ÄúI should have come up with something better. I couldn‚Äôt. You don‚Äôt exactly have a lot of other leverage. And once it was you taking care of things, that made Shmi the next obvious choice for being involved.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know who she contacted,‚Äù Leia admitted. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt ask. I know there was at least a three-person chain to get each piece set up. To avoid leaving a direct trail.‚Äù And Leia hadn‚Äôt needed to tell Shmi about that. It was something built naturally into her system, her network.

A very small, giddy part of Leia hoped very much that her grandmother was exploiting her position in the refugee program expressly to free slaves. She wouldn‚Äôt ask, Shmi hadn‚Äôt invited that. But Leia loved the idea that her demure, humble grandmother was taking advantage of her position because she was not stupid.

Leia knew Luke would approve.

‚ÄúBut she is still on Coruscant?‚Äù he was at least persistent.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù Leia said. ‚ÄúSomewhere anonymous, and therefore safe.‚Äù

‚ÄúIn the lower levels,‚Äù the captain growled.

Leia‚Äôs brows went up. ‚ÄúYou have a better idea?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs dangerous there,‚Äù he grated out.

‚ÄúShe has a Jedi,‚Äù Leia flapped her hands, tossing his words into the breeze. ‚ÄúAnd Artoo. And herself. Pity the fool that does try and cross her, should they dare. But she shouldn‚Äôt have been noticed. The Jedi would have contacted us right away if they had been found. They‚Äôd want to know why we didn‚Äôt contact them when she didn‚Äôt show up.‚Äù

He accepted that with a pinched frown. ‚ÄúAnd Dorm√© knows?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Sab√© stepped back in, placing a hand on Leia‚Äôs shoulder, possibly for solidarity, possibly for balance. ‚ÄúNot yet. We‚Äôre working on getting her a message that won‚Äôt clue in anyone else.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis is a bad idea,‚Äù Captain Panaka rubbed his eyes, then looked bleakly across the landscape below. ‚ÄúIf they get desperate, they might try and shoot her in the senate.‚Äù

Unlikely, Leia thought. It seemed a bit clumsy, and very high risk for low chance of reward. But she just said, ‚ÄúDo you really want to have to face her for the next thirty years, having helped keep her from the vote?‚Äù

He looked positively green at that. Then sighed. ‚ÄúPut together a message, and I‚Äôll deliver it. It will look less like one of your codes if I‚Äôm the one passing it on.‚Äù

Not ideal, but a good place to start. Leia let Sab√© nod their agreement and was amused and surprised when the captain insisted on being the last back down the ladder, and lending each of them a hand for the first few rungs.

Somewhere around the middle of the night (after he couldn‚Äôt hear Padm√© crying anymore), Anakin had caught his stride again and fallen into an effortless workflow with Threepio.

The good news was that by morning, he had a droid frame that was standing, supported by its own two feet, even when inactive. Which was an improvement. Last time, Threepio had only been stable at this stage when turned on.

The bad news was that it had taken him all night to get there and it hadn‚Äôt been a refreshing ten hours, he‚Äôd just been working. So he knew, when Padm√© tried to sneak out of her room to use the refresher, that he hadn‚Äôt seen her not because she‚Äôd been too fast, but because he‚Äôd also been trying to hide his bloodshot, puffy eyes.

From Artoo‚Äôs perspective, breakfast was hilarious. Anakin didn‚Äôt face-plant into his food, but he did have to put extra focus into moving his limbs in coordination so that he didn‚Äôt dump any given bite on his lap. By the end of the meal, in spite of the awkward silence and not talking to each other, he was pretty sure Padm√© had noticed.

‚ÄúThreepio‚Äôs looking really good,‚Äù she said quietly, while they were doing the dishes. He wished she‚Äôd let him do them alone. It wasn‚Äôt a full kitchen, they were kind of squished into the same space. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs‚ÄîYou‚Äôre really amazing.‚Äù

The words sounded awkward, even though they also sounded honest. Anakin thought about that, and was going to say something when she said, ‚ÄúI think we‚Äôre done. I‚Äôll be working today, so I‚Äôll stay in the back so I don‚Äôt bother you.‚Äù

And then she was gone.

He‚Äôd caught her sleeve for half a second, but she didn‚Äôt slow down when she felt the tug and Anakin‚Äôs words died in his mouth.

He was really screwing this up.

The temptation to just stomp around the apartment and be angry was large, but his brain chose this moment to realize that Artoo hadn‚Äôt moved away from the door the entire time they‚Äôd been here. Sure, he‚Äôd rolled forward to help with Threepio. But he‚Äôd kept in a tight rectangle, always covering at least part of the doorway, so that anyone who tried to come in would fall over him first.

And Anakin realized he hadn‚Äôt been doing nearly as well himself.

This was about Padm√©‚Äôs safety. This was about proving, to Obi-Wan and the Council, that Anakin had what was needed to be a Jedi Knight. And this‚Ä¶ this was about helping Padm√© do her job.

Artoo had remembered that. He‚Äôd never lost sight of it. Not like the stupid, sleep deprived organic that was Anakin Skywalker.

Enough. He could do better. He would do better.

The room was way too small for him to practice lightsaber forms, especially with Artoo and a half assembled Threepio around. At least, not with the blade live. So he ran through his basics with just his hilt, letting the movements bring him focus and work off some of his energy.

He was still angry. He didn‚Äôt even know why, but he was. And he was also tired. Which maybe had something to do with being stupidly angry. So when he was done practicing, and checking their floor for the sense of any threat lurking around, Anakin made himself fold up on the floor (couch would have been too distracting) and meditate.

He‚Äôd told Obi-Wan he wanted to, might as well take advantage.

He didn‚Äôt end up doing it for very long.

Any time that he tried to find something to let go of or concentrate on, he‚Äôd be drawn to his half-completed project in the corner. After maybe thirty minutes, he accepted that whatever was going on in his head, Threepio was too important and nothing else (besides protecting Padm√©) was going to matter until he got this done.

And he needed the time if he was going to finish by tomorrow. Especially if he was going to manage the upgrades.

He only interrupted his work for a few minutes to make Padm√© lunch and hover awkwardly near her door, trying to decide the best thing to do. The simple knock and flee option would have worked better if she wouldn‚Äôt have been able to see him in the front room from her open door.

In the end, he accepted the awkwardness and waited for her to open up, holding out a bowl and a cup when she did and saying, ‚ÄúBrain food.‚Äù

She actually smiled, just a little, and he hadn‚Äôt even been trying to be funny. As she took them, she asked, ‚ÄúHow‚Äôs it going?‚Äù

‚ÄúNot‚Ä¶not bad.‚Äù And then, because some part of his brain was still working separately from the rest of him, ‚ÄúDo you think, later‚ÄîWould you have time? Artoo can‚Äôt reach much above his waist, and my hands are‚ÄîI was smaller at nine. Could you‚Ä¶ help? Me?‚Äù

‚ÄúAre you sure?‚Äù she asked, and he felt like she was asking something else and he had just missed it.

‚ÄúYeah?‚Äù

‚ÄúAlright. Let me finish a couple things and eat this and I‚Äôll be right out.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù he told the closing door.

It was several hours later, when he was trying to find a safe place for them to stop so he could get her dinner, when he finally broke down and said, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù

She didn‚Äôt smile at him, didn‚Äôt seem to be making hardly any expression at all, except maybe this hint of, ‚ÄúAre you?‚Äù in the set of her mouth and the way her eyes weren‚Äôt blinking. But all she said was, ‚ÄúThank you.‚Äù

He probably should have added something else, but in her silence he couldn‚Äôt.

She did move back out to the couch later, when she started working again, after he didn‚Äôt need her anymore. She fell asleep there, and Anakin dithered over what he should do for ages, until Artoo pointed out she was in Anakin‚Äôs ‚Äúbed,‚Äù and from there it was an easy choice to move her to the back.

She barely stirred while he tucked her in, and if he stayed there for a minute, just watching her, well, only Artoo would know.

Reinforcements

Four hours of sleep was less than optimal, but Anakin had wanted to finish at least half a dozen toys before they had to leave. He‚Äôd tried to use mostly only spare parts that couldn‚Äôt be easily repurposed, since Leia had sent a lot and apparently they would be collected by people who probably needed them once Anakin and Padm√© left.

But he had to do something for the kids. Adults thought about food, not fun. And that had always gotten him into trouble.

‚ÄúLet‚Äôs hope Padm√©‚Äôs already up,‚Äù Anakin whispered as he reached for Threepio‚Äôs switch. This should work, he‚Äôd done everything correctly. He just couldn‚Äôt test a chatty, excitable droid when Padm√© was supposed to be asleep.

Artoo seemed confident. They hadn‚Äôt had to replace any of the memory units, and the damage there had looked superficial.

Only one way to find out.

He flipped the switch.

Threepio‚Äôs eyes flashed two or three times, there was a lurch and a catch in his voice as he tried to speak, but eventually there came a clear, ‚ÄúSenator Amidala! Is she safe?‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs fine,‚Äù Anakin said, smiling in relief. ‚ÄúHow are you feeling?‚Äù

‚ÄúHow am I feeling?‚Äù Threepio parroted, confused. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm quite fine, I assure you. I was just walking off the ship when‚Äî‚Äú He stopped, and Anakin couldn‚Äôt be sure if it was because of a memory blank, shock, or that Threepio had moved his arm and spotted that it was completely exposed. ‚ÄúAm I‚Ä¶ naked?‚Äù

His tone was appalled and shocked and Artoo beeped irreverent giggles. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been repairing you,‚Äù Anakin said, before the droids could get into it. ‚ÄúWe haven‚Äôt gotten you replacement coverings yet.‚Äù

‚ÄúRepairing me?‚Äù Threepio looked at himself, despairing. ‚ÄúWhy, I must have been blow up! How horrid!‚Äù

‚ÄúThreepio?‚Äù if Padm√© hadn‚Äôt been awake before, she was now. She was wrapping a loose robe around her nightgown and as she did Anakin spotted a familiar flash of white on a cord.

She‚Äôd kept the japor snippet.

‚ÄúOh Senator, I‚Äôm so glad to see you‚Äôre alright. It seems I was in an accident. Did I cause you too much trouble? I was supposed to give all those messages‚Äî‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs alright, Threepio,‚Äù Padm√© soothed, smiling with delight. ‚ÄúWe had to change all our plans. I‚Äôm glad to see that you‚Äôre okay.‚Äù She almost reached out to touch him, but stopped before she brushed against his wiring. ‚ÄúAni, he‚Äôs perfect.‚Äù

‚ÄúPerfect?‚Äù Threepio repeated, before Anakin could drag himself away from the memory of Padm√© saying that before to thank her. And then, ‚ÄúAni? Do you mean‚ÄîAre you, Master Anakin?‚Äù

‚ÄúHi Threepio,‚Äù Anakin couldn‚Äôt help but smile. Threepio was meant to help Anakin‚Äôs mother, but was Anakin‚Äôs friend. Time, and a disgusting explosion, hadn‚Äôt changed that. ‚ÄúHow are you feeling?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou know, it‚Äôs rather odd,‚Äù Threepio answered, looking down at himself. His range of movement had increased just a touch, but some of that would go away again when he was properly covered. ‚ÄúI feel almost like myself, just a little off, and yet even more of what I‚Äôm supposed to be. I wonder, does that make any sense?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve been upgraded,‚Äù Anakin said, gesturing to the crates behind him. ‚ÄúI got some better parts for you this time, and had a better idea of how to put you together. Do you like it?‚Äù

‚ÄúI think so,‚Äù Threepio answered, ‚Äúbut I can tell you I‚Äôd feel much better if I were less exposed. I don‚Äôt suppose you‚Äôll be able to finish me this time?‚Äù

It wasn‚Äôt an accusation. Threepio‚Äôs tone was very clear when he was doing accusations. Or sarcasm. He didn‚Äôt do subtlety, unless it was deeply, deeply ingrained in a culture. But the punch of the words, the weight of the memories they represented, struck deep. ‚ÄúI‚ÄîWe‚Äôre‚Äî‚Äú

He looked hopelessly at Padm√©, wanting to say yes. But there wasn‚Äôt anything in the crates. And they were heading back to the Senate today and‚Äî

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll see what we can do,‚Äù she said, reaching for Anakin, looping her arm through his. ‚ÄúFor now, I think we need to bring you up to speed. We‚Äôre going to be really busy today.‚Äù

The way she was twisting her hair was a distraction, but not enough to calm Anakin down. He could stop his leg bouncing for a few seconds each time she looked directly at him, up from the datapad, but the moment he lost her focus he was moving again.

They were dressed, they were packed, he‚Äôd left the toys he‚Äôd finished in one of the crates, nestled so they wouldn‚Äôt get broken. All they needed now was to meet their ride at the designated time.

‚ÄúDo you think we‚Äôll make it on time?‚Äù Padm√© asked, again, even though the last three times she hadn‚Äôt liked or believed Anakin‚Äôs answers.

His halfhearted, ‚ÄúSure, probably,‚Äù earned a glare from her, and he hunched a bit more, knowing the poncho didn‚Äôt work as well as his cloak for hiding himself with the movement. ‚ÄúEverything else Leia‚Äôs done has worked out just fine. Why wouldn‚Äôt she plan for this?‚Äù

Which was apparently, finally, the right thing to say because Padm√© actually relaxed. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre right. She wouldn‚Äôt let me down.‚Äù

Of course Leia wouldn‚Äôt let Padm√© down. Never mind that she wasn‚Äôt the one who had been here for the past two days, making instant food slightly more edible, fixing Threepio who Padm√© needed to do her job, while also being Padm√©‚Äôs bodyguard. No, Leia was the one who hadn‚Äôt let Padm√© down.

‚ÄúYou ready?‚Äù he asked, because it was the nicest thing he could think of to say. The inside of his head was buzzing and he just wanted to get out.

‚ÄúWe probably shouldn‚Äôt leave too early,‚Äù she murmured, and apparently she‚Äôd noticed that he was in a mood, which‚Äîokay, he hadn‚Äôt actually meant to make her feel bad. Great.

The next twenty minutes were excruciatingly painful. The only good thing about them was that Padm√© didn‚Äôt speak binary, so she couldn‚Äôt hear Artoo mocking Anakin the whole time, calling him an almost impressive number of variations of ‚Äústupid organic.‚Äù Or, even worse, ‚Äústupid baby organic.‚Äù

Anakin was not a child.

He‚Äôd kept Threepio from translating for Artoo the whole time. No kid would have been able to do that.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not really comfortable,‚Äù Threepio said instead, ‚Äúwandering about like this. I wasn‚Äôt allowed outside very often, you know, until I had been properly covered. The race was a special occasion of course, but‚Äî‚Äú

The scorching of two suns, the whipping tears of sand flying across his face, the panic as his power coupling had coughed black smoke, the surge as Sebulba had rolled, rolled to an explosive defeat while he, Anakin, had flown across the finish lines, straight into the arms of victory. To his mother, to Padm√©, to‚Äî

To Qui-Gon. Who had died only a few days later, after seeing Anakin set free. After seeing Anakin into the care of the Jedi, of Obi-Wan.

Things‚Ä¶ boiled just underneath Anakin‚Äôs skin, things he couldn‚Äôt find the words to explain. So close to the surface now. He had a job to do, he knew that. But the twisting and the wrenching inside of him boiled all other thoughts away until just one was left.

Why?

Why hadn‚Äôt the Jedi saved his mother? Why was someone targeting Padm√©? Why did everything seem to revolve around Leia, she wasn‚Äôt the Chosen One, this wasn‚Äôt her destiny‚Äî

‚ÄúAnakin?‚Äù Padm√© was very carefully still, Artoo was silent, even Threepio‚Ä¶

‚ÄúMaster Ani, did you mean to move the table like that?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt a table,‚Äù Anakin wanted to say. And also, ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt move it.‚Äù

But while he might be able to defend his skepticism of whether or not the narrow slab by the couch constituted a piece of furniture, he had moved it.

And he hadn‚Äôt meant to do that.

‚ÄúI think we should go,‚Äù he said instead, standing and moving towards the door, reaching out with the Force. ‚ÄúNo one‚Äôs out there, now‚Äôs as good a time as any.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou sense something?‚Äù Padm√© asked, and it took everything Anakin had not to lie to her. To Padm√©. He wanted to lie to Padm√© so that he didn‚Äôt have to explain his thinking or what he could feel.

But he swallowed the lies and said, ‚ÄúWe‚ÄîI need to move. We‚Äôll be careful. It‚Äôs almost time.‚Äù

As it turned out, leaving a couple minutes early was fine. Threepio took his sweet time shuffling down the corridor, testing his new vocal capacity to whisper aspersions about the lack of cleanliness, the inferior architecture, and the flickering lights while not earning the attention of their invisible neighbors.

Anakin was really grateful he‚Äôd made that upgrade.

By the time they made it out and around to the back of the building, they only had to wait for one minute before their ride showed up.

‚ÄúThey said three of you,‚Äù the man in the front grumbled, but he helped load Artoo into the back and offered Threepio a hand when the droid had trouble with the narrowness of the seats.

He also offered a hand to Padm√© to help her into the front, but Anakin suspected that was less a courtesy and more an excuse to touch her. Which Anakin understood, even if he disliked it. Since Padm√© didn‚Äôt seem to think much of it one way or another, Anakin assumed people did things like that for her all the time. Which also made sense. He just needed to make sure more of those opportunities were his.

It was cramped in the back of the speeder, even with Threepio pinned against Artoo to leave Anakin as much room as possible to react in case they were spotted and attacked on their way in. Which they weren‚Äôt, fortunately.

It wasn‚Äôt a surprise. Their driver actually took them down two more levels instead of up, wending his way in a thick darkness, broken only by neon holodisplays of strange advertisements. These ones weren‚Äôt like the ones in the pleasure districts though. They were shoddier, the services offered much more practical.

Up until the last twenty minutes right under and around the Senate. Then it got seedy and exotic again. Which would have confused Anakin more if he hadn‚Äôt heard some of the choice things Padm√©‚Äôd had to say about her coworkers this morning.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll let you off here,‚Äù their driver said after he‚Äôd already pulled over. Anakin wasn‚Äôt intimately¬†familiar with the underside of the Senate District, but he could feel that they were closer to the Temple, and guessed they were very close to the Senate itself, if quite a bit lower than he would have guessed they could manage.

‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù Padm√© told the man, and he smiled for her in a way he never would have for Anakin. Which made Anakin very glad when the man left. Even if he wasn‚Äôt sure where they were going.

‚ÄúNow what?‚Äù Threepio asked, looking around nervously. The traffic here was light for Coruscant, but there were still plenty of people giving them looks. And while they didn‚Äôt stand out for being dressed too nicely, their particular brand of poverty didn‚Äôt quite match the heavy labor look of the people passing by.

If they stayed too long‚Äî

‚ÄúYou seem a bit lost.‚Äù

Anakin tried to move between the speaker and Padm√©, but she‚Äôd already thrown herself forward, at this new stranger. Who wasn‚Äôt a stranger, Anakin realized as he got a better look. He hadn‚Äôt seen her as much as Dorm√©, he thought, but maybe she had shown up with Jar Jar? That had to be it, otherwise Padm√© wouldn‚Äôt be clinging to her so tightly.

‚ÄúWhat happened?‚Äù Padm√©‚Äôs friend asked, glancing at Anakin and frowning. Which was rude. He‚Äôd gotten her here safely, hadn‚Äôt he? ‚ÄúWe got a coded message and then I got contacted by one of Shmi‚Äôs refugees‚Ä¶‚Äù

His mom. Anakin‚Äôs mom had been helping, arranging this. Every time he thought about it, Anakin was proud and horrified. This was so dangerous. And it was so important, and the person they‚Äôd trusted was Shmi Skywalker. Who hadn‚Äôt even been a year off of Tatooine.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll explain inside,‚Äù Padm√© said. ‚ÄúPlease, I need to get ready.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course.‚Äù

The friend, Eirta√© as Anakin was reminded, led them inside a facility where uniforms were being washed and pressed. They dodged around busy droids, nearly losing Threepio twice as he got distracted, and eventually made their way up a series of service lifts to surroundings that were less and less dingy and metallic and more polished.

His nerves increased with each floor and Anakin wasn‚Äôt sure if it was because he was worried, because suddenly a possible threat felt real again, or if it was in response to Padm√©‚Äôs growing nerves. She was mostly still, but her fingers kept flexing, tightening in ways that looked painful and then stretching out again. The fourth, or maybe fifth, time she did that, he reached out and took her hand, trying to rub soothing circles across the back.

He wasn‚Äôt sure if it worked, he was too busy ignoring Eirta√©‚Äôs stares. But at least Padm√©‚Äôs fingers stopped flexing.

They had exited one lift and were making their way towards another when Threepio suddenly stopped, whimpering, ‚ÄúOh no, I couldn‚Äôt possibly!‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs wrong?‚Äù Padm√© asked, and it was clear to Anakin that her patience gone. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve been here before.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course I have, but not looking like this!‚Äù Threepio might knock himself over if he kept swinging his arms around like that. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs an entrance to the Senate! I know what those locks are. I can‚Äôt be seen in those halls while I‚Äôm naked. I represent the Naboo delegation! The RRM! Mistress Leia! She has messages for some of these people, and I‚Äôm honor bound to pass them along. What a diplomatic nightmare it would be if I did it like this. Do you have any idea how badly they could be offended?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not the main body of the Senate,‚Äù Eirta√© stepped in, plenty of patience to soothe. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll be going through some back halls to a preparation room. Private areas. Low traffic, no dignitaries‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll be there,‚Äù Threepio objected. ‚ÄúAnd if it‚Äôs a preparation area‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúPlease, Threepio,‚Äù Padm√© was jittering again. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt leave you out here. Leia would kill me.‚Äù Which was stupid. Anakin wouldn‚Äôt let her do that. ‚ÄúAnd I need you in there. We all do.‚Äù

‚ÄúHere,‚Äù Anakin said, shrugging out of his poncho. ‚ÄúUse this for now. That way even if the worst happens, it won‚Äôt be as embarrassing.

‚ÄúBut those are clothes,‚Äù Threepio whined. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a droid, I don‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú

Artoo chose this moment to blat out a very carefully constructed sentence on Threepio‚Äôs rudeness in refusing Anakin‚Äôs gift, delaying the Senator, and acting like a moron. This didn‚Äôt seem to be working until he made Threepio angry enough to chase him, and which point they made it into the building, up the lift, and halfway down the hall before Threepio realized he‚Äôd crossed that sacred threshold. By then, he‚Äôd already defaced the integrity of the building, and it was a minor effort to corral him further down the hall, up another lift, and around the corner to a small set of rooms, where he immediately became more comfortable.

‚ÄúI suppose I can stay here until nightfall, when the building is empty,‚Äù Threepio explained to Anakin, who was the only one left to talk to now that Padm√© had been spirited away to wash up. ‚ÄúThen there won‚Äôt be any chance of me being seen.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think‚Äî‚Äú Anakin began, but Eirta√© appeared suddenly, smiling and saying, ‚ÄúThreepio, I think Leia has a gift for you.‚Äù

‚ÄúFor me?‚Äù Threepio asked, shuffling over. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs so kind of her. Do you know what it is?‚Äù

Anakin got a conspiratorial look from Padm√©‚Äôs friend as she gestured them both towards the back of the room. ‚ÄúNot for sure, but based on the casing‚Ä¶‚Äù

It was from a droid parts manufacturer, a higher end one if Anakin had to guess. All gold and bronze lines on the case, which definitely looked pretty but probably wouldn‚Äôt survive being shipped off planet. But it was pretty flat, which might mean‚Ä¶

Threepio invited Anakin to help him with the latches and the lifting and Anakin nearly dropped the lid when he saw what was inside.

Gold plating. She‚Äôd‚ÄîLeia‚Äôd gotten gold colored coverings for Threepio.

Not solid gold, which would have been awful (Anakin had seen some pretty stupid things Core-worlders insisted on doing to some of their droids), but something that had a pristine golden shine with a much higher durability than Anakin would have guessed, especially for a protocol droid.

This was custom. This was a gift. This was protection for a treasured friend.

In all his thinking about fixing Threepio and how much it would mean to his mom, or to Padm√©, Anakin hadn‚Äôt really given a lot of thought to how Leia had gone out of her way to save a droid. Threepio was his droid, his friend, Anakin loved him. It just made sense in a world where Threepio was broken to make every effort to fix him.

What was it the note had said? ‚ÄúHe needs help.‚Äù

Not Padm√©, not Leia, not Shmi. Threepio. For all the other practicalities of the situation, Leia had made sure the most capable person was able to help Threepio.

And as Anakin fitted the new coverings over the droid, listening to Threepio‚Äôs delighted preening and almost violent relief, that realization firmed. Beautiful for the setting Threepio was in. Functional for environments where he might be in danger. Gold rather than a more traditional silver, because Threepio was himself.

Leia loved Threepio, Anakin thought. And it made him a lot more inclined to like her.

She‚Äôd also provided supplies to clean Artoo, which Anakin was very grateful for, almost as much as Artoo was.

‚ÄúOh!‚Äù Apparently Eirta√© hadn‚Äôt told Padm√© about the coverings because she looked completely shocked when she stepped out a while later, staring at their friend. ‚ÄúWhere did you find these? They‚Äôre perfect.‚Äù

‚ÄúLeia,‚Äù was Eirta√©‚Äôs easy reply, and Padm√© shook her head.

‚ÄúOf course. I should have known.‚Äù

Anakin took a brief turn in the back, cleaning up some more and getting into his Jedi attire. It was a little odd after the last few days, to have the loose fabric of his robes hanging around his hands, swishing with his every step. But at least he looked presentable. He would be with Padm√© in the Senate dome. He couldn‚Äôt disappoint her.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm ready,‚Äù he said as he came back out, and Padm√© seemed as uncomfortable as he felt, seeing him dressed like this again. ‚ÄúAre you?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre meeting Dorm√© and Captain Typho upstairs, in the conference room directly across from our pod,‚Äù Eirta√© told him. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll have about fifteen minutes for the Captain to yell at us before we‚Äôll need to be seated. That should give us at least two minutes to tell you where to stand so that you‚Äôll be within reach for safety reasons, but out of the way for visual political purposes.‚Äù

Which seemed stupid to Anakin, but Threepio was already making suggestions about what Anakin should do with his hands and the angle of his head so that it would be appealing to the people Padm√© wanted to impress, and okay, maybe this really was a big deal. He‚Äôd do his best to contribute.

He was only half listening to Padm√© and Eirta√© going over Padm√©‚Äôs speech as they walked along. He hadn‚Äôt realized exactly how intense the discussion on forming a military had gotten, and he felt a little silly about that.

‚ÄúMaster Anakin, we must stop,‚Äù Threepio said suddenly, pointing with his body (it must have been rude in this case to use his hands) at a group they had almost passed. ‚ÄúI have to see Senator Darsana.‚Äù

‚ÄúPadm√©,‚Äù Anakin half called, remembering belatedly that they were in the Senate Building now, and really he should be more formal. When she looked at him, he just nodded at Threepio while his eyes moved to the anselmi leaning casually against the wall. Padm√© frowned, but nodded to Threepio, who made his way over to the group and stood at a respectful distance until he had been acknowledged.

‚ÄúSenator Darsana,‚Äù Threepio executed a bow that left even Anakin impressed, his arms and fingers moving in specific patterns as he did. ‚ÄúMy most sincere apologies. I have a message I was to deliver to you, and it seems to have been irreparably damaged. May I be permitted to at least convey the sentiments of the sender?‚Äù

‚ÄúI presume,‚Äù the anselmi grinned with a multitude of teeth and Anakin wasn‚Äôt sure what to make of that expression, ‚Äúthat the missing message was taken in the storm that has so violently disrupted our dear Senator Amidala.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt was,‚Äù Threepio agreed, still half bowed, his arm now moving across his chest and Anakin couldn‚Äôt quite see if he did anything else with his hands. ‚ÄúBut a fair tide carried us to shore, and we have been granted another chance.‚Äù

There were several seconds of deliberate silence which probably would have made an organic sweat. Threepio, true to his programming, had no problem waiting for his turn, half bowed or otherwise. Eventually Senator Darsana said, ‚ÄúYou may convey the sentiments.‚Äù

What followed was a musical lilt of language accompanied by gestures made close to Threepio‚Äôs body, with a series of hand twitches that were an utter mystery. Padm√© seemed vitally interested in the movements and was making no effort to continue down the hall, in spite of the fact that they were now drawing a crowd.

When Threepio reached the end of his sentiments, Senator Darsana executed his own bow, and said, ‚ÄúIf you remember any of the message that was to be delivered, I would be happy to receive it in private.‚Äù Padm√© granted her permission, bowing in a formal if less ornate way to the anselmi, who did not seem adequately impressed for having just been blessed by Padm√©‚Äôs focused attention.

But then, he was part fish.

The rest of them made it to the conference room, and Captain Typho did yell, but only for ten minutes because they‚Äôd taken so much time with Threepio in the hall. And speaking of Threepio, the protocol droid joined them just before they left for the pod, cheerfully announcing that he had given Leia‚Äôs message and that Senator Darsana had been very grateful to receive it.

That cheered Padm√© up, which meant Anakin was able to smile cheekily when they entered the pod and his attention was immediately drawn to Master Yoda and Master Windu, who were not happy to see him.

He hadn‚Äôt been given permission, so he didn‚Äôt wave. But it was a near thing.

It wasn‚Äôt until he saw the Chancellor‚Äôs horrified face that Anakin wondered if he hadn‚Äôt done the right thing.

Crescendo

Chancellor Sheev Palpatine was a seasoned politician who had seen the rise and fall of many parties and ambitions and frequently joked that if there was anything left that could surprise him, he didn‚Äôt want to see it. The day to day of his life was bad enough.

Anakin had never completely understood why that was so funny, but he‚Äôd always laughed when the Chancellor said it to him, because Anakin wasn‚Äôt stupid and he wouldn‚Äôt make the Chancellor look stupid by looking like an Outer Rim castoff when he was specially invited to the Chancellor‚Äôs office. And anyway, Anakin had understood enough to know that the Chancellor only expected bad surprises in his job.

So when Anakin saw, for just a brief moment, the look of horror on the Chancellor‚Äôs face, it made Anakin‚Äôs stomach twist in an unpleasant way. Did the Chancellor know something they didn‚Äôt? Was Padm√© in danger just by being here? Was there someone in this room waiting to kill her?

Anakin reached out first, and quickly encountered the irritated and even punishing presences of Master Yoda and Master Windu in the upper levels. Who were probably the most dangerous people in the room right now and were definitely considering killing Anakin, not the senator.

Not great, but not terrible.

Next he used his eyes and ears, focusing them with the Force when he realized there were too many people and the room was too large to catch everything the old fashioned way. Maybe the masters weren‚Äôt happy that Anakin and Padm√© were here, but when Padm√© had been given a choice to stay, wasn‚Äôt Anakin‚Äôs first job to protect her? And hadn‚Äôt he done that?

What a lovely dream, Master Windu seeing reason and being pleased with Anakin.

What a joke.

‚ÄúAre you in trouble?‚Äù Padm√© had spotted the Jedi and Anakin made himself look at them again, to see Master Windu‚Äôs violent disapproval and Master Yoda‚Äôs more insidious disquieted look.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he told her, and quickly amended that to, ‚Äúnot yet.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think you‚Äôre the only one.‚Äù Her gaze had drifted back to the Chancellor, but darted around to catch a concerned looking human woman with short red hair, a rodian shaking his head (maybe smiling, it was always hard to tell with rodians), and slowing slightly as it drifted over a human male Anakin thought was the guy from Alderaan Obi-Wan had once introduced him to. It had been a while ago, probably a whole year.

But her attention came back to the Chancellor and Anakin didn‚Äôt know what to make of that face. It wasn‚Äôt the look that had scared Anakin earlier, but it wasn‚Äôt a great improvement either. It was a stern look, unyielding, and Anakin remembered Padm√©‚Äôs comments about mentors. He couldn‚Äôt take her hand out here, so he opted for the ruder (but more politically correct?) offering of his calm and confidence in the Force. He knew it wouldn‚Äôt reach her like it would Obi-Wan, that it wouldn‚Äôt open up a line between them if she accepted it. But her shoulders came back and her chin came up and she looked so fierce and proud it took his breath away.

She could do this. She would do this.

Shmi didn‚Äôt object when Leia brought Sab√© and Vers√© home for dinner (and Leia may have redeemed herself for the last time when she didn‚Äôt ask Sab√© to join them), and also didn‚Äôt object when they pulled up the Senate proceedings. Leia even caught her grandmother smiling as Shmi noticed Anakin standing behind Padm√© in her pod.

Leia had to cover her mouth when the camera focused back on the Chancellor. She hadn‚Äôt gotten to see his face like that very often, maybe ever. But she knew what it meant.

‚ÄúYou outmaneuvered him,‚Äù Luke‚Äôs voice was gleeful in her head. ‚ÄúHe didn‚Äôt see this coming and wasn‚Äôt ready for it.‚Äù

‚ÄúI hope he wasn‚Äôt, but he‚Äôs had plenty of time for contingencies,‚Äù Leia reminded her brother. It was nice to think they‚Äôd outplayed Palpatine and won a solid victory. And maybe they had. But it was early days yet. The Clone Wars had been a massive undertaking on the part of the Emperor, and it was built to be a no-win scenario. For everyone except the Sith Lord. They might have damaged his plans, they might have discomforted him. But they weren‚Äôt winning.

Yet.

Luke seemed to catch the tenor of her thoughts and his presence pushed more forcefully against her mind. When she opened up to him he showed her a memory, the briefest moment, but one she could immediately identify by the feelings that came with it. Luke throwing down his saber, refusing to kill their father.

That face‚Ä¶ was a lot like the one the Chancellor was making now.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think he liked our mom,‚Äù Luke mused, and Leia tried not to choke on her bite.

‚ÄúWe are not talking about that right now.‚Äù

The impression of a shrug. ‚ÄúAlright.‚Äù

But he wasn‚Äôt going to let it go, not now that he knew Leia had admitted the possibility to herself, that Padm√©... And Leia still hadn‚Äôt been able to pin him down on if he had guessed weeks ago, or if he‚Äôd figured it out just a little before her. Or not before her at all. Which meant it was a topic she was going to have to revisit if she didn‚Äôt want him silently making fun of her for years.

‚ÄúWho are the people in the central pod?‚Äù Shmi was asking Sab√© when Leia‚Äôs focus came back. ‚ÄúWhat are they doing?‚Äù

Leia listened halfway to Sab√©‚Äôs breakdown of the Chancellor and his cronies, listing the rules for floor debates (that no one followed) and what the consequences would be for people who broke them (nothing, because enforcement was a pain in the ass).

‚ÄúFear of reprisal is what keeps most people from interrupting in the middle of speeches,‚Äù Leia added when Sab√© was finished. ‚ÄúTechnically during a scheduled debate, as opposed to informative assemblies or celebrations or other nonsense, anyone can interject at any point where they feel false information is being given. But most wait until a lull or after the speaker has closed. You don‚Äôt want to interrupt an ithorian. They make you pay for it.‚Äù

Shmi smiled, but it was only for a moment before she turned back to the debate. ‚ÄúThey are alternating?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe Chancellor and the Vice Chair are usually enough up to date on allegiances to keep that pattern going,‚Äù Sab√© said between bites. ‚ÄúBad ones will moderate so that the party they align with goes last. Really bad ones have their people go first. Morally and ethically bankrupt geniuses have theirs go first and last with the opposition sandwiched in the middle.‚Äù

‚ÄúChancellor Palpatine is a good moderator then?‚Äù Shmi asked.

Sab√© shook her head. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs fine. I don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs him getting lost in his own friendships and forgetting where others‚Äô alliances are, but this will get pretty muddled before it gets to the end.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhen will Padm√© speak?‚Äù

‚ÄúIf they can manage it, last,‚Äù Leia said. ‚ÄúIf not, close to the end.‚Äù

Although it wouldn‚Äôt be a surprise if Palpatine tried to stop her from speaking at all. Or maybe not. Taking a public action against her was much more risky than third party assassins.

‚ÄúShe wants to stand out,‚Äù Shmi seemed impressed and worried.

Leia nodded. ‚ÄúAnd she‚Äôs the leader of her movement. I know they talked about having her go at the beginning. They would have if Jar Jar were there. It would give everyone else time to forget what he‚Äôd said.‚Äù

‚ÄúLeia,‚Äù Shmi scolded.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs right,‚Äù Vers√© stepped in, shaking her head. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs very good for a lot of things, but public speaking always makes him nervous. His accented Basic can get thicker if it gets really bad, and he‚Äôll transpose letters in his words. The Senate floor is a stage. It‚Äôs not fair, but image matters sometimes more than sense.‚Äù

Which was why Padm√© was there in spite of the fact that they hadn‚Äôt heard anything about her bounty hunter.

The proceedings dragged on. Three times pro-military members delayed volunteering to speak in the hopes of provoking Padm√© to go early. Those silences seemed to stretch on forever.

The last one, a battle for what would probably be the last speech before the Chancellor‚Äôs closing remarks, created an empty space of three full minutes, provoking Mas Amedda to threaten to close to proceedings. The Sermerian delegation caved first. Possibly because Senator Paddie had made the mistake of meeting Padm√©‚Äôs eyes.

When the Chancellor turned the floor over to the Senator from Naboo, Leia had to bite her lips to stop herself from sniggering. His face may have looked calm to many, but she knew what those carefully flattened lips meant.

The Senate was boring. Anakin was grateful he‚Äôd had to stay standing because otherwise he might have fallen asleep and humiliated Padm√©.

The first few speeches hadn‚Äôt been so bad. Some of the arguing between speeches was pretty good. But after the third or fourth person, it was getting repetitive, a point for point attack that boiled down to, do you value what we do or what they do?

He wished Obi-Wan was here. Mind speaking was a little hard, but their bond was more than strong enough to share humor or irritation, and sometimes not being alone was the most important part.

Which was why he kept shifting (not because he had to fidget) when Padm√© would start to tense. He didn‚Äôt have another way to remind her that he was here, but from her half glances at him and her slight relaxing, she did get it.

Finally, finally, it was Padm√©‚Äôs turn to speak. Having all the eyes in the room on their pod as it floated forward made Anakin‚Äôs skin crawl. Now he was trying not to fidget. He looked to the Chancellor, hoping for‚Ä¶ something, but the Chancellor‚Äôs attention was locked on Senator Amidala.

She waited almost a full minute once they‚Äôd stopped, until the low rumble of background noise actually quieted to almost nothing. Then she braced her hands against the sides of her podium.

‚ÄúHonorable delegates,‚Äù her voice was low and clear, ‚ÄúI will not waste your time by repeating the arguments against the MCA which have been so clearly stated by my colleagues. Many of you are also familiar with the difficulties our delegation has faced in the last weeks, so I won‚Äôt waste your time with those either.‚Äù

That earned a murmur, but it quickly faded. ‚ÄúWhat I am here to say, to add to what has already been said, is this. You are not alone.‚Äù A breath, and her hands were turning white where they gripped the podium. ‚ÄúNo one of you, not a single one, is alone. Because we are a Republic.‚Äù

Anakin recognized most of the pieces of what she said next. They‚Äôd gone over her speech, very quickly, with her handmaidens. She outlined what a democracy was, why it was important, why the right to choose to participate in it was equally important. Why some people might feel inclined to leave, if a democracy failed to meet their needs.

‚ÄúWe mourn the loss of systems and colleagues who are no longer with us,‚Äù Padm√© said, hand sweeping up and down to showcase empty pods. ‚ÄúWe miss them. We are afraid for them, and what their absence means. But we cannot be afraid of them. And we cannot act in this body based on that fear.‚Äù

He felt her trembling in the Force, felt the weight and the depth of her emotions, screaming to find an escape through her words. Holding her up and dragging her back. How was anyone in this room still breathing, looking at her?

‚ÄúI have been accused of being naive,‚Äù Padm√© said, and some of her anger leaked into her feelings, if not her voice. ‚ÄúI have been accused of being simplistic and pacifist and not knowing what the cost of those things means. And my associates have been accused similarly.‚Äù Her eyes found the anselmi senator across the room. ‚ÄúThose accusations are wrong. We know the price, we know the cost. We have paid it, many times with our lives. The people of Naboo do not say that we should stand back and not fight. We don‚Äôt timidly say, ‚ÄòPick your battles.‚Äô I stand here today with Representative Binks,‚Äù her hand flung back to point at Jar Jar, ‚Äúbecause once I stood before this body and it failed to protect my people.

‚ÄúAnd my answer to that,‚Äù Padm√© continued, ‚Äúwas to reach out to those in my system and beg them to stand with us, when we had done them so much wrong. Because more important than seeming powerful was being powerful. And we were stronger together. Naboo is a microcosm for the truth that can shape our Republic. We ask you to vote down this act so that in its place we can offer others. Ones that are more meaningful, more powerful, because they could bring our Republic back together and reunite us with old friends. And lead all of us to a better future.‚Äù

Don‚Äôt be afraid, her posture said, the echoes of her voice still quivering through the room. Don‚Äôt be afraid, I‚Äôm with you.

Anakin would follow her anywhere, he thought, as in bursts the entire chamber broke into shouts and applause. He would follow her anywhere, do anything, anything she asked. Just so he could stay wrapped in this light that danced around her, bending the universe into something more beautiful.

The applause went on for some time, but the mood was interrupted when the broadcast decided to use the time to recap the explosion on the landing platform and all of the difficulties the Naboo delegation had been going through. And to express some surprise that Padm√© had come, given the imminent threat to her life.

Leia tuned it all out, holding Shmi‚Äôs hand and waiting for the votes to come in. As the moderators reviewed the tallies the whole room held their breath. When the vote came back with the MCA defeated, Leia couldn‚Äôt even be angry that Padm√© collapsed against Anakin in full view of the galaxy and started to cry.

Evanescent

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

When Padm√©‚Äôs guards arrived, Anakin started dragging her away, one arm wrapped around her shoulders, the other pushing away onlookers and well-wishers (or ill-wishers) just outside the pod. She was mostly composed and moving under her own power by the time they hit the hall, but she let him keep an arm around her, for support (or to keep people away, maybe).

It was a lot longer walk back to their conference room than from it.

‚ÄúYou did grand!‚Äù Jar Jar cheered the moment the door opened for them, jumping around in his Senate clothes and looking ridiculous. ‚ÄúYou make Cord√© very very proud!‚Äù

There were equal parts pain and relief from Padm√© at his words and Anakin was disappointed when she stepped away. ‚ÄúThank you, Jar Jar,‚Äù she said, letting Dorm√© bustle over and dab at her eyes. ‚ÄúThank you for being there with me.‚Äù

‚ÄúI'm being the gungan aide. I'm being your partner. We be doing a grand job, I think?‚Äù

‚ÄúBoss Nass will be proud,‚Äù Padm√© said. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôll be proud you were there with me and represented the Gungans. It made a difference, Jar Jar. I really think it did.‚Äù

‚ÄúAquatic planets are underrepresented in the Senate,‚Äù a voice came from behind them, inviting in a wave of chatter as the door slid open and shut. ‚ÄúAnd aquatic peoples. Many of them aren‚Äôt the primary species in their system. Acknowledging Representative Binks was a good choice.‚Äù

It was the man Padm√© had been looking at earlier, the one from Alderaan. He was exhausted, but vibrating almost as much as Padm√© was with happiness. She stepped forward and he pulled her into a crushing hug. Padm√© squeaked in surprise, but she was too happy for Anakin to be worried.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm so proud of you,‚Äù Alderaan‚Äôs senator said, holding Padm√© at arms‚Äô length. ‚ÄúSo proud and so happy to work with you. And I‚Äôm so sorry.‚Äù

Padm√©‚Äôs smile faltered a little, but she kept her head up. ‚ÄúCord√© knew how important this vote was.‚Äù Her lips trembled as her head ducked for just a moment. ‚ÄúShe wouldn‚Äôt regret this.‚Äù

‚ÄúHave you told anyone yet?‚Äù the senator asked, probably looking for a distraction.

Padm√© shook her head. ‚ÄúNo, but I assume people were watching.‚Äù

‚ÄúLeia‚Äôs on the line,‚Äù Eirta√© was smiling. ‚ÄúWith Sab√© and Vers√©.‚Äù She glanced at Anakin. ‚ÄúAnd Shmi.‚Äù

Mom? Anakin almost skipped when Padm√© had them open up visuals for the call, taking his spot behind Padm√©. There she was, and she smiled when she saw him, a look he hadn‚Äôt seen since‚Äî

She was proud of him too.

‚ÄúHow are you feeling?‚Äù Leia asked, her attention riveted on Padm√©.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt even know,‚Äù Padm√© answered, looking around. ‚ÄúRelieved, I think. Overwhelmed.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou were amazing,‚Äù Leia‚Äôs tone was equal parts awe and affection and Anakin‚Ä¶ felt bothered by it. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm so glad for you.‚Äù

‚ÄúStill not sure you agree with us?‚Äù the Alderaan man asked, and Anakin noticed that even in the holo Leia wouldn‚Äôt quite meet his eyes.

‚ÄúPadm√© and her team have had my full support leading up to this vote.‚Äù

‚ÄúA very evasive answer,‚Äù his tone suggested it was a compliment and an insult.

Padm√© frowned as she said, ‚ÄúBail‚Ä¶‚Äù

Oh right. Organa.

Senator Organa shrugged. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt mind if she disagrees. She did do her best to help, and she‚Äôs always been honest about it.‚Äù He was smiling when he said, ‚ÄúShe pushed you, made you think. I think we did better for it.‚Äù

‚ÄúWill you be coming home soon? Or is there more work for you on Coruscant?‚Äù Mom obviously had an opinion on what the answer should be to her question, and Padm√© looked uncertain.

‚ÄúWith the Senate open again, and with the efforts we‚Äôve made to suggest alternative routes, I don‚Äôt think it would be wise for me to leave. I have a lot of promises to keep.‚Äù

‚ÄúOne of which is to rely on others to cover for your weaknesses,‚Äù Senator Organa pointed out, and Anakin wanted to be angry at him for insulting Padm√©, but everything about his tone and intention was pure kindness. ‚ÄúWe do need your experience and efforts, but I think if we have you focus on the refugee movement, we can at least make you mobile if your safety requires it, while keeping you actively involved.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe can make plans another day,‚Äù Leia suggested, and one of the other women on the call rolled her eyes. ‚ÄúWhen we‚Äôve had time to consider the details. I imagine right now what you need most is dinner and a nap.‚Äù

‚ÄúA bath,‚Äù Padm√© answered, and Anakin‚Äôs brain skittered to a stop. ‚ÄúThen maybe food, and bed.‚Äù She turned to Senator Organa. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd like to speak to a few people before I leave. Could you help me put a list together and a schedule, so we don‚Äôt have too many at risk at once?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll even help you make the calls,‚Äù Senator Organa agreed. ‚ÄúIs that C-3PO? He can advise on the order so we don‚Äôt offend anyone.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt is,‚Äù Padm√© smiled and then said her goodbyes, and wandered to the corner with Bail.

Anakin had just gotten Jar Jar calmed down and was about to speak to his mother when the door opened again and Master Windu strode in, headed straight for Anakin, trailing a dark grey cloud around him.

‚ÄúPadawan Skywalker,‚Äù Anakin didn‚Äôt wince at the title, but he knew he was neck deep and sinking in trouble. ‚ÄúMaster Yoda and I would like to speak to you about your mission.‚Äù

That voice meant no arguing and Anakin managed a stuttered, ‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù before a voice from the call said, ‚ÄúAre you Master Windu?‚Äù

It was Leia, of course it was Leia, who had asked. The Jedi master frowned at her, blinking as he said, ‚ÄúYes. I don‚Äôt think we‚Äôve been introduced.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, but I saw you at the negotiation banquet, after the shooting.‚Äù To his silence she added, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Leia Skywalker.‚Äù

Master Windu couldn‚Äôt really turn green, but something about the way his face moved and the feelings around him shifted suggested greenness. Sickly, twisting greenness. ‚ÄúObi-Wan Kenobi has mentioned you.‚Äù

‚ÄúDid he? How sweet of him.‚Äù The greenness seemed to go a bit grey, Anakin thought. ‚ÄúI know you‚Äôre busy, but I did want to thank you, and the other Jedi, for your help that night. And for being so kind as to loan us Master Kenobi and Anakin Skywalker.‚Äù There was something‚Ä¶ deliberate to how she said Anakin‚Äôs full name. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure Padm√©‚Äôs expressed her gratitude, but I hope you know how much it means to all of us that you‚Äôve been so cooperative in allowing her to see this through.‚Äù

It was still green and grey, Anakin thought, but it was getting an edge of red as Master Windu replied, ‚ÄúOur concern has always been the senator‚Äôs safety.‚Äù

‚ÄúAs it should be,‚Äù Leia‚Äôs response was so bland Anakin felt adrift. People did not react to Mace Windu, Master of the Order, with blas√© platitudes. Not in Anakin‚Äôs experience. ‚ÄúIn the context of the safety and wellbeing of the Republic.‚Äù

That was a new face. Anakin had never seen Master Windu make that particular face, ever. ‚ÄúWe do‚Ä¶hope to do our best for the Republic. And it‚Äôs representatives.‚Äù And before she could reply he added, ‚ÄúI need to speak to Padawan Skywalker now. If you‚Äôll excuse us.‚Äù

And then Anakin was being whisked away before he could even say goodbye to his mother. Knowing he‚Äôd be scolded for it, he managed to at least look back over his shoulder and wave. So she‚Äôd know he wasn‚Äôt forgetting her.

He‚Äôd never forget her again.

‚ÄúThat girl,‚Äù Master Windu was rubbing his forehead as they turned down a quieter hall, ‚Äúis dangerous.‚Äù

But it didn‚Äôt seem like the comment had really been meant for Padawan Skywalker, so Anakin didn‚Äôt say anything in response.

Master Windu ushered Anakin into the room with Master Yoda before closing and locking the door behind them. There were only two seats and Anakin was surprised when Master Yoda gestured that he should take the second one, not Master Windu. Anakin made sure to bow respectfully to both masters before sitting.

‚ÄúAn interesting day this has been, hmmm?‚Äù Master Yoda seemed almost amused for a moment, before turning grave. ‚ÄúUnexpected, your presence was. Told you were on Naboo, we were.‚Äù

Lying seemed like a bad option, but Anakin wasn‚Äôt really sure what he could say to get out of trouble, so he just nodded, folding his arms into his sleeves and hunching a little. Master Yoda just watched him.

‚ÄúYour orders were to take Senator Amidala to Naboo, using unregistered transport,‚Äù Master Windu sounded impatient and Anakin wished he didn‚Äôt have to look at him. But it would be rude not to, especially since Anakin had the last chair. ‚ÄúDid you, in fact, go to Naboo?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù It slipped out before Anakin had thought about it. He cringed and then regretted cringing.

Master Windu‚Äôs eyes narrowed. ‚ÄúNo?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe didn‚Äôt go to Naboo,‚Äù Anakin said quietly, glancing back at Master Yoda, who was stroking his chin thoughtfully.

‚ÄúDisobeyed orders, you did,‚Äù Master Yoda said, shaking his head. ‚ÄúYet not told of this, we were. A conspiracy, there was, hmmm?‚Äù

‚ÄúThere was a plan,‚Äù Anakin tried to explain. Conspiracy sounded so bad. ‚ÄúThe RRM had been targeted before and we weren‚Äôt completely sure about the transport and Threepio needed to be fixed and‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúThreepio?‚Äù Master Windu cut in. ‚ÄúA droid?‚Äù

Oh great, this was becoming a mess. ‚ÄúMy mom‚Äôs.‚Äù

‚ÄúYour mother‚Äôs droid?‚Äù Master Windu‚Äôs tone was ice and stone.

‚ÄúSeen him, we have,‚Äù Master Yoda said, not particularly bothered. ‚ÄúHere today, he was. Work with the senator he does. Helpful, he is.‚Äù His gaze shifted back to Anakin. ‚ÄúDestroyed in the explosion, he had been? A great effort, it must have been, to repair him. Much of your concentration it took?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe were in a safe house,‚Äù Anakin tried to explain. ‚ÄúSomewhere no one would look for us. I made sure it was secure and then started working on Threepio.‚Äù This was going all wrong.

‚ÄúAnd how found you this place?‚Äù Master Yoda asked, leaning forward.

‚ÄúMy mom‚Äî‚Äú Anakin started, then realized he didn‚Äôt want her to get in trouble. ‚ÄúWell, Leia asked her. To help. The plan was Leia‚Äôs idea.‚Äù

‚ÄúLeia Skywalker?‚Äù Master Windu was feeling greenish again. ‚ÄúYour‚Ä¶ mother,‚Äù he winced, ‚Äúadopted her?‚Äù

Anakin shrugged. ‚ÄúI guess. We haven‚Äôt really talked about it.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd you just followed her instructions, when you barely know her?‚Äù Master Windu was not impressed.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs Padm√©‚Äôs friend. And coworker. Padm√© thought the plan was a good idea and wanted to be at the vote today. So Leia had my mom arrange it. At least, moving us. And it worked,‚Äù he added, getting angry now. This was his mission. They put him in charge of it. If he had to make changes to finish it, why were they getting mad?

Master Yoda shifted and Anakin turned to him. ‚ÄúA wise plan, it may have been. And successful at protecting the senator, you were. But instructions, you were given, to contact us for help. If danger, you encountered, unable to find you we would have been. If lost, you had become, reflect poorly on your master and the Order, it would have.‚Äù

The way he said lost, Anakin knew he meant dead. ‚ÄúIf I had failed to protect her of course the Order would have looked bad. If you didn‚Äôt think I could do it, why did you send me?‚Äù

(‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt you believe in me?‚Äù he wanted to ask. ‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt you trust me and criticize how I do everything?‚Äù)

‚ÄúWe wouldn‚Äôt have sent you if we didn‚Äôt believe in your skills,‚Äù Master Windu said. ‚ÄúBut we also had a framework we expected you to stay in. One you had the Chancellor agree to. He was not expecting you or Senator Amidala to be here today. Senate security wasn‚Äôt adjusted to account for her presence.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm her security,‚Äù Anakin couldn‚Äôt believe he had to point this out.

‚ÄúBut at risk the other senators were, when Senator Amidala chose to come,‚Äù Master Yoda was sounding more stern. ‚ÄúRealized this, you should have. The senator also.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhich is what happens when you leave plans to an amateur,‚Äù Master Windu sighed. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure Leia Skywalker had good intentions‚Äî‚Äú

He might not know if his mother had formally adopted Leia or not, but she was a Skywalker and that made her one of them. So Anakin had to point out, ‚ÄúIf no one knew that Padm√© was coming but us, how could the other senators be in danger?‚Äù

The masters exchanged a look. Master Windu looked pinched and frozen, but Master Yoda seemed‚Ä¶sad. ‚ÄúCorrect you are, if secret it was. But impossible it would be to know if successful you were until too late.‚Äù

‚ÄúLeia‚Äôs not stupid,‚Äù Anakin felt the need to add. She‚Äôd known what kinds of parts to send for Threepio. She‚Äôd made a good plan, and it had worked. ‚ÄúNo one notices sla‚Äîrefugees,‚Äù he corrected quickly. ‚ÄúNo one cares where they are or what they do, as long as they stay away from important people. Asking Mom for help was a great idea. She‚Äôd talk to people, not politicians. And people don‚Äôt want to hurt Padm√©.‚Äù

He could see Master Windu‚Äôs frown growing as Anakin tried to explain. ‚ÄúSenator Amidala,‚Äù the way he emphasized her formal name told Anakin Master Windu was not happy with Anakin being informal, ‚Äúis well liked by her people. But this is Coruscant‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúImmaterial, the location is,‚Äù Master Yoda waved the half-formed argument aside. ‚ÄúAngry, we were, at being surprised, and frightened by what we did not know. Explained himself, Padawan Skywalker has. Disagree we may, but discuss it when Master Obi-Wan is back, we will.‚Äù And then he smiled. ‚ÄúDone well, Senator Amidala has, and protect her, you did. For that, grateful, we are.‚Äù

Master Yoda might be grateful, but Anakin was pretty sure Master Windu wished they were on a practice court so he could have an excuse to hit Anakin. Or maybe he just had a headache and wanted to go home. It was hard to tell with Master Windu.

But Anakin knew he was getting off pretty lightly for now, so he bowed in his seat to Master Yoda and said, ‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù as sincerely as he could.

He wouldn‚Äôt mention knighthood now. It was definitely a bad time.

‚ÄúIs Obi-Wan not on the planet?‚Äù Anakin asked, realizing what Master Yoda had said. ‚ÄúI thought he was looking for Pa‚Äîfor the bounty hunter after Senator Amidala.‚Äù

‚ÄúHis search took him off planet right after you and the senator left,‚Äù Master Windu said, folding his arms. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre still waiting for‚Äî‚Äú

Master Windu‚Äôs comm buzzed and he checked it. It must have been marked as urgent because he answered it. ‚ÄúYes?‚Äù
