‚ÄúWe‚Äôre receiving a communication directed to the High Council, specifically to you or Master Yoda. Should we patch it through or tell them you‚Äôll contact them later?‚Äù Had to hand it to the regular communications team. They weren‚Äôt intimidated by contacting Council members.

‚ÄúPatch it through,‚Äù Master Windu said, coming to stand beside Master Yoda. The tiny form that appeared in the staticky holo was definitely Obi-Wan. ‚ÄúGood timing.‚Äù

It was hard to tell with the interference, but Anakin was pretty sure Obi-Wan didn‚Äôt know what to do with that greeting. ‚ÄúIs it?‚Äù

‚ÄúExcellent timing,‚Äù Master Yoda agreed. ‚ÄúExpecting your report, we were.‚Äù

‚ÄúConfirming the senator‚Äôs safety is becoming a time sensitive issue,‚Äù Master Windu added, his eyes darting to Anakin for a moment. ‚ÄúHave you found her assassin?‚Äù

Attempted assassin, Anakin wanted to correct. Because Padm√© was still alive, no thanks to Master Windu.

‚ÄúWell, I have successfully made contact with the Prime Minister of Kamino. They are using a bounty hunter named Jango Fett to create a clone army, and I have a strong feeling that this bounty hunter is the assassin we‚Äôre looking for.‚Äù

Anakin had never heard of Kamino (and Obi-Wan was clever with words, he had no excuse for saying ‚Äúassassin‚Äù), but he didn‚Äôt like the sound of ‚Äúclone army.‚Äù The senate had just voted against forming a military, hadn‚Äôt they?

‚ÄúAnd do you think these cloners are involved in the plot to assassinate Senator Amidala?‚Äù Master Windu asked, getting straight to the point.

‚ÄúNo, Master. There appears to be no motive.‚Äù

Master Yoda was stroking his chin again. ‚ÄúKamino is maker of armies, and refusing to take up arms, the senate voted. Perhaps a deal was to be made.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe senate voted against an army?‚Äù Obi-Wan sounded worried. ‚ÄúAre you sure?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe were just at the vote,‚Äù Master Windu said, taking the time to glare at Anakin. ‚ÄúYou can ask your Padawan how it went.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnakin?‚Äù And that was dismay. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs on Naboo‚Ä¶‚Äù A sharp gesture from Master Windu was more than enough to get Anakin to hover behind Master Yoda, watching Obi-Wan bury his face in his hand. ‚ÄúWhat have you done now?‚Äù

‚ÄúDiscuss the matter later, we will,‚Äù Master Yoda actually glared at Master Windu and Anakin smiled. ‚ÄúA motive‚Ä¶‚Äù

Obi-Wan responded to that invitation with, ‚ÄúThe Kaminoans say Master Sifo-Dyas placed an order for a clone army at the request of the senate almost ten years ago. But I was under the impression he was killed before that. And that this was the only legislation to suggest the formal creation of a Republic army.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre right,‚Äù Master Windu said. ‚ÄúThis is the first time that the matter has been brought before the senate, and no one ever suggested purchasing clones. They certainly didn‚Äôt bring that request to the Jedi Council.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut take the matter into their own hands and order these clones someone did, claiming the Council‚Äôs consent,‚Äù Master Yoda was pulling on the Force, and it swirled tightly around him. ‚ÄúIf requested, the Kaminoans will give us this army?‚Äù

‚ÄúI believe so. The way they were speaking, they‚Äôve been waiting for a Council representative to come see the results, and possibly to offer more business.‚Äù

‚ÄúWill there be additional fees if we don‚Äôt come and collect them?‚Äù Master Windu asked. ‚ÄúWe aren‚Äôt going to need them and‚Äî‚Äú

Anakin had a sudden thought, ‚ÄúIf it‚Äôs the Jedi‚Äôs army, why would the bounty hunter helping make it go after Pa‚ÄîSenator Amidala?‚Äù Anakin asked. ‚ÄúDid you miss something?‚Äù

He was definitely going to get an earful for that one later, but Obi-Wan just said, ‚ÄúIf the Jedi didn‚Äôt order the army, which seems to be the case, it‚Äôs much less surprising that the bounty hunter involved would want a senator against the formation of an army out of the way. Fett‚Äôs being paid what I‚Äôm told is a considerable sum of money to be the template for these clones.‚Äù

‚ÄúFett‚Äôs in it for the money?‚Äù Master Windu asked, something in the room tensing.

‚ÄúHe also had the cloners make an exact copy of himself, with none of the acceleration adjustments they do for the army clones to make them a viable option.‚Äù

‚ÄúMore information we need,‚Äù Master Yoda said gravely, ‚Äúif we are to discover the truth behind this purchase.‚Äù

The words made Anakin squirm. This was‚Ä¶ this was wrong. The Republic didn‚Äôt purchase soldiers, not if they were people.

‚ÄúJango Fett is currently here. He claims not to have been to Coruscant recently, but his armor could match what Anakin and I saw the night we caught the other bounty hunter. If he is involved he isn‚Äôt willing to talk. Kamino is technically outside of the Republic, so an arrest might be difficult.‚Äù

‚ÄúBring him here,‚Äù Master Yoda said, waving the concerns aside. ‚ÄúQuestion him, we will.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat about his son?‚Äù Anakin asked.

Master Windu looked irritated at the question, but Master Yoda said, ‚ÄúBring him also. Carefully.‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, Master. I will report back when I have him.‚Äù Obi-Wan glanced anxiously at Anakin. ‚ÄúThe senator‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúMade a stirring speech and is still being congratulated,‚Äù Master Windu said, insult in every word. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll be revisiting the issue of her security and Padawan Skywalker‚Äôs assignment now that the vote has passed.‚Äù

‚ÄúI see. Well,‚Äù Obi-Wan looked to Anakin again for a moment, ‚Äúmay the Force be with you.‚Äù

As the holo flickered out, Anakin found himself fretting. ‚ÄúHow did the Jedi end up buying a clone army?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe didn‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äú Master Windu snapped, but Master Yoda held up a hand.

‚ÄúAn army was purchased,‚Äù he murmured. ‚ÄúAnd in the Council‚Äôs name. More we will learn from Obi-Wan‚Äôs efforts.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat are we going to do with them?‚Äù Anakin asked, hating how small his voice sounded. ‚ÄúThe Senate just said that they don‚Äôt want an army. Who‚Äôs going to take care of them?‚Äù

The masters were silent for a long time. Long enough Anakin started fidgeting.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll wait for Obi-Wan‚Äôs report,‚Äù Master Windu said at last. ‚ÄúAnd we‚Äôll talk to Jango. Once we know how many clones there are and why he helped create them, then we can decide what to do.‚Äù

That didn‚Äôt sound like much of a plan, but Anakin couldn‚Äôt think of anything better. ‚ÄúI hope they‚Äôre not scared,‚Äù he muttered. ‚ÄúIf they know about the vote, that no one wants them, it has to be frightening.‚Äù

Nothing was worse than knowing you weren‚Äôt needed. That was when masters got cruel. Or creative.

‚ÄúIf a home is required then find one, we will,‚Äù Master Yoda said, hopping down from the chair and tapping his way across the floor. ‚ÄúCome, Padawan Skywalker. And speak of this to no one. Not until more information is had.‚Äù

Leia was just getting ready to crawl into bed when she got Padm√©‚Äôs call. Making sure Shmi was asleep, Leia answered, making herself comfortable against her pillows. ‚ÄúHey you.‚Äù

In the stillness of the dark the blue glow of Padm√©‚Äôs form had a sort of haunting effect. Only her expression of joy prevented Leia from wandering down paths that were too maudlin (she didn‚Äôt need to imagine Padm√© dead‚Ä¶).

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, did I wake you?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, I was still up. Waiting to see if we got any updates.‚Äù

‚ÄúI spoke to Sab√©, but she said she‚Äôd already left, and I didn‚Äôt get a chance to thank you.‚Äù Padm√© almost looked flustered. ‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt have to do this. All of it. I don‚Äôt know how I‚Äôll ever repay you.‚Äù

Leia thought about the look on Palpatine‚Äôs face, about the roar from the crowd when Padm√© had finished speaking, about the sadness in Leia‚Äôs father‚Äôs eyes when Bail had used to talk about his dear friend (so like the sadness in those other eyes‚Ä¶), and she couldn‚Äôt help but smile. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt worry. You already did.‚Äù

‚ÄúI thought you were considering the benefits of an army.‚Äù

Why did everyone get stuck on that? ‚ÄúEntertaining an idea isn‚Äôt the same thing as being willing to die for an ideal. I think there is a purpose to organizing something vaguely like a Republic sponsored military force. That being said, with how close the vote was, I‚Äôm not sure I‚Äôd trust this senate to know what to do with it. So a delay might be for the best.‚Äù

‚ÄúI hope so.‚Äù Her attention shifted. Leia couldn‚Äôt say how she knew, but it was no surprise when Padm√© said, ‚ÄúTell Shmi I‚Äôm sorry the Jedi dragged Anakin away so quickly, please. I didn‚Äôt realize they were going to corner him while we were still here.‚Äù

Poor kid. Leia had so many doubts about him, but the look on his face when Master Windu had appeared had sparked her sympathy. Anakin might be a force of nature, but the Jedi Master was a trained, focused force unto himself. ‚ÄúI know she wanted to talk to him, but I think she got busy scolding me.‚Äù

‚ÄúFor what?‚Äù Padm√© demanded, baffled.

‚ÄúThreepio,‚Äù Leia sighed, shaking her head and smiling.

It didn‚Äôt work as well as she hoped it would. ‚ÄúShe didn‚Äôt want Threepio fixed? Or was it Anakin‚Äî‚Äú Then a frown, ‚ÄúHow much did his coverings cost?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat question,‚Äù Leia said, letting her nose drift into the air, ‚Äúis very rude. I can‚Äôt believe you asked it. So impertinent.‚Äù

She tried to give the last words some of Threepio‚Äôs lilt and knew she‚Äôd managed when Padm√© smirked. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very convenient that you can hide behind that excuse, isn‚Äôt it?‚Äù A pause and then, ‚ÄúI know how much we pay you. Anakin said they were custom. Do you need‚Äî‚Äú

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Leia said firmly. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt. I‚Äôd already been saving up for them.‚Äù Which had cut into her speeder upgrade fund, and the tentative dream she had of someday buying her own ship. It would be justified if she kept working between Coruscant and Naboo, and once it wasn‚Äôt suspicious for her to have one, she could use it for‚Ä¶ other things. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôd been fretting about his appearance since the first day in the Senate. I figured now that he would be living off Tatooine, it would be a good gift.‚Äù

She hadn‚Äôt been sure, at first, that she‚Äôd pick the same color as in her memories. But the temptation had been too strong. She hadn‚Äôt even seen him properly yet (Shmi‚Äôd been more angry that Leia hadn‚Äôt asked for a contribution from her grandmother, but that would have required admitting the price, and no sense in provoking that fight), but something about him had felt right as Leia had watched him shuffle into and out of frame for a moment.

‚ÄúWe can reimburse you,‚Äù Padm√© insisted. ‚ÄúYou did it because of your work, we have droid maintenance funds.‚Äù

Probably not in this price range. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll think about it,‚Äù Leia promised, knowing she would eventually cave. Once she got Vers√© to admit to what the droid budget actually was. Then Leia could submit an appropriately reduced receipt. ‚ÄúWhat are your plans?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm staying here for now,‚Äù Padm√© said. ‚ÄúBut they‚Äôre switching my guard. Someone more suited to the senate should be arriving back on planet in a few days.‚Äù

Leia hoped it was Master Gallia, just so she wouldn‚Äôt have to start from scratch wheedling her way into their good graces. ‚ÄúAlright. Let me know if you need me to come back.‚Äù

‚ÄúI will,‚Äù Padm√© promised. ‚ÄúBut for security reasons, it probably won‚Äôt be right now. Is that okay?‚Äù

‚ÄúI live to serve,‚Äù Leia said and Padm√©‚Äôs brow went up. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine. I‚Äôm used to waiting.‚Äù

Padm√©‚Äôs head tilted and a finger came up to touch her lip. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs funny, I‚Äôve never really gotten that impression.‚Äù

‚ÄúEverything is relative,‚Äù Leia sniffed. Then shrugged. ‚ÄúKeep me posted on what you need me working on. I‚Äôll take orders from Sab√© while I‚Äôm here.‚Äù

‚ÄúPromise?‚Äù

Leia opened her mouth to say yes, closed it, and then said, ‚ÄúNo, but I‚Äôll do my best.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôll do exactly what you think is needed,‚Äù Padm√© sighed.

‚ÄúWhatever is necessary,‚Äù Leia agreed.

‚ÄúAnd don‚Äôt look back,‚Äù her memory whispered, the image of Vader‚Äôs ghost brilliant in her mind, before he faded into nothing.

Chapter End Notes

So, I started this story under the belief that it would be long, but it was one story. Maybe a couple hundred thousand words, but all of a nice cohesive piece with a couple overarching themes that would tie into each other, and a few major plot points with a bit of narrative string holding them together. Easy peasy.

I can still hear my beta laughing at me, 800 miles away.

After some consideration, consultation with said beta, some maniacal cackling and some head banging against a desk (I'll let you guess which off us was doing which), I've come to the conclusion that for the way my brain works thematically, this will now have to be cut into pieces. I'll spare myself the embarrassment of guessing how many or few of them. I have always been wrong, and will probably be wrong again if I try.

That being said, while Like Fire is now listed as completed, fear not, I am not leaving the story to end here. There is plenty more to be read. Just probably not this week. I'll need a smidge of time to get a handle on exactly where this next bit is going (especially because it decided to change major plot points just as my head was hitting my pillow last night, thanks brain).

Thank you all for your support and interest. As this project has grown I've had more and more anxieties about finishing it and whether the endeavor was worth it. Your comments and statistical presence make it easier to encourage myself to keep going. I really, really, really appreciate it. I hope you're pleased with the results.

(And yes, if you listen closely, you too may be able to hear my beta still laughing.)

Afterword

Wear and Tear by acuteneurosis
